supporter: January should hopefully bring better things to the world I think. I am really looking forward to it, I think it will be good.

seeker: By God grace I also hope so, Next year will be better.
supporter: Will you be getting a vaccine for Covid? I am really hopeful bout that

seeker: I will if it is proof by government that is ok to take
supporter: That sounds like a good idea. It's been really nice talking, I wish you all the best for 2021!

seeker: Thanks friend 2021 will fruitful for us all
supporter: Take care and goodbye :)

seeker: Nice talking to you goodbye.
supporter: You need to quit first .. I can't :)

seeker: ok thanks
supporter: you need to press quit and take the survey

seeker: Hi, I'm Anna
supporter: Hi there, how is life treating you right now?

seeker: Going through a break-up. My 3rd one this year....
supporter: Gosh you've been busy :). I am sorry to hear that though - I know how much it hurts when you split with someone, especially if it was not consensual.

seeker: I feel like a piece of crap, and childish at that. I can't maintain any of my relationships. I think I'm going to be alone for the rest of my life.
supporter: That is a defeatist way to talk! Just because a couple of relationships fail does not mean that you will never be able to find happiness.

seeker: Well, if past experience has any powers of prediction. I get super clingy, and do this push and pull thingy, where I break up and call them names, and then become so embarrassed it's hard to even bring it up. my last boyfriend said he thought i had borderline disorder
supporter: I have been in that position too. I hate it when I realise that I am not being rational but I can't seem to stop myself sometimes and this has sometimes let to problems with my inter personal relationships

seeker: Yea, that definitely seems to be part of my problem. I really thought he was different, too. And when he broke up with me, I tried to get him to spend the night with me in a hotel, and I felt so pathetic because I was practically begging for sex
supporter: I hear you on that one too! It's horrible to feel that you are losing your self respect but I suspect that we've all done it at some point. Have you considered getting some counselling?

seeker: Sigh.. yes. I have seen several. I also take meds from a psychiatrist.
supporter: I hear  you saying that they are not really effective, is that true?

seeker: Well... one told me that I should be put down like a dog to my face.
supporter: Okay .. I hope you reported him!!

seeker: I didn't. I was younger then. who knows. not gonna lie. maybe they're right. Sometimes I think I'm a psycho. My last therapist was always doing deep breathing exercises. It didn't help.
supporter: I understand that as well .. I am on medication for it. A dog is a wonderful thing to have! Do you feel that it has helped you?

seeker: Yea, he's my best friend. At least I have one boy who has to stick around. He's on a tight leash
supporter: Dogs are very very loyal. They never cheat on you or walk out on you!

seeker: So trueee :) I just wish I wasn't such a freak.
supporter: I think you are probably not anywhere near as bad as you think you are you know :). Anyway I wish you all the very best for the New Year and hope that things pick up for you soon!

seeker: Alright, bud. Thanks. You, too
supporter: take care!

seeker: feeling disgust as usual. yourself?
supporter: I have been feeling a little low too. Would you like to tell me a bit about why you are disgusted with yourself?

seeker: well, i'm not disgusted with myself... it's just people in general. everybody.. they're so selfish
supporter: Ah yes, this has been especially obvious during the pandemic hasn't it? Too many people not following the social distancing rules

seeker: well, you could say that.
supporter: Do you feel that the pandemic has made you feel worse? Or have you felt like this for a long time?

seeker: a long time. more as i age. i'm actually tired about hearing about the pandemic, really. it is all people ever talk about.
supporter: Well, it is a pretty significant issue this year :). Re obesity, have you considered doing something to raise awareness?

seeker: I think it would be beating a dead horse. Ober half the population is overweight. People would just need to be blind not to see it. That's kind of my point. Everything is consume... consume.. consume.... buy buy buy
supporter: So you feel as though there is no bright side - that everything is just artificial and superficial?

seeker: well... you can't really do anything without money. it all kind of rides on it, doesn't it?  what you can buy?
supporter: I don't mean to sound twee but there are things out there in life that can be appreciated for free :)

seeker: Yea, a few things here and there. Nature, let's say. But nature doesn't really give one way or another about you. My friends have a lot of money, though, and none of them are even happy.
supporter: I know what you mean about that. I know plenty of people who spend too much of their life working every hour and it leaves them no time to appreciate their money!

seeker: Yea, I know, right. I have one friends who has probably about 100k in the bank, and he will complain if he spent 4 cents too much on gas over another gas station.
supporter: People like that are irritating, certainly. I am not sure what the solution is, other than to ignore them.

seeker: yea, it's hard, though, because sooner or later it comes out in almost everyone i meet. who knows. maybe even i do it and don't even know it. thats scary, you know
supporter: Well, the fact that you can reflect on it indicates to me that you are probably not guilty. Most of those who do this are totally unaware.

seeker: Thanks. Probably true. sometimes when i bring it up they'll just argue about it and defend themselves. i just try to move on but it is always there. ok. yea it is 15 minutes so bye bye
supporter: you too :)

seeker: Hello my situation is that I'm facing an enormous amount of academic pressure
supporter: Hello. Academic work can be overwhelming at times. I am sure that with the right strategies you will overcome any obstacles, though.

seeker: It's just a huge amount of work that I'm struggling with and a ton of exams and they give me a lot of anxiety
supporter: It is perfectly fine to feel stressful whenever an important assessment is coming.

seeker: Do you have any recommendations on reducing the stress though?
supporter: Do you have an academic councelor you can talk to?

seeker: yes it's all virtual though
supporter: Well at least is something. I am sure talking to someone who might be able to guide you academically will be a significant relief.

seeker: That is a good idea.  Do you personally recommend anything on how to balance my schedule and still be able to have my time to do other things?
supporter: When I was at college, I usually aimed at 2 hours of studying everyday (+ homework) and I also aimed to have at least 2 hours of leisure time.

seeker: I see, and how were you able to maintain a healthy lifestyle with enough sleep and healthy eating habits during college?
supporter: I honestly didn't eat very healthy. If you live with your parents, I think a proper nutrition is easier. I usually slept around 7 hours each night. I picked most of my classes on the afternoon, worked out in the mornings.

seeker: okay i understand, and what do you suggest for when you do poorly on an exam that you studied so hard for, how do you keep yourself from feeling down?
supporter: I would suggest talking to the professor or an academic advisor to explore strategies that could help you improve

seeker: okay but is it normal to be upset?
supporter: Of course, it is normal to feel upset. However, you should not blame yourself. No one is perfect.

seeker: Okay that makes me feel better
supporter: I am glad it does :D!

seeker: that's it! thank you for your help
supporter: You are very welcome!

seeker: Hello I am very sad today. My partner is cheating on me.
supporter: Cheating on you?

seeker: Yes.
supporter: How do you know that your partner is cheating on you?

seeker: I was told by a customer at work. I do not know this person well, yet they knew the person he was cheating on me with.
supporter: I am sorry if your partner is cheating.

seeker: Yes. He says the person who told me is lying.
supporter: How long have you been in a relationship with your man?

seeker: 2 years
supporter: So, 2 years should be long enough to know if your partner has been cheating.

seeker: What do you mean exactly?
supporter: Are you someone who trusts people? I think that most men would fess up about it.

seeker: I guess all people are different. I generally trust people easily.
supporter: Does he show affection to you? If he is adamant about loving you, then, it may be false allegations.

seeker: That is true. He is but, has been distant lately.
supporter: I have had coworkers lie and be jealous that I have a good relationship with my partner.

seeker: Do you think maybe it was a rumor started by someone who could be jealous?
supporter: Ash your partner if he loves you enough to propose marriage. If he says no, then ask him why.

seeker: That is a good point.
supporter: Yes, workers can be a real problem and can make up stories about people. Slander in the work place happens.

seeker: I  am not sure if I am okay with giving him an ultimatum. We are still young and although I love being in a relationship, I am unsure about marriage.
supporter: Sure, I understand.

seeker: I should trust my partner more than any random person.
supporter: Yes, the workplace is not like home life.

seeker: But every time i bring it up, he tries to change the subject. How should I approach him to communicate better?
supporter: I would see if he wants to spend time doing things like volunteering after work.  If he says yes, or is excited, that is a good sign that he wants to be with you....even after work.

seeker: okay! that is a good idea. Maybe I can research something and see if there is anything new we can do together.
supporter: Find things that he has in common or energize the relationship.

seeker: That is a good point. It is just hard to go on with the relationship when I feel I do not know the whole truth and there is little discussion or reassurance.
supporter: You have done your part, but if he wants to show you affection on a regular basis, that is a good sign.

seeker: Okay. I will keep that in mind.
supporter: Are you intimate with your partner, on a regular basis?

seeker: Yes but less over the past few months.
supporter: Spicing up the live life can also help to energize hings.

seeker: That's understandable. Maybe I can communicate with him first.
supporter: How do you all generally communicate? Through text?

seeker: He is going to law school and I am going to med school. There is a ton of stress on both ends.
supporter: Which do you and your man like to communicate?

seeker: No live together so we use call, text, and see each other in person.
supporter: Well, you and your man are under a lot of stress, so keep that in mind. The study may be making him withdraw a lot.

seeker: You are right. I will try to be more sensitive about that. Thank you for your help.
supporter: I would ask his fellow students, if you know any of them if they think he really loves you.

seeker: Do you think getting other people involved is a good idea?
supporter: I would be subtle about that tactic.

seeker: Yeah he has a few close friends but he is pretty to himself. We both live far away from home.
supporter: Are you and him directly off campuses in housing? You both attend the same college, correct?

seeker: Yes off campus. Same college.
supporter: Where do you work? Have you seen the customer who said that your partner was cheating?

seeker: I work at a bar part time to support may way through school.
supporter: Sounds like drunk slander talk.  I would let things go for awhile and follow up later.

seeker: Hello, I'm feeling a lot of anxiety.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that.  Do you know what may be causing ytour anxiety?

seeker: I found out I'm losing my job on January 1.
supporter: You lost your job? thats a tough situation. Is it due to covid?

seeker: No, not due to covid. It's a gig job, much like mturk, but the company is dropping people from my state on that date.
supporter: I know its tough especially with the holidays and all. You have so many great skills and are such a hard worker I dont think you will have a problem at all finding something different.

seeker: I've been looking at other companies, but learning a new system after all these years is difficult.
supporter: I remember a time I lost my job and felt my whole world crumbling but then I realized when one door closes another door opens. when those doors close it seems that its usually for the best because it opens the path for something bigger and greater for you.

seeker: That's true. I've thought about looking into new fields.
supporter: Have you looked into some evening classes or maybe online schooling? I hear there are so many different options when it comes to online learning.

seeker: I was looking into that last night, but with covid,  classes have had to cut enrollment and are already full for next semester.
supporter: They are full? well what about surrounding towns? Have you sat down and really thought about your passions and what you enjoy doing? Maybe theres an elderly person who needs some companionship or something like that in town for the time being.

seeker: I don't have a car, so I'm stuck doing classes locally. I think I'll just have to wait for the next semester.
supporter: Is waiting until next semester something your willing to do? That would give you time to reflect on yourself and your future and figure out what you want to do as a career. I could give you a list of other online opportunities to make money if you would be interested.

seeker: I would be interested in that, thank you.
supporter: your welcome. There are a lot of online options out there. That may be easier for you at the time being without a car. Do you have a support system of family or friends around here?

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hello. What seems to be the issue?

seeker: I don't have close friends because I don't trust people
supporter: You said you generally don't trust family or people in general?

seeker: people in general, I do trust certain family members
supporter: Just people who are close to you?

seeker: no, I have a hard time trusting people i don't know in order to make friends
supporter: I have had a hard time trusting strangers, but that is not a big problem.

seeker: i think it feels like a problem because I never let anyone too close in order to make friends and have an external support system
supporter: I joined volunteer groups to help others.  I made friends with like-minded people who volunteered to make a difference.

seeker: I actually think that is a great idea.  I have never thought of doing that for that specific purpose.
supporter: Groups like Habitat for Humanity or UNICEF will help you to build long-lasting friendships.

seeker: I guess it makes a lot of sense.  If you go to a party or a bar, you don't know what you will get, as it is a mixed bag of personalities.  Whereas if you go to something like what you suggested then you already know that the people you meet have the same kind of heart.
supporter: You can do it. I have faith that you can use volunteering as the right method.

seeker: Thank you for that suggestion, that is really helpful and something that I will take with me from now on.
supporter: Exactly, volunteering is a great option. And there are many organizations to join.

seeker: I feel ok being alone mostly, but other times I would like to have people I could relate with and hang out with.  Probably has a lot to do with ADHD and how I feel misunderstood or my anxiety gets the best of me in social situations
supporter: I understand the ADHD.  There are support groups that can help you make friends; especially with ADHD, etc.

seeker: do you know any specific groups?
supporter: Using tools to build houses helps to release endorphins, which can release anxiety.

seeker: is this something you have done?
supporter: There is a group called, "Harry House" that provides support to those with ADHD and anxiety.

seeker: oh ok! I will certainly look that up, thank you for that information.
supporter: Surely. Is there anything else you need help with?

seeker: Does one have to travel far to participate in building houses?
supporter: No, Habitat fir Humanity has car pools.

seeker: do you know if it requires a person to be away from home a long time?
supporter: They are a good group to help you build meaningful relationships.

seeker: oh! so a person could just choose how often and how long they participate?
supporter: Would you be interested in something like HFH?

seeker: thank you for sharing with me, i might like to participate in it in the future
supporter: Yes, you can sign up online to join a project.

seeker: ok i will look that up, thank you for all your help
supporter: Yes, you can volunteer locally; HFH is nationwide.

seeker: ok thank you
supporter: Any other questions? I am glad to assist.

seeker: no other questions, you have been most helpful, thank you!
supporter: I have done volunteer work; people want to be friends with those who care and know how to use a nail and hammer. :)

seeker: LOL good to know!
supporter: It may also help to contribute some money to keep the organization going.

seeker: I have anxiety about what avenue to take academically
supporter: Hello! Don't worry, I am here to help. So you are saying that you are not sure what career to study?

seeker: I do have an idea about it but I am anxious about choosing wrong and boxing myself into something I wish I hadn't chosen
supporter: Even if you chose wrong, you will generally have plenty of time to make up your mind and choose something that you really like : ), plus, you can reach out to academic advisors, for example.

seeker: I suppose you're right, I think I don't have confidence in myself that what ever I do choose, I will be good at it.  Good enough to make a life out of it.
supporter: I myself lose interest in many things quite frequently.

seeker: but what if that thing is your career choice?
supporter: That is a totally normal aspect of human nature. It's normal to get bored of things even if we really liked them at some point

seeker: I guess thats right.  All I care about is helping others so as long as the choice i make supports that then it will be fine.
supporter: No problem, and it's great that you like helping others.

seeker: yes, it is very rewarding to do so, it should be a part of everyone's life choices
supporter: Remember to always keep a positive mindset. I am sure you will sort this out in no time.

seeker: I am sure you are right, I just get caught up in my thoughts too much. have a great day!
supporter: Yes, sorry

seeker: why does it say im ending the chat early when it has been enough time already
supporter: Try again, you have to hit quit and fill the questionarie

seeker: I am very worried about losing my job
supporter: Hello - How are you today?

seeker: Anxious. I think my boss wants to fire me.
supporter: I am so sorry you are worried about losing your job. I have been in your shoes before.

seeker: Thank you. I think if I am late again, I will be let go.
supporter: Have you explained to him your reasoning? I also once had to take care of my sick grandmother after work and had a tough time explaining it to my boss.

seeker: No. But that is a good idea.
supporter: Maybe your boss can compromise with you. It's worth a shot!

seeker: It's a very competitive office and I don't want to look weak.
supporter: You sound like you care about this job and that is a valuable asset in a an employee.

seeker: I do. I hope I can explain the situation clearly and offer to make up time by staying late.
supporter: I understand. Is there a coworker or mentor that maybe you can talk to?

seeker: I will reach out to HR.
supporter: That's a great idea!

seeker: Thank you. You have been very helpful and uplifting.
supporter: Also review your employee handbook and see if there are things you can do to negotiate with HR or your boss in regards to your hours.

seeker: My anxiety is disappearing with the suggestions you have offered.
supporter: That's great! I am happy I could help you during such a difficult time. How long have you been at the job?

seeker: I have only been here for 6 months. I think being new is contributing to the anxiety I am feeling.
supporter: I understand. Being new at a job can have its difficulties.

seeker: Thank you for your encouragement.
supporter: I hope your boss can understand you are facing a difficult time. If he has loved ones or family of his own, he surely will.

seeker: I swear, I can't take these lockdowns anymore.
supporter: I can definetely understand why. During this pandemic we have been more isolated than ever

seeker: I mean it's one thing to limit capacities in places, but to say we're not allowed to go to our friends' and family's home is just plain ridiculous.
supporter: It is more than reasonable to be frustrated with regards to that. I myself have not been able to visit my ill mother. She lives in another country, so it's especially difficult.

seeker: That is a shame. I mean I know people can still do Zoom or Facetime, but I imagine you can related to me in knowing that both of those options are not the same as face to face.
supporter: Exactly, the experience feels like it lacks the main connection we share with our loved ones. It is totally normal to want to be face to face instead.

seeker: I think that's the other thing that these lockdowns are doing; they're sucking the emotional aspects out of activities and pastimes we love. Instead of laughing or jumping with fright in theaters with everyone, we now have to do it with ourselves. Rather than cheering as an audience over a touchdown, it's now a crowd of one. It just feels robotic now.
supporter: I agree with you, what used to be super-exciting activities now have a much more monotonous feeling.

seeker: Yeah, but even with the distribution, some people are saying that things won't return to normal till about late spring/early summer.
supporter: I know it's not easy, but try to think of this whole situation of a challenge that you are overcoming. What doesn't kill you only makes you stronger. You will come out of this ready for any hardships that life might throw at you.

seeker: I guess, I still think our responce to this was sloppy at best. I mean, lockdown the healthy masses due to a discease with a 99% survival rate? It just doesn't make sense in my book. I'm just glad this silliness will be over soon.
supporter: It will hopefully be over sooner than we think.

seeker: I think over time (sooner than later hopefully) I'll be able to get over it.
supporter: It has been a pleasure : )

seeker: Have a good day :)
supporter: You too!

seeker: Hello, I'm good and yourself
supporter: I'm doing well, thank you!

seeker: I am really a little upset.
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that. What's going on that's making you feel that way?

seeker: Me and my partner had an argument and I got ghosted after. It's been 2 weeks.
supporter: That's terrible. So you had an argument and he hasn't spoken to you in two weeks. Is that correct?

seeker: Yes
supporter: I can imagine that you must be really hurt amongst a number of other feelings. Hearing you tell me that he has done this is upsetting to me as well.

seeker: Yeah, I just do not know what to do
supporter: Do you mind me asking what the argument was about? If you don't mind going into a little more detail, I may be able to help you more.

seeker: I was sick and he did not call me all day to even check in on me. I told him that I was upset about that.
supporter: That must be such a terrible feeling. So the argument started because you were sick, he didn't check in on you at all for that entire day, and when you expressed your feelings to him, it turned into an argument?

seeker: Hi. Hope that you have some good thoughts to share with me.
supporter: Totally, I am here to help! Tell me what's the issue so we can work it through

seeker: Cannot seem to shake the blues even though I exercise and have a friend I regularly talk with.
supporter: Do you think your mood is related to any current or recent events in your life?

seeker: Yes. To handle my previous depression I self medicated and ended up going to prison. Made my situation worse. Now trying to adjust but depression is worse having lost job and social stauts
supporter: Feeling down after an experience like that is certainly understandable, and I suspect that might be the main cause of your depression.

seeker: Yes, but its a vicious circle. Get blue and find it hard to strive. Unfortunately many jobs require background checks these days. Even Amazon!
supporter: I am feeling optimistic about this vaccine, you will see how it helps us all slowly get our lives back to how they were.

seeker: Yeah. The covid thing is an additional layer of isolation and depression.
supporter: It will soon be over hopefully

seeker: political situation in US not helping like with most recent aid bill.
supporter: I agree, but it's not like we have any major control over that unfortunately.

seeker: Serenity prayer. Lord grant me.. to control ..
supporter: You have to hit "quit" and fill the questionarie. And I am sure you can get really strong! Just keep working out :D

seeker: How about you? Holding up to Covid-19 insanity?
supporter: It has been a rough time, but I have just been focusing on work, and hopefully it will be all over

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hello! How can I help you today?

seeker: I am anxious about an upcoming test.
supporter: It's normal to feel nervous whenever we have an important assessment coming.

seeker: Yes I have a bunch of courses that I need to do for my work, it certainly keeps me busy.
supporter: I would suggest that you study as much as you can. The more prepared you are for that test, the more manageable you will find it and the less stressed you will feel.

seeker: Yes I am pretty good about that but it just kills my free time because I am working full time.
supporter: I understand. However, you need to be able to find some time dedicated to your school activities. You are the one who needs to decide how to insert it in your schedule.

seeker: Yes honestly I am the main driver behind me doing all this schooling it is just going to be good for my career and I don't just want to stand still.
supporter: I agree, once you have your career set up you won't have to worry about working and studying anymore. You will be doing what you like for a good living. Think about the future.

seeker: That is certainly the plan
supporter: Just remember not to stress too much about it. It's just one test at the end of the day, you can do this!

seeker: Yes I am not super worried about it it is more the stress from not having free time, also insurance textbooks are not extremely exciting.
supporter: I know that I told you to try to fit school time into your schedule, but the same goes with leisure time for yourself. Find an activity that you enjoy and try to dedicate at least an hour a day to it, be it exercising, playing videogames, reading a book.

seeker: Yes that is good advice, I try to find time for myself but time seems to disappear sometimes
supporter: Happens to all of us. I myself sometimes get too invested in work and the days go by without me realizing it, but it should definetely be a priority. Try to maximize your efficiency so you can do your work while having more time for other activities.

seeker: That is helpful, I am just glad I will have a few days off after today
supporter: That's absolutely great, make good use of them (^_^)

seeker: You have been very helpful, sorry I left for a bit
supporter: No worries, you too!

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi, so tell me, how are you feeling today?

seeker: I am feeling depressed
supporter: If you tell me what's going on, I will be more than glad to help

seeker: I can't pinpoint what exactly is making me feel this way. It could be the pandemic. But basically I started to feel that there is not much point in anything.
supporter: The pandemic can definetely be a key factor here. When it first started, I remember feeling lost and unsure about things that I would normally would have no problem with.

seeker: I am 30
supporter: Do you have any family, girlfriend, boyfriend, children?

seeker: I have family and a boyfriend but they all live far and I have not seen them in while.
supporter: Not seeing your closed ones or simply being apart from them can be more than enough to make us feel depressed or blue.

seeker: Yes sometimes. I don't tell them how I feel though. I don't want them to worry about me.
supporter: I understand. However, there is nothing wrong with telling them that you are sad because you miss them. Something as simple as getting it off your chest can already make you feel better.

seeker: I suppose. I just worry that I will make them sad too. It's hard time for everyone.
supporter: Totally, but remember than they are there for you whenever you need them.

seeker: Yes that's true. Do you have any suggestions on what to say?
supporter: I bet something as simple as "Hey babe, I really miss you. I can't be glad with your abscence" could make your boyfriend feel loved while at the same time relieving you.

seeker: That is true. I believe I have a problem showing vulnerability.
supporter: That might be why you were unsure about telling them. Believe me, there is nothing wrong with showing vulnerability. We are all vulnerable in one way or another.

seeker: I haven't been with my boyfriend that long before the pandemic started so I still have some fears and trust issues. I fear that being weak pushes people away.
supporter: Hey, if he is the right one for you, he will completeley accept you as you are and love you. In the unlikely event that he "rejects" you for being "vulnerable", he wasn't even worth it in the first place. You deserve someone that appreciates you as much as you appreciate them :3

seeker: That is true. I should be brave enough to find out if he will be there when the chips are down. I am going to do it
supporter: I believe in you!

seeker: Thank you for supporting me.
supporter: It has been a pleasure!

seeker: Enjoy the rest of your day.
supporter: You too!

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hello, how are you today

seeker: I am okay but started reflecting on the past and started to feel angry
supporter: I see. Sometimes that can happen when you look back on yourself.

seeker: I am angry I trusted my ex partner. They cheated on me and tried to hide it for months.
supporter: I can personally relate to that myself. I have went through something similar like that 4 years ago. It can be very frustrating when it happens.

seeker: What do you do when you are reminded of that situation or think about the person?
supporter: The easiest thing that I did in my situation was obtained a new hobby. I took my anger out on my ex by joining Crossfit and interacted with that community. It helped me take my mind of from my ex.

seeker: I've seen that Crossfit helps a lot of people. That is a good idea but it is kind of intimidating

supporter: Yes, it sounds like a part of you still misses the retail environment. I see that too. My best advice, is take a few days to think about what you really want to do.  Think about what you are skilled at. Then decide which route you want to go.  I know there will be numerous options out there for you in retail management, but if you wanted to do something different, there will be opportunities there too. Because you have options, you will likely pick the choice that will be most fulfilling for you, in something you will be passionate about - so this will likely be very positive for you.

supporter: So what I hear you saying is that since COVID your friends won't talk to you and that they make fun of you for wanting to wear a mask and protect yourself?

supporter: I am sorry to hear that your friends have been so distant lately.  Have you tried to ask them why they have been this way?

seeker: Yes. They say that because I'm not hanging out with them physically, it's hard. They also say that I don't put effort into conversations when I feel like I am the only one putting in effort (which I have stated and they have said I don't).
supporter: So what I hear you saying is that they have backed away from you because you have chosen to take precautions due to COVID and they are choosing to not? Is that correct?

seeker: Yes this is correct.
supporter: Well you are being smart by doing the right thing and protecting yourself and others during this time.  You should not feel bad about what you are doing.

seeker: Thank you. I just don't know what to do in this situation. I don't want to keep reaching out when I don't feel like they actually want to keep in contact with me. I know we could still get along well, but it's hard when I'm the only one to make the effort.
supporter: Do you have any other friends besides this group?  Do you have other people that you could reach out to that are social distancing that you could relate to more during this time that you would have more in common with right now?

supporter: What hobbies or activities do you like to do?

supporter: Field hockey that sounds like an exciting sport to play!  That does sound like it would keep you busy

But when I have other people it is fun. I haven't tried that because where would I even go? I don't want to be desperate either ya know?
supporter: I understand that you feel that you would look desperate but you said you like reading book so there may be some online book clubs that you could join.  I know that I have been involved in those and I didn't feel like I was seen as desperate since there are so many people that want to be social but don't want to put themselves at risk.

seeker: I never thought of that! That's is an amazing idea -- maybe I will look into that
supporter: I am so glad I was able to help. Maybe we can try and set up another time to talk again?

seeker: Sure!
supporter: Sounds great. You can let me know if you found a book club.

seeker: Awesome! Thanks again for everything -- and merry christmas
supporter: You are so very welcome.  Merry Christmas to you too!

supporter: On FB in groups. I got to chatting with the same people, then began to inbox and then asked them if I  could call. If you are in a group, you could even ask if anyone else would like to connect as friends. I am a woman, so I just picked women.

supporter: I understand how you feel. Have you guys tried spending more time with each other? Maybe going out on dates?

supporter: Its never too late to put spice back into the relationship.

supporter: Show her that your still love because by being spontaneous. Surprise her with gifts. Maybe take her on a random vacation somewhere. Have a deep conversation about how you are feeling and that you still love her and want her in your life.

seeker: I think your suggestions are very helpful. A vacation is currently out of the picture due to COVID. I want to try having deep conversations, but I don't know where to start.
supporter: Start by talking about whats going on. Tell her how you think you guys should spend more time with her. Or that you dont want to lose her. Ask her if there is anything she might want to discuss. She maybe having issues shes afraid to talk about.

seeker: I think you hit upon something. She is quite hesitant in talking about issues. Do you have any thoughts about marriage counselling? We've never tried that.
supporter: I think that would be a good idea. Having the chance to get things out and getting more advice is always helpful. Make sure you leave any issues at common ground.

supporter: Most likely a female therapist would be better. Nobody understands a woman more than a woman.

supporter: I suggest taking one step at a time. I wouldn't rush through things. I would suggest sitting down and talking through some things that are going on. Maybe taking some time away from work. Going out and spending time with each other as much as you can.

seeker: Thank you very much for your response. You have been very helpful. Perhaps, one last question - my wife and I have been hiding our problems away from our teen-age son. Do you agree that we should continue to keep it from him?
supporter: Depending on the nature, I think you should let him know whats going on. He may already know.

supporter: I know its really hard, but I think you guys with work things out. Have hope. Times are stressful, especially in this day and age.

seeker: Good afternoon/evening
supporter: Hello, how are you tonight?

seeker: Doing great. How about yourself?
supporter: I'm doing well how can I help you tonight?

seeker:
So, the issue I'm having is work-related. My son had heart surgery a few months ago. He now has a pacemaker. He's also in the middle of testing for CP. My job requires that I be around a lot of people. I always wear a mask...but sometimes the people I am with do not. Nor do they respect the 6-foot boundary.
A simple cold gives my son a fever of 103. Im scared that if I continue to work, Im putting him in danger. But if I stop, I can no longer afford bills.
supporter: I can see where this would be frustrating. As parents our biggest goal is to keep them safe and healthy. Have you thought about having a conversation with the people you are around to inform them you'd wish they wear a mask?

seeker: I have. A few people respected my wishes. But one in particular stands out. A gentleman who told me he had a medical condition and proceeded to get in my face. He got angry at my request.
supporter: I understand how you feel. Can you tell me a little more about how it makes you feel when they don't honor your requests?

seeker:
It makes me feel trapped. Frustrated. I would never intentionally try to put someone else in harms way and I feel like I don
t
supporter: I can see exactly how frustrated you are in this situation. Before I share some ideas do you have any ideas of ways to combat this issue?

seeker: I've spoken to my boss. He was sympathetic about it all....At this point I'm not sure what to do.
supporter: Alright. Have you talked to your boss about working in areas where you can be around people less? Or possibly going part time for now and finding a lob that puts less danger on you and your family?

seeker: Those are fairly decent ideas. The struggle for money would still be an issue if I worked part-time. And I doubt I could find a better job at this particular time. With that being said, I didn't think to see if the boss would let me work in the office for a bit. I know my fellow employees would respect my wishes.
supporter: We are going through some really tough times right now and I think that most people are very sympathetic. Especially for those who are in your shoes. Our children are our top priority and seeing them sick hurts us more than anything. How do you feel about talking to your boss about working in the office for a bit until things calm down a little?

seeker: That sounds like a reasonable thing to do.
supporter: Another suggestion that I have is maybe you could take some paid vacation time now rather than later to get away from people for awhile. I know it may not be the most fun time to do it but then you know you're keeping safe!

seeker: hanging in there, kinda freaking out a little
supporter: I'm sorry to hear you are freaking out. Perhaps a friendly listening ear can encourage you?

seeker: I think that'll help, yeah
supporter: Sometimes just a friend to hear you out and encourage you can really make a difference. Life has its ups and down.

supporter: That's a difficult decision you have made.

supporter: I have worked at a domestic violence shelter before, the most dangerous time to leave a situation like this is when you leave.  Do you have a plan in place?

seeker: I have some leads on apartments and some savings I'm putting aside, and a friend I plan on living with
supporter: My husband used to be very controlling as well, I dragged him to counseling. He changed. He bucked at first, but eventually he went. We have gone a few times off and on over 20 years. We both came from broken homes.

seeker: I haven't got 100% of the details worked out yet, but I'm trying
supporter: Has he hurt you physically? or is he mainly emotionally abusive?

seeker: He hasn't hurt me physically
supporter: I'm glad to hear that. I can understand that you would be really stressed at this time, however, I do encourage you to get a good plan in place, and definitely get counseling.

seeker: I think that's the best idea

seeker: exactly
supporter: I was just going to ask you if you  still see her, that must have been so difficult.

seeker: very difficult

supporter: I just want to say that the hollidays will be over soon and that may help.

seeker: i loved her just too much
supporter: Experts say that feeling your feelings and talking about them is really good for you to help get over a long breakup.  Also that it takes a year or more to process.  So know that you are doing the right things.

supporter: I was really lonely after my breakup too.  I had to make myself spend time with other people that cared about me like friends and family.  Even though I kind of just wanted to stay sad making myself be around other people that reminded me of the good, perfect and lovable things about myself made me feel better and gave me hope. Maybe easing your lonliness would give you some relief?

seeker: so you are advising me to go out more and mixed up with people
supporter: You sound like a sensitive and loving person.  Those are wonderful qualities.  I noticed them and we are strangers.  I'm sure you have many more.

supporter: It's normal to feel the way you do as  you sort out what happened and how to go forward.

seeker: ok

seeker: ok, thats a good idea

thanks, i will 
check them out

 and it worked?

seeker: oh, thanks

supporter: yes I think that is a great idea, look for jobs that meet your needs and figure out what you can do to look attractive to employers

supporter: I used it a bit, I mainly used indeed.

supporter: coursera has a lot of great courses, it really depends on what you are looking for.

If there are any employment agencies in your area, they may be worth looking into. And if there are any public assistance programs you qualify for, there's no shame in seeking help when you need it.

seeker: i will keep doing that, may be something will show up

seeker: Going to the store gives me Panic Attacks! Driving also makes me highly anxious.
supporter: Hello

seeker: Hi
supporter: So just to ensure that I understand you correctly, you are feeling anxious about going to the store during the pandemic

seeker: No. This has been going on before the pandemic
supporter: Okay, so just general anxiety about it then.

seeker: Yessir
supporter: How long have you had this anxiety issue?

seeker: Only the past couple of years. It came on suddenly at a nail salon after I had an allergic reaction to a chemical in acrylic nails.
supporter: Have you thought about looking for support groups with people who also have anxiety about being in public?

seeker: I have and I did
supporter: Have you thought about brining a friend with you to the store? Someone you are comfortable with? Having someone you are comfortable with may help to calm the anxiety while you are out.

seeker: Support groups don't really help stop the Panic Attacks. They cause all sorts of sensations. Fast heart rate, chills, shakes, My brain feels foggy and impersonal.
supporter: I have also had anxiety in the past when in public places, so I know how it feels to be anxious while out.

seeker: Yeah, it's definitely annoying. But it isn't JUST at the store. I was diagnosed with Panic Attack Disorder and even have attacks at home where I freak out.
supporter: Another thing that may help is having some headphones in attached to your phone or an MP3 player so you can have some calming music or something in your ear while you are out.

seeker: That's actually a really good idea. Distractions definitely seem to be the way to go for me.
supporter: I found that distractions were great for me too!

seeker: I wonder if it should be calming music or music that I generally feel like dancing too
supporter: Whatever music you think would be best would be a good idea.

seeker: I think a lot of my anxiety doesnt stem from social stuff but from a fear of death tbh
supporter: Do you have a stress ball or something you can keep with you in your pocket while out?

seeker: I don't!
supporter: I think picking up one of those and having it with you might also help!

seeker: That's a really good idea too. Thanks so much
supporter: You're very welcome!

seeker: <3 Have a good one!
supporter: Thank you, you too!

seeker: Bad. Almost had a good day and then got treated bad in the end so I don't know why I try.
supporter: I understand how you feel. It seems as if you are being treated badly for no genuine reason. Is this correct?

seeker: That is correct.
supporter: Who is treating you badly? Do you believe there are any causes behind the actions of those hurting you?

seeker: My husband mainly. He just doesn't want me to enjoy life I guess.
supporter: That must be really difficult to go through, I know when my partner treats me badly, I am hurt and upset with them.

seeker: Yeah, just become part of life I guess. Doesn't make it any better.
supporter: Are there any steps you can think of taking to express your frustrations with your husband?

seeker: I have tried many times. It always ends up my fault in the end so I don't bother anymore and just take it.
supporter: It is easy to lose patience when the blame is always directed towards you. I am sorry that is occurring, but applaud you for your efforts in trying to express your frustration.

seeker: Thank you. It gets trying at times. Tonight, I just sit in the dark alone because it isn't worth the hassle.
supporter: I can tell from chatting with you that you are struggling and fed up with this situation because you are trying very hard in your marriage but get nothing but disrespect in return.

seeker: That is for sure. Most of the time it is just the way life is but there are days I get fed up and it irritates me. It has been this way for a while.
supporter: From what I have seen, if a situation like this continues, not only will you be consumed with anger towards your husband which will all come out at once, but it may also lead to divorce based on research I have read about.

seeker: I won't divorce...even if I am miserable, that isn't an option.
supporter: I understand. I would prefer to work out a situation rather than use divorce as an option as well, but I am concerned with how miserable you have become.

seeker: I have gotten used to it. It is the way I am supposed to live my life I guess.
supporter: Some people respond to different strategies. You have tried communication through words to tell your husband your feelings, but have you shown him the consequences of his actions? Does he see how miserable you are? I suppose I wonder if you are interested in utilizing different strategies to find a solution to your issues with your husband and any others who may treat you badly.

seeker: He knows I am miserable. He knows I am upset. He is the living room watching tv and I am in the bedroom. It doesn't bother him that I am upset. It is getting late where I am and I should probably go to bed soon.
supporter: Alright. I have enjoyed talking to you, and hope that things will work out for you. My last suggestion is possibly to try to talk your husband into couple's therapy and see how he responds. Even if he responds negatively, at least you have tried to dissolve the issue once again. In situations like this, remember even when you feel completely alone, that someone is looking out for you even if you do not realize it. Take a few calming deep breaths and engage in self-care, you deserve it.

seeker: Thank you, good night.
supporter: You're welcome. Goodnight.

seeker: Hi
supporter: hi what brought you here today?

supporter: Do you have anyone else to talk to about what you're going through? It also helps a lot of the time to talk to an objective 3rd part to help give you some advice on what they think you should do.

Unfortunately

supporter: I've worked at a place that seems similar to your work environment. My co-workers were not supportive and I was always overlooked. Eventually, I realized that the environment was toxic and chose to start applying for different jobs. I felt like if my potential couldn't be appreciated then I should go somewhere with opportunities for growth.

supporter: You've got this! It's easy to become comfortable in what we know but, change causes us to grow.

supporter: Just start slowly and remember that you can be picky about what position you chose. I also think we all feel like we perform badly during interviews. Preparation is key. I hope discussing your work situation today has made you feel a bit better!

supporter: It was my pleasure! Thank you for sharing with me. I'm glad I had the opportunity.

supporter: What are your hours?

seeker: like generally, or currently in these situations? usually its around 9-5 (give or take).  These days its 9 - 7 or 11pm or later.
supporter: I have to say, when I am physically and mentally exhausted, I don't think as clearly and lose hope more easily.

seeker: right, and that is the issue of where I am at.
supporter: 9 to 11 would exhaust me. That is 14 hours?

seeker: yeah - something like that. and lunches are at the desk - as i am working from home - so its pretty much no breaks either.
supporter: I would certainly agree with you. That kind of work is unsustainable. Let me ask you this. What would happen if you told your employer you simply could not do these hours?

seeker: hah - i dunno. im on a team of 2 people - and i guess if i dont do it, the other person has to. or it just doesnt get done, and i dont know what happens?? nothing? LOL.
supporter: The worst that could happen is that they fire you. But that doesn't seem too likely as they seem to need you. But I have learned in life that if I don't care for myself, hardly anyone does. We need to be kind to ourselves. Set boundaries.

seeker: agreed - i dont think they would fire me, maybe get reprimanded or more likely a guilt trip as to why I cant do it. Im just not sure what kind of boundaries I set when we have things due, and just literally no time.
supporter: Setting boundaries can be difficult if you haven't done that a lot. When we think we don't have the ability to say NO, then we feel trapped, worn out, depressed, taken advantage of. People need to know that we reasonably can say no.

seeker: Well, I have to set boundaries, because working till 11pm most nights is not sustainable. and who on earth is going to view, let alone sign a contract at 12am
supporter: I think that would be the first step. Determine how many hours you feel you COULD work. Then advise them that is what you will do. Find out what kind of timelines there are, and if you can't do it, don't go beyond your boundaries. It is obviously destroying your life. It really isn't healthy for you.

seeker: yeah - ill come up with reasonable boundaries till 5:30 is reasonable, and if its a do or die situation cap it at 7:30 --- and thats only for dire situations. if that doesnt work, well then i guess either i dont have a job, or people figure out how to work in regular hours.
supporter: That sounds reasonable to me. And if they try to make you feel guilty, reject that. Tell them, I'm sorry, but I feel this is reasonable, and truly it is.

seeker: hah i used to go out like a young kid, but still - just because most of us are working from home 24/7, doesnt mean I actually can work 24/7. even fi i were young, hell no. they dont pay me enough.

seeker: yeah, i think a call to not just my boss is in order, but also HR to advise them of the situation. they need to start telling managers, we are NOT front of the line workers, nor police, fire, etc. our jobs are not THAT important.
supporter: I will say a prayer that you communicate your needs politely but firmly. And not believe false guilt. As you said, you aren't putting out fires and doing CPR.

:-)
firm and direct is the best approach. esp for my boss. she will appreciate that and then i will stick to what i say!
