seeker: Yea, she would most definitely call the cops and press charges because she sucks as a human being which is exactly why she's 4 years in my brain still...  Haaalp meh, you have any suggestions for making the lil devil in my brain chill?
supporter: I hope that I've been able to be of some help to you and thank you for talking. Enjoy the rest of your day!

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hello, how is your day going?

seeker: I am okie. how are you?
supporter: A little rainy here but I am okay.

seeker: I am feeling frustrated
supporter: What is causing you to feel frustrated?

seeker: Trying hard to find some work
supporter: It definitely can be challenging finding work in a pandemic but don't give up keep searching I am sure you will find something.

seeker: I am thinking that I am incapable to do anything
supporter: I are capable of doing whatever you decide, maybe try going back to school.

seeker: Despite of professional qualification and work experience, it is still hard for me to get it.
supporter: What is it hard for you to get?

seeker: job
supporter: Maybe try reaching out to Human Resources of the company you are applying for to see what qualifications and experience they are actually looking for.

seeker: Whenever I contact HR they are saying  due to COVID  they are not hiring right now.
supporter: Well have you thought about changing professions just until thing in your field pick back up?

seeker: But I want to do the work which I enjoy
supporter: I understand that you want to do what is enjoyable but how to you know you will not enjoy something else if you don't give it a try?

seeker: I think I wont be able to do well in new profession
supporter: I recently had to change jobs as well I was very hesitant and not confident about it. Once I started the new job and got the hang of things I couldn't see myself doing anything else at this moment.

seeker: Thanks for motivating me. I will try at least.
supporter: It seems that you have a wonderful personality, you just lack a bit of confidence.

seeker: I would try to boost my confidence. Thanks for all your help. Appreciate it.
supporter: You are welcome, now go out there and get that job!! Have a great day!!

seeker: sure! Thank you so much
supporter: Same too you as well.

seeker: Hello, how are you ?
supporter: Hello

seeker: I'm doing well, but it could have been better
supporter: What seems to be bothering you tonight?

seeker: Yes, my boy friend of 3 years has refused to take our relationship to the next level and I'm kind of getting tired, I don't want to play games anymore
supporter: So just to make sure I understand completely, you are ready to move on to the next step of your relationship and you don't feel as though your boyfriend is and this is making you anxious and upset,

seeker: exactly, I hate to feel that I'm wasting my time
supporter: I completely understand that, as I was in a long term relationship and I felt as though my girlfriend at the time did not want to take things to the next step and I was not happy about it.

seeker: Yes, I love him so dearly to want to settle down with him, but if he doesn't want that for me I would rather call it quits now than continue and be disappointed at the long run.
supporter:
Have you had that conversation with him? I know it might be a difficult conversation to have, but it is often good to get expectations out in the open so you are on the same page with your partner
.

seeker: Yes, sort of and he gave me the impression that he is not there yet and that was a like almost a year ago, I don't want it to look like I'm pushing him if I try to talk to him again about it. His nonchalant attitude in not seeing the seriousness of it is killing me, I'm just not happy.
supporter: That is tough, but sometimes people just portray things differently, for instance I am also very laid back and nonchalant about most things which can lead to miscommunications.

seeker: I hope you are right, just don't want to come across as a desperate person and that's why I'm setting myself up to call it quits if he tries to sound like he sounded the last time.
supporter: You need to know where he is so you can make a good decision for yourself!

seeker: You are right, that's exactly what I'm going to do because the wait is killing me.
supporter: Good, I am happy for you!

seeker: Thank you very much, you've been a great help
supporter: I am glad I was able to help!

seeker: Thanks, it was nice chatting with you.
supporter: You're welcome! If you need any more help just chat back with us again.

seeker: no problem, take care.
supporter: You as well!

seeker: Hello. What are some of the quickest ways to kill myself?
supporter: Have you talked to someone about this?

seeker: No, why bother? Everyone is just cruel. People are selfish.
supporter: I understand people can be cruel and selfish, but not everyone is. Some people want to help! Life is definitely worth living for.

seeker: Not at all. Why would I want to live in a degenerate world where millions die everyday? Be it hunger, disease, murder... Human beings are disgusting. We should go extinct.
supporter: Talking to someone you are close to, like a family member who cares about you, can definitely help.

seeker: Family? My family kicked me out of their own house 3 years ago. I am nothing but a burden for them. They would just appreciate if I died.
supporter: What about close friends, or people you care about? I am sure they would not want to lose you.

seeker: I have NO ONE that cares about me. Not a single being.
supporter: I care

seeker: I doubt you do. You are just getting paid to be here.
supporter: Just from chatting with you, I can feel how sad you are about life and maybe a little overwhelmed with what the next step of life is.

seeker: What would be that next step if I asked you?
supporter: I used to be really sad about life too. However, helping others who are sad helped me become happier, knowing that I am helping others also become happier.

seeker: What makes you think someone as useless as me could provide any help?
supporter: Take a deep breathe and think about any happy memories. If you are sad right now, the only way is up from here!

seeker: That's a very optimistic view...
supporter: Like I said, I used to be sad too and not optimistic. But now I am optimistic because I know what it is like to be sad, and I don't want others to feel how I have felt in the past.

seeker: I guess that's a way to view it...
supporter: Have you tried to express your feelings in one way or another? If you don't want to talk to others, there is always other ways - such as writing, music, etc. Have you tried any different ways?

seeker: Hello.
supporter: How has your day been?

seeker: Okay I guess.
supporter: Has there been anything that has been bothering you?

seeker: I have been very depressed lately.
supporter: What do you think has been causing your depression?

seeker: I was raped when I was a teenager by my boyfriend and as you can see its still haunting me to this day.
supporter: That definitely is a very impactful event, but you've already been so strong for reaching out.

seeker: Thank you. I feel as if I lost who I am after that happened.
supporter: I think it would be okay to allow yourself grieve because in a sense the person you were has now changed due to this event.

seeker: It is very hard to be in another sexual relationship after that has happened. Im not sure I will every be the same again.
supporter: I understand, I had a similar event where I was taken advantage of with similar feelings.  I personally decided to share all my feelings with my new partner and we went very slow only doing things I was comfortable with.

seeker: That seems like a good idea. But, what if my partner doesn't have empathy for those sort of things. Im worried he will not care.
supporter: In good relationships both partners have mutual respect for each which extends into their sexual relationship.  Remember you haven't lost your self worth, and you deserve someone who respects you.

seeker: I suppose. I just dont want to burden my new relationship with my past issues.
supporter: Your past is definitely not a burden, it's part of you, even if it's not a positive experience.  By sharing your past, it would bring you closer as a couple.

seeker: I guess you are right.
supporter: Another thing that could help you navigate new relationships is counseling.  I've had counseling sessions that have greatly helped me in the past.

seeker: I will look into that tomorrow. Thank you for your advice and time. I truly appreciate it.
supporter: Of course!  I think we must support each other in our times of need.

seeker: Hello. Not so well. I have a very stressful job situation right now.
supporter: Oh no, I am very sorry to hear about that. Can you tell me more about your situation?

seeker: I really never got along with my coworkers. I think they purposefully harrass me sometimes. For example, yesterday during lunch time, they took my soda and threw it on the garbage can, then said "oops, I thought it was empty".
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that. It sounds like you are being bullied at work. Is that right?

seeker: If that defines it as bullying, then yes, that's right.
supporter: I can definitely understand why that would e so stressful for you. It hurts when your hard work goes unrecognized.

seeker: I feel like I meet all the standards that are expected from me at work. I don't know what else do they want.
supporter: Have you tried asking your boss for a one on one talk where you can talk about ways you can improve? I did that before and I found that it was super helpful in seeing a new perspective about me.

seeker: No, I haven't tried that. And I appreciate it, but you have no way of assuring that I am beautiful when you haven't seen me. Beautiness is relative too. Maybe I am dislikeable for my coworkers but pretty for someone else.
supporter: Okay, well maybe that may be a good place to start with your boss? I think it will be a great place to start. Sometimes it helps to reach out and hear other's perspective of you.

seeker: I feel like maybe I can give it a try.
supporter: And I think everyone is beautiful. You are definitely right about beauty being relative. I personally choose to see the beauty in everything and it has made life a lot more beautiful for me.

seeker: That's a pretty view to have about beauty.
supporter: That's great! How about your coworkers. Do you feel like it might be worth talking to them about what they have been doing to you?

seeker: I honestly kind of fear them. I just want them to leave me alone.
supporter: I see, I understand how difficult it would feel to talk to people who have been treating you like that. :(

seeker: Hello. I am dissapointed in the teachers that I always get. They seem to make my courses so much harder.
supporter: I see. You feel unlucky and disappointed that the teachers cause your courses to be challenging?

seeker: Exactly. I compare myself to my friends and, for example, they get barely any homework.
supporter: Course work is already stressful enough but to be challenging in addition only adds to the pressure.

seeker: Yeah. But I swear, every single one of my teachers just seems so imcompetent at times.
supporter: I remember an English teacher of mine, always calling me out in class, saying that she expects better of me when my papers weren't the best. Her class was hard and I worked hard to complete my assignments as instructed. Instead of her speaking with me personally, she'd embarrass me. I did not like her class at all.

seeker: Those are the worst teachers. I wish teachers like those would get fired.
supporter: Is there enough time to maybe select more compatible teachers or speak with the school counselor about classes that work best for you?

seeker: That's the thing. I never get to pick my classes. And they always give me crap recommendations.
supporter: That is a great idea. I'd encourage you to speak with your school counselor to share your needs and maybe the 2 of you can come up with a plan to create a schedule with teachers that can help you be successful.

seeker: I am absolutely certain that I am capable of succeeding at school without over stressing. Hopefuly this will fix the issue.
supporter: I believe you are correct! Less stress certainly creates a better learning environment. School counselors are your ally. Remember, you can go to them anytime you need them. Are you stopping by this week?

seeker: Maybe. If I have time on thursday or friday, I think I will go.
supporter: I am so excited for you! This is a big step! Looking out for yourself, to assure you are happy, less stressed and learning the important things to be able to graduate.

seeker: I agree...
supporter: For your next year, asking upperclassmen about their teachers can give you insight on who you may have next year. The more you know in advance, the better you can plan for what to discuss with your counselor. So proud of you! I know you 2 will come up with an awesome schedule!

seeker: Thank you. I will try my best.
supporter: Good Luck!

seeker: Hello, I have been concerned lately.
supporter: So you have some worries about life? Would you like to share them?

seeker: I keep failing online classes even when I seem to have them under control. I think it might have something to do with me playing too much videogames.
supporter: Do you feel that perhaps you are playing video games as a distraction from how bad the world is at the moment?

seeker: No, I don't think that's it. I have been playing games since I was 6.
supporter: Ah, so it's a long term hobby? I do love gaming myself I have to admit.

seeker: I tried, but my online rank not being where I want it gives me anxiety
supporter: It sounds like you might have a genuine addiction to gaming. Do you think you might benefit from some counselling? There are organisations that can help.

seeker: Do you really think it's that severe?
supporter: Well, if it is affecting your grades and the rest of your real life then it might be. And it's best to catch these things before they get worse.

seeker: The thing is, I keep telling myself I have enough time to get my school work done. But sooner than later I realize the assignments are already past their due date.
supporter: Have you been getting into trouble with your teachers about this or has no-one noticed so far?

seeker: Yeah, I have. They say that I am either super invested on my school work or that I lack any signs of effort at times.
supporter: Does your school have a counsellor?

seeker: Yeah, they assigned me one.
supporter: Do you feel that they have not been of any help?

seeker: I really haven't reached out to them, so that's probably on me.
supporter: I do understand that it can be very difficult to open up about having a problem

seeker: But I don't think I have a problem
supporter: The trouble is that sometimes the person with a problem can be the last to actually realise it

seeker: Thank you.
supporter: You're welcome  -  enjoy the rest of your day!

seeker: Hello. Not so good.
supporter: That is a very hard thing to be going through where you very close to your cat?

seeker: Yes, I had her for 11 years.
supporter: I am very sorry to hear that i have also lost a pet earlier this year his name was fish and was only 3 years old he unfortunately passed due to liver cancer. It was a very trying experience but slowly the pain of his passing has got a little bit easier.

seeker: No. My family lives in another country, and I really don't have any close friends.
supporter: What have your feelings been like after the passing of your cat?

seeker: I feel hopeless. Alone. I feel like a chunk of myself passed along with her.
supporter: Those are completely valid feelings to have at this time

seeker: No. I fear that things like that may remind me of her and make me feel worse.
supporter: Expressing your emotion is very healthy for example maybe taking up a new hobby or trying something new that scares or excites you to get your mind off of this difficult time.

seeker: I used to play videogames before. Now I'm not so sure I would enjoy them.
supporter: What was your favorite genre of video games?

seeker: First person shooters and MMORPG's.
supporter: Have you considered playing again possibly joining an online team and competing in tournaments?

seeker: Hello. Everytime I Feel like I can get close to someone they show me they really never cared. I feel like I keep getting stabbed in the back.
supporter: I am sorry that you feel that way.  Have you tried asking them why they don't express care towards you?

seeker: Why bother? They most have more important friends out there. Yeah, that's surely why. I am just someone they just met, why would they care anyways.
supporter: If they don't see on the same level as you do then maybe it is time to seek new friends.

seeker: Could it be that I keep trying to approach people without knowing if we have common interests or not for example?
supporter: It takes time to build friendships and relations.  The best way to establish the connection is to find individuals who share similar interests with you.

seeker: I think it's because I like anime. Maybe people hate me for it. You know, they call us "weebs" and make fun of us...
supporter: Anime you say?  I love anime as well!  For me, I use the interest of anime to seek groups who are interested in anime as well.

seeker: Do those really exist? I feel like everyone I meet gets turned down when I tell them I like anime...
supporter: There are plenty of individuals who shares common interests like you do!  Do not let other's opinions hinder your judgement.

seeker: I know you are right, but... it's easier said than done.
supporter: I highly suggest joining open online forums like reddit.  There you can find anime groups that you can join.  They will be more than happy to share similar interests with you.

seeker: Do you recommend joining something like an anime club then?
supporter: I highly recommend for you to join an anime club or group.  These places are great for you to establish a strong connection with others through shared interests.

seeker: That's what I was thinking too. My college has one manga and anime club I believe.
supporter: They have one?  That is fantastic!

seeker: I wouldn't be so sure, but thanks, I guess I might get lucky.
supporter: Part of finding new friendship is to put aside any doubts and uncertainties and say "what the heck" and just go for it!

seeker: You are absolutely right, I might be overthinking this lol
supporter: Is there anything else I can help you with?

seeker: Hey, how are you?
supporter: I am not too bad thanks. Is there anything on your mind?

seeker: I'm doing alright, trying to keep in the holiday spirits. Feeling a bit down, due to my work situation
supporter: You're having problems at work? Does this involve coworkers or is it about your financial situation?

seeker: More financial situation, I was informed that my hours are reduce and will not get an extenison on my job contract
supporter: I am really sorry to hear that. Is that due to the pandemic? Times are really hard for everyone right now unfortunately.

seeker: Yeah my company isn't doing to well at the moment and they are trying their best to keep everyone but they had to make massive cuts/
supporter: I can tell from your messages that you are feeling deeply anxious. Are you worried that you might not be able to support your family?

seeker: That is my biggest concern at the moment, I cut all of my expenses. I didn;t ask my family but they cut a few things out as well. But I feel that I'm not providing for them.
supporter: It is a really difficult situation to be in, especially as it's through no fault of your own. Would you consider taking on some part time work for a while?

seeker: I would, I'm doing odd jobs here and there but no one is really hiring where I live.
supporter: There's a big gig economy out there on the internet - you could always try looking there?

seeker: I will try and good into that, I do feel a bit better. I wish I could do more like I used too
supporter: The restrictions are really getting me down as well although I understand why they are necessary. Hopefully the year to come will be better for us all.

seeker: I hope so, I do feel better and optimistic. I do understand a lot of people are going through what I'm going through.
supporter: I hope I am not being patronising by saying that. I know that just because other people feel bad that doesn't mean you automatically have to cheer up :)

seeker: I just forget that everyone is going through tough times, I was feeling down and being hard to myself the past week. But need to realize we are in bad times currently.
supporter: Maybe you could plan something fun to do once this is all over - a mini break perhaps? Gives you something to look forward to

seeker: Haha I wish, I do have something in mind. Maybe might buy my favorite cigar and whiskey and enjoy myself this weekend.
supporter: That sounds like a really great idea! Sometimes even little things can make a big difference to us

seeker: Yeah, I should plan a little me time from time to time and destress from everything.
supporter: Be good to yourself! I hope that I've managed to help a little.

seeker: Thanks for helping, I'm glad we chatted
supporter: Enjoy the rest of your day :)

seeker: Hi. I'm feeling okayish.
supporter: It sounds like there maybe something you need to get off of your chest.

seeker: Absolutely. I recently broke up with my girlfriend. We had been together for more than 3 years.
supporter: What happened that made you guys break up?

seeker: She said that she simply wasn't in love anymore, and that she didn't have the same feelings she did at the beginning.
supporter: I have also had this situation happen to me. Maybe it just wasn't the right timing or she had other interests.

seeker: She was so important for me. I feel so empty.... I Feel like I'm never finding anyone like her ever again,
supporter: The first step of a break should be to starting loving thyself. If you get out there and find hobbies you enjoy, who knows, you may find someone that will love you more than you could imagine. Take it from me, I've had this happen. Sitting around sulking about it is only going to delay things in your life.

seeker: It's easier said than done. At times I would rather maybe just dissapear. I have never had anyone else show romantic interest in me before.
supporter: What is your age?

seeker: I am 25 at the moment.
supporter: You still have your whole life ahead of you. Some people don't find a partner until their 40's or even 50's. When I left my ex I found this guy that I truly fell in love with. He is still sulking in his living room. I told him that if he didn't move one that he wouldnt get anywhere in life. I told him that if he cared about me, he would move on because thats truly what I would want him to do and I think thats what your girl would want you to do as well.

seeker: I disagree with you regarding that maybe that is what she wants me to do. I don't think she cares about me at the slightest anymore. I was a burden for her and will probably keep being it for any woman I meet.
supporter: Did she give you any reasons to why she wasn't in love anymore?

seeker: I think she wasn't feeling physically attracted to me anymore.
supporter: Did you ever think she maybe possibly has been cheating?

seeker: I could not say for sure.
supporter: Has she ever tried to hide text messages, lock her phone, or tell you she is too busy to come over?

seeker: Actually, In the past few months she has kinda freaked out everytime I tried to get her phone for her
supporter: Im sorry that this stressful for you. In my past, I have had exes do that to me. Most likely she was cheating on you and this was the reason for her motives.

seeker: I can't believe she would do something like that... I really need to confront her about it. I can't have this doubt on my chest.
supporter: I would definitely confront her about it. I wouldn't get angry or fight about it. Maybe she if she has a new boyfriend already. That is a really good indicator.

seeker: You are right. I need to take this slowly and calmly.
supporter: I would calmly ask her. She will most likely deny it. But, some ofher friends may already know about this. If she says she did, ask her if there was something you did wrongthat made her do it. Sometimes its not even the Cheatee. Sometimes they just do it for no good reason.

seeker: I'm fine, but could be better just not too happy with my situation. Hope you are doing great
supporter: I am well. What's going on?

seeker: yes, have a friend who I'm very close to , but have noticed she doesn't tell me the truth this days. And not only that she has been distancing as in not calling , always waiting for me to call. I call her about a week ago, but wasn't happy how she dismissed my call within seconds telling me she will call me back only for her not to call till to day. I don 't feel like calling her again.
supporter: So it seems like you have been noticing some distance between you and a friend and it also seems like he/she is not putting as much as effort into your relationship as you are. It seems at times that you put in all the work and that it's one-sided. Does that sound about right?

seeker: You are absolutely correct and this is someone I care so much about
supporter: This must be very hard on you.

seeker: Oh it is very depressing, have known her for a very long time about 16years now
supporter: Sixteen years is a long time. I recently when through a similar situation with a friend. In my case, sitting down and communicating how I feel about the situation really did resolve many things. It made me understand why all of a sudden she was being distant and in the long run, it made our bond even stronger

seeker: That's very good to hear. I would have loved to do ask her what the problem is, but knowing how she is hiding some things from me, I just don't feel comfortable approaching her. I had this feeling she is doing it on purpose, I just don't understand why.
supporter: I think you should try to honestly talk to her about how you feel and express to her that you are concerned. If she blows you off or ignores you, maybe consider rethinking your friendship. I know 16 years is a long time, but don't feel like you have to hold on to a relationship that is creating all of these negative feelings and unnecessary stress in your life. Friendships are meant to bring you up, encourage you, and hold you through the dark times. If she does not take your concerns seriously, consider taking a break and being distant.

seeker: I will give it a try, but it's very hard for me to swallow the way she has treated me.
supporter: People change sometimes and it is hard to understand. I want you to know that you are ENOUGH! You are smart and beautiful. Maybe it's time for this relationship to come to a close, but other people will come your way that will treat you like you deserve. I know it's painful now, but you will be stronger and better for going through this.

seeker:
Thanks for understanding, I feel better now. 
 I will give it sometime and if I don't feel like it or don't hear from her any more, I will take it that it's time to move on.
supporter: I think that is a good approach. You will get through this!

seeker: You have been a big help and I can't thank you enough
supporter: Anytime. I hope your feeling even a little better. Is there anything else I can help you with today?

seeker: No, you've helped enough already and I thank you once again for your support
supporter: Glad to be of service to you. If there is nothing else, feel free to click quit whenever your ready.

seeker: okay, no problem . Nice chatting with you
supporter: Take care! Bye

seeker: Hello.
supporter: Hello

seeker: Feeling depressed as usual
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. What has you feeling depressed?

seeker: Everything. Life. It's awful. How many years do you really need to stop enjoying this place.
supporter: I understand, but just to make sure I know what is going on fully, you are depressed in general and don't know how to get through it.

seeker: I would say that is fairly accurate.
supporter: Just from these few messages, I can tell you are extremely upset about this.

seeker: Sorry to hear that. Anxiety and depression are dual bladed sword of badness
supporter: It was tough. Have you thought about consulting a psychological professional to help with this issue? I did when I was going through my depression and it really helped.

seeker: NO! I would never do that. I'm already on anti depressants. That didn't help at all.
supporter: I didn't like the meds that they gave me either, however I felt that talking to someone helped me a great deal.

seeker: Well, I'm glad it helped you. I'm not just saying that. Being depressed is awful.
supporter: It was good to be able to talk to an objective third party about what was going on. It allowed me to get my feelings out without the threat of being judges or harrassed.

seeker: I understand. Well, I appreciate your time and advice. I just don't feel like you and I are understanding each other very well, though. Anyway, you made your bonus. I appreciate you trying to help me, though
supporter: Have you tried to focus on more of your hobbies in order to get your mind off of things?

seeker: I used to have more hobbies. Now, I'm not so motivated to do much of anything anymore.
supporter: Why did you stop playing insturments?

seeker: I just lost interest. I'm losing interest in everything, man
supporter: I certainly hope you don't do that!

seeker: Well, that's nice. You are a nice person.
supporter: I apologize that I wasn't able to make you feel any better

seeker: NO!
supporter: Have a wonderful evening!

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hello

seeker: I am feeling  depressed .I don't feel like doing anything.
supporter: What got you depressed?

seeker: I don't know. Maybe stuck at one place
supporter: What have you tried to do to control it?

seeker: don't know what to do
supporter: Everything is going to be okay keep your head up it will get better in time for you

seeker: I am becoming lazy day by day. Things are scattered and disorganized.
supporter: Don't let it take control of you that is what it is trying to do

seeker: I am trying it but not working on me. I feel like my life is no use
supporter: You should never feel like your life is no use because it is you have a lot to live for

seeker: I tried to stay positive but these negative thoughts are always stuck in my head despite of trying to not think about it.
supporter: you have control of your mind and i know you can control those negative thoughts don't let those negative thoughts win

seeker: I  would try to do it. Thanks
supporter: your welcome you will get through this i know you will

seeker: Thank you for all your good words.
supporter: no problem

seeker: I feel sleepy all the time.
supporter: have you tried to do some exercise that works dealing with depression

seeker: I feel horrible to be honest. I can't get anything done.
supporter: I am really sorry to hear that.. would you like to talk about it?

seeker: I guess... But I doubt this will be of any help. I am just here because my mother pressured me.
supporter: So, I hear you saying that you're not enthusiastic about having to talk about your problems?

seeker: I really never find why telling my problems to a stranger can result helpful
supporter: I do understand. I've tried therapy myself and was very hesitant at first. But after a while I found it really did help

seeker: Everything has been going wrong. I have no friends, 0 luck with dating. School sucks. I fail my classes. I can't find a job.
supporter: Well, let's take these one at a time. Firstly, is there something you could do to make friends? Join a group of some kind?

seeker: Do you mean like joining a club at school or something?
supporter: What about something like a book club or a gym?

seeker: I hate exercising. I like reading manga every now and then. I guess I am just a depressed weeb. I'm so useless....
supporter: No you are not. Thinking like that is a symptom of depression. It is perfectly normal but there is help available.

seeker: The thing is I would be in a much better place in life right now if I were capable of it.
supporter: I do understand. I have suffered severe depression and I know how debilitating it is. Can you see your doctor?

seeker: Yeah, I probably can
supporter: Would you be prepared to take medication? I know a lot of people hate the idea but it can really help.

seeker: Medication? Am I some kind of crazy psycho now? No, not at all
supporter: I was talking about anti depressants :). I use prozac and it helps a lot.

seeker: Prozac? Could you tell me more about it...?
supporter: Yes - it is an anti depressant drug that was developed about thirty years ago. It works by preventing your brain from reuptaking serotonin

seeker: Is that some kind of hormone that makes me feel down?
supporter: Serotonin actually makes you feel good. In a  depressed person it can be reuptaken by the brain too rapidly however, leaving you feeling low. Prozac prevents this from happening.

seeker: Thank you. You too...
supporter: Just click the button at the bottom :)

seeker: Yo
supporter: Hi, how are you doing?

seeker: I am decent. I am here because my friend talks way too much on the phone, and it frustrates me.
supporter: It sounds like it would be quite frustrating for your friend to talk way too much on the phone.

seeker: No, he loves it! I'm the one who hates it.
supporter: My goodness! How do they respond when you ask to end the conversation?

seeker: I tell him, but he just doesn't get it. Or, he says he understands, but then just goes back to talking!
supporter: I wonder what it would be like for him if you hung up the phone even after he said he still wanted to talk.

seeker: He will literally talk up to 10 minutes without letting you have a word in. As far as that advice, I have hung up, but he gets extremely offended easily.
supporter: That sounds really difficult if he gets offended so easily. I find it hard to talk to some of those kinds of friends.

seeker: I'm at my wits end. I tell him all the time. "You talk too much. You gotta stop talking at me. You gotta give the other person a turn. You gotta respect other's time."
supporter: What do you get out of the friendship with this other person?

seeker: Well, I've been friends with him for a long time. He's funny and can have interesting perspectives on things. Also, we have done a lot together in the past.
supporter: That sounds like a lot that the two of you have been through. Were there other times that your friends was more equally responsive or attuned to you in conversations?

seeker: Oh, yes, I have other friends in conversations who can take turns and understand the concept of time just fine.
supporter: I wonder if there is anything nice you could do for yourself when you are talking to him that would make it easier to talk to him.

seeker: Do you think I should just have a timer that goes off at 1 minute and let it beep in his face if he goes on for too long to train him like a monkey?
supporter: I can see that you are feeling upset and angry when he talks so much and that is totally understandable.

seeker: I just need a method. Talking to him is just not working.
supporter: Would it hurt his feelings to use a timer like that? It may for some other people.

seeker: Yea, but I might be able to slip some humour in there to take the edge off because it is so silly.
supporter: Humor is really helpful for a lot of people.

seeker: Any other ideas?
supporter: Sometimes, people draw or do something else distracting with their hands when talking to someone who dominates the conversation.

seeker: So your option is to start just doing something else when he is talking? He might get the message in a subtle way?
supporter: Sometimes that is a less offensive way to retrain someone who is being obnoxious or dominant and yet who is easily offended. And, it can help preserve your sense of being grounded.

seeker: This is true, and it isn't bade advice. Haha! That is funny. Yes, maybe I should find something to carry around with me that I can enjoy.
supporter: Is there anything else that you like to do that would be distracting while also letting you somewhat participate in the conversation?

seeker: Yes, perhaps I should just use the internet when he starts talking too much.
supporter: That sounds really helpful. Sometimes people also play phone games or with a fidget spinner. I like your idea of looking on the internet.

seeker: This solves the problem in person, but it doesn't solve the talks over the phone, but it has been 15 minutes now and this has been helpful enough. Thank you for your solutions. You have been very supportive and kind to me
supporter: You are very welcome. I wish you all the best!

seeker: Goodbye. You as well.
supporter: Bye!

seeker: Hey
supporter: Hello! How are you doing today?

seeker: I'm doing alright, trying to stay cheerful
supporter: That's great, especially around this time of the Holidays.

seeker: Yeah, it is good because of the holidays.
supporter: So, how are things in your life?

seeker: Not to bad, just had a death in the family. Pretty bummed about it because we are a close to our extended family and can't visit one another to grieve
supporter: I'm very sorry to hear that. Not being able to be with family when something like that happens is incredibly difficult, those are the people you want to be around the most.

seeker: Yeah, we just had a virtual funeral for him and it was painful to watch. We couldn't console those who needed it
supporter:
I actually had a death in a family a few months ago as well, with a virtual funeral. I really empathize with the way you and your family are feeling. But you know, I tried to look at the virtual funeral as a way for so many people to pay tribute in a way they couldn't in person. People from all over ge
t their chance to say goodbye.

seeker: Yeah thats a good way to look at it, the whole family was able to get together in one place and was able participate safely. We also chatted hours afterwards. I did feel better about it
supporter: Truly, everyone got to participate and pay tribute together. Virtually or not, you were all together.

seeker: Yes it is, I do wish we can meet in person but COVID
supporter: That's a great way to look at it. In a year where COVID had gotten in the way of so many plans, I think it's really great to try and extract the best experience we can.

seeker: Yeah try to stay safe together and reduce the spread of this diseases.
supporter: Exactly, trying to be safe together to keep everyone else safe. Looking out for one another is something this year has made really important.

seeker: Hopefully the cases start declining, it is not doing well for peoples mental health. Just had a friend die from mental illness.
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that. How are you dealing with that loss?

seeker: I'm doing alright, I feel my mental health is weakening as time goes by do to zero interaction and remote working. But staying strong and managing.
supporter: I'm glad to hear you're doing alright. The lack of human connection and socialization this past year has definitely been very difficult.

seeker: Yeah, thanks for the talk. I feel much better. It is good to talk things talk and get them off of your chest.
supporter: Absolutely no problem, getting your thoughts out and talking things out helps me so I'm glad I could help you.

seeker: I am having ongoing depression.
supporter: I'm very sorry to hear that. The fact that it is ongoing must make it even harder.

seeker: I have the symptoms of sadness and anxiety. It first began a couple of weeks ago.
supporter: I see. Are you sad or anxious about anything in particular?

seeker: Yes, I am sad and anxious about the coronavirus. I miss seeing my friends and family.
supporter: It sounds like you must really care about your friends and family, and this awful pandemic is prevent your from seeing them.

seeker: Yes, definitely. I hope the pandemic will end.
supporter: I know this may sound personal, but it is completely normal to have these thoughts though... have you thought about dying at all?

seeker: I haven't thought about dying at all. I take medication each day for my depression, but there are times when I still feel sad.
supporter: Okay, thanks for sharing that personal information. I only ask because thoughts of suicide are normal and anxiety and depression increase the chances of suicide.

seeker: You're welcome. I understand, but I am not suicidal.
supporter: What would you like to talk about, then? We could talk about the problem more, or if you feel like it is defined, we could talk about solutions, or not talk about solutions at all. What would make you feel better?

seeker: I would like to talk about solutions since I feel like the problem is defined.
supporter: I know what it is like to be depressed. I also take medication for this. For solutions, studies show that working out and exercising can help depression. Have you considered this?

seeker: Yes, I enjoy taking walks and doing a cardio workout at home.
supporter:
That's great! 
What ways do you think you could communicate more with your family?

seeker: I could communicate more with my family by calling them on the phone, texting, emailing, or talking to them on Zoom.
supporter: You listed a lot of good solutions such as zoom and texting. Do you think doing that would make you feel less depressed?

seeker: Yes, I think that Zoom and texting would make me feel less depressed.
supporter: Well, let me ask you this. I noticed that you had many solutions off-hand that you could tell me, and you also said it could help you with your depression. May I ask what is keeping you from using these methods?

seeker: Wanting to stay in bed is keeping me from using these methods.
supporter: Oh, I completely understand. Depression has that effect. But maybe you can talk to your loved ones while in bed? How do you feel about that?

seeker: I feel okay about that.
supporter: Well, it's worth a try, right!

seeker: Yes, it is worth a try. Thank you for all of your help!
supporter: Thank you for allowing us to complete this task as well. I know depression can cause us to lose motivation, so I really appreciate it. I hope you feel better.

seeker: Thank you.
supporter: You are welcome. Goodbye.

supporter: ok. How can I be of service tonight

So you had been together for awhile and all of 
 a sudden he has another person in his life

There hasn't been anything like this before that I know of. Maybe there was. I trusted him and didn't look at his messages or anything.

supporter: The fact that he cheated on you and I assume you broke up with him is hard

nth.  I appreciate that.

supporter: I also talked to a few friends who are married and had experienced infidelity. They chose to forgive each other. I learned a lot from them. It helped me to make up my own mind as to how I needed to move forward. I didn’t want to use a therapist since I do better with discussing ideas with multiple people.

supporter: Alot of parents are experiencing the same difficulty, even I am experiencing trouble with my child. It is a lot of alien stress to us when, in the past, we were only responsible for ensuring that homework is done.

seeker: I agree with you there. It would be nice if they could be in school, but I understand that they shouldn't be.
supporter: It's kind of a tired saying, but one strategy that has helped me is the One day at a time strategy. I'm sure you've heard of it. Basically, it means just do for today, don't worry about yesterday, don't stress over tomorrow, just treat this day as it's own task.

seeker: I've definitely heard that before, but you are completely right. I need to stop worrying about yesterday and tomorrow and focus on today, but I'm just not very good at that.
supporter: Then, within that, one task at a time. Segment things he wants to do then reward him with them upon successful completion of school-tasks.

seeker: Yea, I definitely need to get better at doing that. I end up letting them play video games and with toys in the middle of the day sometimes because I have work that I have to get done as well.
supporter: For my example, my daughter very much likes to play video games. In order to earn video game time I need two successful assignments. They have to be small, reasonable tasks, but also an amount of time that allows you to take it one bite at a time.

seeker: That's very smart on your part. I really need to learn to actually follow through and do that.
supporter: Well, one piece at a time. I apologize for the strangeness of the reference.

seeker: No, I appreciate the different references.
supporter: You can't do it all at once, and neither can he.  It's not a perfect solution, but its a solution that has worked for me.

seeker: You've made some very good points and I just need to get better at taking things one thing at a time.
supporter: This is a strange new world. Sometimes we have to try strange new things to cope.

seeker: That is definitely true. No one could have possibly been prepared for what has been happening.
supporter: I'm glad I was able to help.

seeker: It's just nice to be able to talk to someone else who is experiencing some of the same things.
supporter: I think you will find that a lot of your friends are in the same place.

supporter: And that adds to stress beyond the ad-hoc homeschooling. It is important to purposefully socialize by phone or chat with friends. We humans are social creatures, and you are not an island. We all need friends. My wife has been an amazing support, but I still make time to facetime with my buddies.

supporter: I'm grateful to be of help.

supporter: I have been in many work situations and even social situations where I did not feel as if I fit in, I'm rather an unusual person. I had to learn to not focus so much on BEING accepted. I had to learn what God think of me (he loves me) and try to be kind to all I meet, other centered. That is, I also had to make sure I wasn't being rude or mean.

seeker: I think from now on I’m just going to focus on myself and my family, I’m not gonna out of my way to be nice to my coworkers, I’m just going to treat them as coworkers not as friends and just keep to myself
supporter: I think you can be kind to them, but I think perhaps your expectations are that they reciprocate, and they aren't which hurts. Perhaps be kind without expecting anything in return, and know that God sees your kindness.

seeker: I always feel like you have to be a friend to have friends, but I’m tired of being the only one putting effort in and getting taken advantage of
supporter: I also had this happen, I had no friends and at first I thought it was me, then I realized it was an opportunity for personal growth. Which wasn't easy.

seeker: I just feel like they just expect me to do things for them now and when I do it, it’s no appreciated because they just know I will do it.
supporter: I understand. Yes, then they definitely are taking advantage. Have you read anything on setting boundaries and learning how to say no?

seeker: Yeah, I’m working on taking care of myself more than worrying about everyone else. I think the holidays make it even harder to set the boundaries
supporter: I had learned once that it is so important to be able to easily say no because then we are free to say yes.  Because if we say yes because we CAN'T say no, then we feel resentful. So If I can freely say no to you, then i am free to say yes, if that makes sense.  Although for me, it was hard to say no, but it gets easier, now it is easy. It wasn't at first.

seeker: Thank you! You have been very helpful. I think that will be my goal! Start learning to say no and don’t feel guilty about it. I think I am going to lower my expectations from other people and just start treating people as they treat me!
supporter: If I always say yes, because I can't say no, I feel obligated and resentful, when really, it's me with the problem, I had a hard time saying no because I didn't want to hurt people. Now, I  do the right thing in my heart, if I want to help, I help, if I want to say no, I say no even if it is hard, I don't care if they get upset. I can say no, that's true freedom.

seeker: I think I just need to learn a new approach to how I handle my dealings with other people.
supporter: Might be on youtube too. Good stuff on how to say no and set boundaries! :D

supporter: You are welcome! Have a nice evening!

supporter: I've been struggling too, not being able to see my friends. I've been forcing myself to text them more or do phone calls or meet in person.

seeker: That's what I have been doing too. I tried to get together with my friends but we have little kids and that is tough. We don't want to get sick. I worry that we are drifting apart too.
supporter: That makes it hard. Have you talked to your friends about how they are feeling? Is there maybe some compromises you can make to see them more but keep distancing?

seeker: I haven't talked with them. They are busy and we haven't talked in a while. I need to call them.
supporter: You should give them a call. Just out of the blue, nothing commuting. Just a casual chat and see if they want to do something. If finding something to do doesn't work out during the call, at least you contacted them and maybe will feel a bit better because you talked to them.

seeker: That sounds like a good plan. I will call someone tonight.
supporter: It doesn't have to be much but even just a little conversation can go a long way

seeker: Thanks for your help. I appreciate you.
supporter: No problem. I hope you feel better.

seeker: Hi, yes. I am having a really hard time and feeling depressed.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. Would you like to tell me what the problem is?

seeker: I feel like I am very isolated. I can not leave my house because I am at high risk of getting Covid. So I feel so alone and kind of helpless since all this has started.
supporter: I can understand how that feels - I have not been able to go out for weeks either. Are you able to have visitors?

seeker: I am not allowed to be around anyone. I know its for my own health but that doesn't help when I am so lonely. It seems like I can not contribute to anyone or lend a hand to people. I am just stuck at home with a feeling of doom.
supporter: That is very rough. Have you considered joining internet communities so you can at least talk with people who are in the same situation?

seeker: I do not really know how to do that but it seems like a really good idea that I have never thought of before. Do you think it would help my mood?
supporter: I think it really could, yes. Isolation is a very difficult thing to deal with. Just knowing someone else understood could really help.

seeker: I like that idea. I hate feeling like I am a debbie downer type. I do not want to tell anyone how I feel. I am trapped in a few ways.
supporter: There is absolutely no problem with feeling bad and confiding in people. Many people are feeling the same right now.

supporter: So you feel as though life is just passing you by and you are not accomplishing anything during the lockdown?

seeker: Yes, exactly. That is precisely how I feel! It seems like I am in a movie with a sad ending and it just keeps repeating over and over.
supporter: Try to focus on the fact that it will be a new year soon - it surely can't (fingers crossed!) be worse than this one

supporter: Facebook is a great online site and there are lots of groups there for all interests

seeker: That is a really valid point and helping me see the bigger picture in life. I need to know it will not always be this way.
supporter: Please trust me that it will not. Time goes really slowly during a crisis, it seems

seeker: Thank you for your time and help today. I have not felt this good in a long time.
supporter: It feels great to be able to help people. I really wish you all the best in the coming weeks and months. Enjoy the rest of you day!

supporter: I hope you can find some like minded people there

seeker: Hi, how are you?
supporter: I good, how are you feeling?

supporter: So you think that COVID-19 has made you depressed? Could there be anything else that could be bothering you?

seeker: Possibly... I think the remote learning of my kids and the iability to leave the house or go out, is making me sadder than normal.
supporter: I completely understand where you are coming from there. I feel like remote learning takes away from some of the social aspects of life that need to happen in order for a healthy life.

seeker: I am also worried that I am not playing the political game well. I feel like I am too straight forward, not rude, but I should play politics more to get ahead.
supporter: I understand that as well. It seems that no matter how politically involved we are, things are always changing.

seeker: I agree. As I deal with more and more power, there seems to be more politics.
supporter: Sometimes some of the best things we can do is t get out and away from all the things that WE as people have created. Get into the woods and throw a ball around.

seeker: That would be nice. Is that what you do when you are stressed or depressed?
supporter: I understand, especially having the remote learning going on, it is hard to get away from work and school.

seeker: Yeah. How do you cope with your stresses? I find myself drinking more than I want now too.
supporter: I try to, I love packing a day back with some easy snacks, and going out for a hike through the woods. Sometimes I use the state trails but sometimes I just go out and make my own new trail.

seeker: That's fun. I try to get out once a month for a nice hike. We did the Indiana Dunes last month and that was good. With the snow coming, it might be more snow shoeing moving forward.
supporter: Well, drinking doesn't really deal with it. It only pushes things off for later to deal with. Exercising is a really good way to deal with that stress.

seeker: Yeah. I have not missed a workout since COVID-19 started. That seems to keep me grounded.
supporter: That's true! I used to live in Ohio, and the weather was amazing this time of year.

seeker: Yeah. In chicago, we have a lot of snow but also some good state trails. It's been helpful, especially when this first started. I live across the street from a forest preserve, which was a life saver.
supporter: Are you able to do more workouts? Sometimes I have found that running (which I hate doing) makes me feel so much better in times of high stress. Running also releases endorphins into the body which will help to alleviate some of the drinking/stress.

seeker: I am trying to do more. I work out daily and that isgood but I am trying yoga for the second workout.
supporter: Is there anything else I can help you with?

seeker: I'm feeling pretty awful... I've been down and depressed for months now. It's hard to get through the days.
supporter: I understand. Is this related to the pandemic or is it something separate? I am sure that the pandemic has not helped, though!

seeker: It's definitely related! I lost my dream job, went to a lower paying one, and I gained a lot of weight while working from home.
supporter: Oh I can certainly relate to that one! I've gained a stone and a half in the last year. All this sitting around is not good for us!

seeker: It's definitely nice to know that other people are having similar emotions as me.
supporter: Sometimes just having someone to talk to who knows how you are feeling can be really helpful I think.

seeker: It's sad that this year has been so awful. It's hard to convince myself that it's getting better any time soon..
supporter: Can you make a list of all the  things that you hope will be better next year so you can tick them off one by one?

seeker: 1. Better job 2. Healthier habits 3. Better financial situation
supporter: Well, the first and third one are out of your control really but you could make a start on the first one today if you liked :)

seeker: It's hard to take the first steps. I don't even know where to begin, sadly.
supporter: I can understand that. Perhaps you could join an exercise class or similar?

seeker: That's a pretty good idea. Have you ever done something like that?
supporter: I took an aerobics class once. It was quite fun and it was good exercise.

seeker: That does sound like fun. Do you have any other suggestions?
supporter: Well, it's maybe not the best time to be taking on a financial commitment but have you ever considered adopting a dog? Good company and good exercise

seeker: Actually, I have a cat!
supporter: Ah I have two - they are wonderful company. Alas you can't really walk with them though :)

seeker: They are great company. Sometimes when I am really feeling down, I remember that my cat needs me, so I need to stay strong.
supporter: Pets are great like that. Do you perhaps have a neighbour whose dog you could walk if you can't get one of your own?

seeker: That's a great idea. I just moved into a new apartment complex a couple weeks ago. Maybe I can get to know my neighbors. A lot of them have dogs.
supporter: It's a great way to make new friends too!

seeker: That's also a good idea. I know a lot of food banks around me are in need of volunteers.
supporter: I think it would be a really worthwhile thing to do and you would get to meet new people too

seeker: I agree. I feel like I have a bunch of new ideas to start feeling better. I appreciate you talking to me.
supporter: You are very welcome, it was my pleasure. Have a great day!

seeker: I'm fine oo
supporter: I'm doing well. Do you have anything you'd like to talk about?

supporter: Will this new job benefit you and your family more than the job you currently have?

seeker:
The job entails good cash, but I am anxious and worri
leaving my family over here, who will i go out with, when will I see my mother that I usually see seldom, what of my young ones that I need to monitor
supporter: I understand that changes like that can cause some anxious feelings.

seeker: all my families are in Washington, my mother, father, friends and siblings
supporter: Are you able to keep in contact with them through video calls if you move away?

seeker:
I have nobody 
 there, although the job entails big cash . Or I should forgo the job
supporter: Maybe you could discuss everything with your family and see how everyone else feels about it.

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hi there, how are you feeling today?

seeker: Quite bad. I tried to send some job applications but there are still no reply.
supporter: I hear you. It's been a terrible year all round for job seekers, given the global situation at the moment. I have been there myself.

seeker: Can you give me some advice on how to cope with this?  I honestly don't know what to do.
supporter: Well, firstly I think you need to accept that this is not your fault and that at the moment the world situation is beyond your control.

seeker:
I understand, but still,
 emotionally it is hard to cope.
supporter: Are you able to cope financially whilst you are out of work?

seeker: Not really, my savings are running out. I am doing some part-time freelance work but it won't pay all the bills.
supporter: I understand. I have been in the same situation and I know how frightening it is. Have you though of consulting agencies such as food banks that can help you temporarily?

seeker:
I haven't been to food banks yet. I can still deal with food on the table for now, but a couple more months without job then
 I might have to.
supporter: So you feel that you can at least manage for a few more weeks?

seeker: Financially yes. It is just that my emotion is getting worse and worse. Stress I guess.
supporter: I think it might be a good idea for you to consult your doctor? It sounds as though you might be suffering from depression.

seeker: I don't know. Psychologist appointments are very expensive in my country.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. I have had therapy but it is free in my country. Are there any charities that might offer a limited amount of counselling time?

seeker: I have not heard of charities that does that. If I am suicidal, may be, but I guess they are not dealing with stress from normal job seekers...
supporter: Would you be prepared to take on a job that is outside of  your normal field and income bracket, just temporarily?

seeker: I would. I work as an IT consultant before, but I would take any job for now.
supporter: I know that it is very difficult with so many businesses being forced to close. Would you be prepared to do delivery work, perhaps?

seeker: Do you mean like food delivery?  like UberEats?
supporter: Yes. Or most restaurants are offering take out services at the moment so there will be delivery services out there

seeker: I guess I could try that, not sure it pays well enough.
supporter: You are most welcome. I hope that things will pick up come the new year and you can get back to your regular profession! Just try to think of this as a stop gap

seeker: I hope so as well.  Thank you a lot for advice, I feel better just talking about it.
supporter: I am glad to have been of help .. enjoy the rest of your day!

seeker: You too, hope you have a good day.
supporter: You have to end it from your end .. I can't :)

seeker: I see, alright, see you then!
supporter: just hit quit and take the survey :)

seeker: I am having a really hard time in my life right now and need support.
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that. What is going on in your life?

seeker: I have been in a long term relationship and I found out that he was cheating on me. I have been so distraught and I broke up with him.
supporter: I see. That is certainly difficult. How often do you feel sad or blue over this situation?

seeker: Yes, feel sad and I cry or want to cry all the time. I feel like I should not have broken it off with him but I also can not be with someone that I do not trust. He has always been so good to me and so I was totally blind sided.
supporter: I think it is great that you stood up for yourself and broke up with him. That is something to be proud of.

seeker: I did not think of it like that. I did not know that I had anything to be proud of but I can sort of see what you mean. I wanted to get married to him but he never asked and we have been together for 5 years.
supporter: I am so sorry... Do you think a few years from now, after the pain of this situation has gotten easier to handle, you'll be happy with your decision to end the relationship? I know it can be hard to think so far in the future.

seeker: That is a good point because I have no been able to think about the future at all. I am thinking about what I could have had with him like children. I have wasted so much time and I really want kids.
supporter: Maybe something you can do is think about all this time in a more positive light. Instead of saying you wasted time, maybe you can think to yourself, "I am so glad that relationship taught me about myself and my standards." Does that sound good?

seeker: I also know that he never wanted kids so I have learned a lot about myself and what I want in life. I can think of myself and what my standards are. I have to be respected by the man i am with. I also need to feel appreciated and valued by the person that I am committed to.
supporter: That's such a great approach. Do you have hobbies and interests outside of your relationship that brought you joy? Maybe running, painting, or watching movies?

seeker: Yes, I love boating and have not been able to go enough because I was always wrapped up in drama with him. I also love painting and drawing. I have not thought of those hobbies in many years until right now.
supporter: Maybe you can take a day soon and go on a "date" with yourself. You can go out on the boat and have a fantastic, drama-free time. Does that sound like something you're interested in?

seeker: Thank you for all of your help today and nice encouraging words.
supporter: You are so welcome. I am glad to help you.

seeker: Yes, that sounds like a positive way to enjoy my time.
supporter: I think you're going to feel a lot better soon! I'm very happy for your future.

seeker: Thank you and hope to talk again very soon.
supporter: Me too.

supporter: Would it be possible to look at some more home made stuff for this year that will still be fun and meaningful?

seeker: I cannot craft. If I made them something it would be so bad.
supporter: I know it can be really hard to feel like you can't make anything worthwhile, but I'm sure theres something you could come up with that could still put a smile on your kids faces

seeker: Do you have any craft ideas?
supporter: Maybe you could look at involving your kids in the process. The feeling of doing something together as a family can make it way more fun. It could be a shared experience your family can look back on fondly later on.

seeker: That's a good idea. I would like to have it done before christmas. How about some wooden toys or a cardboard box fort?
supporter: I have seen some people make small ornaments filled with candies and treats and other small goodies. So even if all of the gifts feel small, they can feel like they are getting a lot of them. And you could even get them to have fun decorating and painting the ornaments!

seeker: I never that about filling an ornament with small stuff. That's a great idea.
supporter: When I was a kid, I loved making box forts, and its a great way to reuse stuff you might already have around the house. The fun pretend games you can play were a blast. I'm sure your kids might love it too!

seeker: I could paint and decorate it. My daughters would like that. I can make it look like a castle.
supporter: It can feel tough when it feels like you can't provide all the big gifts that you feel your kids deserve

seeker: I do. this has been very helpful. It's not all hopeless.
supporter: Last Christmas when I gave gifts to my family, one of them later told me that the gift they loved the most was the box of Christmas cookies that they were able to enjoy over the course of the week afterwards, and not the keyboard I had gotten them. Sometimes it doesn't take something expensive to be meaningful and make someone happy

seeker: That sounds wonderful. I'm getting to work on my projects. Thank you.
supporter: I'm really glad to hear that. It still might feel tough, but truly things are not hopeless

supporter: I'm not really doing any distance learning right now. Just working  from home and coincidentally most of my work uses excel. I have constant virtual meetings where I have to show people things via excel. It's pretty tough but I found if I use multiple monitors it makes things easier.

supporter: my second monitor is not portable. I don't know if that would work for me because I work better in one designated spot. So I have 3 monitors on my desk (2 separate monitors and my laptop screen). however something like That would definitely be something I'd look into if I was in school or taking classes

seeker: I enjoy portability and minimalism to a fault sometimes. I enjoy being able to work from anywhere.
supporter: I think that's a good call! Do you think you can find a deal somewhere on it?

seeker: I have zoomed with people but that is not great. Have you done anything to help?
supporter: I have also done that as well, though I do miss the human to human connection. I have learn how to knit, hot make bread ( yes! bread lol), and got out of my comfort zone and watched different genres of movies along with books. I am a creature of habit with set routine, I really tried to get out of my bubble as much as I can. Keeping my mind busy makes the days go by faster. have you tried to do something new and challenging?

seeker: I saw that bread trend earlier in the pandemic. How did you do?
supporter: well I can tell you, the first 3 times I tried to make 'regular bread' it was a disaster. my bread came out hard as a rock. I kept working at it. You are truly involved when making bread. Cool! I did not know it was a trend? look at me I am a trendsetter, lol. YES! I recommend that wholeheartedly, Ive walked and done more sight seeing during this pandemic than my entire life. Do you have scenic place to go? Do you like to read?

seeker: I do not have a scenic place but have some nice trails. I do read. I am reading bob iger's new autobiography.
supporter: Trails, offer an experience of letting go, I believe, you become immerse in nature. I would definitely explore all trails.  I did not know Iger had a book out. That sounds really interesting, I would actually love to read it, is it dull? or engaging? I do remember the headlines, he forgo his salary despite the risk of Disney losing billions in revenue, that takes guts. Do you have a pet?

seeker: His book is good. Do you enjoy reading to help relax?
supporter: I need to pick it up and dive into it. I love reading, I always tend to have a book in my hands. Yes, reading has served to not only help me relax but to teach me how to do other things, like baking. what is your favorite book?

seeker: I love the Harry Potter book series. I picked up Sorcerer's Stone when I was 21 or 22 and it provided me with some alternative to the normal drinking and late nights I had grown accustom to. Helped me apprecate books more too!
supporter: Harry potter are THE books to dive into and just immerse yourself in. I would Highly recommend The Hobbit books, I was a bit hesitant about, but dare I say I like them more than Harry Potter? If you want something more adult and edgy go with Game of Thrones. I get it, I think this pandemic is a period to learn about ourselves and truly pick ourselves apart and see what we have missing out on.

seeker: My board is going around me to my staff and I am frustrated.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Would you like to tell me more?

supporter: I could understand how that could make you very angry, I would be too.

seeker: Have you ever ran into something like that before?
supporter: I have not, it sounds like a very bad situation. Is there anyone you can report this to at the company?

supporter: It sounds like you are working in a toxic work environment with poor leadership. Have you considered possibly seeking another job? Or maybe another company?

seeker: Not really. This just started happening last week. I'm still trying to get a better idea on how to deal with this.
supporter: I understand. What do you think about having a conversation with the board and let them know the issues you are having? You could have your coworker back you up.

seeker: I think that is how I am going to respond. I am also hearing this from my staff, which may be part of the problem. I am trying not to let my ego get involved but it is hard.
supporter: It sounds like you take a lot of pride in your job which is very amiable. I think confronting the board is the best way to go about this.

seeker: I am worried that I will not be received well. Should I be?
supporter: It's very possible, but I think you will be commended amongst your peers. You owe it to yourself not to be walked all over.

seeker: That's true... I need that at least.
supporter: And who knows maybe the board will appreciate you coming to them, it shows great strength.

supporter: One thing that worked well for me was speaking to members of the board.

seeker: I feel like they would either blow me off or feel resentment for bringing it to their attention. Did you run into that?

supporter: My husband and I have gone a few times and it really helped having an objective person give us a few tips. We learned a lot even in just a few short months. We set goals, achieved them and then years passed and went again.

seeker: I am happy it worked for you :) I just dont see it working with us. Hes pretty stubborn. I also struggle with a severe auto immune disorder so that is always weighing on me as well
supporter: I had an auto immune disorder too, actually, the counseling helped that a lot. Emotions have a way of wreaking havoc on our bodies. And it sounds like life has been stressful for you lately.

seeker: Yes, stress is terrible for chronic illness. I had goals to get back in check with myself, I've been worried about everyone else for so long and not really about me. The pandemic haulted a lot of that. I used to take rides and go out and enjoy nature or something simple by myself to rejuvinate but it's harder now being worried to be around people. I also have an 8 and 1 year old. While they are my world, it's taxing having littles depend on you 24/7 without a breather :)
supporter: It sounds like you have a full plate with the little one. I know a lot of people are fearful now, but rest assured, children are really resilient to disease. The CDC has not even one record of a healthy child dying. Can you still go to the park and let them run and play? I think it's healthier to be around people then to isolate. That's my personal observation. It's really taking a toll on all of us emotionally to be distant.

seeker: For a few months I eased up and let them play at the park, but we live in MI which is having another huge spike, especially our county. Thank goodness we have a pretty large yard for them to run and play in but I also know its not the same
supporter: One thing that comes to mind about your marriage is how I continued to work on myself, and surprisingly, some of the changes I made in myself helped my husband change. For example. I realized I didn't speak respectfully to him all the time.  So I changed my tone. Sometimes I didn't FEEL respectful, but I read this book explaining how men really need that. So I changed me. And you know what, he really responded well to that. Became more kind and loving. I prayed a lot and that is one thing God showed me. I read a few books on what men were like and how I could help my marriage. My husband often oblivious, but when I worked on me and doing things that men like, he actually became a better man. Hard to explain.

seeker: It makes total sense. I have tried to do some research and yes work on myself as well. I have done a ton of praying. I do need to make new goals. They help me stay on track, thats for sure.
supporter: It sounds like you do know good things to do, and that sometimes you need that encouragement and and support. Do you have friends maybe to check in with? Just to chat. I have been doing that myself. Just phoning people to connect. It has helped so much. Just to say hi and share my life.

seeker: I need to do that more! When my maternal grandma passed away in 2013 I kind of fell away from just calling people up. She was my go to person to call, always. She and my grandpa raised me and its been hard to pick up a phone knowing I cannot call her. Sounds weird I know
supporter: It is NOT weird. I'm like a granma to you! hahaha I'm almost 60. We need people in our lives, older, younger, all ages. We all learn from each other. Perhaps call and aunt and check in with them. Sometimes it makes us feel better to reach out and encourage others.

seeker: I will try to do this more, for sure! Thank you for this conversation, I feel like it has helped me remember the things I can do to start working on myself again!
supporter: As for your son and homeschooling, I'm sure you are challenged but think of this as a great opportunity. Perhaps teach him to cook? Make games up that are learning games about how to care for a home, perhaps repair things, all kinds of ideas. Perhaps have him test you on things.

seeker: Sounds like a plan for sure :) I will do this, he would really enjoy it!
supporter: I'm glad I could encourage you. You sound very intelligent and caring. Marriage is hard work, so is motherhood, but it can be rewarding and fulfilling. Sometimes we lose track of that and we need ideas to perk us up again and help us remember our goals.

supporter: I feel that people have the right to know what is being done and will be happy you told them.

seeker: I agree and I think you're right. I appreciate you chatting with me about this
supporter: You are very welcome. I hope I have been able to be of some help to you and you will continue to talk to other people about it.

seeker: Hello how are you?
supporter: i am good thank you how are you doing?

seeker: I'm ok
supporter: what seems to be making it hard to communicate with him?

seeker: Every time we talk about anything we get into an argument it feels like that anyway
supporter: how long has this been going on?

seeker: We never fight over anything big its always so stupid. Its always someone being rude or their tone wasnt right. But i feel put down and unheard.
supporter: i can understand how you are feeling

seeker: yes
supporter: Communication is key in a marriage without that the marriage will start to fail and I do not want to see that happen

seeker: We always agree and nothing ever changes
supporter: you two need to sit down and have a serious discussion about the way your marriage is going

seeker: You're right. I'll do that.
supporter: have you two ever considered seeing a marriage counselor?
