supporter: The only way you two can work it out is by communicating that is the main thing to do in a situation like that.

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi how are you?

seeker: Im not doing very well at all.
supporter: What's going on?

seeker: I am very stressed out with my work.
supporter: I know the feeling. what do you do for work?

seeker: I am a lab assistant.
supporter: how long have you been in your role? and do you have any coworkers that feel similar to you that you know about?

seeker: I have been in this role for about a year. I am the only one at this level. I take care of a lot of the productivity and logistical work. Im just really stressed recently
supporter: Somewhat similarly I'm in a supply chain role, for a year now, and the only one at my level too. I often feel like I'm alone in my job and that I manage my boss... It's pretty frustrating.

seeker: I think that being able to have a better work life balance would help but I have a hard time talking to my boss.
supporter: do you think your boss would be receptive if you did talk to them? or would they dismiss your concerns?

seeker: I am unsure. They are very much all about work. I am afraid they wont see my point and understand my want for a better work life balance.
supporter: This has been a pretty hard year for everyone. however you ultimately gotta do whats best for you.

seeker: I have but it is hard to find a job at this time. I also really like what I do but wish I could have more balance. Do you have any advice for how to balance stress at work and your life outside of work?
supporter: I'm in the same boat. I would say, the things that work best for me, are to take breaks during my work day and go for walks or as soon as I'm done with work I force myself to go for a walk. I find moving helps me feel better. I also use that time to think about how I can look for a new job or rethink the things that are bothering me

seeker: I think I could try that. I have a hard time detaching from work especially working from home. I feel like I never really 'leave' the office. I am always working even when I normally wouldnt be.
supporter: Change the scenery, it'll help! plus movement releases endorphins which make you feel better.

seeker: Thank you! I will try that.
supporter: no problem!

seeker: Yes, I am feeling very anxious about my school work lately.
supporter: I see, so your main worry is about academic pressure?

seeker: Yes, I am focusing on my grades and the pressure I feel from my mom.
supporter: Have you been performing below your normal standard this year?

seeker: she wants me to get all A's. I feel she has too high of expectations sometimes, which makes me feel like I need to perfect my assignments and spend all this time on them.
supporter: I hear you, I have been in a similar situation. Parents sometimes do not realise just how much pressure they are putting on their children to be perfect.

seeker: I feel like as long as I am meeting the requirements and am passing, she should be proud of my accomplishments.
supporter: Exactly! there is nothing at all wrong with not being a straight A student.

seeker: Exactly. I feel like there is this society stereotype of needing straight A's otherwise you are a failure or something.
supporter: Absolutely not. There is nothing wrong with not being perfect. And she has no right to emotionally manipulate you by mentioning money.

seeker: I agree, but she does have money over my head, which sucks.
supporter: Are there any scholarships or hardship funds that you could potentially look into applying for?

seeker: Yes, I have received multiple scholarships, but nothing that will make a dent in the tuition.
supporter: Ah, it is very expensive isn't it? I understand, I am still paying off my loans! But it should be worth it in the end. One day you could get a job working for Amazon!

seeker: That's what I keep telling myself, but I have this overarching fear that I will be in debt forever then.
supporter: Debt is a very scary thing to experience, I know. I do worry a lot about it sometimes too so you are not alone.

seeker: That makes me feel better.
supporter: The main thing is, do you enjoy your studies and consider them worthwhile?

seeker: yes, somewhat, but who loves school?
supporter: I really did enjoy University .. I made a lot of friends and it was a good learning experience. I hope you feel a bit the same?

seeker: S
supporter: I think that you need to be easier on yourself. Do you have many friends?

seeker: some
supporter: Are you able to confide in your friends about your situation and your worries?

seeker: Yes at times, which makes things a little better in the moment.
supporter: Do you feel that your friends are able to empathise with your situation? Are any of them going through the same thing?

seeker: they all have more independence and pay for their own things, so they can't really relate to me. That is where I feel behind in life than everyone else.
supporter: Would it be possible for you to get a part time job of some description? Maybe bar tending or working in a restaurant?

seeker: That gives me social anxiety, which is something I also struggle with greatly.
supporter: Ah I suffer from terrible social anxiety myself so I hear you

seeker: covid has made the New York job market terrible
supporter: Hello

seeker: hi
supporter: Are you currently looking for a job?

seeker: Partially but it's tough as fear of getting infected as well
supporter: So just to clarify, you are having issues with the job market and fear of getting infected by COVID and it is making you anxious.

seeker: oh yes that's it exactly
supporter: I understand this completely, as I have been working in grocery stores since the pandemic began so it has made me very anxious about contracting the disease.

seeker: And next year I think will be like now. I thought the worse was over but it's not. It feels like March job market wise.
supporter: Just from these few messages I can tell you are very anxious about this

seeker: Yes and the news shows recent weeks cases of Covid going up again. That's very upsetting.
supporter: I have also been very worried about the rise in cases.

seeker: I don't trust the vaccine either, do you?
supporter: Honestly, I am worried about the vaccine as well. I would like to see the side affects before I take it,

seeker: The same or long term studies. They skipped animal testing. All red flags to me. what if it screws us all up taking it?
supporter: If those online gigs are enough to make ends meet currently, I would continue to work those and wait until the pandemic situation improves and then go look into the job market.

seeker: Hello. I’m hoping you can help me as I’m having a hard time recharging. I can’t seem to take a day off without working,
supporter: So you feel that you need to be able to relax and unwind once in a while but you can't?

seeker: I also seem then have trouble doing family time with my job demands.
supporter: Ah that can be a problem. Is this causing problems or tensions within your relationships?

seeker: A little I feel stressed all the time.
supporter: I have experienced something similar. I found myself getting short tempered and taking things out on my loved ones.

seeker: Yes exactly
supporter: Have you considered any kind of counselling to talk through these feelings? There are some organisations around that will offer help for free

seeker: I don’t have time for thst
supporter: I hear you saying that you are putting your work ahead of everything else in your life, is that correct?

seeker: Yes I do think with my partner would help.
supporter: Nonetheless, there is no need to make it the entire focus of your life, especially if it is impacting on other aspects of it.

seeker: Yes but I guess I’m trying to find that balance and struggling
supporter: Do you feel that you have to hit unrealistic goals and meet unrealistic expectations?

seeker: Oh yes all the timr
supporter: I personally sometimes find it difficult not to be too hard on myself. Sometimes I have to remind myself to relax and have fun once in a while.

seeker: Yes I would agree with you there. It feels harder to escape and have a fun night right now
supporter: It has been a very hard year for everyone, I know and I sympathise. Can you think of one specific thing you'd really like to do that might cheer you up?

seeker: Get together with friends and explore a new restaurant
supporter: That sounds like a really fun thing to do! Can you plan one evening soon where you and  your friends will do this and you will promise yourself that you won't cancel in favour of work?

seeker: The issue is I can’t with covid
supporter: Ah yes that is a big problem. Are restaurants closed where you are?

seeker: I like that idea but it’s 30 here. Maybe something like that or a walk with some spiked drinks
supporter: I think that the important thing is to get out of the office and have some human contact. I do agree that it's a really miserable time of year for it though

seeker: Yes. Human contact and ideally in person would so help
supporter: I hope I have been able to give you a little perspective on your problems! Is there something else you'd like to talk to me about today?

seeker: I think you have helped step back. Sometimes when you are in the middle of it you can’t find a way out.
supporter: That is very true. Try and remember that there is light at the end of the tunnel.

seeker: Thank you. You too. I guess I should go try to be present with my family.
supporter: Yes :)

seeker: I am sad
supporter: I am really sorry to hear that. Is there anything you'd like to talk about?

seeker: I am really embarased that I am now getting food from food banks
supporter: I see .. so you feel that you are not able to support yourself or your family and this makes you ashamed?

seeker: yes, and the looks that people give me now hurt
supporter: I know how you feel, I have been forced to use food banks during the pandemic too. You should not feel ashamed!

seeker: thank you, but it seems like a slow slippery slope if I am not careful
supporter: What is your employment situation at the moment? Do you work in an essential worker capacity?

seeker: I have no job thus no money for food
supporter: I am very sorry. Have you visited any other agencies that might be able to offer some form of help? There are several

seeker: really can you list some other resourcs
supporter: Well there is the Citizen's Advice Bureau. They have helped me a couple of times when I was at a low point.

seeker: thanks anything else
supporter: They will be able to give you a list of other places that can help. I suggest you book an appointment with them tomorrow.

seeker: ok thank you I kind of feel better
supporter: Do you have people in your life who are being supportive? A partner, friends?

seeker: I have no one so it is nice to connect with someone thanks
supporter: I know it's hard but do try to remember that there are lots of other people in the same situation. It's a very difficult time for the whole world.

seeker: yes you are very understanding
supporter: Are you trying to find work right now?

seeker: I am but every is in lockdown so it is hard
supporter: would you be prepared to lower your expectations and perhaps take a different kind of work than you used to?

seeker: I am at the lowest expectation level already.
supporter: Well on the plus side then the only way you can go is up :)

seeker: that's the best way to think thanks
supporter: Let's hope that next year will bring better times for all of us.

seeker: stay safe
supporter: And you too thanks for talking!

seeker: Hello, I'm just having a tough couple of weeks in my marriage.
supporter: What seems to be going on in your marriage?

seeker: our main problem is communication. We cant talk about anything without one of us getting mad. Its become a habit
supporter: I can understand how you are feeling marriage is hard for some.

seeker: I need to find some free workshops or something. I think we would both be uncomfortable with therapy. I have looked but cant find any good cheap options.
supporter: Communication is key in a marriage

seeker: I think we are both willing to end it if we cant get along but both want to fix it but dont know where to start. We have lived together for 6 years but only recently gotten married.
supporter: do not let this get the best of you. there are ups and downs in marriage but you have to be able to work through all that with your partner.

seeker: My parents are going through a divorce right now. They were together for 25 years.. my dad has been my step dad since I was two. She went to rehab and they were planning to renew their vows when she got out. She left him for a guy she met in rehab.
supporter: I know you will two will be able to work through this together

seeker: Thanks
supporter: I am sorry to hear and i understand how you are feeling my parents recently got a divorce

seeker: Yeah i think its bothering me more than I realized.
supporter: i can understand but you know you just have to move on with life and not let that get in the way especially your marriage

seeker: youre right
supporter: when there is no communication then that is when the trouble starts and the marriage starts failing

seeker: We have. We cant talk about whats for dinner without an argument these days.
supporter: find the right time to talk to your partner and just explain to your feelings towards what is going on and let your partner know you do not like what is going on

seeker: You're right. Thanks for the advice.
supporter: if that does not help try to seek help from a marriage counselor i have heard they have saved many marriages from failing

seeker: Ok I will. Thank you.
supporter: Your welcome

seeker: hi there
supporter: Hello! How are you doing?

seeker: I'm not doing so good at the moment. I'm feeling very stressed and burned out from work
supporter: That sounds very frustrating. Is this a recent development at your job?

seeker: It's been building up for a while now, but it's really starting to get a but overwhelming
supporter: I can understand how that can have an effect on your mental well-being. Have you spoken to your supervisor about your frustrations at work?

seeker: I have, but sometimes I feel like she doesn't really listen and she sort of talks over me a lot
supporter: It sounds like you don't feel listened to.

seeker: That's right... I guess that is quite a lot of the problem.
supporter: I had a similar issue at my last job. My supervisor constantly spoke over me in meetings, and it would drive me crazy. I never could get a word in edge-wise.

seeker: Yeah, that sounds a lot like what I am experiencing
supporter: Are you considering switching jobs?

seeker: It's been in the back of my mind, but it's a hard time just now with everything else going on
supporter: Absolutely. It's a rough time job searching under the best of circumstances.

seeker: It is.
supporter: Have you tried reaching out to anyone in your network to look for a new position? It helped me when I was previously job searching.

seeker: I haven't, but it might be worth getting in touch with some people
supporter: Absolutely. I also spoke with a therapist before and it helped me a lot.

seeker: I did consider that, but aren't they expensive?
supporter: They can be, but many local governments and municipalities have therapists that work on a sliding scale if the financial aspect of therapy is a concern.

seeker: It might be worth it in the long run though I guess, if it helps how I am feeling
supporter: If it helps to reframe the expense, you can try to think of it as an investment in your mental health.

seeker: Yes, that sounds like a more positive way of thinking of it
supporter: The therapist could likely give you some tools to help manage the frustrations at your workplace more constructively.

seeker: Yes, I imagine they will have come across this before so will be able to help
supporter: Absolutely. I hope that you're able to find some peace at your workplace with your boss.

seeker: Thank you, you have helped a lot
supporter: It's my pleasure. I'm happy to have helped you.

seeker: As my coworker and I start to fill her role, I am worried I am not getting all of the information that I need.
supporter: I'm sorry. I know how anxious I would feel if I thought I wasn't getting the necessary training to do a job well.

seeker: Not yet. They hadn't talked with us prior today. I am worried I do not have a lot of time and I do not want to seem overanxious.
supporter: I completely understand how you are feeling. I think that being proactive with management and letting them know your concerns in a positive way could emphasize that you take your job seriously and want to excel.

seeker: Thanks. You don't think it seems needy? Or like I'm telling them what to do?
supporter: New jobs and roles are always cause for anxiety. Just being concerned shows what a good employee you are. I think they are lucky to have you!

seeker: Thanks, that means a lot. Should I email them my concerns or is this a face-to-face meeting?
supporter: Honestly, I from my own experience, which doesn't include management, I think it's all about the approach. As long as you are not negative and don't sound like you are complaining or telling them how to do their jobs you should be fine!

seeker: Thank you. I will talk with them tomorrow, or if they call me today.
supporter: I would start with an email. This is just my opinion, but with how busy they must be getting people up to speed with training, an email is always a great place to start.

seeker: Thanks. I don't want to seem passive aggresssive, and I care about how I am perceived so that is a good idea.
supporter: Have confidence in yourself as well! Chances are, others are struggling too.

seeker: Thank you. I have tried to talk with others in the district to see how they are doing and most are ok.
supporter: Again, at the risk of being repetitive, it's all about the tone! I recently underwent group training. It was online since we are all working virtually. There were a couple of "whiners and know-it-alls" and you could tell from the start. You don't seem that way at all!

seeker: Thank you. I try to be part of a larger team and I hope they can see that. I just want to do what is best for the organization.
supporter: Good luck! I'm certainly not an expert, but honestly wanting to perform your job well is a positive trait and the sign of a leader. Focus on yourself! You sound like someone that any good manager would want on their team.

seeker: Thanks. I hope they see it that way! Your adviec was really appreciated.
supporter: I wish you the best of luck with the rest of training! You are going to do great!

seeker: Thank you. Anything else I should know?
supporter: I think you are doing everything you need to do. Can I help you with any other questions or is there anything else you'd like to talk about?

seeker: No, thanks for your help!
supporter: Keep up the great work! Good luck, and start with a short email. That's my advice anyways, but do what feels right. Have a great night!

seeker: Hi. My supervisor recently resigned and she reports to a board. I want her job but I am fearful the board does not see me as a viable option to replace her.
supporter: Just so I understand, your supervisor recently quit and you'd like to apply for her job but you're worried you won't be accepted?

seeker: Yes. I have only been with this orgnization for about 2 years and I want to position myself as a viable candidate without seeming needy or desperate.
supporter: I'm sure they won't see you as needy or desperate if you've been with the company for 2 years already. Have you initiated the conversation with the board already?

seeker: No. This just happened last week so I am trying to keep all of the balls in the air. I was thinking about talking with them Wednesday this week. They are meeting on Thursday.
supporter: That is a good idea. I would go over your resume and spruce it up before talking to them on Wednesday to add in anything pertinent that you might have learned or achieved during your time with the company these last two years. Make sure the day you approach them that you're well rested, clean and put together. Google some confidence stances and pay attention to your posture. Even if you're feeling nervous there are ways to hide it and appear confident.

seeker: Wow, that's really good advice. Thanks. I didn't think about updating my resume, and I really should have thought about it.
supporter: No problem, I hope it helps.

seeker: Should I talk with my coworker about it? He does not want that job.
supporter: If you feel that he might be able to provide more advice then sure.

seeker: I just don't want him to think I am trying to weasle my way in.
supporter: If he isn't interested in the job himself I'm sure he wouldn't see it that way. It is natural for people to try to move up in a company when a job opening appears, especially in these current times. If you don't go for it then someone else will.

seeker: He does not want it. I was hoping I at least his support. He does support me. And thanks. I appreciate the insight.
supporter: Having support in the workplace would be very helpful. If he truly does not want the job himself perhaps you could approach him about a memo or something that would back you? Something you can add to your resume from a peer that shows your initiative.

seeker: That would be a good idea. I was also thinking about talking with HR about it. We're a small company so that is only 1 person.
supporter: That could benefit you as well.

seeker: I was also going to talk with everyone in her office, which is only 2 people. I am worried about gossip though.
supporter: Unless you're known for doing bad things in the office I wouldn't sweat the gossip honestly. People are either going to support you or be jealous, either way I wouldn't let the talk get to you.

seeker: I think so. I am not a gossip nor do I want to. Thanks for your help! Any other thoughts?
supporter: I would say maybe try some meditation or something to calm and center yourself. If you feel ready earlier than Wednesday then follow your intuition. You've got this!

seeker: Thanks! I appreciate your help!
supporter: It was my pleasure

seeker: I am worried that my Director played a game she was not able to play, got caught, and was forced to resign. I am not sure what that means for me. Any help would be appreciated.
supporter: Can you explain to me what exactly kind of game it was?

seeker: It was a political game where she isolated the president and made him no longer support her. It was quite a misstep on her part.
supporter: ok so your director played a game she was not allowed to play and she got caught playing it and quit her job is that correct?

seeker: Yes. She got put on a performance improvement plan and responded poorly. She was forcced to resign.
supporter: So you are scared that you might get in trouble?

seeker: Not in trouble but vulnerable because she hired me. Will her boss see me as part of the problem?
supporter: I am so sorry you are going through this and i know how you are feeling

seeker: Thanks. It's been weird. I just met with two of the board today to go over where the organization is.
supporter: you should not have anything to worry about as long as you did not play the game then you will be fine and you will not get in trouble or your boss will not see that as a problem.

seeker: Thanks. I tried to just support her privately and seem neutral publicly. I did like her too. I thought she was good.
supporter: I would just suggest you to have no contact with her right now until all this passes

seeker: I text her to see how she was doing but haven't text with her since Friday. Any other ideas?
supporter: I would also have a talk with your boss about the situation and let him know how you are feeling

seeker: I also want her job. Does that seem weird to talk with him about that too?
supporter: Did you see your director playing the game?

seeker: No, her boss did not play the game. He actually pulled out and let others handle it so he didn't seem biased. She overplayed her hand.
supporter: I can see this is a tough being in a situation like this

seeker: Yeah. I have never been this high in an organization so I just don't know what to do. I am hoping someone outside the organization might have a better view of what I should do.
supporter: As long as you did nothing wrong then i am sure you will be just fine

seeker: Thanks. Your help is appreciated.
supporter: do not let the situation get the best of you everything will be just fine

seeker: Thanks.
supporter: your welcome

seeker: I could be better. How about U?
supporter: I am doing well. Whats bothering you?

seeker: A friend screwed me out of money and a business venture. I am no longer friends with her. We were really close before this.
supporter: Oh no! I am so sorry that has happened to you. That must feel like such a betrayal.

seeker: It does. I've known her for 14 years and we dated.
supporter: Dating can definitely complicate things.. Oh my gosh..... that is horrible. Surely there is something you can do to try to get your money back.

seeker: What do you suggest?
supporter: Did you sign anything? or have proof of what happened?

seeker: No. Other than the money I transferred to her.
supporter: What was the business? It depends on your location but I'm sure just on the transaction alone that shows some kind of intent. or text messages saying it was for a specific purpose?

seeker: A cat cafe. Where you can hang out and work or drink with adoptable cats from the local shelter.
supporter: If you gave her a large amount of money and have any kind of messages about it I would look into trying to get it back.

seeker: I gave her 80K. No messages. It was all done in person. Do you think I should get a lawyer and call the cops?
supporter: I would seek the advice of a lawyer. I'm sorry this has happened thats horrible.

seeker: It is. I don't want to go to the police. I think they are all corrupt and raciest.
supporter: I would say 80K is worth speaking to a lawyer about it. I'm sorry you are so conflicted. I would not call the police because you willingly gave it to her. I would hire a lawyer to handle it.

seeker: That's great advice. I will do that. I have a mutual friend that is a lawyer.
supporter: I would not talk to a mutual friend about this at all....

seeker: The season has me down.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Are you finding time to do things you enjoy by yourself? Any hobbies?

seeker: trying to work and write but lack motivation
supporter: It sounds like you are feeling some lethargy in this cold season, and feel as though you have no support from your family.

seeker: I don't talk to anyone
supporter: Do you have any plans to spend Christmas with family or friends? That may help to break the cycle of feeling low?

seeker: I live in a hotel currently
supporter: What do you do for work? Are you able to get out of the hotel frequently?

seeker: I am a writer. Witht he virus it is hard to meet anyone
supporter: I agree, it is hard to spend time with people at the moment. We are all finding ourselves spending a lot more time alone than we are used to.

seeker: I try the dating sites, but they seem to far away or impersonal
supporter: Yes, I can see that. Keep in touch with your family and try to think of positive, happy times you can all have together in the future.

seeker: No verbal communication makes it hard
supporter: Can you call them?

seeker: I try but the loneliness is the hard part
supporter: It sounds like this loneliness is really getting to you and you are struggling to see a way forwards.

seeker: It is just the lack of communication
supporter: I hear you.

seeker: without any communication it makes it seem like a battle alone
supporter: Maybe schedule in a call with her for the future? I have been making time to speak with my family every Tuesday, it gives us something to look forward to each week

seeker: Children can only share so much
supporter: What are your plans in Virginia?

seeker: Find a place to live for awhile
supporter: Well that sounds as though it will give you something to focus on.

seeker: I just want a person to chat with that we can share with each other
supporter: Perhaps once you get to Virginia you could seek out some groups or activities to find some new friends.

seeker: Unfortunately the virus stopping people.
supporter: It is very hard at the moment. But things will improve, keep communication with your family for now and when the time is right in Virginia you can start to look for new friends to spend time with in your new home.

seeker: Ok well thanks for the chat. I will let you go.
supporter: Keep your head up, these sad days will pass

seeker: hello
supporter: Hi! How's it going today?

seeker: am somewhat fine
supporter: That doesn't sound super positive?

seeker: so my almost supposedly wife ran out on me on our wedding
supporter: What's going on? What made her do this?

seeker: so now am back in our apartment reminiscing all the times we had. that's my question too, I don't know why she left
supporter: Not knowing why must be hard, this sounds like it was more of her problem than yours. That's a terrible thing to do to you.

seeker: i don't know what to do, should i call her or just wait till she is ready to explain
supporter: I think she definitely owes you an explanation for what she's done. That was the worst way for her to do that.

seeker: should i move places because this place has too many memories, should i burn her things or send them to her family
supporter: Time will help with some of that. Once you're able to make new memories in your apartment it won't be so unbearable. But maybe her hurting you this way means you don't need that explanation because she simply wasn't right for you.

seeker: and she couldn't say no when i proposed or any day before the wedding
supporter: As much as it hurts, it sounds like you're better off without her.

seeker: easier said but i guess so. i just want this year to end now.
supporter: Unfortunately this year has been less than ideal in more ways than one.

seeker: i know,  what a year. i just thought this will make this year atleast better after everything
supporter: I can understand, it was something to finally look forward to. Unfortunately, everyone is dealing with all of these emotions differently and it was just too much for her.

seeker: exactly
supporter: Right, but it is worth talking to someone. I always feel guilty until I finally start talking and then it ends up being a support system between both parties. Not just me dumping my problems on someone else.

seeker: you are probably right. Thanks this was actually helpful

I drove myself insane with worry, suspicion. I wanted someone to treasure me, not cheat and lie. Cheaters don't change their spots.

seeker: Basic story, got back to the United States from deployment.
supporter: Ah, so you were overseas and were conducting the relationship long distance?

seeker: She kept me going while I was gone, but since I returned, she's been so cold to me
supporter: Do you feel that is unfair of her to have done this whilst you were away serving your country?

seeker: Kind of, I know that life moves on while people are away
supporter: But she should have understood that you were doing your duty whilst also providing for the pair of you

seeker: Possibly, but we weren't official boyfriend/girlfriend
supporter: Ah I see. How committed did you feel to her?

seeker: Maybe it was my indecision to ask her about our relationship
supporter: I know, as a woman myself. that it is quite difficult when you are seeing someone but have no idea what their intentions are.

seeker: Sure, I guess sex and cuddling is nice, but what I really want is someone to shopping with and eventually build a future
supporter: Have you considered getting some sort of counselling, either just you or as a couple?

seeker: It has peaked my interest, but at the same time, I wonder how much of this is just me buried in the idea of a relationship, even though it's pretty one-sided now
supporter: I am hearing you say that you still have feelings for her but you are not sure whether to totally break away or not, given that she has

seeker: Yes. I hate how I love her, but I'm not getting the same energy back
supporter: I can't tell you what to do but I think it might be best to go with your gut instinct.

seeker: It will hurt, but it's definitely better just to move on, right?
supporter: It has to be your decision but I think you will know if you've made the right one.

seeker: I really appreciate it.
supporter: I hope that I have been able to give you some good advice and that you feel a little clearer about things now.

seeker: Yes, this has helped tremendously
supporter: Thank you for that .. I am glad to have been on assistance. I wish you all the very best in your future, wherever it takes you.

seeker: I appreciate all of your feedback too. It has helped put my mind to rest.
supporter: Thank you and best wishes!

seeker: You too! Take care!
supporter: I have to stay here but feel free to show yourself out :)

seeker: I've been better. I just buried my dog yesterday
supporter: Ouch! I'm so sorry to hear that. I never lost a dog, but I've lost cats.

seeker: Actually, yes. She was old and had dementia.
supporter: I'm so sorry, losing a pet is very hard on us.

seeker: How did your dog come with the house?
supporter: Was that your only pet? Or do you have others? We moved from FL to KY and the little dog just hung out here, he really belonged to the neighbor's son who didn't want him, so he just ran around wild and wouldn't leave. I never had a dog, but it got cold, so i took him in. They never asked about him and after a week, I asked them if I could have the dog, so they said yes. I don't think they cared.

seeker: I have 2 other dogs that are mine and my boyfriend has 2
supporter: So you definitely are a dog lover! I was in my 50s before I ever had a dog, now I wish I had more, they are really loving. Not like cats who don't care much about much except FOOD! lol

seeker: They get to be so close and you can really pick up on their emotions and stuff. That's what happens to me. I get stuck sometimes
supporter: I get stuck too. But you are doing the right things, here you reached out to someone and I do care, so you are moving forward.

seeker: Thanks. Another person who has pets helps
supporter: I do understand. My mom died in 2010, right after she died, 1 of my cats died, my husband went into the hospital and almost died, so we went on vacation so I would not be consumed with grief, and do you know, we brought our pets and our cat died when we arrived here on vacation?  I will never forget that. You know what. I knew I could either get consumed in grief, or push through. Man, that was hard. I prayed a lot and God got me through that and I had a good vacation, all things considered.

seeker: Oh wow, that sounds horrible. Pushing through though I guess is all one can do then. Thank you so much. I believe in prayer.
supporter: Prayer is what gets me through every day!  :D  It was rough, but I believe these hard times strengthen us in some way. Because life throws hard balls, and we have to move forward or be consumed.

seeker: That's true. I'm glad I did this project. You really helped me.
supporter: I'm so glad I did too. It was a pleasure to meet you. And once again, (hug). :D

seeker: You too. Thanks so much. bye
supporter: I have one more thing to say - wise words from this 92 year old lady at church named Sue. She told me this after my brother died. When you get older, everyone you know is practically dead.  She said "Life is for the living, if you get caught up to much in all the death, you won't life."  True words. God bless, have a good night.

seeker: I dislike my job but am unsure about trying online jobs that may not be what I want
supporter: So you are feeling unsatisfied in your work but you are not sure how to change ?

seeker: yes but more so not wanting to change due to uncertainty regarding what I may be walking into
supporter: I have been in this same position! Sometimes you have to take a leap, even though you are not sure what might happen. So far everything has worked out fine for me.

seeker: That's true. I just don't want to lose the benefits that I am currently entitled to at my current bad job
supporter: It is a tricky situation, to be sure. Have you talked to anyone else about it?

seeker: yes my wife, and she is supportive either way so that's not a problem
supporter: I am glad to hear that you have someone supportive in your life. What is your current line of work?

seeker: e-commerce manager for walmart stores inc
supporter: Would you like a total change? Or just a change of scenery?

seeker: looking to work exclusively at home in sales which is more my specialization, so yes to both questions
supporter: Online work can be very lucrative. I have been doing it for years personally. It is nice to be your own boss and choose your own hours.

seeker: I currently do day trading on the side and make great money at it but want something stable to challenge me
supporter: It is true that stability is important. Do I hear you say that you are frightened of the insecurity of working from home?

seeker: more so the lack of benefits I would lose, especially healthcare
supporter: Ah .. I am in the UK so we have socialised medicine :). Would you feel more comfortable if you lived in a country like that?

seeker: lol definitely! Currently I pay $750 monthly if I purchase healthcare on my own but only $163 monthly through my work
supporter: Goodness .. I do not have to pay anything. Also our prescriptions are fixed at about ten pounds each.

seeker: I would lose about $3000 monthly leaving my job
supporter: You might be able to make that much from home though. And what's life if you don't take the odd risk?

seeker: still there?
supporter: Yes I am :)

seeker: Not feeling too great.
supporter: What happened?

seeker: I lost my job and I'm sad.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that, when was it?

seeker: I just found out this morning.
supporter: that sucks, did you tell your family?

seeker: Yeah i told them
supporter: it's ok even if they can't really help, having someone to share your problem is good enough

seeker: Thats true
supporter: Of course, anyone would feel the same. Maybe you should take a short trip, camping or go fishing to clear your mind for now

seeker: That's a great idea!
supporter: I think after you feel calmer then you can look for job. When we are desperate, we are unable to judge which option is good

seeker: This is some pretty solid advice thank you
supporter: you can drink a bit but be careful, people get addicted to alcohol during depression happens very often

seeker: Good idea!
supporter: give yourself a week or two, what done is done, you can use this time as a break for yourself!

seeker: Sure thing
supporter: Anything else I can help you with?

seeker: I really dont know where to turn to
supporter: after the trip, you can start looking around and see, if there's no good openings, you can do part time to get some income for now

seeker: Sounds like a good plan. Thank you.
supporter: good luck on finding a new job!

seeker: Oh, not too bad, thanks.  And you?
supporter: I am okay but feeling a little down at the moment. Is there anything that you'd like to talk about?

seeker: Sorry to hear you're down... I'm definitely tired of this pandemic! Trying to keep in touch with messages and phone calls can help...
supporter: Is there anything specific getting you down? How are things in your work and your personal relationships?

seeker: Well, did you see the problem I originally wrote about?
supporter: No I did not, can you tell me about it?

seeker: Oh! You don't get to see the text of the problem? That's strange... I'll cut and paste it here:  Oops - that's not allowed. Okay - let me input it again.
supporter: Thank you, I would like to be able to help you but do not know what the problem is right now

seeker: I have this friend who is now on the opposite coast. We were out of touch for 15 years, but recently reconnected. We've been texting. But now he's demanding an apology, and it's completely unreasonable...
supporter: Ah I see .. you feel as though you friend is dragging up things from the past which are no longer relevant to your friendship?

seeker: No, not at all. It's new stuff.
supporter: Oh I am sorry, I misunderstood. Can you tell me a little about the situation?

seeker: We've been texting about politics, among other things. And we completely agree on the subject - that's not the issue. But I put up with his sort of acerbic wit - I ignore little put-downs, because I know that's just him...
supporter: What is it that he wants you to apologise for?

seeker: But recently, he was talking as if he was having symptoms as a result of having had COVID previously. So I asked, Oh, you had a positive COVID test? I didn't say it like I was challenging him - I just hadn't heard this before.
supporter: ah I see. I have had problems and sometime negative interactions about Covid with some friends too. I think it's a very difficult time for everybody; we are all feeling the strain and might be more irritable than previously

seeker: Yes - he's always irritable! ha ha. So instead of answering, he launched into this thing about how COVID antibodies disappear, so the tests are pointless. I know there are some issues with the various tests. As it happens, I have a PhD in immunology, so I know a lot about this stuff...
supporter: I think that the tests are very necessary! Also social distancing and mask wearing at this time.

seeker: He started saying things that are just factually not correct.  I get that the immune system is super complicated, and most people don't know much about it. But when I'd try to explain some things to him, he acted like I couldn't possibly know anything he didn't, after reading one Forbes article, and he started making personal attacks.
supporter: I think that perhaps you do not need this toxic person in your life. After fifteen years without him do you really feel you need to stay r reconciled?

seeker: I don't need him, no... But he's funny, and I don't have too many people in my life right now. I just moved to a new state where I literally know no one.
supporter: In that case perhaps you can just agree to disagree on this topic? If you don't want to risk the friendship :). I hope I have been able to be of some help to you today and thank you for talking!

seeker: And I'm also hurt and annoyed that he thinks I have anything to apologize for, when I put up with his acid tongued comments, and just turn the other cheek. I agree we should just go on, but I'm not going to apologize, when I didn't do anything.
supporter: And you too!

seeker: Thanks. Bye...
supporter: bye!

seeker: I'm alright, thank you, but a bit depressed after just breaking up with my girlfriend
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that, it must have been hard for you

seeker: Yes, it has been quite difficult
supporter: I feel you, can you tell me when it happened and why?

seeker: She was annoyed that I was spending too much time doing menial tasks online for Amazon
supporter: She seems to be a bit immature, amazon tasks even if not your main income, is still income and you're just working to make your life better

seeker: Exactly, and I was completing online chatbot tasks to get her a gift when she broke it off
supporter: that sucks, it must be shocking for you. Did you try to explain to her?

seeker: I did try to explain, but she didn't give me much of an opportunity to
supporter: ah it is your thought that counts, I'm sorry she didn't appreciate your effort

seeker: Maybe you're right
supporter: haha, well your future partner might have something even better than that

seeker: One day i'll find a woman who can make the perfect macarons, since i've failed every time i've tried
supporter: of course, if you try to be your better version, a better girl will show up

seeker: I totally agree
supporter: I usually find the right person appears when you don't look for them.So don't give up!

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi there, how is life treating you today?

seeker: Life is alright, but I am facing a bit of anxiety with the lack of work available
supporter: This is something that is affecting a lot of people during the pandemic. Would you like to talk a bit more about your situation?

seeker: I agree, the pandemic has made things really tough
supporter: Are you in employment at the moment, even part time?

seeker: I am making a little bit of money doing online tasks for Amazon
supporter: Ah, I hear you, I am in the same position. Where would you ideally like to see yourself in six months time?

seeker: In six months time, I hope to go to University and get a degree
supporter: That sounds very positive! What would you like to study? Will you work your way through?

seeker: I would like to study Economics ideally, and will work as hard as I can since it's very competitive
supporter: I hear you sounding a little more positive when you try to focus on the future rather than the present.

seeker: Honestly, i'd really love to work as a diplomat or a civil servant
supporter: That is a really worthwhile goal and I genuinely think that you can achieve it if you stick to your guns. Please try not to let one bad year put you off perusing your dream

seeker: Thank you for talking with me, it's been really helpful
supporter: You are most welcome. We have five minutes left if there's anything you'd like to talk about in addition to what you have already told me.

seeker: I am definitely feeling a bit more positive after this conversation
supporter: I am glad to have been able to help. We all need someone to talk to during a time like this

seeker: That's a really good idea
supporter: I do enjoy promising myself treats if I fulfil certain goals. It can be anything at all!

seeker: Yes, you too
supporter: Please show yourself out :)

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi, how are you?

seeker: I'm alright, thanks
supporter: Would you mind possibly telling me a bit more about it? I am not all that familiar with that, and it does sound intriguing.

seeker: I have not done very well in my exams and i'm worried about what my parent's reaction will be when they find out
supporter: I tend to worry at times too, and it almost always helps to talk about it with someone.

seeker: I agree, thank you for being open to talking to me
supporter: It sounds to me like you're thinking that you've disappointed your parents by falling behind in class a little?

seeker: Yes, that is exactly how I feel
supporter: I can tell you from personal experience and seeing others who've gone through similar events, your parents just may be a little upset right now, but they love you and really just want you to have a good and happy life. It sounds cheesy, I know, but it is actually true.

seeker: Thank you, I hope so :)
supporter: I know it may sound silly, but you may want to start meditating on a regular basis. It truly does make a big difference in the amount of stress and worrying that you will find yourself not doing nearly so often.

seeker: I've had other people say the same, thank you for the recommendation
supporter: Studies on the benefits of meditation, mindfulness, and yoga have been pretty definitive in the fact that it drops people's stress levels, and thus their cortisol levels, and makes a real change for the better. I do it myself and it really has worked well for me.

seeker: I will definitely try and have a conversation with them (after some meditation, of course!)
supporter: You may be surprised at how understanding parents can be when you open up to them

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi. How are you today?

seeker: I'm ok, feeling so overwhelmed
supporter: it's really a terrible time.  you are definitely not alone in feeling that way.  Is there something specific going on?

seeker: lately there has been a project at work in which extra help is required. the volume of things i have to take care of has increased, and my manager doesn't seem to care
supporter: Is there a way you can write down in an email why the extra work is required and what specifically needs to get done in order to make this project successful for both you and your manager?

seeker: i have sent her a spreadsheet showing how the project has increased my workload, but she brushes it off.
supporter: I have had managers like that.  It's so frustrating.  Is there a way you can have an in-person meeting and show her how extra help will make HER look good?  Otherwise what I've done in the past is go over my immediate manager's head - or called a meeting with 3 of us.

seeker: that is a very good idea
supporter: I feel for you because I've been there and I completely understand how you feel.  And yes including HER and her manager won't make her feel as though you're going behind her back.

seeker: the other thing that has become an issue is her ridiculing me in front of others
supporter: ridiculing you how?  that's never ok

seeker: i have reached out to HR regarding these incidents but they seem to be uninterested
supporter: I wonder why HR isn't interested.  Have you put it in writing?  No one likes a paper trail that isn't acknowledged.

seeker: i was vague with my initial contact to HR
supporter: that has to be a horrible feeling to be in such a hostile work environment.  do you have coworkers who would be willing to back you up?

seeker: maybe, i'm not sure. it feels like everyone is afraid of my manager but yet no one will speak up
supporter: if it's really that bad is there a way to get a transfer?

seeker: i have considered it, but due to the pandemic, everything is on freeze
supporter: yes and that just makes things so much worse.

seeker: i'm withdrawing from the work and that's bad. i still care about the work, but the toxic environment is messing with me mentally
supporter: maybe seek out someone more senior in a different department who can help

seeker: that's a good idea!
supporter: When I had a toxic manager I went in and did my work and kept to myself as much as possible.   But it does help to have allies throughout the company too!

seeker: it might be worthwhile to try that approach
supporter: you're very welcome.  I definitely understand what you're dealing with!

seeker: i appreciate you sharing thoughts on my situation.
supporter: you, too.  enjoy the rest of the weekend!

seeker: I am having a lot of anxiety and overeating because I cannot decide if I should switch jobs
supporter: I see ... so you're having a career dilemma and this is affecting your overall physical health?

seeker: Yes because I am overeating a lot of sugar and junk food.  And I can't sleep
supporter: Please try not to worry, this is a very common thing to happen to people. I will try to help you all that I can.

seeker: Right, I can't decide what I should do, should I leave my job or not.
supporter: Do you feel as though another job might be more intellectually fulfilling for you?

seeker: That's a really good question.  I think it would, but I'm worried I wont be any good at it.
supporter: I understand how difficult it can be to take what might be a life changing move. I have been in that position myself. I can't tell you what to do but I can say that it worked out very well for me.

seeker: I don't like feeling lots of anxiety, so I feel like I want to keep doing what I'm doing.  But then I don't want to miss out on this new opportunity.
supporter: Have you contemplated seeing your doctor? They might be able to help with your anxiety.

seeker: I haven't thought about seeing a doctor.  It could help.  But I also feel like nothing can help me.
supporter: I know things can feel hopeless when you're in a bad mental place but please don't lose hope. Things will definitely improve but I think you should  take steps to help yourself too

seeker: Yes, that is it, it feels hopeless.  I've always had so much anxiety over my life, I'm so sick of it.  I wish I could just feel calm for a little bit.
supporter: I know that a very large percent of the population suffers from anxiety at some point or another. There are therapies that can help.

seeker: Maybe I should seek treatment, I haven't thought about doing that.
supporter: There are lots of different routes you can go down when it comes to treatment. Some people prefer therapy whilst others take medication, or a combination of the two.You have to find what works for you.

seeker: That does sound like a good idea.  Since we are in COVID, I don't see or talk to anyone that I used it.  So I feel pretty lonely, just going in circles in my head.
supporter: Do you feel as though Covid is making your situation worse than it would otherwise be?

seeker: Definitely.  I can't see people that I used to or my parents.  It really sucks.  This year has been so stressful.
supporter: I have been having a really difficult year too. Roll on 2021!

seeker: I think it's hard for everyone.  I can't wait for it to be over.  I think we have another year till it's really over.  I'm I'm so tired already.
supporter: Me too! Let's hope January brings better things for all of us.

seeker: I need to see friends and do activities.  It's more healthy for everyone that way.
supporter: Yes. Once your anxiety subsides a little do you think that the job situation might solve itself?

seeker: I'm not sure. But I like your idea about getting help.  I will look into that tomorrow.  Thank you for that idea.
supporter: Your are most welcome. Is there anything else that I can help you with?

seeker: No Thank you Bye Bye
supporter: Goodbye and good luck!

seeker: I'm doing okay
supporter: That's good to hear.

seeker: How are you?
supporter: I'm doing great, thank you!

seeker: You're welcome
supporter: Is there anything that you wanted to talk about?

seeker: Ya, I just feel down recently
supporter: I'm so sorrry to hear. that. Is there any reason for it?

seeker: My best  friend and I constantly argue
supporter: That's so hard. Was there any cause for the arguing or is it just general tension?

seeker: She hates who I'm dating and wants me to leave him
supporter: THat's so hard. My best friend hated my ex boyfriend as well and we always fought about it. I tried really hard to understand where she was coming from. IN the end, she was right about somethings.

seeker: Ok I will give that a try. He's very good to me and I care deeply for him.
supporter: You should try setting up a fun day for them where they can get to know each other.

seeker: That's a great idea! Like bowling?
supporter: Bowling is gret!! would your best friend be open ot it?

seeker: Yes she would
supporter: That's great!!! this way you can keep them both in your life.

seeker: Okay we will try bowling. Thank you for the help
supporter: Anytime! Do you need anything ese?

seeker: The virus is making it hard on me and causing me loneliness even more this season
supporter: I'm so sorry that you are feelingly lonely. If I may ask you a question, when did this start?

seeker: It has been for awhile.
supporter: Were you feeling lonely before the virus came this year?

seeker: Not really. I had people to talk with
supporter: It sounds that you are feeling lonely because you cannot talk to people face to face. Do I have that right?

seeker: I WFH. I am a writer
supporter: I WFH as well. It can be very liberating, but oftentimes I feel lonely too.

seeker: The only connection we have is like this
supporter: I know that it's really difficult right now, but it seems that the virus is going to get better in the new year. We need to push through these next few months and then it will be over.

seeker: Do you feel that way?
supporter: Yes, I do feel that way. And yes I will take the vaccine.

seeker: I won't take the shot
supporter: Apparently, the side effects are usually minimal and temporary if you have them at all. The people that are having severe reactions have had issues with vaccines previously. I would keep an open mind. It might help to ease your anxiety about the future.

seeker: Im never take the vaccines
supporter: It sounds like you're being selfish because you're not going to take the vaccine. Does that seem like a reasonable conclusion?

seeker: If the vaccine is that great then why did it take so long to make.
supporter: Yes, I do. It's not bothersome and it's the least I can do to keep myself and others safe.

seeker: I protect myself wherever I go. However the people that ignore the mask are more of a health risk than my not getting the vaccine
supporter: You as well!

seeker: I am really feeling the loneliness of the season and being isolated.
supporter: Good evening.

seeker: Good evening
supporter: So just so I understand, the holiday season is making you feel alone and isolated.

seeker: Yes as well as the virus
supporter: Is there anything in particular about the holidays that is bothering  you?

seeker: Just no family around
supporter: I am also far away from my family for the holidays, so I know how hard that is

seeker: The virus this year does not help.
supporter: Not at all

seeker: ARe you affected by the virus
supporter: Have you thought about setting up some video calls with your family during the holidays? I know a lot of people are doing that so they can feel closer to the family during these tough times/

seeker: I thought about he videos but my daughter lives in California
supporter: That is tough, but I definitely think setting up a time to chat with her would help a lot!

seeker: I have to arrange with her because she does not I am moving. It will bother her.
supporter: I can through our messages that this is a very tough season for you

seeker: I'm okay I guess
supporter: You seem a little down. Is there anything you'd like to talk about?

seeker: I just don't feel like I'm good enough lately
supporter: So you are experiencing feelings of inadequacy? That is very sad. Can you tell me why you think you feel this way? Has anything changed lately?

seeker: Yes I feel very inadequate. Recently my best friend and I can't get along. She's always upset at me about things I'm doing
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. I've experienced difficulties with friendships too. Do you think you can talk with her?

seeker: I've tried taking to her, usually she gets very angry with me and starts yelling. She never listens to what I have to say.
supporter: It sounds a little as though her behaviour is toxic. Does the friendship really mean that much to you?

seeker: She means so much to me and she's my only friend.
supporter: So you feel that the friendship is worth fighting for, but she is not being responsive?

seeker: More than that, she's not being supportive of my decisions and that's all I want
supporter: Was there one specific thing that triggered this or had it been coming for a long time?

seeker: She hates my boyfriend, she wants me to leave him. If i don't she doesn't want to hang around me as much. She said I have to choose him or her.
supporter: Would you consider having some counselling together? Perhaps talk through what is going on?

seeker: She moved all of her things out of our dorm room we share just because I'm still with my boyfriend. I woukd do counselling but I'm not sure she would
supporter: I really feel as though you are the one putting all the effort in here and she is just making selfish demands on you.

seeker: I've realized I want to spend the rest of my life with my boyfriend and I don't think she'll like that.
supporter: I think you know deep down what is the best thing to do. You don't need selfish people in your life.

seeker: I'm a little reluctant, I'm very shy and struggle with making new friends, that's why she is do important to me.
supporter: You have your boyfriend though :). He will always be there for you - and not treat you as badly as she has!

seeker: Yes that's true. What do I say to her?
supporter: I don't think you owe her an explanation after how she has behaved. Leave her to make the next move

seeker: The problem is we technically share a room. She does come in occasionally.
supporter: I know that you must feel that this could be a problem but I think you will be able to just ignore her. I am afraid I must leave for my next appointment now.

seeker: Okay! Thank you for the advice.
supporter: you're most welcome and enjoy the rest of your day!

seeker: Listening to music
supporter: I would definitely go listen to some music and get your mind off of things.

supporter: I think that would help!

supporter: Have a good night!

seeker: hi
supporter: Hello. I am so sorry to hear that. I am unable to depend on my family as well. Did you have an unexpected expense?

supporter: Are you in school and working at the same time? What have you found recently to make extra money?

seeker: ok

supporter: Additional stress right now certainly isn't anything anyone needs.  You may want to consider looking at resources online that provide comparable salary information for your position.  That would help with having a conversation with your current employer if you are being paid less than average.  Since they are a non-profit, I'm sure they would want to do everything to help you with your financial situation.

supporter: That sounds like a great next step.  Is there anything else on your mind that you'd like to chat about?
