supporter: How do you feel in yourself at the moment? Are you worried about your own health?

seeker: I’m not worried about my health. More worried and sad about her. Especially not knowing how severe it is yet. It seems like any extra stress this year is harder to handle.
supporter: You are certainly not the only one who is feeling this - it has been a terrible year. Cancer is bad at any time but this year it is especially awful.

seeker: I agree. It feels like everything is just a bit harder to get through
supporter: I am hoping that in the New Year things will be better .. maybe in January the world will look like a more positive place.

seeker: I’m trying to be hopeful to
supporter: I hope that things go well with you and your mentor.

seeker: Thank you. This conversation has helped and you were able to offer good suggestions
supporter: I am glad that I was able to help. I wish you all of the very best in the coming year.

seeker: Thank you. I wish you the best to during the next year. Maybe a hard year is what we needed to appreciate the easier years.
supporter: This could be true but I want to have an easier year next year!!

seeker: Agrees. Thank you again.
supporter: No problem. I should probably leave now :)

seeker: I am doing ok.  How are you?
supporter: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. What are you seeking support for today?

seeker: I have been struggling for motivation to do anything the past couple weeks.  This is a really hard time of year for me.  I lost my cousin in a car accident at the age of 14 in a car accident coming up on 20 years this year.  We were very close.  I was 17 at the time.  Her was an alcoholic and my parents raised her a majority of her life.  Then 3 years ago 5 days after her death anniversary I lost my boyfriend at the age of 32 in a car accident.  I dread the holidays.
supporter: Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you are describing a strong association between the holiday season and loss of loved ones. This leads to less of a desire to engage in typical holiday events. Does that sound right?

seeker: You are exactly right.  The year my cousin got killed her mom was hungover so I went and picked up my cousin and her little brother to take them to our grandparents house for Christmas dinner.  She died 4 days later on Dec 29th.  And my boyfriend it was his first day back to work after the New Year.  He died on Jan 3rd.
supporter: I can see why this time of year is difficult for you. Trying to hide depression can be a challenge. Rather than hiding the sadness or grieving feelings, some people find relief in acknowledging and sharing these feelings with family members who may relate. Do you ever share these feelings with your cousin or grandparents that you mentioned?

seeker: My cousin doesn't live around here and we have never been real close.  He is alot younger than me.  We just never had the connection like his sister and I did.  And both my grandparents have passed away.  Grandpa has been gone for 12 years and Grandma has been gone for 4 now.
supporter: I understand. When losses are experienced it is a great change in many aspects of our lives.

seeker: They say it gets easier. And I agree it does.  Things just have changed so much.  I miss how life was before I lost them.
supporter: I understand - and it is normal to feel that way. When we lose someone who brought us happiness, it is only natural to miss them and their company.

seeker: I love giving gifts.  And I always put lots of thought into the gifts I give.  My nieces and nephews can't wait every year to see what I got them.
supporter: That's great! You must have a special talent for personalizing your gift selections. Perhaps focus on that reaction from you nieces and nephews to support your motivation for giving gifts this year.

seeker: This year I am tie dying hooded sweatshirts.  I make tshirts for a hobby.  And to tell you the truth thats the only gifts I have gotten so far.  My oldest daughter turned 18 this year and lives with her boyfriend so its just me and my 15 year old daughter.  She struggles with depression/anxiety as well.  Her dad has been in jail for some stupid actions since August.  She has had to deal with him being an addict pretty much her whole life.  I think we are both missing how the holidays were with her sister still living at home.  Too much change in our lives in such a little time frame.
supporter: Wow, what a great gift idea! That is a solid start on your gifts for the season, and something to be proud of.

seeker: They will love them.  A couple years ago I put their names on fleece blankets when I worked at an embroidery shop.  They absolutly loved them!
supporter: And I see, it sounds like the changes in your life are potentially impacting your daughter as well. However, I'm glad you have each other for support this season. This year has been crazy for many reasons, and many people tend to find comfort in routines or traditions. Do you and your daughters have any holiday traditions you typically complete?

seeker: I am ok.  Kinda having a rough day today.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. Do you want to talk about it?

seeker: Sure.  It's coming up on 3 years next month that I lost my boyfriend in a car accident.  Its just really rough this time of year.
supporter: Oh I am so sorry to hear that. I cannot imagine how hard that must have been for you.

seeker: Extremely hard.  I remember that morning like it was yesterday.  He got killed within an hour after leaving the house on his way to work.
supporter: He was killed so soon after you last saw him?

seeker: Very soon.  And the worst thing is I was upset with him that morning.  He had an addiction to xanax.  I was not ok with it.  He had went and got some that morning and he would always give them to me so I could give them to him so he didn't take them all.  I was so upset that he went and got them.  He was packing up his truck with things to take to the new shop that day.  He was a tattoo artist and just started a new job.  I didn't even get out of bed to help him and he knew I was upset with him.
supporter: Have you considered any sort of bereavement counselling? Addiction in a partner is a very hard thing to have to deal with. It is not your fault!

seeker: I had decided that I was gonna wait to hear from him that day instead of texting or calling him.  I wanted him to realize how upset his addiction made me. Instead the phone call I got was that he had been killed.
supporter: Do you feel any sort of guilt about it? You should not, of course, but do you wonder if things would have been different if you had talked to him first?

seeker: I haven't done any counseling.  I know I should and it would probably help me.  I don't know why I have not.
supporter: I have previously had counselling and found it very useful but there is a long waiting list for a free counsellor

seeker: I don't feel guilt about it.  Now at least.  I was pretty hard on myself at first.  But I know that he knows why I was upset that morning.  It was something we dealt with a lot.
supporter: Are you still in touch with his family and friends?

seeker: I went and talked to a therapist once right after and never went back.  And I don't know why.  He was amazing to talk too.  But I just never went back.
supporter: I think you should do things in your own time but I would recommend doing it again one day.

seeker: I don't have any contact with his family.  I actually had to block them on all social media.  They are extremely religous.  Which there is nothing wrong with that.  But he didn't have the best relationship with any of them.  They couldn't accept him for who he was.  His biological father didn't have anything to do with him.  His mom was remarried and had two more kids and they didn't treat my boyfriend very good growing up.  He ended up living with his grandparents.  He finally had acceptance in my family.  He actually talked to my mom more than I did lol.
supporter: Sounds like a very complicated set up. It is sad when family members become partially estranged from one another.

seeker: His family has been pretty horrible to me and my girls.  And I know it's because they have guilt for the way things were with their relationship.  They didn't even invite me and my girls to the burial of his ashes.
supporter: That is extremely offensive and I think you would have had the right to contest that.

seeker: It's very sad.  Not what I wanted at all.  But they were really horrible to me and my girls.  I know he would not be happy that they have treated us so poorly.
supporter: I hope that you are able to come to terms with things in the near future. Please try and focus on your girls and not worry so much!

seeker: His sisters went and cleaned out and took everything he had from the shop the day after the funeral.  Which really hurt.  The stuff he had there meant alot to me.
supporter: I think you should talk to someone about this. Maybe a lawyer? There must be something people can do to help.

seeker: I hope I can too.  I just take everything day by day.  I start a new job this week and hopefully things will start looking up.  The last 3 years have been rough to say the least.
supporter: I have to wrap this up now but I wish you all the very best for the future. Please try and reach out to people for help!

seeker: We weren't married. And of course he didn't have a will.  He was only 32.  So according to his family I have no legal rights.
supporter: You are very welcome!

seeker: Have a good night.
supporter: And you too, goodnight.

seeker: Hi I am doing okay, how are you?
supporter: I'm good, you can go ahead and tell me your problems

seeker: I am deciding if I should break up with my boyfriend or not.
supporter: Can you tell me what  happened that makes you consider that?

seeker: About a month ago I found him looking at provocative pictures on Instagram of girls he didn't know but I am friends with and he admitted he did that repeatedly on many occasions, even when I was at his house in the other room
supporter: Have  you told him how you feel and asked him to stop doing that?

seeker: yeah and he has stopped he deleted insta but it still hurt my feelings and trust a lot
supporter: Ok, it's a good thing that he stopped. What he did was bad though, no denying that.

seeker: its not cheating though bc he never did anything w anyone its just a violation of trust buuutt I don't know how big of a deal it is
supporter: Maybe he feels ashamed about watching porn, that's why he tried to hide. I would hate it too if my partner watches porn

seeker: yeahhh, my friends have given me very mixed opinions abt what to do lol
supporter: Other than that, is there anything else?

seeker: and it wasn't just like he lied once he did it constantly over the course of a year of dating  and hid everything and cleared his search and all that
supporter: I think you should be firm, let him know how much you hate what he did and how much it affected you. I think it's a serious issue, him not being honest with you over trivial things. At the same time, breaking up  without any other issues is kind of not optimal considered you;ve dated for 1 year

seeker: I mean I def let him know I hate it
supporter: Did you see any changes in behavior after that?

seeker: I feel like its maybe not something worth breaking up over but its just gross and makes me feel bad
supporter: you should tell him that, and let him the problem is you feel disrespected when he watches porn while dating you

seeker: yeah truuue tysm. one of the girls he lusted over goes to college w us and she literally got kicked out of her sorority last year for sexually assaulting a guy who was passed out drunk and posted it on her snap story and he didn't care at all bc she posted cute pics of her booty lmao I was just so disgusted since I was r*ped last year at a frat house and like idk how u can still have any kind of attraction to people who do terrible things like that
supporter: I am so sorry to hear that, you are not oversensitive at all. Trust me, any normal girls would feel the same

seeker: I appreciate it
supporter: Breaking up over this is a pity, however, he doesn't seem trustworthy after everything you told me. How about give him some time, 3-6 months and see if he changes at all. If not or if you really think he's not worth your time, go ahead and cut tie with him

seeker: life is pretty bad latley
supporter: I am so sorry to hear that, can you tell me a bit about what is wrong?

seeker: 2020 has just been a bad year, i got kicked out of my dads house and also lost my main job because i was working with him
supporter: So you have been made homeless and have lost touch with one of your closest relatives?

seeker: I still ilive with my mother but he was a big part of life
supporter: I understand how you feel. I am estranged from my mother. Is there any chance you could reconcile?

seeker: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope it gets better. We are in family therapy but he refuses to apologize
supporter: There is a good deal of therapy available for your circumstances. Do you think you should try a different kind?

seeker: what other options are there?
supporter: There is free therapy available for people who feel that they cannot get along with one or both parents.

seeker: I am already in therapy with him but it doesnt seem to be helping that much
supporter: Please know that you are not alone in this situation.

seeker: Thank you i appreciate that
supporter: Do you think it might be better to make a totally clean break and move on from your dad then?

seeker: its hard to do that since everyone in my family thinks i should move on and forgive him
supporter: I hear you saying that you feel that you are being unfairly blamed for things, is this true?

seeker: yes it is
supporter: Do you feel that perhaps holding onto this relationship is doing harm to you?

seeker: I think if things were to continue as they were then it would be. I am more hurting now knowing that someone who is suppose to be there has been able to drop me so quickly over something very small
supporter: Can you tell me some more specific details

seeker: We were having issues at work due to covid and he did not want to help me with any of the work that was required. He had invited me over to his house to which I found my clothes in a trash bag and he wanted to talk to me which i was reluctatnt after that
supporter: To me this sounds like a very toxic relationship. I have been in a similar situation and I really think that it is best that you move on from this. You do not need this level of toxicity in your life

seeker: I know its toxic but the influence from other family members makes it hard since everyone is so accustom to how he acts and they let it slide
supporter: Unfortunately that is often how it works with such people. Would you be able to make a completely new break and move away? I know it's hard.

seeker: I am trying the therapy to not be the stubborn one and say that i atleast tried but if it does not work then that seems to be the only option unless he makes changes
supporter: So you feel that you are trying hard to mend the quarrel but he is not putting in any effort himself?

seeker: I dont feel like he is. He still thinks I should apologize to him for what I said but I don't think what i said was bad at all or warrented his reaction
supporter: I do not feel that you are the one in the wrong. Unfortunately, there are some people that you just can't reach

seeker: i believe that is the case as well, thank you for your help
supporter: You are more than welcome. I do hope that you can break free from this relationship and find some way to be happy though.

seeker: Thank you very much, I hope your situation is not as bad anymore as well, its a hard situation for anyone
supporter: Things are very much better for me now. I promise that they will be for you soon too!

seeker: thank you :) I will be ending this session now but i appreciate your time
supporter: You are most welcome and all the best to you. Happy Holidays!

seeker: Hello! Life is treating me fair, what about you?
supporter: Well, I've been a bit worried this year due to Covid and everything. Have you been worrying about anything?

seeker: Yes, not covid tho. Mostly, it's academics. It paralyses me.
supporter: Do you work in academia then? Or are you a student?

seeker: I am a college student, and I miss my high school days.
supporter: So you feel that life was more simple when you were still in high school?

seeker: Yes, schoolwork wise. Now, I can never stay on top.
supporter: I think that it is quite usual to feel a bit disorientated when transitioning from school to college. It is strange to feel like an adult all of a sudden

seeker: Do you have any experience with that?
supporter: Yes I do. It took me quite a long time to adjust to college in my first year too.

seeker: Woah, I am sorry it was rough for you.
supporter: It was a bit but I think that it was not just me. It's a huge life change. Is your problem mainly with your grades or are there other issues?

seeker: I would say my grades is the most important part of my llife, so it's the only thing that worries me
supporter: Do you feel scared that you might fail your exams?

seeker: All the time. I didn't fail any this semester, but the anxiety makes me irritable and worried.
supporter: There are personal tutors available who could help you with any academic problems you are having?

seeker: hello?
supporter: hello, how can I help you?

seeker: I'm seeking some support. Specifically looking for advice concerning my depression
supporter: How long have you known you have depression?

seeker: I've struggled with depression my entire life. It's been especially difficult this year
supporter: Because of Covid? So you know at least the cause of your depression?

seeker: Yes, because of Covid. I have two small children both born with genetic disorders. If they catch it they could die. They're both now displaying signs of anxiety and that's worsening my depression because there is very little I can do about it.
supporter: That must have been tough for you. I know Covid is scary, however, I think you're a very careful parent so as long as you keep the routine safe, you can at least not worry too much about it

seeker: I'm doing my best, as is my husband, but with the holdays here we're struggling to explain our decision not to visit family because we want the children to be safe. Our family is a combination of Covid Hoaxers and antimaskers sadly.
supporter: Now is not the time to please your family or anyone else. You did the right and responsible thing for refusing to visit them.

seeker: Thank you for agreeing with me. They are nine and four.
supporter: they might have been scared because of external forces, as in they might see you being stressed out. I think it's good to talk to them about the seriousness of Covid, but also explain them it's not unpreventable. By discussing, you can reassure yourself too

seeker: Maybe. I'll have to give them a few days as my mother is very self centered and we just got into it last night, but I might give that a try
supporter: I think you can also cut down on watching news, when it first began, I followed the news closely, however, I realized I felt depressed hearing new number everyday so I only update myself once a week now and I feel bette

seeker: That's good to hear, maybe I should do that.
supporter: Having a family meeting with your husband and children as much as possible to share your feelings might also help quite a bit

seeker: I'm not so sure. My husband's anxiety is worse than mine and I carry the mental load for the entire family. He's usually happier staying in the dark, otherwise it's too difficult to lift him up when he's depressed if I'm also depressed.
supporter: Then do as you think is best for your husband. I'd say focus the work on yourself first, you need to feel good in other to take care of your family

seeker: That is true. Thank you for the advice
supporter: you're welcome, I hope you feel a bit better

seeker: Hello. Better than usual. What about you?
supporter: I am good thank you. Is there anything you want to talk to me about?

seeker: Yes. Recently, I broke up with my fiance. And no matter how much I tell myself that life continues, I still feel like there is a void inside of me ever since it happened.
supporter: So your relationship ended and you feel that you are struggling to get over it, is that correct?

seeker: Yes, that's exactly right.
supporter: I am very sorry. I have been through something like this myself in the past so I do understand.

seeker: How long did it take you to get over it?
supporter: I think it was at least a year before I felt truly myself again and that I was able to enjoy life

seeker: That gives me some perspective.
supporter: I can tell that it's all very raw to you at the moment. You really need to step away and give yourself some time to heal

seeker: I am not sure if I can leave my obligations behind.
supporter: What sort of obligations do you feel that you have? You need to be kind to yourself at the moment

seeker: I have a job, and my siblings are not doing too well, so I have to make sure their stuff is taken care of, or else my parents will end up babying them, and my parents are not in their peak health. This is not something I can afford to step away from.
supporter: It is good of you to be so caring and responsible towards your family. Do you think that perhaps you are taking too much on yourself though, especially at such a difficult time?

seeker: It might be so, but the sad truth is that when people don't fulfill their functions, someone else is going to have to do it for them. Maybe tho, I could fix my schedule to where it allows me to have firmer boundaries.
supporter: I think that that is an excellent idea and that you are being very mature about this.

seeker: No, I made a commitment not to contact him.
supporter: That seems sensible. I had a problem with not contacting my ex when we split. I kept wanting to talk to him again even though I knew that I should not

seeker: What made you stop?
supporter: A restraining order :D

seeker: This actually made me laugh :D Thank you for elevating my mood
supporter: In all seriousness though, with hindsight I realise that our separation was for the best. I think and hope that you will realise this in time too

seeker: Thank you. Your analysis is extremely helpful.
supporter: You are most welcome. I really hope that things start to go well with you soon.

seeker: hello
supporter: hi there! how are you doing?

seeker: I feel ashamed thinking of my future career
supporter: Can you tell me a little about what you feel ashamed about?

seeker: whenever we have family gathering, my aunts and uncles would brag about how much their children make. I have higher degree but will only make half of their salary so I feel bad
supporter: So, you feel that your family is judging you for your earning potential?

seeker: yes, my parents won't say it to me but they never show they're proud either
supporter: I am very sorry for that. They should be proud that you have such a good degree!

seeker: What's good if it doesn't translate to my earnings.
supporter: I think you are coming at this from the wrong perspective. Life is not all about money you know!

seeker: I want to think otherwise but it's difficult, especially when capitalism is everything nowadays
supporter: Do you think that you enjoy your current field even though it is not as well paid as it could be?

seeker: I enjoy it, I did some internship and it was nice
supporter: I think that you should focus on how much you enjoy it. After all you will be working for the next few decades so you do not want to do something that you hate just because it pays well.

seeker: Is there anyway for me to change my way of thinking? I keep worrying about all the expense that I'll have to spend and what if I can't afford because of how much I earn
supporter: Is it possible for you to talk to your parents about this? It seems to me that they  are at the root of your problems

seeker: I don't really want to talk to them, I'm not very close to them and rarely tell them my problems
supporter: Well, if you are not close to them does their opinion really count for so much?

seeker: it still affects me nonetheless
supporter: I do understand how hard it can be to shake off your family's preconceptions and expectations even though you are not close to them

seeker: thank you for understanding
supporter: You are very welcome. Please know that this is a very common problem and a lot of people feel the way that you are feeling now.

seeker: it's tough when I look around and everyone seems to do better than me
supporter: Do you think that you might benefit from some counselling to help you overcome your self esteem issues?

seeker: I've thought about thaat but I'm not in a financial situation to afford that
supporter: I can provide you with a list of places that will offer a few counselling sessions for free. I think you need to be able to talk this out with a professional.

seeker: that would be great
supporter: I think that you need to accept that your parents' opinion should not colour your whole life

seeker: yeah I should start doing that and not let others affect me
supporter: Once your self esteem picks up a little I think that you will find that it's very much easier to ignore other people's input.

seeker: Hello.  Thanks for helping me today.
supporter: No problem! How can I help you?

seeker: I'm feeling anxious about finding work and and impatient with the application process at many places I"ve applied.
supporter: So from what I am understanding, you have been applying for jobs and you are having anxiety about finding one and waiting through the application process.

seeker: Yes thats right.  I keep trying and feel like I"m not getting anywhere.
supporter: Just from the few messages we have shared I can tell how anxious this is making you.

seeker: Yes.  I think that I might have to try to find a different type of work than I"m used to and I'm not sure I'll be good at trying something new.
supporter: I just recently went through a layoff at my company, and I had the same situation trying to find another job. It is very stressful.

seeker: I wish that I could get more of a reason than just a denial of my application.  I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong and most companies won't give any feedback.
supporter: What have you done to reach out for feedback from the companies? Often it helps to send e-mails or make phone calls to have them give you some feedback.

seeker: I haven't tried reaching out.  Most of the places I"ve been applying are huge corporations with no one to call at HR.  Maybe I should try to apply somewhere locally and see if I have better luck.  At least then I could talk to a person.
supporter: I think that would be a great start!

seeker: Thats a great idea.  I've been considering going back to school to see if I can maybe get a higher degree.
supporter: What type of work are you interested in?

seeker: What I'm most interested in is importing and exporting of exotic fruit but the recent restrictions on travel have really hurt the business.
supporter: I think that would be a great idea! It has been shown that people with higher level degrees make more money and have more opportunity than those without,

seeker: Ugh getting accepted for a masters program sounds stressful.  I'm thinking I can't go wrong by becoming a plumber or an electrician.  Everyone always needs that, even with the pandemic.
supporter: I think learning a trade would also be a great idea! I would definitely reach out to see where you can start that process.

seeker: I wish there was a way you could try different jobs for a few days to see if you like it before starting the process of going to school
supporter: From our conversation so far, I can tell you are extremely anxious about this whole situation.

seeker: My boyfriend broke up with me.
supporter: Hello there, how are you?

seeker: I'm very upset.
supporter: Your relationship has ended? I am very sorry about that. And your boyfriend ended it?

seeker: Yes, after seeing him act this way I agree
supporter: I have been in this position myself and I know how painful it is but it turned out for the best for me - I now have a great relationship!

seeker: Well that's good for you, but I'm so mad right now I can't see straight!
supporter: Noone has the right to put you down like that. You really are better off without him.

seeker: I know. I do deserve better. But I was with him a very long time.
supporter: Can you think of something to do that will take your mind off him?

seeker: More than a year, but I've known him since childhood.
supporter: He should not be treating you that way when you've known one another so long!

seeker: All those years of friendship down the drain.
supporter: I think that you should call one of your girlfriends and suggest you have a movie night. It would make you feel better

seeker: But all of my friends are still friends with him!
supporter: Oh that is rough. That happened to me too when I broke up with my ex.

seeker: How did you get through it?
supporter: They all took his side? Not one took yours?

seeker: Not one!
supporter: I tried to find some new interests. One thing I did was take a salsa class .. that was a great way to meet new people

seeker: I'm not much of a dancer, but that might be a way to meet new people.
supporter: There are lots of other things you could do. Maybe you could take an evening class in something that interests you?

seeker: He's a teacher, so taking a class might remind me of him.
supporter: I think also you need to think a bit more highly of yourself and not let idiots like this treat you so badly

seeker: But maybe I deserved it.
supporter: he seems to have damaged your self esteem badly

seeker: Yes, he did.
supporter: No you did not! Please don't think like that

seeker: I'm just so angry that I could break something.
supporter: I think that that is a normal reaction to feeling ill treated. I hope that it will pass soon and am sure that it will.

seeker: But what if it doesn't pass?
supporter: I think you really need to take it one day at a time. Things are very raw for you right now

seeker: I don't know if I could do that. I don't like talking about my problems with strangers.
supporter: And yet here we are :P. Therapy can be surprisingly beneficial, I have found.

seeker: Do you have any suggestions about how to open up to people I don't know?
supporter: I think that is useful to remember that we are all human and that most people have been hurt in this way at some point. No-one will be judging you

seeker: That's what I am afraid of. Being judged by people.
supporter: Do you think that this might partly because your ex has eroded your self esteem?

seeker: Probably. He called me a lot of names.
supporter: The important thing is to gradually rebuild your self esteem. Do you have any things that you excel at?

seeker: I'm good at bowling. And I like riding horses.
supporter: Animals are a wonderful source of comfort when we are feeling very low! Could you join a riding club to make some new friends?

seeker: Maybe I will do that. Horses are so cool.
supporter: I can feel that you are starting to make progress already and are thinking of things that you can do post break up

seeker: I sure am. Thanks for your help.
supporter: You are most welcome. Is there anything else you would like to talk to me about?

seeker: I don't think so...
supporter: Well, I wish you all the very best for the future. I know that things seem terrible right now but please believe me they will get better

seeker: Thanks! Have a good day.
supporter: And you have a lovely day too. I know that you are going to be just fine in a few weeks from now. Stay strong!

seeker: Hi! Did they send you a summary or anything of what's going on?  If not, I've been struggling general depression.  And overwhelming anxiety.
supporter: They did not, what is causing your depression and anxiety?

seeker: A cycle of anxiety.. overthinking that leads to depression.
supporter: So just to clarify, you are having overwhelming depression and anxiety today that has been caused by nothing in particular?

seeker: yes
supporter: I completely understand, I have had many issues in the past with anxiety and depression.

seeker: Any advice on how to push past the racing thoughts?
supporter: Have you tried to talk to a professional about this, it is always helpful to talk to someone who is trained to talk about things like this with people.

The problems I've been going through are very serious, and I just don't have time to sit on the phone listening to the same stuff I've been dealing with for years.

Stuff about how she didn't post on social media about her birthday, and little petty things like that. Not something an adult should be concerned with. And I still sat and listened to her all that time.
supporter: I completely understand how unappreciated and stressed this would make you or any person. Especially when our plate is full and its the same old same old and nothing is changing. Its like thinking doing same thing over and over you will get a different result when 2+2 equals 4

supporter: You are an extremely good and loyal friend and I am so proud of you. Most people would have left her.

supporter: However, it is time to take the hard road. YOu are going to have to say with LOVE because its not always what you say but how you say it.  Give me a minute to please type it

seeker: Okay, thank you.
supporter: You are going to have to sit her down and say  I need to be honest with you.  I have always been there for you but you are not willing to take my advice or others advice and quite frankly I just can't do it anymore. IF you want to remain friends I need you to grow up and realize the world doesn't revolve around you or even me.  Right now I could really use a good friend. I am going thru A LOT OF Sh** and I don't need this in my life. So

seeker: I think that's a good idea. I'll try that.
supporter: if you aren't able to do that than I am afraid until you can be a true friend and not just a user than I need to end this friendship . I don't want to but I need to for my mental health and for myself and even for you.  I say this because I love you and I do care but this has become toxic

supporter: she really needs to hear it and it sounds toxic to me . I know I wouldn't want a friend to accuse me of not being there and from the chat look like its all about her and she s acting like a spoiled brat

supporter: youre welcome and above all continue to pray for her or start praying for her. You really are a great loyal intelligent person. Keep safe

supporter: Has he gone to therapy with you? Maybe you can try doing some fun activties together.

I work 50 to 60 hour weeks and this is stressing me. I want to make them happy. I feel there are two alpha males in the house. My son clearly needs boundries, but I want him to finish school and stay safe during covid
supporter: That's such a hard position to be in. I am so so sorry that you need to go through this. I think trying to get them to therapy would be realaly amazing for both of you.

supporter: I can definitely understand why that would be stressful. Do you have anyone to help you study?

seeker: I do. There is a study group of people in my class. I am preparing really well but I've struggled with this class so much that I still get really worried.
supporter: It sounds like you are preparing well but are still worried that it won't be enough. Does that sound right?

seeker: Yes, that's right. I feel like I could literally study 24 hours a day and it won't be enough. It's hard to know if the information is really getting into my head, and if I'm actually understanding it all.
supporter: Sometimes taking a break and clearing your mind, taking a few deep breaths, can help people calm down. Is that something you can do?

seeker: I have tried that. And it does kind of help in the moment. It's when I get back to studying that all of the anxiety sets in. And it gets worse as it gets closer to the test. If I'm not studying, I feel guilty that I'm taking a break.
supporter: I understand that. I have felt the same way before. But I realized I don't have to feel guilty for taking a break. It's important for my mental health.

seeker: And I try to remember that, too. And I know that's right. But in the moment I feel guilty, so it's so hard for me to relax taking a break.
supporter: Just in the conversation I can see how stressed out you are and struggling with how to handle that.

seeker: Yes. Once my head is in this stressful mode, it's hard to break free.
supporter: Sometimes talking with a close friend can help. Have you tried that?

seeker: I have. And that does help in the moment. It's always when I get back into the actual studying that it's a problem. I think getting the test over with is the only thing that will help.
supporter: It sounds like the actual studying is what is causing you to be stressed. Does that seem to be true?

seeker: Yeah, definitely. I'm just worried about the test.
supporter: I think you have done everything you can to be prepared for the test. And know a few strategies to help you cope with your stress. I think you will feel much better once it's over!

seeker:
I agree
\.

supporter: You're welcome.

seeker: Hello: Thanks for offering to help.  My friend Mark is suffering from bi-polar disorder, and despite being on medication, is spiraling out of control.
supporter: I am so sorry about your friend mark. I will try my best to help you today.

seeker: I suspect he's not taking his medication as prescribed.  He's become a sociopath, which I understand is common with people suffering from this disorder.  He's unable to be empathic or sympathetic to anyone else's life.
supporter: To confirm your friend mark, you suspect he is not taking his medicine and that is why he is acting the way he is?

seeker: Yes, it is affecting me.  In sum, I'm the only one left in his corner, but I feel like he's slipping away and becoming completely dysfunctional.  It's tough with privacy laws for me to even talk to his doctor to see what's going on.  I did send his doctor a long email, however, so hopefully he'll make whatever adjustments need to be made.
supporter: Have you talked to mark about his behavior and how it is affecting everyone around him?

seeker: I have talked to him repeatedly.  Each time, he assures me that he understands my concerns and that he's going to get things together.  Literally, within a day or two, I hear from a mutual friend or family member that he's reverted back to doing things that are sociopathic.
supporter: Have you asked him about him taking his medication?

seeker: I have.  He tells me that he's taking it regularly (or most of the time).  I challenged him on it and told him it can't be "most of the time."  That's why I sent his doctor a long email, explaining things to him, to see if he can't intervene and try to straighten him out.
supporter: ok. dealing with someone with bi-polar disorder can be really tough and challenging but it is not there fault that they are acting the way they are. They just honestly can not help it. I know you are doing everything you can to help him and to stop him from acting that way.

seeker: You're right.  Mental illness, in all of its forms, is especially challenging.  Physical illness is more easy to understand, of course.
supporter: you are right. So do not think he is doing it on purpose. Do not let it bring you down or hurt your feelings in anyway.

seeker: Thank you.  I think you understand the sadness and anxiety in feeling powerless in this situation (or mostly powerless).  I have no real expertise in this area, but by contacting his doctor, maybe he can reevaluate whether the medicine and dosage needs to be changed.
supporter: I understand a lot.

seeker: It started about 14 months ago - at least that's when people started alerting me to strange behavior.  I thought people who were bi-polar contracted the illness earlier in their life.
supporter: How long have you known about his bi polar diorder?

seeker: Around 10 months ago is when I first found out.  Since then, I've received about 5 phone calls from people expressing concern.  I've visited him 3 times.
supporter: i got you. having a mental illness is challenging and i can provide you some suggestions.

seeker: Before we end the conversation, I'd love hearing a few of those suggestions, if you don't mind.
supporter: ok. just be there for him no matter what because you know he can not help it. Be understanding of his mental illness.

seeker: Thank you.  You've been great.  Have a nice holiday and new year!
supporter: no problem. Have a nice holiday to and remain safe.

seeker: Hello, thanks for offering to help.  My sister is battling with heroin addiction, and I am raising her children.  It's quite a bit of pressure and responsibility.
supporter: Hi! Of course. I am happy to help.

seeker: She has been in and out of rehab, and I see no end to her problems, other than a tragic one.  Thankfully, the children are adjusting to it, probably because they are happy just to be in a stable environment.
supporter: Are you raising them alone?

seeker: I have a romantic partner who helps.  I also have two of my own relatively young children.
supporter: That's a lot of children! It's great that you have a partner who can help you.

seeker: Thanks for being sympathetic and for the words of encouragement.  Yes, needless to say, Child Protective Services were involved, and I was granted Foster Parent status.  I'm sure your friend went down that road, sadly.
supporter: Yes, she did. Her children seem very lucky to have you. Do they get along with your children?

seeker: They all get along famously.   You can find that video on YouTube.  It's a true story of how his mother died from heroin addiction.  It's a powerful song.
supporter: That's so awful. the only thing you can do is show the kids love and make them feel cared for.

seeker: Thank you.  One piece of good news.  Her son went from failing most of his classes to making Honor Roll this trimester - that's what his advisor tells me.
supporter: That's so good!!!

seeker: Thanks so, much.  Have a great holiday and we'll try to do the same.
supporter: You too. Enjoy the holidays!!!

supporter: Under any circumstances, make sure you know you are not at wrong here.I hope it will not be the case but your friends might try victim blaming

supporter: I'm pretty this has happened a few times already, hasn't it?

seeker: Okay makes sense
supporter: Yes, that's good, ask them if you did something that offended them and why they excluded you. If they deny, then you can tell them how you feel. If they care about your friendship they will do something to fix

seeker: That is good advice. What is your advice if I still come out of the situation negatively (e.g. the friends do not seem to care about the friendship?)
supporter: honestly, I think you also know that if you care about someone and they feel upset, you'll do everything you can to help the situation. Therefore, if your friends refuse to acknowledge your feelings, I don't think you should be friends either

supporter: I focused a lot on myself and making more time to do some of the hobbies that I didn't get a chance to do when we were together.

supporter: I know things are really hard right now, but I know you will make it through this!

seeker: Thanks, I appreciate it. What do you suggest I should do to begin with?
supporter: Have you talked to her since she broke up with you? Sometimes it helps to talk with your ex so you can get closure on the situation.

seeker: No I haven't talked to her. I think that would only make me feel worse right now.
supporter: I understand that, have you tried to talk to a friend or family member who has gone through the same thing?

seeker: No, I haven't yet but that is a good idea.
supporter: Doing that definitely helped me too!

seeker:
I was thinking about
 going to a gym.
supporter: I think that would definitely help too!

seeker: I want to start dating in the future but I am afraid.
supporter: I felt the same way for a while after my breakup as well, but after I took my time it was good to get back into the dating game.

seeker: I appreciate the help.
supporter: No problem! I am glad I was able to help you tonight,

seeker: Hello, how are we doing today?
supporter: Good, how are you?

seeker: Not so good unfortunately.
supporter: You can tell me what's bothering you

seeker: Due to this pandemic, I fear for the safety of my job.
supporter: Totally understand your worries

seeker: Anxiety is at all time highs due to this.
supporter: Is there a reason for your fear?

seeker: My firm has already cut 10%. I feel like I might be going next.
supporter: it's important right now to take one step at a time, you should always prepare and find a backup plan in case it happens, but at the same time not worry too much because it won't help

seeker: I can't stop worrying. If I lose my job, I don't know where to go, what to do.
supporter: You should look around and see if anyone hiring

seeker: With lock downs in my area, small businesses will go under. Which means fewer jobs. I'm really scared.
supporter: You can try gig worker, being on Mturk can bring some decent money if you're diligent

seeker: Anyone tips for Mturk? I'm new to this.
supporter: I only work after office hours now so I aim for good paying gigs. Back when I had more time, I just did any gigs available

seeker: Any suggestions for gig work?
supporter: Do any work you can get, it's all about speed and willingness

seeker: Thanks for the positive vibes, but my future looks dim unfortunately.
supporter: I understand, it's hard to be positive right now

seeker: Hi, how are we doing today?
supporter: Im doing good. How are you doing today?

seeker: Not so good unfortunately.
supporter: Oh no! I'm sorry to hear that. Would you be willing to talk about it with me? Sometimes talking with someone is the help that we need.

seeker: Due to this pandemic, I fear for the safety of my job. It's cause me anxiety and stress.
supporter: I can sense how stressed you are about the safety of your job. This pandemic has caused so much stress and very much anxiety on everyone, so just know you are not alone. I'm not sure on the work you do, but you putting your health at risk everyday to make a living for you and your family makes you an amazing person. Just try and remember that your health is very much more important then your job and just make sure you are trying everything possible to keep yourself safe out there.

seeker: Thanks for the positive vibes, but I doubt things will get better.
supporter: Of course! I also am afraid that this pandemic is going to get worse before it gets any better and that is just my opinion. I am scared for everyone out here anymore and its not just people getting sick and ill, but people like you who could be in jeopardy of loosing their job or their source of income. That's is something that would be on anyones mind, more yours then mine due to you actually working in the public.

seeker: There is a lock down in my area, I fear it will only get worse.
supporter: We thankfully have not got on lockdown just yet, but I know it will be happening soon. We live in a very small town and it has got bad here that either we know someone who has it, or someone in the family has it. It seemed like it just happened over night that it just spread so fast here that everyone is in a panic mode again. What type of things do you do while you are on lockdown?

seeker: Think about the bad things that will happen if I lost my job. I have been only thinking about the bad..
supporter: I can only imagine. Is it yourself in your home? What I have tried to do is stay away from the news that has anything to do with covid that could maybe help a little. And god forbid anything happens to you and you do loose your job just know there are a lot of resources around that would help you in any struggles that you fear or end up facing. I know its hard and stressful to search and look for things like that but trust me it will take a lot of stress off your mind.

seeker: I am not religious, but thanks for the uplifting words. I just don't see a bright side over the fence.
supporter: I'm sorry about that I didn't realize I put that, sometimes it just comes out but I do apologize. I know it's hard to think that this will not come to and end, but just try and think there is always a light at the end of the tunnel, and I'm hoping for you and what your doing and putting in, something will come out positive in your favor, even if its just a small step forward. Hey its all gotta start out somewhere.

seeker: No worries. Any activity suggestions to keep my mind off of COVID-19?
supporter: Do you have children or a spouse that lives with you?

seeker: Yes, this is why, if I lose my job, my financial situation will affect the family.
supporter: I have children as well, and what I have tried to do is like a at home drive in movie night, or simple board games. I don't have a spouse but I would think maybe an inside dinner night or even a lunch date. Have the kids even help out with that. You'll be amazed on how excited they would be even if it's the little things they can help with like the seating or drawing of the menus. And for maybe the inside drive in make up little movie tickets, and candy and popcorn like a little concession stand.

seeker: Thanks for the suggestions. This pandemic has really taken a toll on me.
supporter: I completely understand. I know its hard not to think about it because it is EVERYWHERE, but if your spouse or children see or sense the stress its causing you they can also feel it, and can start stressing over it too. Even trying these things will cause a smile and a fun time for those moments that will make every one happy and not think about covid, because they will all be thinking about how much fun they are having with you and the family, and that will help with the stress even if its just a little bit.

seeker: I'm a little bummed because my friend is not only a junkie but he got arrested last week.
supporter: Ouch! Your friend got arrested for drugs last week?

seeker: He got arrested for stealing to fund his addiction.
supporter: I had a neighbor who was doing meth, and he got arrested, and that actually saved his life. He had to get sober and look at what he was doing.

seeker: Sadly my friend has been arrested a few times, spent time in prison, and is fully locked in his lifestyle. He's such a great person, very funny, nice, but he is lost
supporter: It can be very hard to watch a loved one destroy their lives. Has anyone every discussed an intervention?

seeker: He has alienated all of his friends, including me. I was the last one holding on
supporter: My husband and I actually have worked with recovering drug addicts and alcoholics. We are retired now, but still volunteer. Sometimes we have to let go of our loved ones - they have to hit rock bottom. Very hard to do, but unless they see their behavior as destructive, they don't want to change.

seeker: I agree, I'm afraid that's what I have to do. Another one of our mutual friends passed away recently to an overdose. I don't want to lose another friend.
supporter: Have you seen the serenity prayer? Knowing what to do, what not to do and accepting life really is a great thing to ask God for. We can't change others. Yet you have to find a way to have peace.

seeker: Yes. I know I have to let go. I've punished myself trying to stay in his life.
supporter: It's very hard to lose friends to addictions. It's epidemic in our society now. However, you can pray for them and look for ways to keep your life on track so you don't get lost focusing on them and not where you want to go.

seeker: all drugs are bad, but meth is a truly evil drug.
supporter: very evil, I agree, I like to write out a list of things I can do to distract myself from overly being concerned, if that makes sense. Like I take time to think about them and pray for them, then I have to move on with my life, so a list helps me think of where I want to go and how to get there. Even if it is just a list of how to clean my pantry! lol

seeker: That's a good idea.  I don't have many friends left, close friends that is, and this guy is my best friend of 20 years. We were in a touring rock band together.  He's my last close friend.
supporter: It is hard to lose friends that we have had for years. Maybe you can write that on your list -- perhaps just brainstorm ways to make new friends - take a college class, join a gym, take a dance class, volunteer at church, something like that. That way you open up yourself to make new friends.

seeker: I'm a single dad so my world is my children. I guess that's enough for me really. I just watch this guy sink and often feel like I should be doing something, but I think you're right.
supporter: I've learned the hard way, if a person doesn't want to change, I'm just beating my head against a wall. I can pray, then leave the rest to God. It seems like a lesson I learn over and over again! Hahah.

seeker: I'm hanging in there. I'm in a funk.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear things aren't going to well. What's the problem in a nutshell?

seeker: I split with my girlfriend after 5 years together last month/
supporter: Breakups can be hard, I can understand your frustration. Five years is a long time to have a relationship and then end.

seeker: I caught her cheating on me.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. That's hard to forgive and move on from that.

seeker: I'm trying to just move on but I feel so insulted. I'm mad then sad back and forth, over and over.
supporter: I find that when I have a very painful situation, I try to only thing about it for a certain amount of time. Then I make a list of things to do so I can be occupied to not think about it.

seeker: Yes, but my whole life was upended. My living situation, my friend circle is broken up over this. I don't know how to move on. Any suggestions?
supporter: Getting over a breakup will take time? Have you ever heard of DABDA? Denial (I can't believe this happened!) Anger (we all know that) Bargaining (If only I had done that, or if only - trying to make it FEEL better by imagining other scenarios - doesn't really work) Depression - sadness, then Acceptance -- we go in and out of these emotions and sometimes it can make us feel crazy, but all of them are normal in varying degrees and we don't know when they will happen.

seeker: No, but those sound like the typical stages of grief. I guess I'm in anger. I have no interest in barbagining.
supporter: I would make a list of things you have always wanted to do and then just BRAINSTORM any idea, no idea is too out there -- learn to ice skate, learn to play the ukulele, sign up for dance lessons, join the gym, go to a singles group at church, visit the elderly, volunteer somewhere.

seeker: I think I need to focus on exercise. Just get my body and mind healthy and full of energy. What do you think?
supporter: I also find it helpful not only to limit how much I dwell on my pain, but make sure I reach out to help someone else. I will tell you, that is the secret to happiness. Maybe help a neighbor with groceries or hanging lights. Old people (me) love help, bake something or call your aunt or uncle.

seeker: True, but it's hard not to dwell. It's not like I have a choice. It overcomes me.
supporter: I agree, get healthy and try to help others. One thing about feelings is that if you change your mind, you can change your feelings, it might happen slowly, but if you put your mind off of it, it will help. Not saying NEVER feel the emotions, but feelings are the tail of the dog, not the dog itself, You do not have to be ruled by them. You don not have to FEEL like going for a walk to go for a walk.

seeker: It's hard not to just drown myself in booze and cannabis.
supporter: A healthy balance of self care, and other centered behavior and know this will take time. I just takes time.

seeker: Time heals all wounds for sure
supporter: I understand, but those are choices that really, long term, are not for your benefit. Her cheating was a reflection on HER bad character, not yours. You have to love yourself and try to fight this.

seeker: Are you Ai or a human mturker?
supporter: I'm a human. I live in KY, retired counselor! hhahaha I prayed for someone to encourage.

seeker: OH cool. Well your prayer came true. I'm, also a human....from Georgia
supporter: I'm from the city, so there isn't much to do on a farm in the middle of cold weather. I have been through a lot of breakups, so I know what works, and yes, I was cheated on, devastating. But you can overcome this. Make that list and do NOT let your feelings rule your life. You can recover and find someone worthy of your love and care.

seeker: Thanks so much!!! I really appreciate it! :)
supporter: The WORST breakup came a year before I met my husband. in retrospect, it was the best thing, listen,you could have married this girl, count your blessings. cheating is just terribly destructive. And you are welcome. Take care of yourself. Write the list of goals and fun things to do, choose one every day.

seeker: You are very kind! All the best!! Take care!
supporter: Bye now! God bless!

seeker: I could be better.
supporter: Sorry to hear. What's going on?

seeker: i'm having difficulty dealing with a coworker that doesn't take constructive feedback on standard work procedures well and is now starting her own investigation.
supporter: Sorry to hear that. An investigation on who? you?

seeker: Me and my manager. She feels that we are targeting her.
supporter: That's unfortunately. Have you talked to someone in upper management about this?

seeker: I have talked to him about past issues with her but not this most recent. I'm trying to give myself some time to talk to him because I'm still very angry and don't want to talk with so much emotion
supporter: That is understandable. People can be hard to deal with at times. What did the co-worker do that upset you?

seeker: We have a set process of how we are to screen employees as they enter the workplace.  She doesn't follow the procedures or makes up her own way to do them because she is lazy to either stand up or greet them.  She is also rude at times to customers and has an attitude that is not friendly.
supporter: Oh, that's unfortunate. Have you brought this issue to upper management in the past?

seeker: I have and so my manager sent a general memo reminding employees about our standard operating procedures.  And from that memo, she thinks it's only about her and that we are discriminating against her.
supporter: Sorry to hear. Has upper management done anything about this issue?

seeker: I haven't taken it past my immediate manager but I may have to at this point if she is looking to file a grievance or submit a statement that we are discriminating her.
supporter: Well, in my opinion, I think you did the right thing. Has anyone else mentioned her rudeness in the past?

seeker: Thank you.  Yes others that have worked with her share say the same thing about her rudeness and laziness on the job.  I am probably going to submit some kind of report or statement to upper management.
supporter: I was wondering, how long has she been an employee at your work?

seeker: I'm just unsure because I have not documented the  incidents that I have had with her.
supporter: No, I think you did the right thing.

seeker: Thank you.  With everything going on in the world right now, it's frustrating to have to deal with this person also...
supporter: Well, I hope everything works out for you.

seeker: I'm looking for support in regards to a recent break up
supporter: sorry i'm here

supporter: First of all, I have a fre questions to ask

seeker: What's the fre question? what is fre?
supporter: I would say you should cut tie with him. Being  into porn is a serious issue but what's more important is he lied to you about that

supporter: I think you can also feel it yourself that there's something not right between you and him

seeker: I appreciate your thoughts.
supporter: This is a wake up call for you I must say, to get away from him

seeker: I feel like I really can't trust him and find myself looking through his computer and phone questioning things. makes me feel crazy.
supporter: I understand how you feel, it's not easy to get over this feeling

seeker: Is this a clean site or do people use it for porn chat?
supporter: That's why you need some time for yourself to think whether you can forgive him and try to help him or not

seeker: I know . That sounds like great advice. Hard to pull off during the pandemic though.
supporter: To be honest, watching porn is normal, however, I feel that if someone is too into it, as in watch it more than 1-2 times a month, it's problematic and won't be easy to fix

seeker: Ah. I think it's more of a real issue when it comes to controlling himself or using sites because he was single for so long. He is currently staying with me.
supporter: You can ask him to stop doing that for you, if he really cares, he will try

seeker: His latest obsession has been 3d printing. I have found weird sites with ' funny'' dildos on them in his feed and stored data. Do you think he might be gay?
supporter: goodness

seeker: stored data with adult printed groups on fb! dildos with star wars themes. Immature stuff. IDK.?
supporter: That you have to ask him, tell him to have an honest thought, no judgement, be completely honest with each other

seeker: He laughs when I show him mens underwear. I think maybe that's a sign he's uncomfortable. What do you think?
supporter: Yeah, laughs can definitely be a sign of someone getting nervous

seeker: Yep That's what I thought too. He does have a few close male friends. Nothing that looks suspicious though.
supporter: Whether he's gay or not, it's hard to say just from a few things, but what's more important right now is for you two to sit down and talk

seeker: I wonder if there is a way to find out why he joined all of these weird servers and is trying to learn code. Is it really for 3d printing or is it to make a secret platform to hide his data etc?
supporter: Maybe it's just simple as he tells you, but you have to talk to him.There is no use sitting here and let all those thoughts and questions consume you

seeker: Have you ever used jatos? or done any surveys for the universities?
supporter: What is jatos?

seeker: It's a link I found while searching but it turns out to be a server that is used for studies.
supporter: oh interesting

seeker: JATOS
supporter: I just use my experience and try to help

seeker: just another tool for online studies
supporter: Is there any problems you need help with?

seeker: I think that You have helped me allot. Thank you!
supporter: no problems

seeker: Hello. Is anyone there
supporter: Hello. How are you today?

seeker: I'm doing good. I need some advice
supporter: What can I help you with?

seeker: Lately, my friends started to make jokes about my face being ugly. They even called my face as flat as a pan! What should I do? I see them everyday on the bus
supporter: Have you tried confronting them and asking why they are being bullies?

seeker:
I did and they respond by saying that they are just joking and that I'm handsome. But it's starting to get on my nerves because it's all they make fun about every time
 they see me!
supporter: I'm sure you are very handsome! They could just be jealous.

seeker: Haha I would hope so
supporter: I understand, school was tough for me too.

seeker: Should I just beat them up with my backpack
supporter: No, beating them up will only get you in trouble and that won't help.

seeker: There's another bus route. Should I just take that instead
supporter: I think that could be a good idea if it's not too far out of your way.

seeker: I think I will. Their comments make me very insecure
supporter: You could also tell a teacher what is happening. They will help you out.

seeker: The teacher would probably make fun of me!
supporter: Try to tell yourself you are good looking and deserve good things to happen every morning! Look in that mirror and tell yourself good things.

seeker: I'll try to be positive for once.
supporter: Working out will help a lot! When I was feeling down on myself I decided to go to the gym three times a week. It was a great confidence boost.

seeker: Awesome. I will start to take care of myself and not worry about others then.
supporter: That sounds like a fantastic idea.

seeker: Hi, how are you doing today?
supporter: Are you there?

seeker: Yes I am. How are you?
supporter: I am okay and yourself?

seeker: Not so good these days.
supporter: I have had a lot of bad days in the past talking it out with friends helped me get through it.

seeker: That's good to hear, though I don't have any friends. Now I feel even more depressed.
supporter: How long has this been going on?

seeker: My depression? 3 years unfortunately.
supporter: That is really upsetting to hear. But I think that you can get better.

seeker: I doubt it.
supporter: After I had my daughter I had severe depression and thought that there was no way out, I went to the hospital and they referred me to a psychiatrist so I could get help.

seeker: Good to hear that you're doing good. I am taking medication for my depression currently.
supporter: I can say that it didn't get better over night, it  took years of medication adjustments and a great therapist to get me through since I also did not have friends at the time and an unsupportive family.

seeker: Thanks for the positive vibes. I am trying to do activities to past the time. Like reading.
supporter: Reading is a great coping skill. What are some of your favorite things to read about?

seeker: Mainly self improvement books. Any genre suggestions?
supporter: I recently read a study that suggested that reading fiction may lead to inceased empathy and this increased empathy help the reader basically pay it forward by being more willing to do good deads.

seeker: Good to know. I will definitely check it out. Any title recommendation?
supporter: The study suggests that the story be upbeat and be very discriptive of positive messages. I would avoid sad stories.

seeker: So it really happened just like that
supporter: What happened?

seeker: My life just got flipped-turned upside down
supporter: It seems like you are feeling a little bit like the Fresh Prince of Bell-Air.

seeker: First diagnosis was accurate so I can only trust you from here on out
supporter: Sounds good. I am glad that you trust me. What did the strange machine do?

seeker: When it didn't quite work, my folks just quit so I decided to take a look inside of it
supporter: I can see that you are taking this opportunity as a joke.

seeker: What would you rather we discuss?
supporter: I am here as your peer-supporter to help you. Is there anything that you have been struggling with recently?

seeker: Just everyday sluggishness and feeling down
supporter: When did this start?

seeker: last year is when I got diagnosed
supporter: It sounds like you had a life-changing diagnosis last year. How has it affected your life?

seeker: been getting lit a lot
supporter: I know getting "lit" is an easy way to deal with our problems, but it is not always the healthiest thing to do.

seeker: It's more like constantly feeling like there's a weight on my chest, tired but can't fall asleep, and having a terrible appetite
supporter: Life can be really hard, but I know you can turn things around!

seeker: Life has been getting better despite it but doesn't feel like my mood improves for long
supporter: Do you have any close friends or family that you can talk to?

seeker: I talk to my gf about it but doesn't really improve anything
supporter: I think that's great that you have a girlfriend whom you can talk to!

seeker: Yeah probably the best play and we got over 15min
supporter: Good luck with everything, bye!

seeker: Hello.  Maybe you can help me calm down.  I just found out that I'm losing my job in January. (1)
supporter: Hello! I hope I can.

seeker: Yes and that worries me even more.  More people competing for the same jobs. (2)
supporter: That's a fare worry but you can't be discourged. YOu need to think positively.

seeker: I will have to do a new resume definitely. It's been awhile. (3)
supporter: That's a good activity !! Do you have anyone who can help you with it?

seeker: I'll have to think on that, I have a friend that might be able to help but it's been awhile for both of us (4)
supporter: Do you have any hobbies you can work on while you're home?

seeker: Well I don't think they are hobbies, but there are things that need to be done around the house.  Guess I can keep myself busy at least (5)
supporter: That's really helpfuL! staying busy is good.

seeker: Yes, but I know I'll also have a lot of work to do to get ready to find a new job.  I'm really hoping I can find one before I lose this one (6)
supporter: HAve you been searching online sites? They post so many nowadays! If you spend a few hours a day. i'm sure that you'll find one in no time!!

seeker: I looked at indeed and I did apply to one thing.  But when it came back to me it said that 4970 other people had applied for the same job! (7)
supporter: That happens but keep looking. It's a numbers game, so you have to just apply to a ton them once your resume is ready.

seeker: I wish I knew how to make myself stand out more.  So many people are out there looking for work. (8)
supporter: There are online career counselors or resume helpers, they can help you figure out how to make your resume stand out. What industry are you in?

seeker: I'm an accountant (9)
supporter: So you're smart! You will defintiely find a job, i have total faith in you.

seeker: Well, with numbers at least!  I just worry about companies that aren't able to be open, well they won't need an accountant. (10)
supporter: I think with the vaccine coming, things will be going back to normal soon enough! They already started giving the vaccine out.

seeker: Hello.  I will be losing my job in January.  I am very worried (1)
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. Why is it that you are losing your job?

seeker: The company just has to make cut backs and a lot of us are being furloughed. (2)
supporter: I had the same situation not too long ago when the IT department I worked for realigned and my position was cut and I was laid off, so I completely understand the situation.

seeker: It is so hard to even contemplate finding a new job in this economy. (3)
supporter: Just from sharing a few messages with you, I can tell how anxious you are about this,

seeker: Yes, it has me very worried.  I have bills and kids and a husband - I need a job. (4)
supporter: I know how difficult this situation is, but I know you will be able to get through this!

seeker: I've tried to get in touch with the unemployment office, but they are not answering the phones there I guess (5)
supporter: I know unemployment offices have been very busy during this pandemic

seeker: Ours does not even appear to be open.  I thought they would be able to provide some help. (6)
supporter: I would think that would be a good resource to start. Have you updated your resume and cover letter?

seeker: No I need to do both of those things.  I have not needed a resume for over 10 years (7)
supporter: I would definitely update both, it helps to show new employers all of your relevant experience and what you have been doing.

seeker: Yes I will have to look into the new ways people do them now.  I'm sure things have changed (8)
supporter: Another thing that might help would be to talk to the others who are being furloughed and see what plans they have to get through this,

seeker: I thought about that but then worried we'd be looking for the same jobs and they may not want to share tips (9)
supporter: I think they would be more than willing to share tips! Networking is great!

seeker: Hello. Is anyone here?
supporter: hello

seeker: I need a bit of advice
supporter: Sure, what is going on?

seeker: My partner of 4 years... i never thought this would happen but they ended up cheating on me
supporter: I am truly sorry you had to witness that. Would you feel more comfortable with them leaving or do you think either relationship is salvagable?

seeker: That's my current problem. I do still love them but... what would happen if I stay and we work on our relationship?
supporter: If you feel that something might be salvageable it might be worth looking into. Do you think they'd be open to sitting down and talking it out?

seeker: They did end up crying and saying that it was a mistake. I don't know if it would be a good idea. I think I would have feelings of regret
supporter: I think that either way you choose to proceed there is always the choice of remaining amicable. You're all adults, so sitting down and discussing what comes next is an inevitability. Maybe they will choose to leave, or you'll decide it would be better for you to go, but at least the discussion would be ongoing to perhaps resume the friendship at a later time?

seeker: I'll give it a shot to talk with them. Do you think there would be hateful feelings even if we decided to resume the friendship?
supporter: If you're trying your best to move on and the other party ends up with hateful feelings then I feel like at least you gave it your best right? It might be worth laying low for a little while to sort through the feelings of mistrust and betrayal.

seeker: That is true. I probably will give it some time to decide on a best course of action. I just needed someone to talk to.
supporter: I'm glad I could help

seeker: Thanks again friend!
supporter: I would talk to them as soon as you feel comfortable enough to do so. It might get awkward and leave people to come to other conclusions if it's avoided for too long.

seeker: That's true. Right now I think it would be too awkward to talk
supporter: That is completely understandable. Maybe take a day or two to collect your thoughts. Do you have somewhere to be alone to sift through your feelings?

seeker: hello, I need some help
supporter: Hi, tell me all do you want to say!

seeker: I have my friends and family that have been very supportive but I guess its just going to take some time.
supporter: It absolutely will take time. You are right. Can I suggest that you try to look at what went wrong before getting involved with someone else? Would it be possible to talk with your friends and family about what they think might have happened?

seeker: Yep, thats a great idea. I definitely plan to take some time to thing about everything that happened. I feel blindsided but ultimately I think just spending time with my friends and family will help.
supporter: I'm sure it will help to be with people who love you when you feeling so devastated.

seeker: Exactly, it just happened at a time when the holidays are coming up and you want to spend it with people you care about.
supporter: I hear you. All messages this time of year are about being with people we love and that will hit you hard at this time of year. Do you have any particular things you like to do to take care of yourself?

seeker: I enjoy snowboarding as a hobby. I might try to get back on my board depending on what locations are open. It's just hard right now with having no motivation to really do anything.
supporter: Yes. when you are depressed it is hard to become motivated to do anything. However, it is extremely important that you do act. Keep moving through your days, even if you feel like you are in a haze. It may take awhile to build up to snowboarding. Maybe start with a daily walk and build from there. Action (physically doing something) triggers psychological movement. It will help you move through the pain that you are feeling.

seeker: Thank you! I really appreciate your advice. I will try my best to build myself back up, I know the coming days will be hard, but as long as I keep trying then things should eventually get better. Thank you again for talking to me today. Its been extremely helpful. Have a great rest of the week!
supporter: Thank you so much for asking for help.  It has been so nice talking with you. Take care and know that in time this pain you are feeling will become less and less intense. Have a great rest of your week!

supporter: Is it crucial that you be in the South versus Northwestern region? Are you willing to lose her in order to move South?

seeker:
It
'
supporter: A compromise would definitely be the best and most fair for both of you. You may just need to sit down and ask some tough questions to determine where she sees things. She may be thinking the same thing you are.

supporter: Somewhat but not identical. My now husband and I attended different colleges and we both agreed on a fairly selfish approach of finding our careers while dating and not letting our relationship dictate what either one of us did. No one wants to be the reason someone holds back or gives up on something they've always wanted.

seeker: I don't think that's selfish, but knowing your experience is helpful in understanding your advice.
supporter: You don't want her to resent you for telling her you want her to move South, but that goes both ways. She needs to be willing to see your side too and you'll need to make those decisions together.

seeker: I appreciate your help! I'll try to have a productive conversation with her soon.
supporter: Great, the sooner the better. I have a feeling you'll both be relieved when you do.

I don't know if it's something she's considered, because I've expressed interest in moving to the northwest just for fun, but I've also noted that the schools I'm actually looking at are Arizona and New Mexico. I do think the field she wants to go into could be applicable in almost any state, but I'll be gentle. I don't want to lose her, so if I need to look into a different section of my field, I definitely could.
supporter: I'm sure she's considered it, expressing interest in both of those areas could just be that you're sending mixed messages too. So really, just talking it out is your best bet. Good luck!

supporter: as long as you believe in yourself to be honest, don't worry about what other people think. Your boss will come to understand you are a honest worker. It is also amazing that you have come such a long way without having other problems. that is great!

supporter: Yes, i understand what you are saying. It's really hard to move on from bad experiences, staying positive is important in these situations.

seeker: Yes. I guess so. You are right. I just going to move on and do my things
supporter: There's no need to thank me! i hope I could make you feel better.

seeker: Yes you did. God bless you and have a good one
supporter: Yes, you too! have an amazing rest of your day!

seeker: Hi
supporter: hello

supporter: How are you feeling now?

supporter: Have you seek therapy? Even if they can't lessen the pain, at least you have a place to vent out

seeker: I have not for this particular issue, I tried it in the past and didn't like it too much.
supporter: You can ask around to see if your friends know anyone good. If not, I'd suggest joining a group of people of the same problem where you can talk to each other
