supporter: Yes I have, I lost one of my friends by suicide, It's very difficult and took years for me to somehow get over it

supporter: I just cried my heart out, I talked to my other friends just to get it out of my heart

seeker: How long was it before you felt normal again?
supporter: 2-3 years, at first I thought it was over but once in a while I would think of him and had this sharp pain in my chest. I tried to busy myself with work and other stuff too.

seeker: I try to do the same thing.
supporter: I know it's very tough, especially when it's sudden like that but we can only do our best

supporter: of course, I hope you feel better

supporter: Both will help. But ebooks are easier to get and you don't need to contact anyone and anything outside your home.

supporter: I like biographies. Stories of real people are inspiring.

supporter: That is a great idea! Dog is human's best friend. I would love to have a dog myself.

supporter: I don't have a dog, because I like to travel. However I have taken care of other people's dogs a lot when I am home.

supporter: We are in similar situation. These days I only go out for grocery shopping.

supporter: Yeah, economy cannot do well if this situation drags on. Hope the vaccine will soon be approved and life can be back to normal.

seeker: When do you think things will go back to normal?
supporter: Based on the news and information I read, I think things should get better by the next spring.

seeker: Hi :)
supporter: Hello! How are you doing today??

supporter: I understand that you are going through a stressful time with finishing up finals. Are you doing anything to destress

supporter: That is awesome! Sometimes it is really hard to take time for yourself.

seeker: Yeah, it can be difficult to convince myself that being good to myself isn't just me being lazy. I've gotten a lot better at this during the quarantine though!
supporter: It is tough to take time, I am glad that you are making time for it. This time in quarantine has been helpful for everyone to slow down a little. Making it easier for us to give ourselves more self care.

seeker: I have enjoyed that aspect a lot. It has definitely been tough being isolated from my friends though. I wish America would've just handled this properly :(
supporter: I know, in the end we can only control what we do. It has been hard to be away from everyone. Have you been able to use any video chatting to help bridge the gap?

seeker: Yes, video chat has been good. A lot of my interactions were like that before anyways, so it has gotten pretty stale though.
supporter: At this point in the quarantine it has been hard to keep going with these strange practices. I have found some comfort in returning to the normalcy of a regular phone call. Are you self isolating alone, or are you fortunate to be with others.

seeker: It's just me and my small family. I was at college but moved home a few weeks ago. At school we were just as isolated though.
supporter: I have heard that is the norm among colleges. That has to be really tough. So much of college is in the experience of being with other young people. You are fortunate because you are learning skills like how to be really flexible when it comes to tough times.

seeker: Yeah, I always try and remember that I've got it pretty good in these times
supporter: Is there anything else that is going on aside from the isolation that is stressing you out?

supporter: I totally understand. It has been really tough. What are the things that you miss the most in this time?

seeker: I'm so sad
supporter: Hi, so from what I understand you are feeling sadness at this moment due to your partner leaving you for someone else.

seeker: Yes! I can't believe he did this to me
supporter: Just from the few messages you sent, I can tell this is really hurting you a lot.

seeker: I feel so sad. I just want to crawl into a hole and die.
supporter: I had a similar situation where my fiancé left me after cheating on me and getting pregnant by another man, so I understand completely what you are feeling.

seeker: We were so in love! How could he do this to me?
supporter: This is a really hard situation to get through, but I know that you can do this!

seeker: How? Please tell me how? I don't feel like I could ever be happy again
supporter: Whenever I am feeling upset about the situation I look at all the good things I have going for me, like my job, and my family, and my health.

seeker: I lost my job a few months ago. I do have kids though.
supporter: From what we have talked about so far, I can see how losing your job would also make you much more anxious.

seeker: Yes! i have been struggling so much with losing my job! And now this. How am I going to get through this?
supporter: Yes, your kids definitely need you and they will help. I would make sure to play with them and get together and maybe watch some holiday movies or videos since it is so close to Christmas.

seeker: I will try, but it will be hard. Christmas just won't be the same this year.
supporter: What are some of your favorite things to do during Christmas time?

seeker: I like to make ornaments with my kids, and shop for family, and wrap presents.
supporter: I would spend time making ornaments with your kids to help get through this time!

seeker: Yes. That is a great idea! Thank you.
supporter: You are very welcome! I am glad you chatted with me today.

seeker: You have been so helpful. I am glad I could find someone to talk to.
supporter: I'm so happy I was able to help.

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi from Michigan! How are you doing today?

seeker: Im going pretty good, just trying to get through laundry
supporter: Ugh! That's a never ending battle for me! Do you have a lot of it?

seeker: Not too bad, it's more so the folding and putting away afterward that seems to take the longest.
supporter: That's the worst part. I've given up on folding.

seeker: It does feel good to put things away though, my room has been a tornado recently, just not feeling like doing much these days. The pandemic crazies hit pretty hard recently.
supporter: I can relate. This whole year has been a mess.

supporter: Do you think you're staying away from people because you're supposed to or you're afraid of getting sick?

seeker: I would definitely say both. I also don't live near any family or friends anymore. I moved to a totally new place a few months before the pandemic
supporter: It's hard to be optimistic when everything seems so uncertain. I can't imagine how lonely that would feel especially in a new place.

seeker: Yup.
supporter: Are you still keeping in contact with your friends and family back home?

seeker: As much as possible, but it's never the same.
supporter: It really isn't. That's such a hard situation to be in.  I really can't think of much of a solution unfortunately.

seeker: There's no need to find a solution, really. It's just sucks, and that's okay
supporter: I guess in a way this whole thing has been an eyeopener for you. Are you considering moving back home when this is over?

seeker: Haha no way that place sucks. :)
supporter: Very true about perseverance. I think everyone is feeling a bit depressed at this point.

seeker: It's very easy to. Just watching old videos with crowds of people is so strange and nostalgic
supporter: You seem to have a good mindset about everything. You should try doing the support side of this next time! lol

supporter: No problem, you too! These are actually pretty decent hits. Slave wage though lol

seeker: Agreed. It's better than nothing though
supporter: True! Keeps it interesting and some cash flow! Have a good night :) Hope ya get to explore the world soon.

supporter: hi, how can i help?

supporter: i see. so if your firm starts making staff cuts, you think you'll be one of the folks they let go?

supporter: can you share a bit about what type of work you do?

supporter: I see. well the great thing about accountants is that every business needs them, regardless of the economy

supporter: it is pretty rough. unemployment has hit a huge spike and there are a lot of people who are moving away to find better opportunities

supporter: i've managed and coached a lot of people in my career, and i think what's important to keep in mind in how you adapt to the current situation

supporter: of course! Can you tell me what is going on? IS there areason you are feeling stressed?

supporter: That is a lot to have on your plate.

seeker: Yes it is
supporter: I totally understand how you feel. This pandemic has ruined a lot of things this year.

seeker: Any advice
supporter: Is it possible for your partner to help with some of the load?

seeker: We both work full time so we are both trying to balance it out
supporter: I feel you. My kids have been at home during this pandemic because the schools are shut down and I cannot imagine what the parents working full time and dealing with this are going through.

seeker: It is hard to do well being a parent and being successful at work
supporter: Have you tried simplifying your routines? Cutting yourself some slack hereand there?

seeker: I’ve tried but that’s easier said then done.
supporter: I totally understand. These days we have this expectation to be perfect, but it is so important to show yourself some grace.

seeker: That you that is good advice. How are you balancing it?
supporter: Some things I do with my family after a stressful day is order a pizza and have a movie night, this seems to help everyone relax a bit. Things I do personally for myself is take a warm bath with some hot tea. I also go for a short walk when it is warm enough outside.

seeker: That is wonderful advice. I like the walking part. Get some fresh air.
supporter: As a mom, I struggle with that too, trying to get everything done, while being present. But i do find that with kids, the more simple the better. They just want us and out time. things do not have to be complex, even small things reading a bedtime story, or actually sitting down together for dinner helps.

seeker: Thank you that helps a lot
supporter: Thank you for talking with me! I hope things get easier! Have a greatnight !

seeker: Just found out my position will be eliminated in January.  Freaking out! 1
supporter: Wow.  So you're being laid off soon?

seeker: Yes.  Apparently the company just can't continue to operate and pay all of us.  So my position will be gone.  They said they may be able to hire me back after all the Covid stuff, but couldn't guarantee it 2
supporter: I've been laid off many times.  Never gets easier.

seeker: It is hard emotionally - as well as financially.  I tried calling the unemployment office to find out what help they may have but no one answered me. 3
supporter: Your not getting the unemployment office to respond seems to be a common problem.  They weren't geared up for this.  Fortunately, the online portal has been helpful for many.

seeker: I will have to look at that.  I've not been in the job market for 25 years.  I thought they may be able to provide some assistance in just where do I begin. 4
supporter: You want to know where to start.  Sounds like you are young.

seeker: Well not as young as I once was - in my 40s. 5
supporter: Teachers are wonderful!  Experienced teachers are even better.  Age 40 is still young enough to be competitive in today's market.  You will get lots of job interviews and offers before you know it.

seeker: I'm concerned because now is just not the normal time they hire new teachers on.  Plus a lot of the school systems around me are all virtual right now, so I'm concerned about that 6
supporter: How are your online/virtual skills?

seeker: We've used Zoom for some of our kids at my current school but it's usually one on one, not an entire classroom 7
supporter: There's many online job hunting sites that are free.  Indeed, Zip Recruiter, Craig's List, Monster, newspaper classifieds.

seeker: Yes I need to investigate those.  I got my current job right out of college and I've been there 25 years!  I'm so nervous about teaching somewhere else. 8
supporter: I feel your pain.  Being laid off is a stab to the heart.  Very disconcerting.   Sounds as if you have been thrown out of your comfort zone.

seeker: Most definitely.  Not to mention the children that depend on me, many of the children that I work with have special needs and changing their teachers can be traumatic.  So I'm worried about them as well. 9
supporter: I'm sixty and one thing I've noticed during past lay-offs is that people end up in a better position.

seeker: I hope that is the case this time around for me.  Ugh, I've got to do a new resume too!!  EEK! 10
supporter: I admire your dedication to the children.  They will always have a place in their heart for you.  Fortunately, children are resilient so the trauma could be short-lived for them.

seeker: Hi.

supporter: From what I have seen, the vaccine will be coming soon to the United States and after we get that we will be in much better shape.

supporter: I completely understand where you are coming from. I also work in a grocery store and with being around a lot of people all day I also worry at times about COVID-19.

supporter: Yes, in my store all employees and customers must wear masks and our store provides masks to those who don't have them.

supporter: Yes, is yours?

supporter: I like comedy movies.

seeker: Hello
supporter: How are you feeling?

supporter: I understand. I have been feeling the same way lately -- my family has been distracted and stressed and it's rubbing off on me. Are there other people around that you can spend time with?

seeker: Not really, I'm not a people person and the couple people I do talk to aren't supportive or going thru their own issues.
supporter: I understand. It seems to me that much of what makes the holidays worthwhile is the opportunity to spend time with people we care about. It makes sense that you would have a hard time celebrating with nobody there to share it with you.

seeker: I have my family to share it with, my husband and kids. The teenagers are more about me buying them stuff and getting presents, and we're broke so I haven't been able to do the things I want to with my toddler.
supporter: (Even if you don't talk to them much, do you think it would be worth reaching out to them?)

seeker: Outside of my household, I have my grandparents and some sibblings I don't talk to much.
supporter: Do you remember enjoying the holidays more when your kids were younger?

seeker: Absolutely! They always had great Christmases. I feel they're takking away from my toddler's christmas
supporter: I see. Do you know what has changed? You said that the teenagers are more interested in getting presents than actually celebrating the holiday itself. Is that a major reason? What about your husband?

seeker: That and the teenagers aren't listening well. They're kinda out of control. I don't think they deserve a Christmas, because they need to learn responsibility.
supporter: I see. You are frustrated with them because of the way they have been behaving. What do you think they should be doing differently?

seeker: Exactly. Sorry if I'm taking a minute to respond. I just got put into 2 of these things at once where I'm a supporter lol. It's much harder. But yes, I'm in Michigan.
supporter: Oh, that's okay. :)

seeker: Do you have kids?
supporter: Something I tend to struggle with is the way things change over time, when they can never go back to the way they were before. When my sisters and I were little, it seemed like everything in the world was so much simpler, and we had certain Christmas traditions that we always looked forward to, like cutting down a tree, making pumpkin pie, and singing carols and Christmas hymns together. As we've gotten older it seems like our family has gotten split apart a bit more and everyone is too stressed and hurried to enjoy the old things that we used to do. That has been pretty hard for me because things used to be so much different. Has that been difficult for you, as well? Just the fact that things are different now than when your kids were little.

seeker: Yes! Exactly. You're very wise for your age! I am sure they feel similar to how you do. They're grown up and not able to appreciate the Christmas magic.
supporter: Thank you for talking! Oh, one thing--

seeker: Oh my goodness that would be amazing. Bree Fair 4481 Division  St Wayland MI 49348
supporter: Okay. Who should I address it to?

seeker: Have a nice night wherever you are in mturk land :)
supporter: Oh, right. Okay. Good night and Merry Christmas!

seeker: Feeling a little stressed
supporter: I am so sorry that you are feeling stressed, what's going on?

seeker: I have a big essay due on Monday and I can’t bring myself to write it
supporter: I completely understand I've been there myself, finding motivation can be so hard, but I know you can do it!

seeker: How did you get motivated? Do you have any advice?
supporter: I always thought of my GPA and how a single grade could affect all of my hard work. Perhaps thinking of what this grade can affect will motivate you to really avoid any stressful situations it may bring.

seeker: Yeah to be fair this is a big part of my degree so I can’t not do it. I just find the subject so hard compared to some of the other ones I’ve done so far. It’s a lot of maths which I suck at
supporter: I have been there, I major in Biotechnology engineering. Image what life will be like once you are finished with this nightmare assignment. Give it your all. Find that fire inside of you and push through. You are almost there, remember everything you have overcome, dont let this little hurdle set you back. I have faith in you!

seeker: Wow, biotech engineering must have been cool. Makes my economics module seem a bit silly now haha. I think I’m just getting frustrated with myself which is annoying in itself when I know deep down I probably could do it if I stopped trying to avoid it
supporter: oh no! my best friend has a business major and economics class almost killed her. she took it FOUR times before she passed it. She never gave up! this is your dream, chase it, own it, and conquer it.

seeker: I’m glad I’m not the only one who struggles with economics although I definitely don’t want to have to retake it haha. I guess I will have to retake it if I don’t actually do the work though!
supporter: My poor friend, economics in itself is a beast that only unique minds understand. But, I do believe that with effort and dedication. She will be so mad for telling someone else how many times she fail the class. You can do it! you are at the end!

seeker: I am feeling angry today about work.
supporter: Oh no, what happened to make you feel this way?

seeker: My coworker expects me to do things the way she does and is constantly critical. I just want her to understand that I am able to do things my way and it is still okay. I told her this and she ignored me.
supporter: I'm sure that's terribly frustrating having someone treat you like that. Is this something that your boss is aware of?

seeker: I have not told her yet. I do not want to get her into trouble and I want to have a good relationship with her.
supporter: Can you discuss it with her in a respectful way to get her to understand that you're not trying to undermine her but that this is how you work most efficiently? And maybe mention that you don't want to involve the boss?

seeker: That's something I could try. I really care about my coworker and it makes me so angry that she treats me this way.
supporter: I think sometimes it's easy to jump to anger when you feel hurt. It might be worth telling her how you feel and also maybe ask why she thinks you should be doing things her way. Maybe there's a give and take in this situation. Some of her methods could be beneficial.

seeker: Do you have any advice on how to start my conversation with her? I have found some of her ideas to be beneficial. I just would like my ideas expressed as well. I feel we can learn from each other.
supporter: Tell her the things that you like about her method and maybe suggest some of your methods to her as well. Maybe she'll find them to be more efficient. Make it a partnership rather than a fight for whose method is better.

seeker: That's a great idea. It is possible. I am the new kid on the block. I will try by being non confrontational. Any specific ideas to how  I can do that? She gets offended easily. I want her to know I am helping.
supporter: I'd suggest how much she's helped you since you are in fact the new kid on the block.  And tell her that you want to work with her to have the most efficient partnership possible and use each of your talents to the best of your ability. Then you can lay out how you work best and see where it goes from there.

seeker: Thanks! I will try that. You made me feel so much better!
supporter: I'm so glad, these can be frustrating situations but sometimes it's worth looking at the other person's perspective.

seeker: I agree. Sometimes you just have to take a step back and have a conversation with someone not in the thick of it.
supporter: Absolutely, I have no emotional stake in this. The two of you do and that can cloud things sometimes.

seeker: I think people get territorial when they have worked somewhere and a new person comes in. I see that now. I am optimistic we will work it out and be a great team!
supporter: That's great to hear, I'm glad we were able to chat!

seeker: Me too! You really helped me. Have a wonderful day! I know I will since you helped me out.
supporter: That's great, good luck!

seeker: hi
supporter: Hi! How are you today?

supporter: I'm doing well. How can I help you today?

supporter: I understand feeling connected to someone you've only known for a short amount of time. I'm sure you feel like you wont be able to let your guard down again anytime soon.

seeker: yes i have faith in people very fast
supporter: Maybe this could be a learning experience? I always try to see the best in people, but have learned to let people earn my trust. Not just get it for free.

supporter: Ok,  can you tell me how long ago this happened.

seeker: a week ago.
supporter: So your girlfriend broke up with you a week ago and you have no idea how to move forward. Is that correct

seeker: yes. she was my rock.
supporter: You know I am sure that hurts but  like they say  that "time heals all wounds"

seeker: but, i have been with her for 3 years.  She is a part of my everyday life. we split household chores. now im overwhelmed
supporter: That is a long time. Event though she was your rock,  just know that you will eventually find someone new and this hurt will be no more.

seeker: But im not sure how to survive in the time being.  my life will be a disaster.
supporter: I can feel your pain,  i have had similar experience and it took quite a while to move on, but know that this too will pass

seeker: I dont have the time to do all she did to maintain my house.  What am i supposed to do now she is gone.
supporter: There was a time when I had a breakup that left me feeling like it was the end of the world,  but i am fine now and  so would you.  Take some long walks but he sure to socially distance and try meeting new friends online and just talk.  That will help

seeker: But what about my dishes, and bathroom cleaning that she did, and i dont have time to do?
supporter: think about it,  the added exercise will help you from getting lonely with her not being around

seeker: But  i have never done laundry.  My mother did it when i lived with her. and i moved out from my mother to live with my girlfriend. How am i gonna do my laundry? I've never done it.
supporter: If you focus too much on the break up,  you will have a hard time getting over her so try to do some fun activities that you can enjoy alone  so that you are safe.  You can search youtube on how to do laundry and other chores,  you will be ok

seeker: Thank you for your advice.  It probably isnt that hard. I just am nervous about trying to do it myself for the first time.  Its starting to pile up now.
supporter: Don't be nervous,  Just take some time to learn the house chores and you'll be fine

seeker: It'll be new, but i guess i could at least try.  But i miss her so much.  I dont think i can ever find someone else like her.
supporter: You will find that someone. Hope I was able to make you feel a bit better.

seeker: You are very positive.  I wish i had your positivity.
supporter: Think of the glass half full.   You will do well.

seeker: Exactly. Jogging, eating breakfast, getting dressed
supporter: Yep, for me it's kind of felt like working remotely and all the crazy 2020 stuff was kind of an excuse to just "take a break" from grinding. MTurk has kind of helped me get back in a working mindset and given me more energy...have you been doing a lot of MTurk lately?

seeker:
Yeah, 2020 has been a crazy year. I've been doing Mturk
 here and there. I plan on doing it more. It helps me stay productive.
supporter: Yeah it helps, just forcing yourself to have goals, for sure. I've been determined to hit a number on MTurk and exercise every time I'm feeling tired, instead of taking a nap because my boss can't see me, lol. I would definitely say just start setting goals and try to look forward to 2021 being better.

seeker: Okay, I hear you. Thanks. Yeah, I guess I have to really force myself.
supporter: Force yourself at first, then the "body in motion, stays in motion" law will take over. :)

seeker: Okay okay. cool. That's a helpful concept. I'm going to force myself to get up and then hopefully my body will get used to it. Yes, that's true. I hate ending the day knowing I've bummed it out
supporter: One of the things I've noticed about 2020 and I think this contributes is that this year has taken away almost all incentives...you know before it would be like, "I'm looking forward to this concert, or this movie coming out next weekend." So, when you aren't planning things and don't have these milestones throughout the year of events breaking up the monotony, it stinks.

seeker: Yes, I agree. I used to go to at least one concert every year. Now that's out of the question. It gets boring and a little depressing. Hopefully 2021 will be better.
supporter: I'm sure it will be. Definitely try tomorrow morning to get up and exercise and maybe hit the MTurk hard, also hobbies definitely help and being at home is a great time to learn new skills.

seeker: I will definitely. I just got to get up and get with it. I'm really in need of some exercise so I'll do that too. I used to paint and draw but I kind of fell off and stopped doing it. I'll get back into that too.
supporter: Oh yeah, nothing is worse than losing joy in something you love doing. But, getting back in an active mindset helps. I used to love to have bonfires, it really was therapeutic for me but then I just lost the will to have them. Since I've been back on MTurk and trying to be more active these last couple weeks, I had one on Saturday and really enjoyed it. So much of the passion lost for hobbies isn't because we grow out of them, it's quite frankly because we are probably just depressed.

seeker: I agree fully and I'm happy for you. I think I've been in some sort of depression for some time now. I stopped doing everything I loved. I used to love jogging but I stopped doing that too. I ended up gaining a lot of weight and now I don't like going anywhere or being seen at all. I'm usually 130 and I've shot up to 200. So I think if I can just get my routine down and exercise, I'll be alright.
supporter: Yep for sure, just get back at it and learn to love it again. Anyways, good talking to you!

seeker: I'm so anxious. I'm losing my job at the end of the month and I don't know how my resume is going to hold up with so many other people looking for work too!
supporter: I can understand why you would feel this way. Maybe you should try to take a step back and reassess the situation.

seeker: Maybe, but it's hard to feel like there is another way to approach it. There's so many people struggling. It's all so sad and scary right now.
supporter: It may be a good time to go over your resume, making sure to fine tune all of your achievements and qualifications. This may help ease some of your worries and fears.

seeker: Wow, that's a great idea.
supporter: It seems that you are mixed up in the decision to put in extra funds in a professional resume polish or use your time and energy instead of actual financial means. Is that right?

seeker: Exactly. I'm anxious that if I don't get professional help I won't land a job but then on the other hand I'm anxious that if I don't get a job I'll have needed the savings.
supporter: Perhaps you should speak to a trusted mentor or a closed loved one and seek their opinion. Often, we need someone outside of the actual situation that can give us great advice.

seeker: That's a good idea too. Maybe even someone who recently changed jobs can give me some interview tips! -Even if I get the interview I know I'm going to be anxious about that!
supporter: I understand we can all feel anxious during an interview, but remember what great qualities you can bring to the table and believe in yourself!

seeker: I'll try! Thank you so much for the advice!
supporter: Also, there are many online resources that are great at finding available jobs and require your time and effort, but not any money invested. This might be a good tool as well!

seeker: That's very true. Maybe I'll get started on that tonight.
supporter: I hope so. I've also been in a similar situation so I can completely understand your feelings.

seeker: That's nice to hear! Sometimes it feels like I'm being dramatic. I really appreciate your thoughts, having an action plan really helps me feel less anxious. Thank you.
supporter: Can I help with anything else?

seeker: I don't think so. I already feel excited to get started looking at those resources and tweaking my achievements.
supporter: Your feelings are completely valid and I wish you the best. You got this!

seeker: I've been dealing with a lot of depression lately.  not sure how to shake it (1)
supporter: Im sorry to hear that, has there been anything going to cause the increase?

seeker: My daughter was born about 3 months ago.  I guess it's post-partum.(2)
supporter: That is really rough, though it is good you recognize it. A lot of people do not.

seeker: Well I figured when I was crying at the Pampers commercial that there might be an issue (3)
supporter: Have you tried to talk to a professional. It is very prevalent that mothers experiencing this do.

seeker: I've talked to my doctor that delivered my daughter about it.  He recommended medication but I'm not so sure I want to take something for the rest of my life (4)
supporter: As long as you recognize that it is a much more common thing that people go through, that is a great start. I experienced it with my second child as well.

seeker: Did they put you on medication (5)
supporter: There is no harm getting a second opinion. I never did take medication, i found a good therapist to talk too.

seeker: A second opinion is probably a good thing.  I just know I can't keep laying in bed 1/2 the day with the baby. (6)
supporter: Yeah that you cant, and i cant stress how good it is that you realize it. I would definitely go for a second opinion. Or even search for therapists that specialize in it in your area. Never have been a fan of using medicine as the first go unless really needed.

seeker: Yeah, I'm not big on the medication.  I've talked to several moms that went on it and years later had to stay on it because the withdrawals were so terrible.  I'd like to be able to process through it(7)
supporter: And whats the worst a little talking can do for you. Has talking to other moms been helpful at all?

seeker: Well, some of them LOL!  Others just scare me to pieces so it really depends on who it is!  My husband does not understand at all but he's trying (8)
supporter: At least he is trying, as i said before, even with it being so common, it is a mystery to most.

seeker: I don't think a lot of people talk about it.  You have this new healthy child, you should be excited, and yet there is extreme sadness and no idea why so you stay quiet about it (9)
supporter: Yeah its a rough cycle, you get down on yourself for feeling down.

seeker: Exactly, like it's my fault that I feel this way.  My head knows that is  not right, my heart another story. (10)
supporter: Well, i am glad you want to do something about it. I hope you do follow up with a second opinion, or maybe even support groups in your area.

seeker: Yes, I am going to look into some support groups in our area and maybe a therapist as well.  Just need to do some research to find some locally
supporter: Great, thats wonderful news. I think you are on the right track to being yourself again.

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hello, how are you doing today?

seeker:
I'm ok, how are you
?
supporter: Just ok? Is there something bothering you?

seeker: I'm struggling with depression. I'm a mom at home with my children throughout the day.
supporter: That must be a lot to manage, I'm sure you're doing a great job.

seeker: It is, thank you. I think I need to cope with self isolation better. Being a mom is self isolating by itself without the pandemic.
supporter: I completely understand, the pandemic and having added responsibility definitely has been very isolating and can feel like you're losing your sense of self.

seeker: I've joined "mom groups" and that does seem to help some. You're right I am losing my sense of self, that is a very good way to put it.
supporter: It's completely normal to have that sense of guilt for feeling that way as well. This whole situation is not ideal for anyone, which somehow makes it worse. It's hard to talk to someone about these feelings when you know everyone else is in the same or worse situation.

seeker: It is very hard to talk to someone about these feelings, when we are all going through it. How have you been able to maintain your sense of self? Any tips?
supporter: It's taken a while to figure it out and get on the same page with my husband, but I try and practice self-care when possible. It can be something as simple as going for a walk alone or sitting and reading alone. There's no shame in needing some time alone to reset.

seeker: Thank you for your empathy and understanding. You are so right, self care is so important as a mom, especially right now. My husband doesn't understand that just by going to work he is able to escape for a little while. I will definitely try to practice more self care. Good luck to you and thank you for your advise! You have been very helpful.
supporter: I'm glad to hear it, good luck to you as well. I hope you're able to practice self care and reset. Stay safe!

seeker: Thank you!
supporter: Too kind, thank you.

seeker: Have a good afternoon:)
supporter: You as well, I'm so glad you're feeling better.

seeker: Hi, how are you? Are you working?
supporter: I am working today.

seeker: I've been working from home since March. Today I get a letter saying I have to return to work. Can my job make me come to the office?
supporter: Different jobs have different policies so you could check into that. I do know people who have had to do that.

seeker: Who would I check with? The letter says "failure to return to physical could result in loss of employment."
supporter: You have a direct supervisor or a human resource person that you could talk to at the company. They should be able to answer those questions for you.

seeker: hello
supporter: I am still here. I'm supposed to be supporter.

supporter: I was like that as a teen. I read a lot and kept to myself

seeker:
Really? 
did you see that as a problem?
supporter: Maybe you could try getting another set of friends that don't insult you.

seeker: they are my childhood friends
supporter: Mine were too. Just because you grew up on the same block doesn't mean you have to keep hanging with them.

seeker: they are good people i thing the problem is with me
supporter: why? you think you are non-social?

seeker: yes i'm
supporter: sounds like a good impulse

seeker: really?
supporter: sure. Do your "friends" get into trouble?

seeker: not all of the time
supporter: again, it sounds like you're impulse to stay from them is correct.

seeker: i guess so too
supporter: no. there's nothing wrong with you

seeker: i feel better to know that
supporter: great! and you just finished a  HIT, too!

seeker: Hello!
supporter: Hi! How are you today?

seeker: Im really nervous about my upcoming finals :/
supporter: Finals can be so stressful. Have you been studying?

seeker: I keep trying, but it seems my nervousness from wanting to do well is clouding my mind and making it hard to study
supporter: I can imagine. When i was in school , i had the same thing happen to me. I was so sterssed, it led to me nto being able to focus.

seeker: I like to lift weights for gaining muscle mass. Usually pushups are my favorite bodyweight exercise
supporter: Have you made time to do that latey?

seeker: I havent really no, should I?
supporter: Definitely, exercise is a really good way to de-stress. It releases endorphins which can calm you and make you happy. This is a great way to reset before studying.

seeker: That is a good tip, I should really start working on that more. What could I do to help me study more efficiently though?
supporter: HAve you tried setting small study goals? That always helps me. I set a hour for one small topic at a time , it makes studying less overwhelming.

seeker: Okay, so If i have 6 finals, would I be able to study for all by studying less?
supporter: Not necessarily studying less but break the 6 finals into smaller tasks. Use index cards to organize yourself. I alwyas start with an outline of topics i need to cover then put them onto index cards.

seeker: I really like that, I should definitly start doing that. How about work school balance, I currently work and am enrolled full time. Should I request time off to prep for finals or what should I do?
supporter: That's up to you. WIll your employer be accommodating about taking a day or two off? You want to make sure to not lose your job.

seeker: Thats a good point. I really like my job so I wouldnt like to lose it. But I feel like I should ask anyways. I mean the worst they can say is no right?
supporter: Definitely, worth a try.

seeker: Thank you so much for your help, you have been great. Have a good day
supporter: Happy to help!! have a great day.

seeker: hello
supporter: Hello, how are you feeling today?

seeker: having a rough day.
supporter: I am sorry you are having a rough day.

seeker: i feel like my life is an unscheduled mess. nothing ever happens when its supposed to
supporter: It sounds like the chaos and disorganization is really bother you.  Is that right?

seeker: yes
supporter: I can certainly understand.  When my children were young and I worked full-time outside of the home, I found it very difficult to keep things in my life organized.

seeker: my partners schedule changes about 3 times a day. so i never know if what i had planned will happen or not. usually not.
supporter: I can understand why that may frustrate you.

seeker: i stay home all the time and even our plans for doing things at home fall through. he will promise to do something simple and months later its still not done
supporter: This can be very stressful and lead to a lot of problems in a relationship if not dealt with early.

seeker: its more of the reasons why he has to work late that bother me
supporter: Have you tried hanging a large calendar and writing down his schedule as well as any plans you made? Then each morning, do a quick 1-minute check on the calendar to ensure you are BOTH on the same page.

seeker: the people he works with either screw up a machine or flake out not even working an 8 hour shift. yet my other half is always the one to stay
supporter: Is he aware of your concerns?

seeker: i mean i admire his work ethic but why does it always have to fall on him to be the one to stay
supporter: I feel like I had very similar issues in my first marriage.

seeker: it makes my anxiety go crazy
supporter: Communication can be very key here.

seeker: we talk often and i have actually broken down several times and cried. funny thing is im not mad about the situation itself. i just feel robbed sometimes
supporter: I can understand why that would make you feel that way.  We enjoy spending time with the people that we love.

seeker: it would be different if i didnt care or it made me mad. it just make me feel alone
supporter: Why don't you choose even one night each week, and see if he will commit to being home that one night - then plan something special TOGETHER.  It could be a game night, cooking dinner together, or just sitting talking.

seeker: we have tried that and he still got stuck working.
supporter: Also, when he is home, you could both try REALLY connecting during that time.  Then maybe when he is at work, you won't feel so alone having made that connection that morning or the night before.

seeker: we do make the most of our 2 to 3 hours together at night. otherwise i would completely break down
supporter: That is good.

seeker: he feels the same way about our time
supporter: So it sounds like time together is important to him as well, and the fact that you are both on the same page about that is wonderful.

seeker: we had a lot of talks about this issue
supporter: Instead of you making the plans, why don't you try giving him suggestions and have him make the plans next time?  Perhaps by him making them, he will be more focused on ensuring that he can be there.

seeker: that sound like a great idea
supporter: And then he will also see how much effort you put in!

seeker: thank you for your help
supporter: You are very welcome!

seeker: It is finals week at my college and I'm beyond anxious about it (1)
supporter: Taking finals certainly is tough, there's so much to think about. What's bothering you the most?

seeker: Probably my stamina and endurance to finish all the work.  I'm still recovering from Covid-19 (2)
supporter: Have you spoken to anyone at the college about this?

seeker: Yes, but they haven't been much help unfortunately.  My classes are online and finals are due when finals are due.  They are not giving any wiggle room (3)
supporter: It must make you feel quite trapped knowing that the college aren't cutting you a bit of slack considering you are still recovering from a serious illness. It sounds like you are trying your best and not giving up already.

seeker: No I cannot give up at all.  My scholarship requires me to maintain a certain GPA and I can't afford to lose it (4)
supporter: It's good to hear that you're not giving up. Sometimes in these situations, you just have to do your best and then at least you know you did what you could. I like to tell myself in these situations that if there are no other avenues to explore, you just have to 'go with the flow' and don't beat yourself up thinking about it over and over - if there's nothing you can do, just do your best to ride it out

seeker: I know, there is just so much riding on these finals.  I have great grades so I'm praying that I pass without any issues and that I don't bomb even one of them (5)
supporter: If you tried hard previously then you may come out the other end having done very well!  When I was at school a long time ago, I had to stay off school for a month, when they were practising the exams. I didn't get chance to do those and I thought 'wow I'm totally screwed here', but guess what? I did okay!

seeker: I hope that's what happens, I just don't know how to calm down about it (6)
supporter: Yes, I'm here

seeker: Do you know any techniques to help me calm down? (7)
supporter: It's totally understandable. I think even without the COVID situation, you would still be anxious. It's totally natural. Not that that discounts how you feel. Do you agree?

seeker: Yes, that is true.  I just can't quite seem to quiet my mind. (8)
supporter: Well, I've tried meditating a few times before which doesn;t take it all away, it just takes the edge off! I used a guided meditation app. I also listened to white noise when I went to sleep as I was having trouble sleeping. I find even if you're mind is just taken away from it all for a few minute, it can re-balance you a little

seeker: I've tried watching some comedy shows and listening to music to take my mind off of it.  It works sometimes (9)
supporter: Maybe you should do more of that, it sounds like a good idea? Don't feel guilty for doing so either as it acts as a 'medicine'. If the 'medicine' works then take it

seeker: I will try to focus more on that when I'm not studying and see if it keeps helping then (10)
supporter: Sounds like a plan! It's certainly worth giving it a go. We need a break from it all sometimes or we'd all go mad.

seeker: Hello?
supporter: Hello, I'm sorry I didn't reply faster.

seeker: It's okay. Thank you for replying.
supporter: I understand. What are you struggling with concerning time management?

supporter: I can see how this would be very overwhelming. I have a child learning virtually as well. Similarly, I am a student. I am not working on my masters degree... I can't even imagine.

seeker: So you understand how the virtual learning has affected the day to day goals? I used to work during the day, complete my school work when the kids are in bed, but now everything seems so stressful.
supporter: Is your child old enough to do some of it on their own? I have "independent" or "together" next to each task. I purchased a large magnetic chalk board for our fridge. If your child is to young to do this I could see how this would be much more challenging for you.

seeker: That's a great idea! Two of my kids are old enough to work independently most of the time, they are 11 and 8. However, I also have a 3 year old that requires constant attention. Unfortunately, her daycare is closed. Even more, I had to take on my nephew because his mother could not handle the virtual learning.
supporter: I completely understand how you feel. Virtual learning has affected our daily goals, though we are doing prerecorded lessons. That does make it easier I am sure. I have a 10 and 2 year old at home with me. One thing that has helped me is support groups. There are so many moms going through the same thing we are at this time.

seeker: I never even thought of support groups. It would help to connect with other moms, just to remind myself that I am not alone in this. Thank you so much. You also have a busy bee on your hands!
supporter: You are not alone in this. You could take the 3 year old to another room if possible and work on phonics/numbers, then help the older children during naptime. Then maybe they could help entertain the 3 year old while you work on your own schoolwork? This is similar to my daily schedule... but as you know with kids you have to go with the flow most of the time.

seeker: Definitely have to go with the flow. They make life wondefully unpredictable. Thank you and those are fantastic ideas. I'll have to create a naptime, that would be the most helpful.
supporter: It helps so much to talk to other moms who understand. Being a mom is hard enough without all the added extra stress of 2020. It sounds like you're doing the best you can, and your kids will remember that in the long run. You can do this!

Yes 
i

supporter: It will get better, this is just now and there's a lot to look forward once you're through this. Make sure you're taking care of yourself first and foremost. That will ultimately provide you success.

I can't wait to be successful one day, but the thought of working also sc
ares me. I fell be by myself.
supporter: From what I've seen, you're not alone in that feeling. It's a natural fear for just about anyone approaching something new. But there really aren't any rules, your life and your decisions decide your success.

supporter: hello how are you today?

supporter: When did this start?

supporter: Can you tell me some examples about the injustice?

seeker: Some colleagues are given an option to log out early, whereas some of us have to slog .
supporter: Is the logging out early a reward for their work? I had a job that offered similar rewards based on performance.

seeker: No, it's a privilege given to them if they agree to anything the Manger says like going out with him for a drink, etc..
supporter: That is very inappropriate. This must be very hard for you.

seeker: It is, I try to let it go, but fail at times.

seeker: Yes, I have that as my last resort. What do you think? Should I go ahead as I'm afraid my step may backfire me.
supporter: I would not be able to let this go either. I'm so sorry you're in such an unfair and unethical work environment. Do you know the supervisor well or interact with them? It could backfire if they both interact with this behavior. I believe you will make the right decision. If it does backfire, this is a toxic work environment and not a good fit for you.

seeker: Yes
supporter: You are very welcome. It does feel good to communicate with people who can understand how you feel. I wish you the very best of luck.

seeker: Thank you so much. Take care. Be safe.
supporter: You're welcome. You be safe as well.

supporter: Well, i think its most people are afraid of what they have become but are more afraid of the hard work needed to get through. Its not easy.

supporter: Yup, gotta take the small wins, let them build up. I hope us talking has been a small win.

supporter: Well I'm not sure what type of gig work you do, however, just the fact that you are a gig worker for a long time tells me a few things....1, you are a self starter 2. You have great pritoritizing and time management skills 3. You learn new things easily and with little instruction.  All of these things are skill sets that many employers find extremely desirable.

seeker: Yes, I guess these are helpful qualities.  I just don't know if I can find another gig to fit my schedule that I am excited about doing
supporter: Perhaps thats where networking may help. If you are able to find employment that is similar to gigwork, you may be able to have a schedule to works for you.

seeker: Unfortunately I have been so focused on my current position I have no network to speak of.  I am alone in my new search.
supporter: I am not too familiar with gig work, but perhaps you know of a site that is similar to Indeed.com but specifically for your line of work or for gigwork .

seeker: Online teaching.  I have developed a strong foundation with the company I work for, unfortunately they are actually doing less business at this time
supporter: Maybe you can develop your own courses ? Or, you can also become an online trainer for a variety of organizations. Since many companies are transitioning to a work from home environment, this is a great time to offer your training services to various companies.

seeker: Yes, I guess there ar emany opportunities that might work.  Thank you for your help.
supporter: You are very welcome!

seeker: I appreciate your help.
supporter: Great! Feel free to come back if you need additional help!

supporter: I'm doing fine, you can tell me your problems

My ex lives next door though, and her and my wife bump into each other all the time and sparks tend to fly.  It's kind of awkward in the neighborhood.

So she's brilliant, but kind of emotionally stunted at the same time.

supporter: What I found helped somewhat was joining a few social groups online. find something you like and find a group related to that. For example, I love horror movies, so I joined a horror movie group on Facebook. While it's not face to face, it is a good opportunity to just connect with others about a common interest.

seeker: Good idea..
supporter: I am hoping they get the vaccine going as well. But I am hoping they get it right, and not just rush to get something out there that may or may not work.

supporter: Yes, if you are doing longer videos, I recommend YouTube. What you can do, is do a short clip on TikToc and then in that clip instruct viewers to follow your YouTube Channel

seeker: Wow.  Thanks for all the great information.
supporter: Sure, my pleasure!

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hello! How can I encourage you tonight?

seeker: I'm really anxious and I javen
supporter: So you have a lot on your mind and you are losing sleep over it?

seeker: Yeah my company laid off 10% of the workforce last Friday and furloughed another 10%. I'm afraid I'm next
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. It can be a bit stressful to think you may lose your job.

seeker: yeah my mind is racing and I can't stay calm.
supporter: I have found there are ways to calm myself down when things in my life seem very uncertain.

seeker: Really? What seems to work? I'm willing to try anything right now
supporter: I make a list of the things I can do - And the things I can't. Then you can have goals. And if you can work on a goal, for example, if you need to write a resume, you start working on that a little bit every day until it's done. But if there is nothing you CAN do about the situation, you have to pray to God to help you then LET IT GO. If you can NOT fix it now, you will only make yourself sick thinking about it.

seeker: I know. I can't seem to shut my mind down.
supporter: It is much more difficult for me to remain focused and positive when I lose sleep. I have had to focus on self care, finding a friend to talk about my problems with, not someone who will TELL me what to do, but support me. So you need a good support system. And I find things like prayer, Bible reading, nice soft sheets to sleep on and some herbal tea like Sleepy Time help me relax before bedtime.

seeker: Those are some helpful points. I didn't think about herbal tea
supporter: And be kind to yourself, no one likes to lose a job, it's unsettling. Do try to tell yourself things that are true to encourage yourself, like you will find another job, it might be uncomfortable and hard, but it actually might work out for your good in the long term.  I always found better jobs, but at the time I lost my job, I felt as if the world was ending.

seeker: Yeah I am really concerned because my wife lost her job this summer so I'm the only breadwinner at the moment
supporter: You aren't in an easy place, but this can actually work out for your good.  I think if you focus on the GOOD that can happen, that might help your more. I would be concerned too, but if you even start looking for a job now, that might help you become more confident. I do encourage you to set goals.

seeker: oh wow
supporter: If I had to do it over again, I would have encouraged him more to get that resume out and look for another job. The threat of losing his job was always hanging over his head. Yeah, it's not worth it my friend. Be pro active.

seeker: I've been trying to look on job boards and company websites but it's hard to find something that is close to the same level of pay. So far the ones I qualify for I will have to take a 25% pay cut or more
supporter: I would also encourage you to get outside and run, or walk or play with the kids or do exercise everyday, because if you are tired physically, that helps reduce stress and helps you sleep.

seeker: Yeah I'll try that.
supporter: Sometimes a pay cut in the right company is a stepping stone IN the door, My husband lost a lucrative job one time, he started at a company washing dishes in his 40s, I kid you not, but he wound up moving up and retired early.

seeker: Yeah but with my wife out of a job we can't afford for me to take a pay cut. We're already dipping into savings now.
supporter: I can understand that. Perhaps get together with her and look for ways to cut out spending. These are tough times. Even one car, or chicken instead of steak or canceling netflix or something like that. A few steps back is NOT failure, it can be prioritizing things in a difficult time.

seeker: ok thanks
supporter: I do want to assure you that even though I don't know you, you sound intelligent and caring and obviously wanting to provide for your family. That's honorable. These are difficult times, I do encourage you to write things down because sometimes stress clouds our eyes and if you set goals and brainstorm, you will be amazed at what you can come up with.

supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. How are you feeling about that?

supporter: That seems like a hard situation. It must be difficult.

supporter: Okay. I am very sorry to hear that! Do you want to tell me more about that?

supporter: I really feel you there. Holidays are so hard.. especially with the way this year has been. Anything specific?

seeker: Yes. I am a college student and I live on campus. The day before I moved in my dad said some unforgivable things to me and we haven't spoke since
supporter: Do you feel scared for your own self? Or of the situation in general? I'm sorry to hear that. Relationships with parents can be very difficult sometimes.

seeker: more for the situation in general. i know we will not speak but we will constantly be running into each other, my house is not big.
supporter: It's like we live the same life. I also have no car to escape! It seems so small, but it's such a huge stressor when you feel trapped in an environment you're not positive in. I feel your pain and I empathize with you completely.

supporter: It sounds like Covid- 19 is going to be a personal stressor for you. It's such a strange thing to have to live with already, the pandemic, and i'm sorry that it might end up pushing you where you don't want to be.

seeker: Yes it is very strange and I know that it is a big stressor on all of us, i don't want to sound selfish.
supporter: I don't think you're selfish at all. You have feelings you are entitled to have and are expressing them which is healthy and I encourage that behavior!

seeker:
Well thank you that does help me to feel better. Yes I am happy to bring him home with me and hoping I can have my niece over to intro
duce her to him
supporter: You sound like a very determined person in making this trip as stress free as possible. I commend you for that! Maybe you could have your niece over often to play with your hamster just to soften the stress of being there

supporter: Is Uber an option for you? I know there's a lot of rideshare services but they're not always financially reasonable. But that could be a way to get away if you ever need too!

seeker: that is very true i didn't even think of that to be honest! I may use that along the way, thank you for the reminder!
supporter: Sometimes I forget little things like that to help myself whenever I get too involved in the emotional aspect of things. I'm glad I could suggest it to you!

seeker: Thank you! Well i appreciate your help a lot and hope you have a great day!
supporter: Of course! I hope you do as well and happy holidays!

seeker: Hi, I am doing ok.
supporter: That's good to hear. Can I encourage you in some way?

seeker: I am afraid about changing my job during COVID but I am not happy at my current job.
supporter: So you are unhappy at your job and want to do something else? What exactly are your fears?

seeker: I am a helpdesk associate for a large telecom company. I don't like the hours and the pay here but I am afraid if I can get a job outside in this time.
supporter: I can understand that looking for a job can be stressful and challenging at this time, but one thing is for certain, you will never know if you don't try.

seeker: I have tried the Pros & Cons method. Pros are better pay and hours, cons are tougher interviews and more rounds
supporter: I like the "Do it afraid!" method. I can still try even if I feel nervous.  You really do not need confidence to put your resume out there, you just need to do it afraid. And when I "do it afraid" I realize it was easier than I thought.

seeker: "Do it afraid"? Do you mean do it even if I am afraid? It sounds a bit too optimistic to me.
supporter: I used to be paralyzed with self confidence, but the truth is, your confidence doesn't come from your job, your confidence comes from being a lovable person. The confidence that you are the person you want to be.

seeker: Ok, I think it makes sense. I may have to give it a try.
supporter: I always felt awkward and nervous looking for a job, I think I went to one interview calm and cool, in 30 years! Hahaha.

seeker: I am a good team player, I don't have any inter-personal or communication issues. Just that I need to be at a higher pay to reach some financial goals
supporter: You have nothing to lose, really, you have weighed out that there is only good things that can come, but you think you must "feel" a certain way. You don not have to feel confident, you just have to do the work. For example, you don't FEEL like walking your dog, changing a diaper or helping someone, but you DO IT anyway.

seeker: Cool! I will try to get motivated and start applying. Your words are just what I needed in this gloomy atmosphere.
supporter: Inter personal skills can be learned. I was very shy as a child and I learned how to be more friendly. And I was VERY shy.

seeker: Ya, I think the key is to keep my current job and start looking elsewhere.
supporter: I'm very outgoing now. I had to learn a lot of skills to be this way and I like myself more too. Hahah. I'm old though, 59. You have nothing to lose, consider it a learning opportunity.

seeker: Thank you sir, I will definitely try it! You have shared Pure words of wisdom
supporter: I'm a lady! I pray to God and read the Bible and get wisdom there. Plus I have been to the school of hard knocks! lol

seeker: Oh my apologies, mam!!
supporter: I look forward to your new job! And celebrate with you. Take deep breaths and forge ahead!!

seeker: Definitely! Thanks a lot for your mentorship
supporter: You are welcome! Thank you for sharing your life with me!

seeker: Good evening
supporter: Hey there! How are you feeling?

supporter: Correct me if i'm wrong, but it sounds like your husband may be controlling you a little and you're expressing reasonable emotions because of it. and Okay!

seeker: I'd love to hear them. There is one problem in general i'm having that i seem to have always had because of the Depression. supporter: I have had trouble sleeping in the past and sometimes I still do, usually if it is when I'm nervous about the future.

It was very helpful for a while there
supporter: If I didn't get good rest, then I would definitely feel tired the next day and over time, it would wear me out. I believe medication will help with the symptoms, but it is important to get the root of the problem, why exactly you find it difficult to sleep.

seeker: I plan on seeing a sleep doctor soon! Sometimes I lose sight of fixing the issue and need to be reminded. And yes!! I was treating my sleeping with Benadryl as well but it wasn't healthy to keep doing that.
supporter: I'm also thinking there are a few practical ways you can help yourself sleep. I was advised to get soft sheets, make my sleeping area more restful, make sure the time before bed is relaxing and calming.

seeker: I always lose sight of how to make things better. It really helps to talk sometimes so someone can help me put things into perspective. I'll look into Frank Hammond! I am actually religious and would love to look into that.
supporter: I will definitely pray for you tonight because I know losing sleep is hard to deal with. But please have hope, sometimes we go through these things to possible get to deeper issues that might need to be dealt with. We only have a few minutes here, but I'm pretty old and I have found this to be true so many times.  Get a good support system of good friends. Having people who "get" you is SO vital to our lives. And learning to be grateful helps too. And especially journal, find out what may be bothering you.

supporter: Thanks you too! We are all blessed when we help each other! Have a great night.

seeker: HI, I need help, I have been feeling very down lately.
supporter: Okay, how can I help you?

supporter: Is there anything particular that has got you feeling down lately?

supporter: Its always good to have someone to talk to, I am happy to help. I have felt stuck many times, so i can understand that.

seeker: What did you do to get out of the rut.
supporter: Well I had to sit down and think about why I was stuck and tried to come up with as many options as I could to be unstuck, then i put them in order based on which I thought would work best. It took quite a few of them, but I did finally get unstuck.

seeker: I can try doing that.
supporter: Every one is different, but it is worth a shot, might help the rut your having, might also give you new ideas that will help you decide on how to not feel like your in a rut anymore. Sometimes just talking to someone can help too, bouncing ideas off of each other can help in some cases.

seeker: True,  I have been avoiding most people.
supporter: Its hard to talk about certain problems, so I can't blame you, however you can get some good ideas from others. You might have just needed some space to evaluate your situation, nothing wrong with taking a break from things or people if it helps you.

seeker: I will try reaching out to my sister tomorrow.  maybe she can help.
supporter:
From chatting with you I can tell you might be ready to start talking and maybe get some help or advice, family is a great start they are typically a great support system. It is okay to feel embarrassed but being unhappy will eat at you, sometimes its good to set our pride aside so that we can figure things out. In my situation of feeling stuck I was ashamed that I sat and let people treat me so badly but it wasn't until I seen it as a problem that I started making my lists and getting advice. Some things we do on our own and some its good to have people to help. I think reaching out to your sister would be worth a try, she might also have different ideas and suggestions you haven'
t thought of yet.

seeker: Thanks, you have been a lot of help.
supporter: Thank you for chatting with me, I am glad to help. I hope you have a great day! Stay positive!

seeker: Friday while out doing last minute Thanksgiving shopping I got a call from my best firend's that my best friend was rushed to the hospital. I hung up and rushed to the hospital. When I got there my fiance and my best friend's family were all there. Hold on let me finish.
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that. Take your time!

seeker: The sister told me my friend has advance Kidney Failure and could die at anytime. I just saw my best friend Thursday and she fine. The sister also told me my friend has AIDS and hasn't been taking her medicine. My jaw dropped because this is my best friend. She went on to say I need to get  tested because my best friend and fiance has been having an affair. I couldn't believe anything she was saying. I confronted my fiance know he would say it wasn't true. He didn't deny or confirm anything. He kept saying he was so sorry. I've been at moterl since Friday after i ran from the hospital. I don't know if my best friend is dead or where my fiance is. I'm scared and mad.
supporter: Oh my goodness. I am so incredibly sorry that all of this happened to you. I can tell that you are completely overwhelmed with emotions right now.

seeker: With all the crap happening in the world this had to land on my head. WHY? WHAT DID I DO?
supporter: I don't believe that you did anything wrong whatsoever. Sometimes, really unfair things happen to really good people. I can't even imagine how hard this must be, but I would try to look at it in a positive way. I know that losing your best friend and your fiancé must be devastating, but at least you now know that your fiancé is someone who you most certainly probably don't want to spend the rest of your life with.

seeker: Were you married to him?
supporter: I think I would start by putting your own health first and getting yourself tested to make sure that you haven't contracted anything from your fiancé. I know this will be incredibly hard, but I wouldn't want to see you getting sick and suffering as a result of his infidelity.

seeker: I'm scared to get tested. What if it comes back positive?
supporter: I would be scared, too. However, it's better to act now because to my knowledge, the sooner that you find out and treat it, the better the chances are of you treating it. There are a lot of new medications out there that can be used to treat HIV and AIDS.

seeker: Have you been tested for AIDS? What do they do when you get tested?
supporter: I know that their first child is a girl. I'm not sure if their second is a girl or a boy. I haven't spoken to him in several years. I found out through a friend about their second child. We haven't spoken at all since I found out about the first one.

seeker: Didn't you say you have a daughter by him? And you haven't talk to him since he cheated? What about your daughter feelings? She has a right to know her father doesn't she?
supporter: I am so incredibly sorry that you have to deal with all of this at all but especially at the start of the holiday season. My heart absolutely breaks for you.

supporter: I'm a great mother and I always put my daughter's feelings first. She made the decision not to see or speak to her father. Him and my now ex-best friend are on drugs and don't have custody of their own children. It's in my daughter's best interest that she doesn't know him.

seeker: Here! Last Christmas I bought the condo of my dreams. This April 2020 I lost my job due Covid 19. My unemployment is ending and my savings are depleted. I've recived an eviction notice and don't know what to do. Help!
supporter: Where are you that you are able to be evicted?

seeker: I'm still in my condo but I no longer have a job, umemployment has run out and my savings are all gone.
supporter: Well the plus side is they cannot kick you out right now. Have you talk to your landlord about working out some payment arrangement. Have you tried applying for any job?  Now is not the time for pride to get in the way, i would accept anything

seeker: When you say work out a plan what do you mean? I have no job. I have been applying for jobs but I haven't received a callback or an offer of employment. Have you ever been in this situation?
supporter: I have but the referendum on evictions with covid makes this situation different. I am sorry if that pride comment came off as crass. I was just trying to say desperate times come with desperate measures

seeker: It's kind of hard to work out a plan when you don't know where your next meal is coming from don't you think? Do you know anything about the eviction process and where do people go once they have been evicted.
supporter: Your landlord. I worked out a way with payments when i was furloughed from my job. And yes i was actually homeless many years ago so i do know what it feels like to miss out on meals for a days at a time. It seems you should look up evictions during Covid. They are not allowed to throw you on the street as long as the pandemic is going on.

seeker: How did you eat and where did you sleep when you were homeless? How long did it take to end your situation?
supporter: Oh for my situation it was 100% my fault i was in a bad place during that time. I spent my time couch surfing til my friends got tired of me. Bounced around shelters after i sold my car. Washing up and brushing my teeth were the least of my problems.

seeker: I rather not say. But thank you for you for sharing and i hope you and your family have a good Thanksgiving.
supporter: I was going to paste a link for you on evictions during covid. Please just google Evictions during covid (your state) you will find groups that can help and the laws, that are on your side.

seeker: hi, how are you?
supporter: I am sorry for my late reply, i did not hear the chat go off.

seeker: its so annoying and hurtful
supporter: Yeah i can tell you something you might not want to hear but it ended with us ending our friendship on that level

seeker: i definitely do not want to end our friendship, that would be even more painful
supporter: I didnt end it but we grew apart as people do over the years. We still hang out but it isnt like it was before. People move on to others and it hurts. They usually are not trying to hurt us though.

seeker: I know, but its hard when you are the one still stuck, Im not ready for change.
supporter: Yea it was hard for me too. Thats the thing about change it just happens. I would do something focusing on yourself. Trying to make yourself feel better.

supporter: Everyone needs to and everyone forgets too heh

seeker: I agree, i need to focus more on myself
supporter: Good, im glad you can realize that! Some people cant

supporter: Great, any ideas on what you would like to focus on?

seeker: focus on me, doing things by myself instead of with my friend. going to eat, spa time, me time, only with me. then allow myself to make new friends
supporter: Those are great ideas actually, When i want some me time, i usually go for a nice long hike or run.

seeker: i thinks hikes and runs are good too, they actually are peaceful and makes me focus on life

supporter: Oh sorry i guess it came off wrong. I meant try not to let it overwhelm you so you can focus more on the kids.

supporter: Do you want to go into whats going on right now?

supporter: I see, have you just started them?

seeker: I have about two months on the meds and I do not think it needs more time to take effect in my system. I know working things out while talking to someone on this platform would work, so here I am
supporter: With medicine like that, it can take months to take its full effect. Stopping can reverse and even make the depression come back worse. Have you told your Doctor your concerns?

seeker:
Yes, I have told my doctor my concerns and he mentioned this portal to go talk to someone without a face to get a broader view on your problems. This method has been working for a lot of his patients
 so far.
supporter: Hmm, well yes this can be helpful but that is strange he did not run any tests to see how the medication is reacting with you. On that note though what is going on with you now?

seeker: I am crying everyday and need to know what can I do on daily basis to keep me busy from doing other things that can harm me....
supporter: I would look to talk to a therapist about these matters. Platforms like this can help with some issues but if you are not reacting to the medication and these thoughts are still occurring then that is the path i would take.

seeker: Therapist wants me to use this. My blood work will be done this week.
supporter: Im not telling you to quit on your therapist but if their techniques are not working for you, or you do not think they are a good fit. You should not feel guilty looking for one that is better suited to your needs. Self harm is a very serious issue that strangers really cannot help you with.

supporter: So it is your therapist, or psychiatrist that put you on this medication? Do you feel they listen to you?

supporter: Thats very good then, Oh great im very happy to hear that!

supporter: That is awesome, You have a great evening!

supporter: Of course! What is the problem?

seeker: My boyfriend has been cheating on me, He constantly denies it and I want to believe him, but my family also knows and thinks I need to end things.
supporter: So to make sure I understand, have you caught your partner cheating?

seeker: I haven't actually caught him myself.
supporter: Has someone told you they suspect he is cheating?

seeker: Yes, My best friend and my sister have told me.
supporter: It is a horrible feeling when that seed has been planted in your head.

seeker: Exactly and he denies it.  I just don't know what to do or who to believe.
supporter: I know you mentioned you want to believe him when he denies it, I guess the important question is what is making you have that shadow of doubt? Has he been unfaithful in the past?

seeker: I know he cheated in the past on a previous girlfriend, but not on me.
supporter: And know I am not saying I don't believe you, I think your feelings are valid, and I just want to get the full picture

seeker: at least no that I am aware of.
supporter: Ok. So there has been a past history of this.

seeker: yes
supporter: And what are your friends and family saying to you? Are their accusations valid?

seeker: I can see their point.  They think he is using me for my car and money.  He is constantly between jobs.
supporter: I know for me, sometimes friends and family will say things like this is they personally do not like the partner themselves without taking your feelings into consideration

seeker: I don think they dislike him, I think they fell he is using me and I am blind to it.
supporter: Ok I see. And for yourself, do you see a future with him? Because in the end it matters how you feel. Do you feel taken advantage of?

seeker: I do financially feel taken advantage of.
supporter: So possible cheating aside - there is definitely some others issues that needs solving. Have you calmly confronted him saying that he is affecting your personal financial goals?

seeker: Yes, and he always promises to do better.  I know deep down it should end.
supporter: I think you may have answered your own question. I know it is hard, but if someone shows a pattern and they do not change their behaviour, most likely they will not anytime soon. Meanwhile, your mental health and finances will suffer. If you want my unprofessional opinion, I think your friends and family care for you, and they will be there to help you through this
