supporter: That’s understandable. Maybe talking to a professional who you don’t have to worry about burdening with your concerns will  allow you to talk about your concerns.

seeker: That's why I'm here ;). You are being very helpful, thank you! It's just nice to be able to tell people what I am worried about and not have them think that I am just being silly.
supporter: Many people are struggling with the current state of affairs. Don’t be afraid to talk to people they may also be afraid to talk to people and you could miss out on supporting each other.

seeker: That does sound like really good advice. The other thing I haven't mentioned yet is that I have been having financial pressures because I am on furlough. I am worried that if this lasts much longer I will end up deep in debt.
supporter: I am sorry that wasn’t helpful.

seeker: I felt that you were very helpful. It is nice to just know that someone is listening. I do not think that there is much in the way of local resources at the moment - everyone is very stretched.
supporter: That is true it has been hard for many people.

seeker: I do feel better for having been able to talk to you about this - thank you very much!
supporter: I’m glad I could provide you some support

seeker: Just can not seem to get out of this funk
supporter: What kind of a funk is it? Do you have to go to work or school? Please tell me more about how you are feeling so I can understand better.

seeker: Nothing seems to be fun and I work from home
supporter: Are you doing okay workwise, getting enough done, getting it done on time? Or is it difficult to get motivated about anything? Is there anything that you think started making you feel this way? I am very interested in understanding how you feel.

seeker: I think this whole Covid thing has been depressing! I get my work done but it is a chore.
supporter: Do you live alone? Did you work at home before COVID? I worked at home before COVID but with COVID I became very isolated. I don't have any neighbors within sight of my house. This my sound weird but I make up  fantasies in my head like I am an alien's pet and my home is my habitat or I pretend I am hiding out  keeping something safe, or a pioneer woman waiting for her family to get back from the store which is a six  month trip.

seeker: I live with my spouse, and I did work at home before. Pioneer story funny! It is hard not being able to enjoy going out.
supporter: I am glad you are able to work, financial stress really sucks. I think Covid has us all down at least at some point.

seeker: Just want it to be over and then the election too!
supporter: Yes, and it doesn't seem to have an end in sight. But at some point it will be over. If you don't feel more like yourself say a month from now I have to seeing a doctor because some depression requires it but that said some depression is normal and usually precedes change. I was told that it sort of erases our expectations and allows us to accept the new thing in a better way.

seeker: I would say when i take a walk at the park it does help
supporter: You sound  stressed over things that you have little to no control over. Take a deep breath. Tickle each other. Pretend you are the adam and eve couple traveling to populate a new world and the house is your spaceship run with it and have some adult play time lose yourselves and destress. It is good that you can enjoy the sunshine and the park. You can only control and influence what happens around you. Concentrate on making that a good place to be and that will change the world a little at a time.

seeker: good advice
supporter: Just hoping to make you feel better and help with some of your worries that don't need to add to your stress. So you don't seem to be depressed as much as stressed and worried which is interfering with things, would that be accurate or could you explain more?

supporter: Happy Thanksgiving to you as well.

seeker: What happened out of interest when you had the conversation?
supporter: Ignoring this will NOT help things. There is NO relief in pretending a question or concern does not exist.

She is just too attractive for me. Everyone told me Iwas 'punching above my weight' and now they will all be laughing if it ends.
supporter: Honestly, its not anyone else's business. IF you're suspicions are in fact correct, then you've got to see that a loving and faithful 5 is better than a heart-breaking 10. However should you find that maybe the devils of insecurities are tricking you into thinking that she's cheating, then remember that what the two of you share o=is FOR THE TWO of you. Its a relationship, not a community project! Even mu advice, albeit in the air to help you best I can. is not more important that what matters most to YOU and HER!

seeker: I'm almost certain of it, she is super protective of her phone and never used to be. She is always texting and vague when I ask who she is messaging. She goes away with work and when she does she rarely messages me. Recently she said when was going way for a work trip for three nights but when I called her office her colleague said they got back after two.
supporter: Hmm... So have you two live together?  How long has this kind of behavior persisted? When you ask her about this behavior, how do you present the question and how does she react? Finally, how often do you talk with her about the situation?

seeker: That's just it. I kind of know she is cheating but I haven't approached it with her because I'm scared see will just leave and I'll be a laughing stock. I suppose I'm a joke either way!
supporter: Don't get me wrong, I completely understand why you have suspicions. Really I think anyone would in the same shoes... However, as humans, we tend to either assume the best or the worst of others. There's always a margin of error present as a variable in such situations.

seeker: very true. I suppose I have just assumed at this stage with no real evidence. do you think I should just talk to her?
supporter: Forgive me if this comes off as disrespectful... I only want to help you.

seeker: not at all. I appreciate your candour.
supporter: But if you feel as though you're a joke regardless, then why stay in a relationship where you're getting hurt? I know that you don't want to lose the beauty but would you not be happier with loyalty?

seeker:
All this is tied up with who and I know I'm valuing the wrong things. You are right actually. I think some of this comes from my low 
self-esteem. having a 9 helps with that. but maybe I need to deal with it directly.
supporter: I wholly believe you should gently but steadfastly confront her. I absolutely do not mean to suggest a dispute or argument. That will not help either. Simply ask her about the things that you KNOW aren't acceptable; lying about how long her trip was is one of them. Also, its okay to talk about how that stuff makes you feel, but try not to project your feelings as her fault. I know that it seems like they are... But she didn't MAKE you feel any specific way, even if her ACTIONS influenced how you were already feeling.

seeker: Hello
supporter: Of course! What sort of issue is it?

seeker: I have done the same job for 7 years but it is now full and boring. It pays OK but it is all I know. I'm scared that I will get resentful in this job if I stay where I am but I haven't got a clue what to do for the best.
supporter: I see, so you feel that your position has become stagnant and you know longer take any pleasure in your work?

seeker: That's exactly it yes. The question is I don't have any official qualifications, just experience and I'd like a change of career but this scared me to death!
supporter: Are there any opportunities for advancement or retraining in your current position? Perhaps strive for a promotion?

seeker: Potentially yes but the position above me is not really like for me and I don't like the reporting line. I think I fancy a change but not quite sure how to tackle it. I need the income so can't just leave but also need to do something about it. do you understand the predicament?
supporter: Yes I do. I sympathise with you because it must be terrible to feel that you are stuck in something that you really no longer like and yet be afraid to try and change your situation. I am sure that there is some solution though!

seeker: Yeah meet too it's just finding a way where I can maybe stay where I am whilst exploring other opportunities to see what I'd like to do. It's a tough one.
supporter: Well, you will never know unless you take the plunge into the unknown! I do realise how difficult it is for you to do that though. Perhaps start putting out feelers to other companies? There is no harm in that.

seeker: Sue that's actually a good idea. No harm I suppose and my current employer would be none the wiser.
supporter: True! it would also be great for your self esteem to realise just how much more there is out there that you could be doing.

seeker: I know, it is a big world out there and I have been doing the same thing for so long. It is exciting but also quite unnerving. Is this normal?
supporter: Yes, there is nothing to worry about. Do you have any relevant qualifications that might help you find another job?

seeker: I have experience and I am pretty hard-working. I have also made quite a few connections over the past 7 years.
supporter: It all sounds very promising. If you think they'd not tell your boss why don't you talk to some of your connections and see if they can put you onto something better?

seeker: Yeah reaching out to my network is probably a good idea - as long as they keep the fact that I am looking for something else quiet. I'd state on Linked in that I'm looking for work but then everyone would know :-)
supporter: One other suggestion - it's a high risk strategy but do you think your boss might be sympathetic if you discussed this with him or her? You never know, they might even have some good suggestions - perhaps they feel the same!

seeker: Actually you might be right there. I should be able to open up about this and they should be supporting my development. Great suggestion. I think I'm overthinking things.
supporter: No I do not believe that you are overthinking at all.  This is a very important aspect of your life and will shape your future!

seeker: Yes true thanks for your understanding
supporter: You are most welcome - I hope that I have been able to give you some peace of mind.

seeker: You have indeed, thanks for this conversation.
supporter: Please let me know how things go for you in the future - I am sure that in six months time things will be looking a lot brighter!

seeker: Will do, thanks again!
supporter: Erm .. cup of coffee?

seeker: Hello there. I'm suffering with increased depression and I'm not quite clear why.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Is there any change in your routine as of lately?

seeker: No not really. I have suffered from depression before but it seems to have spiked recently. The only thing that is different these days is lockdown. I think that's the same for everyone.
supporter: These past few months has been extremely difficult. In the past, what did you do for your depression?

seeker: I saw a psychiatrist face to face but only once every month. I've always had a low mood but now I'm anxious that it will continue to get worse.
supporter: Talking to a professional is always ideal. Is there a way to see that psychiatrist again?

seeker: Since lockdown  haven't spoken to her but maybe she can do a video call. At the start it was fine, I was feeling just as I always have but I don't want this to get any worse. What if she isn't available?
supporter: It wouldn't hurt to try and reach out. If she isn't available, there are other services.

seeker: What like support groups etc? I'm also sure this isn't just related to lockdown and not seeing my specialist. It's weird and a little concerning to be honest.
supporter: Not necessarily support groups, but more like psychiatry apps where a trained professional is available via chat, or video and its specifically through the app.

seeker: I hadn't thought of that. I know there are a few of these nowadays.
supporter: There a lot more since Covid began in March, so it's worth as a backup plan if your doctor isn't available. Sometimes its good to have options.

seeker: I'll start a plan and seeing if I can see my usual therapist and go from there. Sometimes it just helps talk it through depression stops you from seeing things clearly. Do you have any experience with mental health issues?
supporter: After my son was born I developed Post Partem depression and anxiety. It wasn't until almost a year and half after he was born to realize it.

seeker: That must have been difficult to deal with. Mental health affects so many people in so many ways. It's good that it's recognised these days at least.
supporter: It was. Luckily I had my doctor to help me. Family members meant well but chalked it up to "that's what its like to be a mom" but it is more than that.

seeker: I think this is why it's always best to see a professional. I really should try to reconnect with mine.
supporter: I agree. There is a lot of well meaning advice out there, but its best to see a professional to really help you.

seeker: Thanks for the chat, it has helped me put things in perspective.
supporter: I'm glad I could help. I hope you get to speak with your psychiatrist, or at least find a good one through an app.

seeker:
Hi my company laid off 10% of the workforce yesterdsy and I'm worried 
I
supporter: My goodness. I know that's very difficult to handle. Are you feeling anxiety?

seeker: Yeah, I'm really nervous about what's happening. Based on who they let go, I think I'll be next because of tenure and experience level.
supporter: So would it appear that they are laying off the people who have been there the shortest time first?

seeker: Well it's a mix of tenure and department. They also furloughed another 10% of the workforce as well so we're 20% smaller now
supporter: I know this is a terrible time to be laid off from your job. Do you feel that you have a contingency plan if you are one of those who is laid off?

seeker: No and we are in a worse position. My wife was laid off from her job 3 months ago. I'm the only breadwinner right now
supporter: Oh my goodness. Will either of you be able to claim unemployment while you search for new jobs? My brother was recently laid off and he's considering out of state options to hopefully find a job sooner. While that's certainly not an option for everyone, his unemployment is helping to keep his family afloat.

seeker: Yeah my wife filed and we just started getting it but it's nowhere what she was making of course. But yeah we can at least pay the electric bill and stuff.
supporter: Ok, well that's one small thing to help. Are you a renter or owner? As there are a few programs available to help with mortgage payments.

seeker: I'm an owner. What kind of programs?
supporter: Check on the government page for your state. It's usually your state.gov  an example is Utah.gov. Google it. Most states have aid available but a lot of people just aren't aware of it.

seeker: oh ok that's a good point. I will definitely go look for it after this discussion
supporter: I hope you can find the assistance you need. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss?

seeker: yeah how can I make more money on the side?
supporter: As there are a lot of people who've lost their jobs the pickins' are quite slim. But being as the holiday season is upon us. I do knwo there are several stores hiring for seasonal help. Also, Amazon is hiring for customer services reps to work from home I've heard.

seeker: oh cool, that's good to know. Well, I appreciate all your help. I hope you and your family stay safe during the holidays!
supporter: If it's in your area Instacart is also hiring shoppers and delivery drivers. Is that something you might be able to do?

seeker: Hi I am not sure what to say here. I am not doing very well at all. I am feel sad and hopeless all the time, nothing is any fun, nothing makes me feel that I am doing anything good for anyone.
supporter: I am truly sorry you are feeling this way. Those feelings can be overwhelming. Have you tried talking to a professional about this?

seeker: I don't have any money to pay someone, my boyfriend tells me to quit having a pity party no one is coming to it and to just get over it. His comments and suggestions have not been helpful. My friends have tried to cheer me up but I can tell they are getting frustrated with me and I try to avoid them now.
supporter: There are many therapists out there that work on a sliding scale based on your income. Some even offer free sessions. I would look into that for your local area. It also does not seem like your boyfriend is taking the issue seriously.

seeker: I don't mean to put obstacles in the way of your help but I live 25 miles from town and there is no public transportation here and I don't have a car. You have felt like this before? How long did it last? What did you do to get better?
supporter: It lasts until you deal with it. I talked to someone to help me understand why an dhow i was feeling this way. Dont worry about putting obstacles for me heh im here to help you.

seeker: I think I feel this way because I feel so stuck. I make a little money working remotely but not enough to make any     big changes and the things I do don't ever last like the house is only clean for moments.
supporter: I can relate to that, spend 8 hours cleaning the place up for my 10 year old to tear it all down in 10 minutes. Jobs are a whole other can of worms as well. May i suggest though that, even though big goals are great to strive for, you set a bunch of smaller goals to complete?

seeker: What would be an example of a smaller goal? Enjoy your son my kids are grown and gone and it happens faster than you think.
supporter: Yea just last year they were a baby in my eyes ha. Maybe just even something as apply to 2 new jobs this week. Clean the kitchen on monday. Simple things.

seeker: I don't really have big goals because they all seem too impossible to be realistic.
supporter: How about starting with just doing the dishes, or wiping down the counter?

seeker: That would be a simple goal, I could try for that, I think maybe I should make my first goal to find an online therapist with a sliding fee scale. Do you know if there are any kind of directories for online therapists?
supporter: Yes i think that would be a great first step. I would try a google search like "Therapists (My Area) Sliding Scale"

seeker: Thank you things don't seem quite as hopeless now and I don't feel so alone and misunderstood. You have a nice day and I am going to go do that search now.
supporter: Great! I hope for the best for you!

seeker: Hello. I just find life very hard. I have not been happy in months.
supporter: i hear you. it has been a hard year. what's been the biggest challenge for you?

seeker: Going out and getting things done. Shopping is hard especially when stores are picked over.
supporter: it is frustrating not being able to get what you want when you want it. are you having a hard time finding the things you need for right now or for in the future?

seeker: Both. I feel like the future is uncertain. Not just for me but the world.
supporter: it's true, we are not sure what to expect. have you looked for things online?

seeker: Yes, but I feel like a lot of it is speculation and news just makes people more fearful.
supporter: it is like there's a collective panic going on right now. I know for me focusing on the things i CAN control has helped me from spiraling into panic and depression

seeker: How do you deal with other people who focus on all the bad things?
supporter:
the "little black rain cloud" people? LOL

I try very hard to be kind and remember that we all are going throgh the same pandemic and for most of us it's our first

seeker: Thanks. Do you think things will get better any time soon?
supporter: While there is a lot to focus on that is just awful, it has really helped me to look back to the spanish flue of 1918

seeker: I know people thinking the country will collapse soon. Hard to deal with them.
supporter: The doomsday people are always around. remeber they mayans predicted the end of the world in 2012

seeker: I have family like that and it is hard to deal with them. Especially during the holidays.
supporter: are you familiar with Mr. Rogers' story about looking for the helpers when things go bad?

seeker: No but I did love that show as a kid.
supporter: Family is hard! So many strong emotions and opinions that aren't always helpful. anyone in particular for you?

seeker: My dad and my GF's dad both have their own opinons on things
supporter: so when disasters happen you dont focus on the bad things but look and you will always find people helping other people

seeker: Yes. I also don't feel like the world will decent into madness, but they do not believe it.
supporter: oooh, that's hard. are you living at home with your dad?

seeker: No but near him and take care of him.
supporter: that's really nice of you. i'm 800+ miles away from my parents

seeker: That is good and bad. I think it is good to talk about though I do feel a little better thank you.
supporter: if i can suggest something that might help - brene brown, a leadership coach and researcher has a great TED talk about shame and vunerability and a CUTE cartoon animal video on yourtube about empathy

seeker: Ok thank you very much. I think this is a good stopping point, so thank you for your help
supporter: those help me focus on how hard it is for everyone around me and that i should be kinder to them. everyone has their own crap

seeker: Indeed. it helps to have people to talk to right?
supporter: true. stay safe

seeker: Hi, I'm feeling really anxious today.
supporter: What has made you feel anxious?

seeker: Yesterday my company laid off 10% of the workforce and another 10% got furloughed.
supporter: I am very sorry to hear that. I am currently in a situation where furloughs are greatly affecting my family as well.

seeker: Oh no that's terrible.
supporter: Are you given specifics on time of furlough?

seeker: No, it's basically until things get better.
supporter: I know that's very difficult. And no doubt why you're here working for crumbs.

seeker: Yeah, trying to make ends meet wherever I can
supporter: I know it's a difficult time. Yes Uber is definitely overrun right now. Have you taken any time out to address your anxiety so it doesn't become more serious?

seeker: I don't know what I can do. I've been trying to keep busy. And I can't afford a therapist or anything like that.
supporter: Yes, that's definitely an expense you can't afford right now. But are you familiar with the concept of controlled breathing to help reduce or relieve anxiety?

seeker: Like meditation?
supporter: Not exactly. Controlled breathing is more of getting yourself into a quiet room. Closing your eyes, and purposely and intently focusing on your breathing. Slowly breathe in for a count of 5, then slowly exhale for a count of 5. Repeat this process for approximately 10 minute. It will help your stress levels and help regulate your heart rate!

seeker: Oh I didn't know that. No, I haven't tried that. Does it really work?
supporter: I've been using it myself over the past 3 months and it most definitely helps! But it's absolutely imperative to clear your mind and have complete quiet.

seeker: ok I can try it I guess
supporter: No problem. I hope this gives you some relief! Stay strong!

seeker: yeah, thanks. same to you
supporter: My final piece of advice would be to set aside time that is specified where nothing negative is discussed. No politics, no bills, nothing anxiety producing for you. It's probably best if this time is within an hour of your bedtime becuase anxiety is not conducive to a good night's sleep.

seeker: That's helpful. Thanks.
supporter: No problem. Take care. Wishing you well on your situation.

seeker: Online learning is not seems easy, Seems I am going to fail this year
supporter: chill my dear friend, nothing of that sort will happen

seeker: In-class learning was way better and I learned a lot but now its so confusing
supporter: everything you need is a little peace of mind, patience and little more effort

seeker: Even working with online tools is hard
supporter: i understand, but just think everyone else like us are doing the same and facing the same difficulties

seeker: I know but what is I loose a whole year in academic,
supporter: Think positive my dear friend

seeker: But I have been in low grades continuously during my last semesters.
supporter: Just have the confidence within yourselves and believe in YOU, that is the most important thing

seeker: Well it is still hard to understand online learning tools
supporter: Watch Youtube videos

seeker: And my internet sometime screws up when I am submitting the assignments
supporter: Why cant you seek help from a friend of yours who studies well?

seeker: Due to social distancing I am not meeting with many people
supporter: you dont have to meet a lot of people, but atleast one or two of your friends with all the safety measures ? who could really help you,and also one of the best solution can be group studies as well

seeker: I'm so sad all the time.
supporter: Is there something that you think is causing this?

seeker: Nothing in particular, I'm just so sad.
supporter: Have you any history of depression before?

seeker: I do have some family members with depression.
supporter: Have you seen any physicians about the problem?

seeker: Maybe I should make an appointment.
supporter: Getting help from a trained professional can often help to solve problems

seeker: You make a good point.  What type of doctor could I see?
supporter: You could try going to your primary care physician and ask for recommendations.

seeker: I can do that.  Are there any doctors that deal with emotions?
supporter: I've help take a family member to a psychiatrist for help and it's been a tremendous support to help their lives be full again after great hardships.

seeker: I'm worried about the stigma of going to a shrink.
supporter: Under HIPPA your visit is confidential.

seeker: Well in that case, if it can help it may be worth a try.
supporter: You deserve lots of credit for taking care of yourself and seeing a doctor.

seeker: Thank you for the encouragement.
supporter: You are very welcome.  Is there anything else I can help you with?

seeker: Hi there. I'm seeking some support, maybe some advice in dealing with a situation at my work.
supporter: Sure, I see you need some support at work because your new supervisor is so different than your previous one

seeker: Yes. They have a Military background and bark orders, and change the way I'm working without being open to conversation.
supporter: Wow, that sounds difficult with them being so militant.  Have you been able to talk to any co-workers in a similar situation?

seeker: Yes, there are two other people supervised by him. One of them is also Military and new him before hand, they seem to get along great.
supporter: That sounds hard that it is so hostile at work when you trying so hard.

seeker: Yea. But when he threatens and calls my insubordinate, I worry he might be making a case to remove me.
supporter: It sounds like you worry about having your job taken away from you.  Talking to someone above your supervisor may be a good solution.

seeker: Its been 3 months since he started, I just wonder if its too soon.
supporter: When I was in a similar situation I had to go to a higher supervisor and was helped a lot. It probably is never too soon, but could be too late if you wait.

seeker: Thats true. I'm not happy at work, but I do love my job. I enjoyed it a lot before him arrived. But now I'm constantly thinking about finding a new job, or worrying about him pushing me out. Maybe thats what he wants, so he can bring in his own people?
supporter: I see you really like your job.  Sometimes just taking a deep breath can help to calm stress.

seeker: Thats good advice. I do need to do more outside of work to relieve the stress.
supporter: Do you think he'll be receptive to your communications if you speak directly to him?

seeker: I think its worth a try, but I don't want him to think I'm being argumentative. Any suggestions on how to have that conversation?
supporter: I can see that you worry about your boss seeing you as argumentative, but could you try it from the perspective of making your boss feel like he is in control?

seeker: Making it his idea. That's a good tactic. I could try that.
supporter: Is there anything else I can help you with today?

seeker: I think you've given me some good advice.
supporter: You are welcome.

seeker: I appreciate it!
supporter: I wish you well.

seeker: You too. Good bye!
supporter: Bye

seeker: The unemployment office is overwhelmed and I'm overwhelmed trying to help my family member.
supporter: These days all of us have this situation. I can assure you that your family can understand it

seeker: Yes,it just very frustrating. My family member has taken another restaurant job only to lose it again for the same reasons, COVID.
supporter: I also worked in a coffee house and it has been closed for this damn virus.

seeker: The job center's can only help so much. And if they don't have internet skills,then online jobs will help.
supporter: This sounds good.

seeker: So this family member gave up their apartment, moved back in with family, still fighting unemployment and going to food banks. It's crazy
supporter: I wish this virus ends soon. But believe me everyone have similar situation these days

seeker: No online computer skills, but they now learned where to get some basic training.
supporter: This sounds good. Wish to learn soon

seeker: I'm so sorry. I feel a little better talking about this. My family tries to help other family members but we can only do so much. That's when I got frustrated (helping them with unemployment)
supporter: Money is not always a big deal honey

seeker: Yes, there is more to life than money. Unfortunately $ is needed for the basics.
supporter: Of course but having them by your side is a gift.

seeker: Yes and I wish you a good thanksgiving holiday.
supporter: You too

seeker: I am very upset
supporter: Hello, how are you doing today?

seeker: A friend of more than 20 years hurt me deeply by judging me for not buying a gift for my nephew for his birthday.
supporter: Why would they judge you on that? Do they know your nephew as well?

seeker: Yes, she is very close friends with my nephew's mother as well. She is the kind of person who will go into deep debt and overdraw her bank account to buy someone a gift, I am not. I could not afford the gift, I am disabled and on a very minimal income.
supporter: That i can relate too, i am also disabled and on SSI. Have you spoken to her about how she upset you?

seeker: I did. I took a few days to cool off and then told her that her comments hurt me. I know that she's aware of my financial situation as well as the fact that I am disabled. Her response was that she said nothing wrong.
supporter: Thats a tough spot to be in with a friendship that has lasted so long. Does she tend to treat you like this regularly?

seeker: No, she really never has. Typically, she feels like other people walk all over her and take advantage of her, but that's never been me and its never been our relationship.
supporter: Then would you say its a little odd for her to be acting in this manner towards you?

seeker: Yes, quite. At times over the years she can become quite self absorbed. But she's never been so downright hurtful. I can't really see a way for our relationship to be the same anymore.
supporter: I would agree that the relationship is getting a bit toxic but before terminating such a long relationship i would do one thing. I would try to see if there is something going on in her life right now for her to be acting like this. Sometimes people dont know how to talk about something thats bothering then and it in turn comes out as anger or spite.

seeker: That's true. We've been through a lot together over the years. But I can't deny that what she said hurt, and our conversations are just so superficial now.
supporter: Yeah to be honest if you press the issue and ask if anything is going and you continue to get toxic responses. It might be time to end the friendship. I would do that as a last resort but there is no need for you to be carrying it one sided and holding all the burden as well. It hurts to have to end a long friendship but unfortunately sometimes it has to happen to keep yourself in a better spot.

seeker: Hello, I'm feeling very anxious about my classes. How are you?
supporter: I am doing well, I also get really anxious about my classes. They can be really stressful

seeker: Yeah, especially with the pandemic, it's just been so hard to try and focus
supporter: I agree, there is so much going on that it is hard to stay focused while trying to make sense of all this

seeker: Exactly. Do you have any suggestions for what I can do to try and do better in my classes? I've tried talking to my professors, but they've all been really unhelpful thus far
supporter: Of course! I like to wake up a little earlier and at least get started on an assignment to feel like I have accomplished something at least before the rest of the world wakes up. I understand some people like their sleep, so another suggestion is to review any notes you take and use different colored ink for different topics or important highlights

seeker: I think that's a really good idea! I usually sleep in too late and then feel like I'm rushing around to get all of my work done, only adding onto the stress. I also really like the pen idea. Do you have any suggestions for good brands that I should use to help make my notes better?
supporter: Uniball makes really good pens that the option to switch colors on the pen, but they sell packs with different colors too. I like to use red ink for really important things, and blue for things I might think I will need later but aren't sure.

seeker: I think that's a really good idea for helping to improve my focus. If my notes are more eye-catching, it'll help to keep my attention when I'm looking over them again after class and trying to study. I think your suggestion of waking up earlier is good too, what time do you suggest waking up in the morning? I usually don't set an alarm and find myself rushing around before class
supporter: I personally wake up around 6AM and have just gotten used to it so I wake up that time no matter what. I blame the army.  But, an alarm on your phone or computer can be effective. Even having someone you know that wakes up early call you can be a help, provided you are not grumpy at being woke up :)

seeker: I think that would really help. I sometimes have trouble waking up to my alarms in the morning too, but maybe making the ringtone louder would help with that as well or putting it further away from me so that I have to get up further in the morning to get it. Do you think those would be effective too? Or would getting a different alarm help?
supporter: That is a really good idea actually!! I should try that and put my phone on the other side of the room next time I want to wake up earlier. I personally use the most annoying thing I can find as a ringtone/alarm, so that I will make every effort to turn it off but a lot of the alarm clocks you can find in stores are plenty loud and annoying.

seeker: Ooh, yeah. I like your ringtone idea too! I usually make it some sort of song that I like and then end up either sleeping past it or not hearing, but I think making it something loud or annoying would really help to get me up to turn it off.
supporter: What exactly do you think causes you to have to rush around before class? Just not enough time or just situations you cannot control. Trust me I understand myself, I have been in college 2.5 years myself. and it took about 1.5 years to get to where I was comfortable with my schedule and personal time

seeker: I think knowing that I don't have to drive to campus is what makes me feel like I can sleep in. It feels much easier to just wake up and go onto my computer than having to get ready in the morning and drive to campus. I think I mostly miss that routine. Because of that, I also find myself going to bed much later than I should be, even on school nights.
supporter: That is a good rational reason I would say, I do online classes too and it is far too easy just to wake up, go to the computer and that is it for the day. Campus life seems more structured and like you could plan a routine, but being stuck at home sort of changes all of that.

seeker: Exactly. It was much easier for me when I had a routine schedule, versus knowing that I can just wake up, roll out of bed, and go to class, but I think that your suggestions are really going to help me finish my semester on a better foot
supporter: I am really glad I can help, I think part of me was talking to myself as well when giving advice since I have gotten alot lazier these days. I hope you have a great day and hang in there and stay focused and you will do great!!!!!

seeker: hi my friend
supporter: Hello ! How are you doing?

seeker: feeling very shame
supporter: Oh my god ! What happened?

seeker: i have cheated on my girlfriend
supporter: I feel sorry for you .. What was the reason behind that ?

seeker: me and my girlfriend mom had an physical relationship but till now my girlfriend belives im good guy
supporter: Calm down friend

seeker: what should i do now
supporter: Can i know the reason why you got attracted to her mom when she herself is there ?

seeker: i have gone to her home.her mom taken advantage to me what should i dothat time so we did it
supporter: I understand , so now forget from beng guilty

seeker: sure i will try to solve my problem

Tell her, if she repeats this , then you are either gonna tell it to your girlfriend or either file a complaint against her.

seeker: yyeah sure my friend i will try this
supporter: Yess

seeker: I am worried about being perfect on my job.  I don't want to lose my job.
supporter: I hear you are trying to be perfect on your job because you are worried about losing your job.  How long have you been at your job?

seeker: I have been working for about 4 months, but I just am not as fast at it as everyone else.  I'm trying so hard working late and everything but it's never enough.
supporter: That can be hard when you are working so hard to try to do your best.  Can you consult with a supervisor or co-workers to get some help?

seeker: Maybe I could ask my friend and co-worker for some tips.  I'm a little embarrassed to do so, but don't know where to turn. I don't want to get fired.
supporter: Asking for help isn't always a bad thing.  I asked for help at my last job and they gave me someone to help out.  I was so relieved.

seeker: That's true maybe it could turn out for the better.  But what if they see me as incompetant?
supporter: I can see that you have worry of being seen incompetent but as long as you are doing your best, they have to see the efforts you are making as positive.

seeker: That's a good way to put it.
supporter: Sometimes deep breaths can help keep you calm when approaching others in an anxiety provoking situation.

seeker: I will have to try that.  That might help.
supporter: Have you thought of doing additional work related trainings?  Sometimes they can give suggestions to improve work abilities.

seeker: That sounds great.  Do you think my work would be supportive?
supporter: Work can often pay for trainings or offer suggestions what may improve work strategies.

seeker: Wow, I hope I can take advantage of that.  I will have to check into that.  Who should I approach at work?
supporter: You could ask your immediate supervisor or sometimes Human resources for support.

seeker: I can do that.  I think I'll reach out tomorrow to Human Resources for some help.
supporter: That sounds like a good plan to reach out for support.  Is there anything else I can help with?

seeker: No that should be all.  I am feeling more confident in strategies to use to help me.  Thanks
supporter: You are very welcome.

seeker: Hi I am so sad my boyfriend was cheating and broke up with me when I found out. I don't think I can ever be happy again.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. reading your opening statement it sounds like you are now suffering from low self-esteem is that true?

seeker: I have always had problems with low self esteem this makes it worse. I have lost interest in everything I can barely make myself go to work.
supporter: do you think if you knew the reasons why the relationship ended it would help you deal with things a lot better?

seeker: Maybe, why would he cheat? I have seen her she is not that pretty. I thought something was going on the last few months but he kept telling me everything was fine and that it was all my imagination.
supporter: remember the fact that he cheated is not your fault. if he entered into a committed relationship with you you should not be cheating. if things aren't right you should be talking this through with you before deciding to move on and see someone else.

seeker: I thought I was a good girlfriend, I was loyal, nice to his friends, kept the house nice, cooked for him, he never said he was unhappy he just started having to work nights and weekends a lot with no overtime he said he was salary now. I must just be unlovable.
supporter: have you tried getting back out there and dating again? just because he didn't want to have an honest relationship with you, doesn't mean that nobody else does. also in my message above I have made a couple of autocorrect errors, apologies for that.

seeker: I trusted what he told me despite my gut feeling which turned out to be right. I thought we were so perfect together, I don't want him back I could never trust him again, I am not sure I could trust any guy right now, I am so hurt and confused. I don't  ever want to feel like this again.
supporter: relationship issues, especially when they and suddenly can be one of the most stressful periods in an adults life. you are not alone in that other people have been through similar experiences themselves

seeker: This was the first guy I ever lived with, I  thought we would get married one day. How do people make it through the pain, it actually hurts.
supporter: Do you have someone who you can talk to about this to support you?

seeker: I have a couple acquaintances at work but I wouldn't want to discuss my personal life with, my mom said to have  a good cry but I almost couldn't stop once I started. He was my best friend and who I talked to once we got together I didn't seem to need anyone else which looks like a mistake now. That is why I am here for support.
supporter: Ok I understand. It is normal to be upset in a situation like this. When I ask if there is someone to talk to, I meant perhaps a friend or someone who has experienced a similar breakup. There are also support groups out there that can really help. Getting your emotions out and seeing that others struggle with the same issue may be a very good thing.

seeker: Have you ever had a break up of a serious relationship or know someone who has? Does the aching inside ever get better? How long will it take?
supporter: When I was younger, my girlfriend cheated on me. We were together for 4 years. For me, it turned to anger not sadness, I was so angry that she did that to me. I realised that if she was capable of doing this, it's better that I found out now, rather than when we were engaged or married. I loved her but after she cheated, I couldn't stand the sight of her. I completely understand the feelings you are experiencing. The good news is that I have since met someone wonderful, we have children and I am now very happy.

seeker: I am sorry that happened to you but glad it turned out well in the end. You have a good point that it is better to know now than after we got married. I do have a nice neighbor who expressed concern when he noticed my boyfriend was gone. He said if I ever needed someone to talk to he was there. I thought he was just being nice. Maybe I should go talk to him some time maybe he was sincere.
supporter: I think that that would be a good idea! for info, In terms of how long it takes to get over it. I have read a statistic that is takes half the length of the relationship to truly get over it. Personally I think it does depend on the person and how things end in terms of the breakup.

seeker: Thank you for checking on that for me, I hope it is quicker I would hate to feel this way that long. I think I will go see him he is home right now. You have made me feel hopeful and that there will be an end to these feelings and maybe things will go as well for me as they did you. Thank you again.
supporter: You are very welcome!

seeker: I am worried after breaking up with my boyfriend that I will never find love again.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear about your breakup. Was it your boyfriend that ended the relationship and how long were you guys together?

seeker: We were together for 3 years and he ended it suddenly.
supporter: this actually happened to me last year. my girlfriend ended things completely out of the blue. it came to light that she felt this way for a while but didn't know how to speak to me about it.

seeker: It's such a shocker and I'm dumbfounded and sad.
supporter: it is true that relationships can have a big impact on us especially when the end suddenly and seemingly without reason. this must be very stressful.

seeker: Yes, I wonder if I will ever love again.
supporter: it does take time to get over a breakup especially one that ends suddenly but I think once you get over the initial shockyou seem like a positive person so I believe you can get over this

seeker: Thanks.  What should I do next?
supporter: do you have any friends or family that you can talk to about your feelings?

seeker: Maybe I could talk to my friend Sam because she just broke up with her boyfriend.
supporter: speaking to others who have had similar experiences it's always a good idea. they may be able to offer a fresh perspective that you haven't considered before

seeker: She's worked through the process a little longer than I so maybe she could see things from a more rational perspective.
supporter:
that's good, I'd definitely reach out to her, especially when the Break-Up is so fresh. you may not be thinking clearly and a friend that
 understands might really help.

seeker: You are right.  I hope this works.
supporter: you have been through a really tough time. I do think you can get through this though and come out the other side. I believe you can do it!

seeker: I am glad for the encouragement.   What should I do when I start to panic about being alone?
supporter: I can tell that you are worried that you will be lonely forever and I can tell you are anxious about that.

seeker: Yes, that is scary.
supporter: It is a big world out there and there will be someone else that is right for you. Personally, if he cheated then it may be a good thing that you found out now and not further down the line, after you had invested even more time into the relationship.

seeker: I love my friends but today hatred in my life
supporter: It's great that you have friends in your life that you love. What is causing you to feel that you hate your life today?

seeker: My friend saw the lie
supporter: Ok. Your friends saw the lie. do you mean to say that your friends uncovered a lie you told them?

seeker: Yes he told lie to me
supporter: So a good friend told you a lie? Do you feel that the lie was meant to hurt you?

seeker: I am very hurted
supporter: How did the lie hurt you?

seeker: He say that lie i will hurt
supporter: How long have you know him? Has he lied to you in the past?

seeker: 10 year friendship no one lie to the past
supporter: That says a lot that he has never lied to you prior to this. What do you think changed about him to cause him to lie this time?

seeker: He say sorry to me i accepted
supporter: Sometimes a little space can help resolve feelings. Do you feel that a little time would help you to be able to accept his apology and forgive him?

seeker: Ok i accepted
supporter: Have you communicated to him that his lie hurt you?

seeker: Hello.
supporter: Hello how are you today?

seeker: I'm okay. Facing a tough decision and having a hard time coping.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. Would you like to talk about it?

seeker: Yes, thank you. I decided to go back to school to finish my BA.
supporter: Its great that you decided to go back to school. Are you having trouble selecting a college or something like that?

seeker: Well now with the pandemic I don't know if it's the right time anymore.
supporter: I understand your concern  given the current pandemic situation. But I have heard some colleges are offering online courses until this pandemic is over. Maybe you can explore in that direction to ease your worries.

seeker:
I'm taking online courses right now, and I really don't like it. I much prefer in classroo
m lecture.
supporter: I definitely resonate with the way you feel about online learning. Although difficult it is also important to stay indoors to keep yourself safe. Is there anything that will motivate you?

seeker: I don't know. I want to see if I could find classes conducted with Zoom or video.
supporter: Maybe you can check with the college if they would consider offering classes over zoom as this is the most preferred mode of instruction.

seeker: I will try to do that. If that's my only option right now, then I will have to settle for classes conducted over livestream. I just don't like self-learning.
supporter: Sounds like a plan and am happy to see that you are sure about what you want.

seeker: Yes, I just wish it could be the way it was. I was so happy to be back in school and I'm so close to being done.
supporter: I too wish everything goes back to the way it was and it will one day. We have to adjust to a slightly new way of living and this would happen if each one of us do our part to break the chain and flatten the curve.

seeker: I agree. I still hate it though.
supporter: You can do it, as you said you are almost there. Once you do it you will be very proud of yourself. Believe me this is just a temporary setback and you are doing a great job.

seeker:
Thank you for the words of encouragement. I do appreciate
 that.
supporter: I am glad I could make you feel better. Is there anything else I can do today for you?

seeker: Hello there.  I am feeling a bit down.
supporter: Would you like to go into the reasons why you are feeling down?

seeker: Sure.   I am not going to be able to do Thanksgiving with my parents because of Covid and I am kind of bummed out about it.  Some mild depression.
supporter: I hear that, we are only doing it for just our house this year. Have you considered doing something virtual?

seeker: Well yeah, but it's not the same.  I know I am doing the right thing, but it still sucks.
supporter: Yea some times the right thing does suck, and i know its not the same. I do know zoom has removed the 40 min restrictions for thanksgiving, so at least you can see your parents as long as you want.

seeker: Oh that's nice, I didn't know that.  Thanks.  I thought about trying a video wifi call on the phone but that would be better.
supporter: Thought it might help a little. These times do hurt but at least you are being smart about it. I would maybe try to plan something fun you guys could do over the call. Make it a bit interesting.

seeker: Yes, I think I going to get some bread pudding and drop it off over there too.  I can take enough precautions to make sure it is safe for them.
supporter: Oh thats nice that you are close enough to be able to do that now. At least you will be able to taste a bit of home cooking right?

seeker: Yeah I guess we can do a toast and stuff on zoom.  That might be a little better.
supporter: Yea, and hey maybe when the vaccine is readily available and we can start seeing our family safely again, we can make a new tradition. A new V-Day celebration heh.

seeker: Are you kind of in the same boat?  It helps a little bit talking with somebody that is.
supporter: Yea, i have my daughter and partner. But we usually have a big family dinner with people coming in from all over the country. We are trying the zoom thing too. Gonna be hectic but hopefully fun

seeker: I see, well my family isn't that big but we do try to get together every thanksgiving to have a good meal and hopefully watch the Cowboys win.  This will be the first time in a long while that I can even think of we aren't doing it.
supporter: Yea i dont think anyone here has missed one in years. My partner will be cheering on the cowboys for you as well ha. I was trying to tell my partner though, traditions have to start somewhere, why cant now be time to start a new one?

seeker: That's a fair point.  Hopefully this will only be a one year disturbance with these vaccines on their way.  They should both have theirs well before then and hopefully me too.
supporter: Yea it is looking good with for both vaccines right now. I always try to focus on the positives. You can almost always find some good in a bad situation.

seeker: Agreed.  Well you have been most helpful letting me vent a little and talk about it.  Thanks a lot.
supporter: Not a problem. I hope you get to see your family sooner than later. No reason why you cant cook up a nice turkey when we can!

seeker: We will make it through this.  Take care and thanks a lot.
supporter: You too and stay safe!

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hello!  How are you doing today?

seeker: Not too good, I've just been feeling really tired lately. I haven't had the energy to do anything no matter how hard I try
supporter: What do you do for a living?  Are you stretching yourself too thin?

seeker: I'm a freelance writer so I can choose my own hours. I haven't been going over the top with my hours, I'm definitely doing less now than I did before
supporter: Sometimes I find that when I am doing less I end up being more exhausted.

seeker: Yeah, the more I sleep the more I want to sleep. The fact that I don;t have set hours means that I just stay in bed for ages before a deadline
supporter: Have you been spending any time outside or exercising?  Science has shown that boost of endorphins you get from sunlight or exercise can help with energy.

seeker: No we're back in lockdown here so I've been staying inside unless I need groceries and stuff
supporter: Not having motivation is a tough feeling to overcome.  I think a lot of people are suffering with this issue due to todays current affairs.

seeker: Yeah I honestly think that's what's affected my mood, it doesn't help that my uncle recently got diagnosed with covid
supporter: Do you think it could help you if you tried to spend some more time outside or exercising?

seeker: I'm just burnt out I think.
supporter: Even if you just do something easy like a walk around the block.  Or sit in front of a window while the sun floods in on you.

seeker: Yeah I guess that's something I should consider
supporter: I try to make sure that on sunny days I open all of my blinds.  It forces me to get out of bed, and the vitamin D boost from the sunshine helps to keep me motivated.

seeker: I honestly can't tell the last time I even opened my blinds so I could do that.
supporter: That's great!  I am glad to help.  I am confident that you can overcome this time.

seeker: Fingers crossed, I'll try those options you've given me though
supporter: You are very welcome.

seeker: Have there, I have a work issue that I'm hoping you can help me with
supporter: Sure, How can I help you?

seeker: I want to get a qualification but I'm working full-time at the moment and I also work very long hours. the problem is the courses that I want to do a huge time commitment. I'm really angry that I can't seem to get better qualifications to improve my life, because I need to work and need the income to keep me going. I feel stuck and don't know how to get past this.
supporter: Working and going to school can be tough. It must be very stressful.

seeker: you are right this is very stressful. I've gotten used to the steady income and now we lie on it. the problem is I do work quite late hours so have limited time to study. any suggestions?
supporter: I would ask for lesser hours if you can or study during your lunch breaks.

seeker: Perhaps I can ask for a different shift pattern yes, or reduce my hours. I may need to take a look at my finances and do a bit of recalculating. Have you ever had a situation like this?
supporter: I have not but I know people who are in your situation.

seeker: I wonder if there are courses and qualifications that you can get just by studying maybe an hour a day or an hour every other day?
supporter: I would look on sites like Skill share.

seeker: ok I've never heard of skillshare, is that a website where you can get more information about work based qualifications etc?
supporter: I think so

seeker: yeah that's very true. I've never heard of that before so thanks for the tip.
supporter: Youre welcome

seeker: also I'm not sure why this is making me feel so angry I think it's the stress of the situation. you mentioned what I can do to relax at the end of the day, do you think this will help see things more clearly?
supporter: Skill share can help you learn new skills and try out yoga or mediation.

seeker: yeah I read that yoga I can be really good for your health and your mental well-being.
supporter: There is an app called Calm that you can use for free or you can pay for it to unlock new features.

seeker: I didn't realise there was so much support available. thanks again for the suggestions!
supporter: You are welcome anything else I can help with?

seeker: No that's great. Thanks for your help
supporter: Youre welcome have a nice day/night!

seeker: Hello.
supporter: Hi how are you doing today?

seeker: I'm alright, just feeling a bit depressed.
supporter: Im sorry you are feeling depressed. Whats making you feel that way?

seeker: Thanksgiving is this week and I will be spending it alone.
supporter: Youre spending thanksgiving alone? Do you usually spend Thanksgiving alone?

seeker: Yes, and no because of COVID I haven't been able to see my family.
supporter: I understand how you feel. COVID is causing a lot of distance between familys making relationships difficult.

seeker: Yes very. My family lives in another state.
supporter: I know what you mean, in-person is always better than over the phone. I understand why you would feel this way.

seeker: It's made me feel very depressed and I am only feeling worse as the holiday grows closer.
supporter: You're not alone in feeling this way. A lot of people are missing their families during the holidays. What would help you during this difficult times? besides video chatting? Can you still cook yourself a nice meal and do any traditions you normally do?

seeker: Yes I could do that. I was thinking about ordering a Thanksgiving Platter for 2 people so I could have some leftovers from a restaurant that I really like in my town.
supporter: thats a great idea!

seeker: And AMC always shows great holiday movies so I will watch a bunch.
supporter: dont worry, soon this pandemic will end and we can go back to the holidays we are used to. We just have to wait. I understand how hard it can make it on holidays though.

seeker: Yes I do hope so.
supporter: I love AMC/Holiday  movies as well!

seeker: I understand the situation is dire and people are sick, but everyone is suffering, even emotionally.
supporter: that is very true. our world has been so different this year

seeker: Yes it's sad.
supporter: Is there any foods you are looking forward to from your favorite restraunt or movie your interested to watch this year?

seeker: Yes of course. Mashed potatoes and gravy and the movie Four Christmases is hysterical.
supporter: great choices! mashed potatoes and gravy is my favorite too! and that movie is so funny.

seeker: Haha thanks. Well thank you for chatting with me, I feel better.
supporter: You sound like you have a great plan in place as a temporary holiday until we can be with our familes again. i know its not the same but you sound like you are making the best of the situation. which is all we can really do .

seeker: Thank you. I'm trying. I really miss my parents.
supporter: im glad you are feeling better and glad we could chat!

seeker: Hello there.
supporter: Hello, how can I help you today?

seeker: I'm having a bit of a bad time at the moment. I've been with my partner for 2 years she's great. unfortunately my feelings for her changed and we broke up recently. the problem is I think I've made a big mistake and worry that she's moved on with her life
supporter: OK, thanks for explaining. Can I ask what makes you think she has moved on with her life? how recently did you guys split up?

seeker: About three months ago. I have started to miss her badly. I saw her with another guy when I was out at the supermarket at the weekend. She lives near me so I wasn't surprised but I don't know who this guy is.
supporter: So to clarify, you ended things and think this wasn't the right thing to do. You have seen her with someone else and now you think you want her back.

seeker: Yeah that's right. I can't believe she has moved on so quickly.
supporter: Can I ask, for  how long have you thought you have made a mistake by ending things. was it when you saw her with someone else?

seeker: I must admit it was only when I saw her with someone else that I started to really miss her. do you think I'm just feeling jealous because we were so close and now I've seen her with someone else?
supporter: I had a friend who was in a very similar situation to this. he was in a long term relationship with a girl for 5-years. they split up and stayed friends. It was only when he saw her with someone else that he decided he wanted to give things another go.

seeker: I think you might be right actually. I didn't really miss her until I saw her with someone else. is this normal I don't know what to do about this?
supporter: I'd say this is completely normal. I can tell by talking to you that you did have strong feelings for this person once and seeing her with someone else has made you remember the good times.

seeker: Well that's good to know. I'm not normally the jealous type but I suppose we did have good times and I want her to be happy I suppose. I do think I've made a mistake though now I've thought about it!
supporter: I can tell you are a caring person and really do care about your ex-girlfriend happiness. I'm sure you will do the right thing but you need to think of yourself.

seeker: do you think I should try and get in touch with her and tell her how I feel?
supporter: I think you need to think carefully about what you really want. If you feel like this then I would suggest you do talk to her about it, however you may be best talking it through with a friend or family member first

seeker: That's not a bad idea. I think I will speak to one of my friends about this ,he's normally pretty good with that kind of thing.
supporter: yes it's really good to talk it through with someone first just really understand if trying to restart your old relationship is the right thing to do for you.

seeker: I think I conversation has actually helped me understand my motivations a little better. you have also given me some good suggestions so thank you for that
supporter: I'm happy to hear that.

seeker: Thanks for the conversation. It really helped.
supporter: You are very welcome.

seeker: oh hello
supporter: Oh I see. You feel as though you don't have any friend's currently? I totally get that. I feel like that a lot too, especially in these weird times we are going through. It's so hard to see people and keep relationships right now

seeker: Well it's more that I think I've never had friends. Not anyone I can confide in or laugh with
supporter: That's a really hard thing to be going through. I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have any really close family members that you are able to confide in?

seeker: I don't think I'd want to let them know how unhappy I am to be honest
supporter: Oh I see. Well personally, when I was going through a hard time and I felt like I didn't have any friends, I found a couple pretty cool apps that helped me out! IT sounds crazy, but there are apps specifically for finding friends. They are kind of like dating apps but it's 100% meant for friends so everyone on them has the same intentions you do. I actually found a couple close friends through apps like that. Have you heard about those or looked into them?

seeker: I've never heard of friendship apps to be honest
supporter: Yeah! They are a really good way to connect with people that you share a lot of similar interests with.

seeker: I'd really like someone local though, someone who I could meet up with face to face and who knew my town
supporter: On most of the apps, it connects you with people in your town!

seeker: I don't know if it's more than that. What do you mean?
supporter: Well personally, I have struggled with putting myself down a lot and blaming myself for things that I shouldn't blame myself for. You shouldn't blame yourself for not having the courage to go meet people, or blame yourself for not having any friends! And if that is what you are struggling with, then I think the apps would be a really good first step for you! You can create those bonds and connections with people close by to you on there first, and then when you feel comfortable enough with them you can meet up

seeker: oh you mean chat online first, before actually meeting in person?
supporter: Yeah, that is what is great about those friendship apps. You can get comfortable with them before you hangout :)

seeker: That's so cool. Thanks for your help
supporter: Yeah of course! I hope this helps you, and I wish you the best during these weird times :)

seeker: I don't know how to get over this
supporter: You are having some trouble getting over something is that correct?

seeker: I'm feeling just alright because nothing excites me or gives me joy anymore. Many of my family have passed on and the holidays are coming.
supporter: I understand that it is hard to have some type of joy especially with the holidays coming along especially when family has passed on.

seeker: This pandemic doesn't help either. No gatherings with many people.
supporter: I know it is hard, it also has taken a toll on me as well this pandemic is hard to go through, but I take it day by day. Maybe you should take to someone if there is anyone close to you?

seeker: Only my Aunt, but I haven't talked to her in a long time. I just figure she's busy.
supporter: maybe you should try to call her sometime im sure she would like that

seeker: How do I get over feeling like I'm dumping on her? I know she's family but i'm sure she has problems too.
supporter: right I see where you are coming from, remeber she is your family

seeker: Yes, I suppose you are right. My aunt is the youngest sister of my mom. We used to see each other at family gatherings. Maybe she won't mind me calling.
supporter: see you got this, a call is all that it takes to feel better

seeker: I'm going to follow your suggestion and get myself out of this slump I'm in. I know I'm not the only person who goes through this, but it feels this way sometimes.
supporter: I used to feel like that all the time but then I thought to myself that i needed to surround myself with people and not be alone.

seeker: You have a good point there. I used to think if I had my family then I didn't need anybody else. But we all need somebody to talk to.
supporter: exactly you got it, we all need to surround ourselves with good people, im glad that you realize this. I hope that my insight has given you motavation to pursue relationships

seeker: Thanks for your help. I'll go now and get my thoughts together to call my aunt.
supporter: alright awesome it was a pleasure talking to you, have a good day.

seeker: Enjoy your holidays!
supporter: you too!

seeker: i'm stressed about my family getting covid
supporter: I am sorry you are going through that and hope the results are negative. This are some tough times. Have you all been following protocol after finding out?

seeker: yes, he's been isolating. but i'm worried that we all with have to quarantine if he's positive
supporter: That is stressful to think about but would be a necessity. The only thing you all can do if it comes down to it is try to set it up so you all can be as comfortable as possible during the period.

seeker: That's true. everything just feels so out of control
supporter: When i feel like everything is out of control, i try to focus on small tasks that i can complete with ease. Maybe you can focus on setting up quarantine room, or getting medication and food to last for those weeks just in case. Worst case out of that is that you have some extra food and medicine.

seeker: i can focus on the things i can control - that's good advice. what have you been doing to stay sane through all of this?
supporter: Well for one my house has never been so spotless ha. I have been exercising more, going for more walks with my dog, having more family nights, just anything really that can take my mind of it.

seeker: Hello, I've had trouble with depression all my life but it hasn't been so bad in the past few years. But lately, with the pandemic, I seem to be sinking lower and lower
supporter: So it's been more difficult for you to remain cheerful since the plandemic?

seeker: Well, I'm still taking my medication, but now, I seem to be anxious all the time.
supporter: I actually have struggled with depression and anxiety most of my life so I can understand.

seeker: It's great to talk to someone who actually knows what it feels like!
supporter: That doesn't sound helpful at all.

seeker: It isn't, but I guess it's because they don't really know what *depression* feels like.
supporter: True, many people do not understand depression. I actually have found it easier to find a person who DOES understand and not talk to those who don't. When I talk to those who don't, it brings me down, so I find a good friend I can confide in.

seeker: Yes!! Talking to someone who doesn't know what it feels like REALLY makes me depressed!
supporter: I find it important to take care of my physical being first: eat well, drink water, exercise, get fresh air. Don't wear the mask if you can help it. Seeing smiles helps.

seeker: I haven't been exercising nearly as much since March. Maybe I need to start walking again.
supporter: I personally don't know anyone who has died and my nurse friends say it is no worse than the flu. So I try not to worry. What I think about is so critical. I try to pray about what I can't handle, then move on, change my thoughts.

seeker: I have a friend who did get it and almost died. He is 40 and pretty healthy. His wife and daughter got it too. They just had flu-like symptoms, but he was in the hospital for 9 days.
supporter: So to recap, find a good friend, get exercise, eat well, talk to people who will try to understand you.  And of course, pray.  The survival rate is 99.996% so the fact that you know no one who died is good news. I had flu like symptoms before this all happened and I still have a cough. They spray the skies too, so I try to not live in fear. There are a lot of consequences to fear, your heart beats faster, you stress yourself out, so it's important to not focus on negativity for too long.

seeker: I like your idea of changing thoughts. That would help keep me from "going down the rabbit hole!"
supporter: Here is a good saying -- if you want to change your feelings, change your thinking.  Feelings are like the tail on the dog, they follow thoughts. So keep your thoughts positive, cultivate an attitude of gratitude, even write a list of of things you are thankful for.

seeker: LOL! That's great!  I'll have to remember that "feelings are like the tail of the dog"!  That's a cheerful way of thinking about it!
supporter: I'm almost 60 and my husband is 66. We refuse to live in fear. These are difficult times, no doubt, but I believe if you take the time to pursue good healthy, you will be better for it, emotionally and mentally and physically. All around!

seeker: Yes, I think walking, changing my thoughts, praying, and taking care of myself will really help. Yes! You've really helped me out.
supporter: So we are about the same age then! I encourage you to write down the strategy, while the ideas are simple, sometimes they are NOT easy! We must make a choice to do what is healthy! God bless you!

supporter: Ok so you have felt like this for a while and it is getting worse not better. The intensity of your feelings is getting stronger and you worry that this will continue to get worse.

supporter: Firstly, you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with depression and it's good that you have reached out for help for this.

seeker: Any suggestions on what to do about it?
supporter: There are many reasons people have depression. It is a recognised medical condition and the good news is that there is help out there. The first step is recognising the problem.

seeker: Ok well there is definitely a problem.
supporter: Have you spoken to friends and family about this? do they know how much you are struggling with it at the moment?

seeker: not really I don't want to bother other people with my problems.
supporter: if people care about you then they will be happy to give you the time and listen to how you are feeling at the moment. I think it will be a really good move to speak to family or friends tell them how you are feeling and talk it through this might really help.

seeker: Yeah maybe. I suppose nobody really understands but I could at least speak to them about it.
supporter: everyone has problems and it is good to talk about them because a problem shared is a problem halved. It doesn't mean the problems will go away but it might help you understand them and then be able to deal with them better.

seeker: I don't want to feel like this anymore. I'm willing to at least give it a go.
supporter: I also think that it will be worse to get in touch with your doctor or a medical professional. these people are trained to deal with problems like yours and will be able to offer effective Solutions from a medical perspective.

supporter: are you worried that speaking to a doctor will lead to you being given medication, and you don't want this?

seeker: yes that's right I don't want to take any pills or anything like that.
supporter: I know that some forms of depression are caused by an imbalance of chemicals in the brain and medication in these cases can help. Also psychologists can support with mental health which means that this would not be a rude day involves any medication at all potentially

seeker: what do you mean be a rude day.
supporter: apologies this was a typo by autocorrect. I meant to say that this would not be a route that involves any medication at all potentially

supporter: That's great. I think the first step is always the hardest but you come across as someone that is willing to seek help and I believe that if you face into this you can overcome it witht he right support.

supporter: You're welcome.

supporter: I can tell that you are a nice person that cares for your girlfriend and you want the best for her. I think you want to be honest with her which is a good sign of maturity and integrity.

supporter: Unfortunately this may be upsetting in the short term. I had a friend who had a similar issue. He wanted to end things with his girlfriend and they ended up having an honest conversation, which was upsetting at the time but they are still friends to this day and parted on good terms.

supporter: I think the best thing to do would just be honest about your feelings and start the conversation with her. I think you could also consider when is the right time to do this so that you minimise the affect that this may have on her.

supporter: People who have a negative experience at a key point in their lives, such as a birthday of Christmas, tend to remember that bad experience the following year. I mean choose an appropriate time to have the discussion.

seeker: Ok I get it. Don't dump her on her birthday LOL. So I should just start the talk then, may be one evening?
supporter: Yes when she is available to have a good talk about this. Do you have my friends that you can talk to about this?

supporter: I think it's best to be honest and if it comes from the heart then you can at least say you have been honest with yourself and your girlfriend.

seeker: I think this is going to be hard but thanks for the suggestions
supporter: I think you can do this and have confidence that you will do it in the right way. These things are not easy but I know you can ride to the challenge and do this tactfully and with care.

seeker: Thanks for the kind words. I'll give this a try.
supporter: You are very welcome.

supporter: Take care

s

In reality everything was fine. There was an explainable reason behind the behaviour and it was nothing bad in the end.

supporter: Yes, I have had to deal with time pressures quite a few times. I am sure most people have in the modern era where everything moves so fast. I have usually gotten help from friends, or done my best to delay or remove other commitments from my life. As a last resort, I have sometimes had to accept that I would be getting less sleep than usual for a few days.

seeker: Perhaps I can ask if I can finish early from work for the next couple of days and get some time that way. I do think however I'll be more nervous due to less time to prepare. The thing is I'd delay the interview but this might affect my chances.

supporter: Well, everyone handles stressful situations differently, but there are some things you can do or try that might help. If you prepare as much as possible in the time that you have, you can be confident that you have done your best, and that is all that matters. You can decide that while you would like to get this new job, the world will not end if you don't get it, and you will worry less and have less stress. Also there is the classic technique of picturing your interviewer in their underwear. It makes them seem less imposing, and you can feel more confident.

seeker: I guess we are all in the same boat
supporter: Personally, I have tried to lessen my anxiety by limiting my intake of news and social media.  No matter what one might believe, there's always someone out there that's apparently going to take it to an extreme, and reading over and over about that is emotionally exhausting.
