supporter: Those both sounds great! Yoga is great for the body and the mind! I will sometimes just do it to clear my mind after a tough day. If your nervous about it, you could try out a few online classes first to see what to expect.

seeker: That is such a good idea. I often feel nervous going into a situation I'm not familiar and I feel like everyone will judge me.
supporter: That's understandable. Everyone has insecurities in unfamiliar places but in reality, most people are too wrapped up in their own heads they don't even notice anything else. You just have to feel confident and not worry about what other people think, that will set you free.

seeker: Hi, just needed some support for an issue
supporter: Sure, I'd be glad to help you.  Can you tell me more about the issue?

seeker: Sure, that would be fine. Can I ask first how you're doing today?
supporter: I'm feeling well, thank you!

seeker: That's good. The issue that I'm having is that I can't find a job/path in life, feels like I'm really struggling all the time
supporter: It sounds like you are working really hard, but struggling in job finding, is that right?

seeker: Yeah that's correct
supporter: I've often struggled with the same thing often sending out hundreds of resumes waiting for a response.

seeker: Yeah, tell me about it, it can be a real headache to say the least
supporter: It sounds like you are stressed about the situation and looking for a solution to move forward.

seeker: Yeah, exactly. Do you have any suggestions that could help with this? Seems like I'm going in circles
supporter: Have you tried speaking to job coaches or college counselors? They often have experience in this area and can be of support.

seeker: No I haven't reached out to anyone besides family, but that might be a good idea, getting a professional to help me out with some options
supporter: Have you thought of trying to search online?  You may be able to seek out different colleges and careers which may give you ideas and options you didn't explore before.

seeker: Yeah, I do most of my searching online, but maybe it's where I've been going that hasn't been helping much. Do you have any suggested websites or apps I could try out?
supporter: It sounds like you have been working hard looking for online options but maybe didn't find exactly what you are looking for.  Perhaps searching specific colleges in your state or areas of interest may help.  Also, career websites or job sites may help explore ideas as well as civil service career options.

seeker: That's a good idea, yeah I think I really need more options out there. But I do like your idea of talking to a professional or career counselor, maybe they'll be able to help me in more ways than I can help myself. I'm definitely going to try that!
supporter: I'm glad that you were able to get some ideas to try  and wish you well on your search.  Is there anything else I can assist you with at this time?

seeker: No, that's all right. Thanks for the suggestions, you've been really helpful, I'm going to try some of those out!
supporter: Great that sounds wonderful that you are trying out some ideas and keeping positive!

seeker: thanks again! bye!
supporter: Have a nice day!  Bye!

seeker: Hi! 😊
supporter: What's on your mind today?

seeker: Thank you for asking. I'm feeling very overwhelmed at the moment. My depression and the weight of everything is getting on top of me.
supporter: How long have you been in this state?

seeker: Well, the depression has been there as long as I can remember. It fluctuates. But the last few days have been particularly challenging and it's been difficult to get out of bed in the morning.
supporter: Is there any event happened the last few days that triggered your depression?

seeker: Yes. I guess it has coincided with an increase in challenging behaviours from my children.
supporter: That is tough, having depression and dealing with children at the same time. I totally understand how you feel

seeker: Thank you. Yes, he has been helpful today. He took the children to school for me so that I was able to get some things done around the house.
supporter: That's great, you have an awesome partner. I'd recommend spending time outdoor. Getting coop up for too long indoor is damaging to your mental state

seeker: It is very challenging as they both have complex special needs. It's hard to find time and energy to operate the household in between.
supporter: Have you considered hiring caretaker?

seeker: Thank you. Yes, I haven't been out to check on the veggie garden today. That usually gives me an opportunity to calm my mind.
supporter: whenever possible, you can take your children out with you on a trip to the park or the mountain. Nature is also good for kids with special need.

seeker: Most certainly. We try often to explore our natural environment. It can be limiting due to our daughter's physical disability but we manage the best we can to include her.
supporter: You are such a great mom, I can totally see how much you sacrificed for them. But please take care of yourself, i think you should see a therapist and get proper treatment

seeker: Thank you. I will definitely touch base again with my therapist soon. I have a follow up psychiatrist appointment next month too. In the mean time, I will definitely put some of these things you've recommended in to practice. ☺️
supporter: Exercising might be helpful too. I like doing yoga or pilates, it really eases my mind when I have too much going on

seeker: Thank you. Yes, I need to get back in to the Ring Fit adventure on the Switch. It definitely helps my my and body feel stronger.
supporter: I believe you will overcome this!

seeker: I am getting ready to sue my mother and am very nervous about the ordeal.
supporter: You're worried about being in court against your mother or are you worried about your relationship after that?

seeker: Both
supporter: Can you tell me about the situation, why did you decide to sue her?

seeker: My stepdad raped me and got me pregnant and I delivered a still born and i just remember the incident happened 23 years later. So now I am suing my mother.
supporter: So she knew about the incident but did nothing to help you?

seeker: yes
supporter: that sucks, I understand why you resent her so much

seeker: yes it is very difficult but im not as upset as i was i cried a lot
supporter: Crying is good, you shouldn't bottle your emotions

seeker: yes i am kinda numb to it but I have to call the police dept tomorrow for a copy of the police report from when my step dad took the baby to them and I dont want to
supporter: You should talk to someone you trust, they might be able to give you specific advice regarding your situation

seeker: that might help, i am just nervous about this whole thing i am estranged from my family for the most part so
supporter: Also, you seem to still care about your mom despite what she did. Did you consider reaching out to her after the court?

seeker: yes i imagine that we will talk
supporter: Maybe talk to your friends, it's easier for people of similar age to empathize with you

seeker: i do not have many friends really
supporter: Try to keep your cool, let her know you did it because you wanted justice.

seeker: yes that is what i am worried about thank you that is really good line i can use when she asks me why
supporter: If you still care about her, make sure to let her know you don't hate or resent her and you still hope to be able to fix your relationship

seeker: yes but what she did you really can't move past a certain point of tolorence and forgivness so i will always wish she had believed me
supporter: I understand you, it's normal to feel what you feel. It's a terrible situation and what she did really is unforgivable

seeker: yes it is. but i basically do its just i feel that she doesn't love me
supporter: I don't think she doesn't love you. Maybe she just didn't want to believe it happened

seeker: yes i think you are right. I think that my time is running out. i will thank you. I am going to go now.
supporter: Sueing won't solve anything, you have to talk to your mom and get all the knots in your mind out

seeker: I'm still sad about it.
supporter: Please tell me more about your story

seeker: I am living abroad and was really into this guy. We dated for almost a year but both wanted to do our summer vacation with friends. When he got back, he told me he was with another girl. I broke up with him. Now I miss him.
supporter: Please don't do that. You made the right decision to break up with him as he doesn't respect you at al

seeker: It was just one time, but I wonder if he'd do it again.
supporter: I would say this, if he does it once, he will do it again

seeker: How can I know that for sure?
supporter: Maybe going home isn't too bad after all. You may even meet someone better there

seeker: I really like it here though, and with Covid, it's hard to think about traveling.
supporter: Luckily I have never been in that situation but my friends have

seeker: It never happened to me before.
supporter: But trust me, you made the right decision. If anything, it proves you're a strong and independent person

seeker: Maybe I'll just go home for the holiday season.
supporter: People can only love and respect you when you treat yourself that way

seeker: I wanted to throw something at him, I was so mad. But I just made him leave.
supporter: You are very mature. Anyone in that situation would feel the same.

seeker: Thank you. It was hard not to let my emotions get the best of me. I don't even know why he told me. But I guess it's good he did.
supporter: He did a good thing at least, being honest with you. However, cheating, even just once, is something I always warn people

seeker: I don't know if it was good. Maybe he was just being mean.
supporter: I know it's useless to tell you to not be sad. Go ahead and let it all out by crying or screaming but please know you didn't do anything wrong

seeker: I just hope I don't see him before I go home.
supporter: No problem. and don't see him again, it's tough but it's better that way

seeker: Have a good rest of the night.
supporter: you too, i hope you feel better

seeker: I am anxious right now about how my family will react when I tell them I'm not coming back for the holidays
supporter: yes

seeker: Because of the health risks and also the unhealthy emotional environment with my family
supporter: What kind of health risks are you concerned about? I imagine that hasn't been easy couple with the tough home environment.

seeker: Health risks are primarily the pandemic. Covid-19 cases have gotten very high where I live and my family members are not very careful.
supporter: I think you are doing the right thing by being careful. During these times, keeping loved ones safe is more important than having gatherings.

seeker: I'm glad you said that. Yes, when I told my family that I wasn't coming, I stated health risks as the reason. But, I am worried that they may insist on me attending as we get closer to the holidays and in some ways I feel guilty because it isn't just the pandemic that makes me not want to go. I usually don't feel great during holidays with my family and I think they are harmful to me overall
supporter: I understand how you feel. I'm currently saving up to move out myself because I think it would give me a chance to think for myself.

seeker: Yeah, I think people deserve to build whatever home, family, or environment is best for them and shouldn't be judged for it
supporter: I don't think you should feel guilty about that because you are looking out for yourself which is the most important thing. And it always helps to voice your feelings to your family. Whether or not they choose to accept it, just getting things off your chest can help too.

seeker: Yes, it made me feel powerful in some way to say no to going to holidays even if it was in the context of the pandemic
supporter: That's good! It's definitely a great thing to look out for yourself rather than trying to please people all the time especially if it makes you feel uncomfortable in the process.

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hello

seeker: I just don't feel enthused about anything lately.
supporter: I am so sorry to hear that. How do you feel right now?

seeker: Just kind of "blah."
supporter: I understand that feeling. Have you lost interest in things that you normally would enjoy?

seeker: I don't know that I have exactly lost interest.  I still do them, but somehow it feels like I'm just going through the motions.
supporter: I can relate to that. Have you thought about trying something new, or taking up a new hobby? That has helped me before

seeker: Not really.  I guess that I'm just kind of stuck in a rut.
supporter: Would you be willing to try a new hobby to make each day less monotonous?

seeker: Yes, I would be, but I'm not sure that it actually needs to be a new hobby.  I just need to have some sort of project that I'm working on.
supporter: Maybe a new home improvement project?

seeker: No!  I've got a jigsaw puzzle that I could start, and I also have a list of "21 books that you've been meaning to read."
supporter: Those both sound like great ideas! I think starting one, or both, would really make you feel a lot better.

seeker: If I start working through the 21 books, that should keep me going for quite a while (even if I'm not interested in all of them)!
supporter: I believe it will also help give you a sense of accomplishment. I know that it would me

seeker: I agree.
supporter: Perfect! It sounds like you may have found a solution to help you get out of this rut and "blah" feeling

seeker: Thanks for chatting.
supporter: I hope that you start feeling better. I'm glad we were able to chat

seeker: It was helpful for me to have a chance to put my feelings into words.  It just seems like I haven't had the opportunity to do that recently.
supporter: I glad that you were able to talk about how you are feeling. That is a big step in feeling better

seeker: I believe that we've successfully completed the task, and I need to go cook dinner.   Goodbyt.
supporter: Enjoy your dinner! Goodbye

seeker: Hi there
supporter: Hello, how are you today

seeker: I've been better. I have to give a presentation at work on a stage. This is causing me a lot of stress and problems sleeping
supporter: What about giving a presentation gave you stress?

seeker: It is the thought of getting nervous in front of people and forgetting what I want to say.
supporter: Have you taken steps to help you overcome this fear, such as rehearsing in front of the mirror or in front of another person?

seeker: I have learned my lines and practiced at home a lot. I know what to say almost word for word but I had a bad experience in the past that has scared me.
supporter: I understand giving presentations is nervewrecking, but at least you are trying. Are you allowed to take a few notecards just in case?

seeker: Thanks for understanding, yeah I suppose I could take notes. I think it is being in front of people and looking foolish that I'm scared of the most. I know a lot of people at work and don;t want them to think I'm bad on stage. Can you related to that?
supporter: I can definitely relate. It is best to look past the audience and just focus on an object close by. Everyone of us have had to experience this. You are not alone.

seeker: Hopefully I can try to get past the nerves, some people make it look easy. I'm usually really confident but something about standing on a stage makes me feel very scared and anxious.
supporter: Before you go on, try taking a few deep breaths.  Why not try meditating a few days before?

seeker: I could do I suppose. I won't be the only one presenting that day so I feel like I won't be able to measure up against the other people on stage.
supporter: Try shifting the focus on what could go wrong, to what could go right? Focus on others congratulating you on a job well done.

seeker: Yeah I do have a tendency to be negative sometimes and make a big deal out of things. I should actually focus on the good things. Has this technique helped you in the past?
supporter: Yes, in the term "fake it until you make it." I keep on thinking of what could go right, or in my favor, and when I am done, it actually went okay, and any "fears" i had, never came to fruition.

seeker: I think that is really good advice. I think I have just suffered from a bad experience in the past and this has shaped my way of thinking to always be fearful. I'm fine in meetings or virtually but something about a stage just scares me.
supporter: That's understandable. But now that you're aware, you have the steps the move forward and be successful.

seeker: yes I don't want it to hold me back personally or professionally any more
supporter: I believe you can do it.

seeker: hey thanks that really helps
supporter: HOpe you ace your presentation.

seeker: I'm not feeling great. I think my girlfriend may be cheating on me.
supporter: So you think she may, have started a relationship with someone else?

seeker: Yes, I think so although I don't have any proof. Things were going really well and then all of a sudden she text me and told me things aren't working.
supporter: Ok, well that doesn't sound pleasant and must be difficult to hear. Perhaps her feelings have changed and there isn't necessarily another person involved?

seeker: She has started a new job and I think she might have met someone at work that she likes better than me. I can't believe she is doing this to me!
supporter: Ok so it seems like you are quite angry at the moment at the thought of her with someone else, is that true?

seeker: Yes I suppose it is true. The thing is I thought things were going well and she is stressed out at work with her new job but we were getting on great!
supporter: I had a similar experience myself. My partner was stressed and I was busy myself. It turns out that I wasn't paying him enough attention and this made him feel like I didn't think he was important to me any more.

seeker: I haven't thought of it like that before but still I want to talk to her about it not just text me randomly and hint at ending things.
supporter: From my experience, when I actually talked to my boyfriend we agreed to make more time for each other and things did improve.

seeker: Okay what do you think I should do about it because the text seemed very final? Looks like she has made her mind up already about things.
supporter: Sometimes people say one thing but actually mean another. They are complicated and don't always say what they really mean.

seeker: Do you think that she wants to talk rather than end the relationship?
supporter: I cannot say for certain however I think you should talk to her but also prepare yourself for the fact that she may actually want to spend some time apart or end  the relationship. it would be wise to prepare for that outcome as upsetting as it may be.

seeker: That makes sense but it is not what I want to hear. After all we have been through together, we were even talking about getting our own place together and now all that will be for nothing!
supporter: I think you are reflecting on your plans together and the thought of the relationship ending is making you upset and angry.

seeker: Yes that's right. I know getting angry doesn't help but I want things to go back to the way they were.
supporter: Ok so based on what you have told me I think that your girlfriend has got a new job and you are planning on moving in together is that correct?

seeker: Yes that's right but that's what couples do isn't it?
supporter: It is but that is a lot of change all happening at once. Perhaps she is getting a little bit scared and rather than dealing with the situation she is running away, perhaps you should talk about this and see how she responds?

seeker: I still think there is someone else that has come between us.
supporter: Have you got any evidence of this like seen a text message or has she behaves strangely?

seeker: No I haven't, it is just a feeling.
supporter: Ok well it is natural to feel like this sometimes. People tend to fear the worst.

seeker: So do you think I should try and talk to her and ask her outright if she has met someone else?
supporter: I think rather than ask her that question directly, you could start the conversation and ask her why she is feeling this way. This would show you care and are prepared to listen without jumping to conclusions.

seeker: I think I do need to calm down a bit and maybe talking to her would be the best way to start. I don;t know what I'd do though if she ended it.
supporter: The best thing to do would be prepared to have the conversation, stay calm and listen. She may just want to talk but also be prepared as it may not go the way you plan.

seeker: Ok well maybe if I show her that I can stay calm and strong then she will stay with me?
supporter: Be prepared that she may end the relationship but getting angry is likely not to change her mind. Getting angry does not improve difficult conversations.

seeker: I suppose I could go into it and listen as you have said, there could be other reasons like the new job or maybe morning in that is causing some of it. I'll try and keep calm but it is hard when emotions run high.
supporter: Take a deep breath and try to relax beforehand. Staying positive and allowing her to speak will make for a better conversation. She will be more likely to open up to you.

seeker: That is actually pretty good advice. I hope we stay together and there is nobody else though.
supporter: I hope you manage to work it through and can at least talk about your feelings

seeker: Hey thanks for the words of wisdom. Not sure I'll like the chat but I'll try and stay calm.
supporter: You are very welcome and take care

seeker: I'm sad and angry because I no longer talk to my best friend
supporter: Do you know what might have happened to cause your and your best friend to not talk anymore?

seeker: Well she was staying at my house for a month and we were constantly fighting so she just stopped talking to me
supporter: That sounds really stressful and I can see how troubling that is for you.

seeker: Yes it is and then she began avoiding me while we were in the same house, so we started arguing again and I found out she's been lying to me since I've known her and I'm very upset.
supporter: That's definitely very upsetting. I know how it feels to have that sense of betrayal from a friend I was close to for many years. However, I was able to discuss the issue I had with my parents and other friends. Do you have anyone else close to you that you can talk to?

seeker: I don't think so, my parents think I was too harsh by deciding to end the friendship, it as if my own family doesn't understand.
supporter: That can definitely add to frustration. What about your other friends? Do you have anyone who either shares the same opinion as you or does not know your friend that you can talk to?

seeker: My other friend believed that it wasn't too harsh to end the friendship as they know I value honesty but it makes me feel angry that I was being used for so long and constantly lied to.
supporter: You have every right to be angry, but the most important thing you can do is find a good support system with your other friend. It will take some time to heal, but I'll tell you a paraphrased version of one of my favorite quotes: "Resentment is like swallowing poison and expecting the other person to die." It's important to find support in your other friends and heal properly.

seeker: I really love that quote, it's absolutely true; I think I will talk to my friend about the situation some more so I can fully get over it.
supporter: That sounds like a wonderful idea. Is there anything else you would like to discuss?

seeker: Yes, I also realized that I wasn't angry with my friend but rather myself
supporter: Can you elaborate more? Earlier you said you and your friend were arguing while she was living in your house, then she stopped talking to you. Why might you be angry with yourself?

seeker: Because I basically allowed her to use me for seven years and kept lying to me or gave her space because I thought I was being a good friend.
supporter: If I may, I would argue that your actions don't make you soft and they certainly don't make you stupid. They are certainly not any reason to be angry with yourself. If I may bring up another cliché: "Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me." I would say you're in the "fool me once" stage and it is your friend's actions that have brought you pain. I think you're unlikely to trust her again.

seeker: Thank you very much, I'll continue to talk about the issue with my other friend, I really appreciate your wisdom.
supporter: Of course. I think you'll be alright and remember the healing process can take a long time after betrayal. Remember to be kind to yourself and keep that support system of your other friend by you.

seeker: No thank you, enjoy the rest of your day
supporter: You too!

seeker: Hi, I'm not doing very well. I feel very depressed.
supporter: Are you aware of things that may have cause your depression?

seeker: I recently got fired.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear, that can be really straining on someone, sounds like you're stressed about the situation

seeker: I guess, I mostly just feel really depressed, like I didn't do a good job.
supporter: I often feel the same way when I'm unable to achieve something However I talked to a close friend about the issue to get some feedback

seeker: That sounds like a good idea, I could talk to my best friend about this.
supporter: It's great that your willing to speak to someone about it.

seeker: I think it might help, maybe I won't feel so sad afterward or so useless.
supporter: It sounds like being fired has made you more self negative. Does that sound right?

seeker: Yes.
supporter: What are some ways you might express this to your best friend when seeking valued feedback?

seeker: I guess I could say that being fired has made me feel useless and very depressed.
supporter: That's a good place to start and hearing feedback can sometimes be hard to hear but I think you can do it !!

seeker: Thank you, I think that this might help me.
supporter: You're very welcome and I know will start to feel better soon.

seeker: Thank you very much.
supporter: Is there anything else you have on your mind?

seeker: Hello.
supporter: hey how are you doing?

seeker: Doing alright, thanks. Yourself?
supporter: Doing fine, thank you.

seeker: Good to hear.
supporter: What brings you here today?

seeker: I've been feeling very down lately.
supporter: That sounds difficult, Would you like to elaborate on that?

seeker: Sure. I feel depressed about the state of the US and of the rest of the world. It's very overwhelming.
supporter: That is completely understandable, there are a lot of overwhelming things going on right now.

seeker: Yes and a lot of uncetainty.
supporter: Most definitely, I've also been feeling a bit overwhelmed by what's going on.

seeker: It's good to know others feel the way I do. I've been trying to keep busy and not watch the news too much.
supporter: That is a good strategy, all the news outlets can be very overwhelming.

seeker: Yes with lots of conflicting information.
supporter: What do you like to do to keep busy?

seeker: Work, read, exercise. I've been going to the gym more.
supporter: Those sound like really good coping skills.

seeker: Thank you. I'm trying. I really don't want to be on medication.
supporter: That's a personal choice you're completely allowed to make. It sounds like you have a good foundation for building on your ability to cope.

seeker: I am trying. I don't want to fall deep down an emotional black hole.
supporter: Understandable

seeker: Yes, my husband is very supportive but I don't want to upset him too much so I don't fully open up.
supporter: That's great he is supportive. Seeing an individual counselor or someone of the like can also be helpful. They're there for just you and they have unbiased opinions. A lot are doing telehealth right now.

seeker: I will look into the telehealth. Thank you for that recommendation.
supporter: You're welcome, hopefully it can be helpful. I, myself, have used telehealth therapy recently and it's just been helpful with all the unprecedented chaos going on this year.

seeker: I will give that a try. Thank you again.
supporter: Is there anything else you would like to talk about or that I can help you with today?

seeker: Hello I am here to discuss my anxiety over the current pandemic.
supporter: Hey there! That's a good topic to talk about. With everything that's been going on, it's normal to feel some anxiety.

seeker: Thank you very much for your understanding. Yeah it's tough especially with rising cases for the past two weeks or so in my city.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Similar stuff is happening where I am, and I also get anxious hearing about it.

seeker: And we had a lock-down earlier this year and yet, with the exception of one province, every province remains operational at full speed despite lock-downs earlier, and now a lot of provinces are seeing record cases with the second wave.
supporter: What do you feel when you feel on guard and paranoid? Try to say some more about that if you can.

seeker: I go out pretty much only when I have a purpose and personal admin/errands. I work about one or two days a week out of my home. So with the rising cases, I just feel anxious having to get out of the safety of my home. I was a lot more anxious earlier this year though. I am much more used to it at this time.
supporter:
Yeah, that makes sense. When this was all new, the uncertainty probably made for more anxiety. Now that we know some more about what is safe and what isn't, maybe less so.

But it doesn't mean the anxiety is gone, of course. It's still around in our day-to-day lives.

seeker: yeah I have been adjusting to it and the cases were down and even to zero in my city for most of the last few months, but there's definitely the start of a new community spread now.
supporter: I can rephrase some of this, if you don't mind. In a way, you're talking about activities that you may have used (gym, hikes, etc) to keep yourself in a good mood. Now that those don't seem available, you just don't have those opportunities to boost your mood. It makes sense that you would be feeling this way.

seeker: now I am more used to it of course, but this summarizes how I have been feeling for most of this year.
supporter: I think you explained yourself really well. Thanks for sharing how you've been feeling.

seeker: yes you're right. That's exactly it. I think it's going to be this way for a long time. I see other people compromising and taking the risk to go out for walks or runs, and even to the gym. I could have done that for the last few months when we had zero cases for awhile, but I didn't want to gamble and compromise. And I still see those people as selfish when I choose to do what I think is right.
supporter: Do you think if you went ahead anyway to the gym or out for runs that you would feel guilty for doing them?

seeker: We won't know more about the mental implications and the sociological aspects of the pandemic probably until years to come.
supporter: Yeah, and that just throws on another layer of why things are difficult right now. No one wants to feel guilty for doing things that could help themselves.

seeker: to the gym, I certainly would. Because it's indoors and I do feel it's unsafe as there are many equipment that others could touch. Running I felt that way because the path that I usually run on is narrow and other people walk through it also. However, I did have second thoughts about that when the case numbers were down. But I finally decided to keep doing it and stick to all outdoor trips for essential business.
supporter: Have you ever heard of the phrase "black or white thinking?" As in, thinking that situations or people are completely good or completely bad? Or completely doable or completely impossible?

seeker: so in my opinion, I feel a little indignant at the people that have been going out frivolously like there's nothing going on, to even gamble their safety and their family's. Like I live in an apartment building, and the people around me and below me are always going out, even for the last few months. So I don't feel safe either but also indignant that others are doing what I could have done, but that I had compromised on for my safety and everyone else's safety. So I just didn't feel it was fair for them to do that when I could have done that anytime I wanted.
supporter: Yeah, I think I understand that too. I get really frustrated hearing about people hosting big parties or not wearing masks because they think it's no big deal. They're putting others at risk.

seeker: Because I either go out or I don't. I have to compromise my values and everything I worked hard to preserve for the last few months to go out, even if I put on extra protection etc. And I just rigidly refuse to compromise my values because I don't believe it's right. Because if I had done that, I would have done that already, and long ago. And even though it's really hard on me.
supporter: I think we all do black-or-white thinking to some extent. We're wired to try and make sense of the world, and maybe our brains don't like to spend time on nuance and grey areas. We all tend to quickly categorize things into good or bad, easy or hard, black or white.

seeker: yeah I understand your thinking with the grey areas as well. I suppose for this case, it's all black and white for me, no grea areas or compromises.
supporter: Does this time have to be a "waste" for you? With no productivity? That seems pretty extreme.

seeker: it's a fascinating area though, fascinating thinking. I am also curious on the social and mental implications of this in the long-run
supporter: Thanks for saying that! I liked talking with you, and we can wrap this up. I guess I'm saying you sound thoughtful and intelligent, I'm confident that you could find ways to get more out of this time if that's what you're wanting to do.

seeker: I am productive but not as driven or productive as before at home.
supporter: Not as productive? Of course! It's a pandemic. We all are.  :)    Hope you're not too hard on yourself right now.

seeker: no no I am okay thanks for asking
supporter: Ha, exactly. Maybe we're not all thriving and getting rich and adding 15 pounds of muscle during this time. But we can get through it.

seeker: yup. Exactly. Lost time can always be made up later.
supporter: Before we quit, would you want to say one specific thing you know you can do today to help yourself out?

seeker: Yeah for sure
supporter: Nice! Good job with those things.

seeker: thanks. I hope you best of luck then with all your endeavours. I know we can all get through this time. Thank you.
supporter: Right on, same to you. It's okay to feel anxious right now. It's okay to feel unproductive right now. It's also okay to keep on doing the things that make you feel okay. Great job keeping up the workouts and the classes.

seeker: Thank you and all the best.
supporter: Stay well and safe to you too! Take care.

seeker: I can't take it anymore the stress from my parents.  They don't acknowledge I am doing my best.
supporter: I can see you are trying hard but aren't feeling acknowledged.

seeker: It's so hard to not get the affirmation that I am doing a good job.
supporter: What is it that they aren't affirming you on?

seeker: They don't say that I made the best choices I could given the circumstances.
supporter: I see that can be frustrating.

seeker: I want to cry every time they talk to me.  I don't know how to communicate any better what I'm feeling.
supporter: I see that you are communicating to them but they don't understand where you are coming from.  That can be frustrating.

seeker: What can I do to please them?
supporter: When did this start?

seeker: When my children started getting in trouble at school
supporter: When my children were in the same situation I felt a lot of heat too from my parents.  It's helpful sometimes to talk to a school counselor.  Have you tried that at all?

seeker: That would maybe help.  I have to see maybe they could help me with solving the situation.
supporter: They have some experience with other families and maybe could connect you with people who are having similar issues. I've done that in the past.

seeker: I see your point.
supporter: Do you have other family members or friends who you could talk to?

seeker: Yes, maybe my sister could help.  She has children too.
supporter: That sounds like a great plan to try.

seeker: Thanks so much for the help.
supporter: It has been my pleasure.  Is there anything else I can do?

seeker: No thanks
supporter: You are very welcome.

seeker: Have a nice day.
supporter: You as well have a nice day.

seeker: Hi
supporter: What sort of problems were in your past and now?

seeker: I loved physics and I decided to attend university, but soon after I slowly lost my interest and became unmotivated
supporter: What was happening in your life that made you lose interest?

seeker: Actually the professors and the class atmosphere was the reason, and of course the quality of teaching
supporter: It sounds like that is a lot of reasons to be stressed. Have you spoken to a school counselor?

seeker: Yes lots of stress and pressure. I did not, because we didn't have such things or at least I wasn't aware
supporter: I agree it is a lot of pressure, but do not let bad teachers deter you. I would reach out to a school counselor and let them know your situation. Every school must have one.

seeker: I loved physics a lot more than now, but what's the point of studying when the teachers are pulsing you not to study! (because of the quality of teaching)
supporter: More reason to speak to a school counselor or school administrator. We need to provide help to students, not have bad teachers deter them.

seeker: Yeah, same with me! I wish I could attend a better univeristy
supporter: What made you choose this particular university you are at?

seeker: I didn't have another choice but this
supporter: Have you looked into other Universities for the possibility of transferring

seeker:
Hmmm, actually I didn't think about
 this option
supporter: Just think about what you want in a good university and research from there

seeker: Yeah, I should do it
supporter: You're welcome I hope you find the perfect university for you

seeker: Thanks, I wish  you luck in your future endeavours
supporter: Goodbye

seeker: I do not what what to do
supporter: Being friends with who?

seeker: My friend does not want to be friends anymore after 13 years, she thinks I am too buys with my kids
supporter: She doesn't want to be friends, but what do you want?

seeker: To be friends, its been 13 years
supporter: So you still want to be friends but she doesn't.

seeker: yes
supporter: Have you talked with your friend about your feelings?

seeker: yes, but she does not understand since she is not married and does not have children
supporter: Does she just want to spend more time with you?

seeker: I think she feels left out
supporter: Is there a way you can help her feel more included?

seeker: I guess I can reinforce that she is always invited over! But I am just soooo exhausted after having twins
supporter: I understand, that must be exhausting!

seeker: No time to sleep... ever.... How do I tell her I have feelings too
supporter: I understand, I think that you should tell her about your situation and how you feel.

seeker: I am not very good at expression my emotions rn with out getting emotional
supporter: It is okay to get emotional, it may even help her understand how you feel better.

seeker: ugh you are right! I just get scared to break down that all, even after 13 years.
supporter: It is okay to be scared, but having emotions and getting emotional is natural.

seeker: you are so right
supporter: Do you feel like you have a better understanding of what to do?

seeker: yes I do! Thank you so much
supporter: You are welcome, I hope everything turns out all right.

seeker: Thank you! Your help means a lot
supporter: Have a great day, and good luck!

seeker: Hi, I was wondering if you can help me with my academic issues.
supporter: yes. tell me what happened?

seeker: I am very stressed. My parents want to me to go to the school of their choice but its not looking good. If I dont go into their choice school I will have to pay for school on my own.
supporter: it sounds that you dont feel heard by your parents.

seeker: Yes, they just tell me they want the best for me but its making my stomach hurt constantly
supporter: i think you have done your best and you are continuing to try hard.

seeker: Thank you. I just don't know what I should do about my school and future college endeavors
supporter: everything happens  for a reason. you just have to stay calm.did you express yourself to your friends or a caretaker?

seeker: My friends just tell me to take loans out like they are.
supporter: do you think that will help you out?

seeker: I think it would but I don't want to go into debt because of college
supporter: try do get some online jobs so that you can cop up with both your college and finances.

seeker: Okay I can try and do that
supporter: yes, i hope everything ends well.

seeker: Thank you
supporter: welcome

seeker: Hello.
supporter: how are you feeling lately?

seeker: Sad. I don't have any motivation.
supporter: That's really hard. but,i think you can do it.

seeker: Yeah. I just was supposed to be something important ya know?
supporter: It seems that you are really stressed about the situation.

seeker: Thank you. I am. I just tried so hard for so long to do something meaningful with my life. And now I am coming to terms with having a "normal" job and I can't even do that right.
supporter: i feel the same way.now i understand the reason though.it is because i didn't know what to say to strangers.

seeker: Yeah. I mean I know a lot of people struggle the same way. I just need ways to find validation that are not based on my job.
supporter: some people express themselves in person, some communicate in words.have you tried any different ways?

seeker: No, I will try that. Thank you for your advice.
supporter: no mention.

seeker: I hadn't thought of that.
supporter: could you try to take few deep breaths?

seeker: Yes, I think I will do that.
supporter: happy to hear.

seeker: I think I will follow your advice and try to take more mindful deep breaths and try to communicate with some other people in different ways.
supporter: well, thats a good idea to do do.

seeker: Thank you. You have been very helpful. Enjoy the rest of your day.
supporter: yes, you too.have a great day.

seeker: I'm so tense all the time since my son is ill.
supporter: Can you tell me more about what you're feeling?

seeker: I wonder if he will ever get better.  I'm so scared for his future with perhaps others having to care for him or even if he will eat.
supporter: It seems like you are concerned about your son's future and wellbeing. Is this correct?

seeker: Yes, absolutely correct.
supporter: Does your son have any other supports in his life?

seeker: Supports don't help him get his mind back only the correct medication.
supporter: I see how that could be intensely difficult to deal with. I think your strength is admirable

seeker: Thank you, but I'm worried about how long my strength can last
supporter: From our communications it seems you are feeling anxious and stressed as well.

seeker: Do you have any suggestions?
supporter: Yes, I would suggest you find a place where you are comforted and feel safe. You are in a difficult situation and it is clear you need emotional support as well. Do you know of any support groups in your area?

seeker: I could reach out to my parents.  They have supported me the most.
supporter: I think that is a wonderful idea. You deserve to feel safe and supported too.

seeker: Yes, they can help me just to give me comfort.
supporter: Some people find comfort in hobbies as well. Do you have any comforting hobbies?

seeker: I like hobbies but I have to watch my other children all the time and don't have much time for myself.
supporter: Are there other people in your life who can watch the children too?

seeker: No, they have disabilities too so it's hard to get someone to watch them.
supporter: You are certainly in a frustrating situation, but it is clear you are a good caregiver.

seeker: Thanks. I guess I just have to make the best of the situation and pray for a miracle.
supporter: There are some charitable organizations which may be able to provide some relief in your area. Have you looked into those?

seeker: I contacted some support services, but haven't found anything yet.  Thanks for trying. I will have to try more groups.  You have been helpful .
supporter: I personally have been a caregiver in the past and it can be exhausting. You are a strong person.

seeker: hello
supporter: Hi there. How are you doing?

seeker: ok. not great
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. What is going on that makes you not feel great? I am well, thanks for asking.

seeker: breaking up with husband.  mixed emotions on it.  relieved it is out in the open, sad it has to be over.
supporter: Going through a break up is never easy, especially when it is with someone you thought you would spend you life with. I understand completely. It is natural to feel sad for a while

seeker: yeah. it sucks. wish it was not this way.  do not want to move on but without trust there is nothing
supporter: Of course and it is normal to have mixed feelings

seeker: I just cannot get out of this funk.  why me?  what did i do to make him want someone else?
supporter: Have you looked into any divorce support groups in your area or online? It can help to discover that you are not alone in how you feel

seeker: Yeah, but the only one  in my area in person is cancelled.  online seems impersonal.  I dont mind being on my own, but like companionship.  But will not trust again.  I am in a no win situation.  At least the kids are grown.
supporter: I understand. I went though a lot of feelings myself when I divorced. Blaming myself, blaming him, missing him. It took some time to work through but thankfully today it is all a distant memory. Sometimes time is the best healer. Be kind to yourself and take time for you.

seeker: yep. i guess it is too soon.  2020 is the suckiest year ever. On so many levels.
supporter: I hear you on that. It has been a very unusual year in general. I think that with everything going on in the world it is more important than ever that we take me time.

seeker: got plenty of me time. lol
supporter: I know how hurtful that can be when people chose sides. It happened in my own divorce. The best thing you can do I think is to remember not to let anyone else's misinformed opinions affect how you ultimately view yourself. None of those people were there and none of them experienced what you did.

seeker: yeah, i am ok with losing certain friends.   some have surprised me some not so much.  no way to meet new people or get away.
supporter: I understand, it is a difficult time to meet new people. Even in normal times a divorce is difficult but even more so with the restrictions we have at the moment. I think everything you are feeling is normal. Have you connected with a therapist to help you process all of your feelings. I know that helped me. Many are doing virtual sessions at the moment

seeker: How do you become happy? How do you find something worth living for?
supporter: Hi, I think there are a lot of ways to become happy and to find something worthy living for. Let's start with things that interest you. What do you like doing for fun?

seeker: I don't really know anymore, nothing makes me happy these days.
supporter: And what kinds of things did you like to read?

seeker: Mostly fiction books. Fantasy, historical novels, contemporary fiction, anything really.
supporter: That's really great! I used to struggle with finding joy in reading as well. I was a graduate student at the time so I was mostly reading research papers.

seeker: Do you like reading again? What helped?
supporter: Have you tried picking up a new hobby? Something you have always thought might be fun but haven't ever tried because of lack of time or energy?

seeker: I wanted to try rock climbing, but I don't know. I'm not really in the best shape.
supporter: I do like reading now. I took some time after school to take care of my mental health by going on walks and being in nature. Overtime, I started to pick up books again. I've found I really like true crime and autobiographies the best

seeker: I feel like people will just make fun of me.
supporter: Rock climbing is so fun! Have you tried taking a beginners course? I started there. I was very nervous I would be made fun of, but found that it was a really supportive community.

seeker: I guess I can give it a try.
supporter: You might find it's just the community of people that you need right now. From my experience, they were all super friendly and open to helping me along the way.

seeker: I guess you're right. I tend to get caught up in my own thoughts, which never have anything good to say about me.
supporter: Just from chatting with you, you seem like such a nice person. I don't think anyone would have mean things to say about you.

seeker: That's kind of you to say.
supporter: I really hope you'll take the leap to trying rock climbing! It was so fun for me when I did it and I can't wait to get back out there to learn more (hopefully COVID will be over soon!) :-)

seeker: Yeah I think I'll check if any gyms are open right now and try a class.
supporter: That sounds great! Hoping they are open and safe!

seeker: I feel like shit and I don't know how I can move on.
supporter: It sound like you are having a really hard time right now.

seeker: Like I had all these plans and they just came crashing down, and now I have to start all over again.
supporter: That is a very difficult situation. Starting over again can be a great opportunity for growth.

seeker: I feel like I'm too old to start over again. There must be something wrong with me after all.
supporter: I understand how you feel. I had a bad break up, but it turned out to be a good thing in the long run.

seeker: How so?
supporter: Well, looking back the relationship was pretty toxic and everything was better once I was out of it. I am sure your life will be happier and more fulfilling soon.

seeker: I don't know, it doesn't feel like anything's getting better soon. I've been busy with work so I haven't been spending as much time with my partner.
supporter: It sounds to me like you have been working hard to support your life with you partner. They should respect that.

seeker: Maybe it is my fault, maybe I didn't communicate enough.
supporter: Is this a relationship you would want back if you could get it back?

seeker: No, I don't think I'd want to get back with someone who cheated on me.
supporter: I would agree with you on that! That was how I felt too.

seeker: I guess I just need some time to think things through.
supporter: For sure. Just take things slowly, one day at a time. Take the time you need to learn to enjoy your new life.

seeker: Here's to hoping things get better. Thanks for listening anyways.
supporter: You're welcome! I'll be rooting for you!

seeker: been better how are you?
supporter: I'm doing well, thanks. Is something bothering you?

seeker: That's good. yes about my daughter. I typed it all in already.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Unfortunately I didn't receive the message you had typed, would you like to talk about it?

seeker: My daughter is 16 and got out of hand for a little while. I grounded her. And since that time, she has decided to move in with her dad. which is fine. But I've only gotten to see her once in 3 months. She don't want to see me.
supporter: That's tough, I'm sorry. I don't have children of my own yet, but I remember being a teenager and having a similar phase. If it makes you feel any better, I eventually grew out of that phase and have a wonderful relationship with my parents now!

seeker: That's good.
supporter: With the holidays coming up, maybe that's a good opportunity to reunite and spend some quality time with her?

seeker: By law though I don't think that my ex husband can keep her from me? I feel like I have a right to see my child. I have 4 kids altogether. My other 2 daughters are older and have already moved out and my son is still at home. I've dealt with teenagers and it's not easy but this is too extreme.
supporter: Does she have a good relationship with her siblings? Maybe they can help convince her to spend some family time at home?

seeker: She did but not so great anymore. I sure hope so.
supporter: Maybe she just needs some time to decompress. Being a teenager is a stressful time, especially this year with everything with COVID. I'm hopeful that she will come out of this phase.

seeker: I'm gonna keep praying. Thank you. You made me feel better.
supporter: I'm glad I could help! Keep your chin up

seeker: bye
supporter: Have a great day!

seeker: Hi there, I was hoping to get some support. I'm having a hard time with things.
supporter: Ho,  Can you please tell me specifically what things you are having a hard time with.

seeker: I broke up with my boyfriend because he cheated on me.
supporter: I hear you saying that your boyfriend broke up with you. Is that correct

seeker: Yes, that's correct. I'm heartbroken!
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. Can you tell me what led to the breakup

seeker: I caught him cheating on me with my best friend. They were together at the movies and I caught them

seeker: Are you sure? Because I keep wondering what I did wrong for him to cheat
supporter: You did nothing wrong,  when people cheat it is their own issue they must deal with. You must be feeling horrible,but know that it will be ok, there is someone who will treat you with more respect

seeker: I appreciate you saying that. It makes me feel a bit better! Do you have any advice about how I can take my mind off of things?
supporter: Do  not let this affect your self esteem, as you are a valuable person. Take long walks,  spend time enjoying your own company and know that you are worth it

seeker: Taking a long walk is great advice. Perhaps I will try doing that more often. The fresh air always does me good.
supporter: Great, it will make you feel so much better about yourself and help you put things in perspective. You will eventually see  your ex-partner for who he is.

seeker: I have some weight to lose, so taking a walk would help me with that also. Added bonus!
supporter: Great, so you can look and feel great. With COVID around, it is not the best time to go out and mingle but you can surely look around online and finds some online friends so that when social distancing is no longer an issue you can meet others

seeker: That's not a bad idea either. I think I'm feeling much better now
supporter: Wonderful,  I am glad I can be of assistance

seeker: You too :)

supporter: From what I know, you can try to relax before making any decision. I usually follow my intuition and decide. I deal with the outcome later. But meditating has really helped me avoid anxiety.

supporter: Taking up an exercise you like can be helpful.  You can work on yourself and blow off steam.

supporter: Know also that you will find someone new when it's right, and that you will create a new synergy with that new person.  We don't ever love anyone the same way twice.

supporter: That sounds like fun!  Whatever you do, take care of your heart

supporter: It sounds like you worry you will not be able to trust him in the future because of this no matter what his future actions are, do you think there is anything he could do or say that would change this?

supporter: What would you define as full commitment from him?

seeker: I think marriage, but then again if he cheats then what commitment is that really if it ends in divorce?
supporter: That's true and divorce can be expensive. You mentioned before that you feel like you are with him mostly because you are lonely, is that how your relationship started?

supporter: I don't think you are naive, you are clearly asking yourself the right questions about building a future with him

seeker: Thanks for the encouragment.
supporter: Do you have friends and family around that could help distract you from the loneliness until you find someone you are comfortable starting a family with?

supporter: Of course! There also probably community resources where you can meet new people and explore new interests! Unfortunately I think a lot of that might have to wait til Covid passes

seeker: Thanks that might be another suggestion to consider.
supporter: Of course! Anything else on your mind you would like to discuss?

seeker: When will this COVID ever end?  It's even hard to find new partners
supporter: I know, I've heard some people have found success with zoom dates.

seeker: just graduated university and my parents are pressuring me to pursue becoming a doctor
supporter: Oof, that is a very difficult situation.  I'm sorry you're going through that.  How do you feel about it?

seeker: I'm angry. I just want to be done school. but parents are on my butt about it.
supporter: What do your parents say when/if you tell them you want to be done with school?

seeker: they get mad at me and say they are dissapointed. I want to travel and see the world. not more schooling.
supporter: That's not a fair thing for them to say to their child.  I will say that there are academic programs that combine travel and credits, but you probably know that already.  And I don't think you should have to compromise anyway.

seeker: They won't take a compromise. parents are stubborn. What should i do? please parents or pursue my passion?
supporter: I cannot tell you what to do exactly, but I would encourage you to fulfill yourself before anyone else's dictation of your life.

seeker: Yeah i'm leaning that. i already graduated university. i fulfilled half of their dream.  you think telling them my honest opinion will be a good idea?
supporter: I think you need to be prepared for them to not be happy with your honest opinion, but that just because they aren't happy with it doesn't mean it's wrong.

seeker: thanks great advise. i will definitely be prepapred. i don't care if i dissapoint them. it's my life not theres. i'll live with the consequences
supporter: Keep in mind that from their point of view, they want the best for you because they love you, so try not to burn the bridge or salt the earth.  I had a rocky relationship with my dad after college too, but it's better now.  They will survive, and you will thrive.

seeker: Thank you. yeah i get that. but they should be happy for me. They cant make decisions for me all the time. let me free!!!
supporter: That feeling is totally understandable, I felt the same way.  They need to let you find your own way, it's apart of growing up.

seeker: Thank you. at least someone agrees with me.  Do i have the right to be angry at them?
supporter: The anger is understandable, but I think it is slightly misplaced as they are not trying to hurt you.  You are frustrated by their lack of understanding and their judgement of your choices, but you and they are both attempting to solve the same problem of your happiness.

seeker: Good advice. you are great at this.
supporter: That's very kind of you to say, thank you :-)

seeker: Thank you for the great talk. im not as angry anymore. will take there feelings into consideration
supporter: You are a great listener and have a lot of passion, I think you will be successful for sure.

seeker: Thanks have a good day.
supporter: You too!

They are young and as long as you truly do your best and sometimes that means taking care of you so you can be the best , you are only one person and the kids when older will appreciate all that you did . Keep the faith

supporter: I have an idea, do you have any friends in the same course or know anyone that is familiar with that subject? If so, maybe you can communicate with them and they can break it down in a short version.

seeker: Wow, that's actually a really good idea. I have a friend who took the course last year but I am worried that if I ask her for help she will think poorly of me.
supporter: Don't worry I know you feel exhausted from studying all day, but she is your friend and friends have each others back especially for school work. You don't have much to lose, go ahead and give it a shot.

seeker: That is true. I will reach out to her now.
supporter: I'm sure you will do just fine, you can do it!

seeker: I still have some self-doubt given that I have failed an exam in the past...
supporter: Well studies show that if you continuously think negatively, than that is how your life will be lived. But if you try thinking positively and confident than you will more likely live a better life and do better. Try thinking positively the rest of the night and your brain will feel confident enough to remember and retain important information about your exam.

seeker: I really appreciate this advice. I am feeling better about the exam and feel like I should envision myself passing and doing well.
supporter: Yes, thats the spirit it works for me!

seeker: I will give it a try!
supporter: Okay is there anything else I can help you with or should I let you go?

supporter: Of course anytime, have a goodnight!

supporter: Yes, what is that?

seeker: Do you have any tips for staying cool under pressure while I am taking my exam?
supporter: Yes I do actually. First make sure you get a good nights sleep so your brain can rest and function at its best. Next get to class a little early so you have time to soak up the energy in the room and you get a sense of your surroundings. Take it easy and do not rush. Just one question at a time, next thing you know its over.

seeker: That is great advice. I will certainly try and get a good night of rest.
supporter: Great anything else?

supporter: Okay  it has been nice chatting with you, feel free to end the chat now, goodbye.

seeker: That's a good point! lol
supporter: Foster the people around you that can provide you support, be a reliable producer and leader, and you will find that those that don't like you will move on.  And, most importantly, you can only control how you respond/behave.  If someone wants to instigate conflict, that will reflect poorly upon them.

seeker: So avoid them if they get hostile with me?
supporter: You can only engage with what abuse and hostility you accept.  If you smile in response, it will make you feel better than if you internalize their aggression.

seeker: I had been seeing a therapist online and two weeks ago he was really mean, but said he thought it was a good session and we were making a breakthrough. Then when I signed on last week I signed in to request entrance into the meeting and after a few moments was told it was denied. Nothing like feeling the person who is paid to help you refusing to talk to you
supporter:
That seems like a frustrating experience. What were your expectations of the session you were supposed to have? Did you feel like what you learned in your previous session would have helped you with dealing with what you typically work on in your mental health sessions
?

seeker: I feel like he didn't help at all. Up to that point we mostly just talked about politics or whatever. I'm a charity patient, he get's paid through the organization, but because of my financial difficulties, I'm not paying. I think he saw that as a shortcoming on my part.
supporter: I think that is definitely one way to look at it. But another way to look at your situation is you figured out a therapist who isn't worth seeing. That brings you one step closer to finding one who does actually help you. All you need to do now, is do some research and find someone who has your best interest in mind. Believe me, there are great therapists and terrible therapists. You just need to find one of the good ones now.

seeker: I'm not sure I can find another who I don't have to pay. My insurance has a $20 copay and if I had to pay that I wouldn't be able to buy groceries. This came through my religious organization and he was the only one available in my area. I guess I just have to find another way to cope
supporter: If you have financial issues and you need the help from a therapist you deserve the treatment. One thing you can do is apply for Medicaid and EBT. The state you live in will give you money to pay for groceries and to get help from a therapist for free if you don't have a high enough income. It may be worth looking into because all you really need to do is fill out some forms and likely you will be approved. When I was younger and struggling, this had happened to me and I received both of these benefits and it totally turned my life around. I think it can do the same for you as well.

seeker: I'm on Medicare and supplemental insurance. I didn't know you can, possibly, see one for free. I'll look into that. That is helpful.
supporter: Sure thing. What are some of the coping strategies you've been practicing with your prior therapist?

seeker: I asked him to help me with some but all he would say is that I should stop vaping (I switched from smoking some years ago). I told him it feels like I'm walking a tightrope and he's suggesting I get rid of the safety net without giving me something else, some other way to cope. He said that's not what a therapist is supposed to do and that my resistance shows I don't really want to change.
supporter: I can see how that comment he made would be frustrating. If you feel like vaping, you should continue to do; however, what happens if say you go somewhere and find yourself in a stressful position? What would be strategy you could use in order to recenter yourself? Strategies are important as they balance us when we experience stressors that through us off. Have you ever thought about meditation?

seeker: I asked him about meditation and if he could recommend something. He wouldn't. I have only been able to do it successfully once, at the meditation gardens when I visited my son in San Diego some years back. Since I can't always get to that kind of natural setting, I was hoping he could give me some resources. Do you know of any place I can find some?
supporter: Oh yes. Me personally, I like to scour youtube and find an environment with a sound I enjoy such as the beach. When I listen to that sound, I try to put myself by closing my eyes while sitting on the floor and breathing deeply for some time. It may be worth a try for you. I hope it helps you. Good luck!

seeker: That sounds like a good idea. I'll give that a try
supporter: I wish you all the best!

Doing what others did to overcome it means not having to reinvent the whole process on your own.

supporter: This seems like a very sudden reaction from him, from what I've gathered, seeing as how it took you by surprise. Is there anything going on his life that may have put him into a negative mindset? Perhaps he's having problems in a relationship or at work that is leading him to rabbit holes on the internet.

seeker: He just got furloughed.
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that. He might be struggling with that and looking to shift his negative feelings onto another issue, one that has the support of many. It could be providing him comfort to be angry at the suppression of Twitter rather than coming to terms with his own turmoil. I think talking to him about his job status might be a start in reasoning his new outlook.

seeker: I dunno. How do you think I should approach him about that? He's sort of touchy about the whole subject.
supporter: Gently. It's never a good idea to press the issue, especially if it seems like he's trying to avoid it.

supporter: Perhaps you should implore the help of somebody else in his life. I understand wanting to help your friend, especially when it's negatively impacting your own mental health, but there's only so much one person can do. You both deserve to be in a good head space and asking for help is okay.

seeker: Yeah I guess you're right. I suppose I can talk to his wife about it but I'm not sure how to bring it up.
supporter: I'm sure she might already be concerned as well. It might be easier than you expect. If he's consistently getting in arguments with you, it's likely that he's stuck in a negative haze and it might be affecting his other relationships.

seeker: That's true but I don't want to make this more complicated that it should be. But I used to date his wife so I'm sure in his state of mind, how he would take it if it were the two of us bringing this up.
supporter: Try having a private conversation with her and don't ask her to talk to him, merely push her in that direction. It's less plotting and more seeing her point of view as well.

supporter: I'm glad to have given you some steps that may help you!

supporter: I understand your frustration, it's upsetting when they dismiss what you say even though you have been friends for so long.

supporter: What I would recommend in this case is, spend more time with other friends who appreciate you. You also need to tell Rick your honest thought, don't beat around the bush but let him know you're serious

seeker: That's good advice! Thanks. I wonder how I can get through to him to really let him know I'm serious. Ideas?
supporter: I have been in the same situation myself, what I usually do is sit down with them and start the conversation in a serious mood. Explain everything I need to say and tell them that I mean every word. If they don't seem to accept and change, I keep my distance from them

seeker: Makes sense. Unfortunately we live on the same street so it's kind of hard not to run into each other. :/
supporter: That's even easier to make it clear, if you run into him, just give him a polite greetings. The point is, make it clear you have had enough

seeker: Right, so basically let him know if he continues to act like he does, we're done as friends, correct? Or should I not be that bold?
supporter: Yes. Be not too harsh at first. I would say to give him 1 more chance. If he still doesn't respect your words, it's the best for both to say it clearly.

supporter: Getting emotional is totally fine, that's why you need practice

I think I expect too much  from people - but really my expectations aren't that high, I don't think - if I really think about it.

Well, it seems someone has to have to have gone through some hard times as well, for me to relate to them.  And to have learned from those hard times.  So that cuts out a good bit of people who have had good lives - and then half the people who have gone through some stuff haven't learned from it and made themselves better.  So it
s

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hello, how are you doing?

seeker: I have been better. I am really stressed and feel like I am at a breaking point.
supporter: I am sorry to hear you are near your breaking point, do you have any idea when the decline and stress began?

seeker: It began a few weeks ago. I have had a really intense project that is on a time crunch. I feel like I am overwhelmed and unable to balance work and personal life.
supporter: Work and personal life are very hard to juggle with each other, especially in the current life situations around the globe.  I am sure you will successfully handle both in the overall.

seeker: What should I do to help feel like I can manage and push through? Right no w i feel like giving up.
supporter:
For me, when I start getting overwhelmed and need to "debrief" my mind, and "declutter" the stresses, I use a notepad. I jot down every detail I can that pops into mind. Every upcoming task, everything that has caused anxiety or similar, and then I prioritize them in an agenda. It seems tedious, however once you get a handle on scheduling, in my personal ex
perience, it is easier to hold yourself accountable and slowly work your way through accomplishments, even small tasks, which is encouraging to continue.

seeker: Thank you. That seems helpful. I tend to make excuses for myself when I feel like this and allow myself to slip in other areas of my life. For example if I am stressed, I tend to eat unhealthy food. Overall its hard to juggle all things I want to do and be at once. I will plan to make a list and check off some small things.
supporter:
When you visually see your success, I hope it will help like it does for myself. I personally believe that it is a useful tool, depression runs deep and anxiety pushes it over the edge with deadlines. Life and Personal are very complicated situations. As is living, in itself. Small accomplishments, maybe with minor rewards to
 yourself as you go, boosts confidence and tends to fade out the overwhelming heavy feelings.

seeker: What do you consider to be a minor reward that would be a good tool for me today?
supporter: A punch card. If you have one handy, a note card/index card. Draw maybe, 15 circles around the edge, and call it "My rewards" In the middle, choose one thing you enjoy, for instance, if you like an ice cream sundae, put that in the middle. For your first task, just jot all that is on your mind down, and also use that as the first task to yourself. Check off one circle, and once you hit 15 get that sundae!

seeker: Thats a great idea. I really like that!
supporter: I do sincerely hope you start feeling better, the current average life has altered greatly, and it has changed workloads and balances with great challenges.

seeker: Yes. We are all being challenged and perhaps this will help people grow. I know that once i an over the hump I will be happy i did it and put in the effort. I appreciate the in the moment help!
supporter: Absolutely, I appreciate the chance to speak with you and give suggestions.

seeker: Do you have nay other tips that i may use?
supporter: Perhaps, nature. A walk alone somewhere pretty tends to be a refreshing, zen-like activity. Or even, as a meditation type approach, rock stacking. It takes much focus, and tends to leave your mind clearer in the end. I also recommend reading, or listening to audio books of a theme you are interested in. It brings comfort in activities

thanks maybe I will take a vacation to Europe

seeker: Hello, I'm having a very rough day, how are you?
supporter: I'm doing well, thank you! I'm sorry to hear that you're having a rough day. Do you mind me asking what happened to make you feel that way?

seeker: My mother passed away about a month ago due to alcoholism, it has been rough attempting to cope with the many different emotions.
supporter: I am so sorry to hear that. My brother suffers from alcoholism as well. I know how worrisome and difficult it can be. I still have a hard time dealing with my emotions. What different types of emotions are you feeling?

seeker: I'm so sorry that it's a situation that you can relate to, its such a hard situation watching someone drink their life away no matter what you do until they eventually pass away from it. I can say my anxiety has increased immensely as well as depression. It seems that quite a bit of pressure has been placed on me because of the family business she ran and my dad who is now trying to live without her.
supporter: Wow, that really is a lot to deal with. It seems as though you have a good understanding of what you're feeling but that you are trying to figure out how to move forward from here. It seems like you are trying to figure out how to work through your feelings as well as how to manage and deal with the pressure that has been put on you as a result. Does that sound accurate to you?

seeker: It definitely does, I know it feels like quite a bit now but will gradually become easier to deal with.
supporter: That is a great attitude to have. I'm very proud of you for trying to stay positive and for reassuring yourself that it will become easier for you to deal with over time. You sound like an incredibly strong person!

seeker: Thank you so much! That means a lot just to hear and I think it is incredibly refreshing talking to someone that has a fresh mind about all of it rather than another family member that is attempting to cope with the same situation.
supporter: You're very welcome! I know from experience that it is usually best and much easier to talk to someone on the outside who doesn't know all of the ins and outs of what you are experiencing.

seeker: Very true, especially someone who is willing to listen and provide advice or positive conversation.
supporter: It's great to hear that you are on a medication that will hopefully help you. Have you also considered speaking to an outpatient therapist or someone along those lines? That way, you could return to the same person as often as you feel necessary to continue to work through your feelings with someone who isn't directly involved with your situation.

seeker: Okay. How are you?

supporter: Totally! It's hard to plan for success when life seems a bit uncertain. Is there anything in particular that's bothering you?

seeker: It's a combination of things. I have no idea what I'm doing most days, just kind of going through the motions. Kind of like Groundhog Day, repeating the same day over and over with slightly different variations. Trying to get things done and taken care of, thinking I'm doing my best and feeling like it's never good enough. Feeling like I'm failing all the time.
supporter: Ah yes, the cog in the machine sort of vibe. Boy do I feel that. Well, the good thing is your not alone. The bad thing is societal pressure demands that we be productive or we think we're wasting time. When's the last time you took a day to enjoy something you like to do?

seeker: It's been a long time since I did that, I can't even remember when
supporter: What activity or activities are you thinking about? Anything that you enjoy or makes you smile.
