One of my good friends got married recently and my parents watched them for me so I could go to her bachelorette party and wedding without them. That was the first time I'd gone anywhere without them in....over a year
supporter: Ah weddings, did you have fun?

seeker: I did. I had a really good time. It was weird being out without them, but it was fun
supporter: Nice! Well, two kids is A LOT, especially since they aren't in school yet. You are dealing with the care and growth of the most complex organism on this planet...times two! That's incredible. First of all, give yourself a pat on the back for that. Secondly, is it ok if i ask if you felt guilty for having fun without them? Often times guilt robs us of the ability to take care of ourselves, which happens to me all the time.

seeker: I'm working on that but I feel guilty wanting time to myself to do things
supporter: I think that's a systemic problem. Guilt is this powerful check when we do things that are wrong but self love is not wrong. When you constantly take care of others, you might forget to take care of yourself. We are only able to give the best version of ourselves when we feel validated. Perhaps there is a daycare or at home assistance program that will help give you the time to remember how great you are! Do you have some friends or close relatives that can talk with?

seeker: Not really. They're all dealing with they're own issues
supporter: Have you asked them? I don't mean to be rude, but I have trouble asking for help and sometimes asking people for help seems like this huge, monumental task. But people can often surprise you. Of course, If you have, then I'd suggest looking up some motivational apps and trying meditation. While it can be hard with two young kids, meditation, even for only a few minutes, will help you relax through your doubt long enough to handle the challenges of the day. When you say you feel like your failing, do you think it is because you hold yourself a standard that is hard to reach?

seeker: I'm feeling so worried about the COVID-19 crisis.
supporter: So you feel anxiety about this whole COVID-19 epidemic?

seeker: Yes, I'm particularly worried about my parents. One is on oxygen at night, but he still doesn't want to listen about not going in crowds.
supporter: Oh well I understand your concern then.  As a son or daughter it is certainly reasonable to be concerned about your parents especially as they grow older.  I have a similar situation with my own mother.

seeker: I just don't know what more to do.
supporter: Well first of all, you have to take care of yourself because if you don't you can't help them.  So just take a moment to close your eyes and take some deep breaths and realize you stressing is probably going to make them stress.

seeker: That is helpful information.  What can I tell them?
supporter: Well if you can get some concrete info such as from the CDC and John Hopkins showing case counts in your area.  Show them graphs so they can visually see the impact.  Also if you can get a hold of their doctor yourself, see if you can convince them to give your parents a call, say to check on them and give them some advice.

seeker: That sounds like a good plan.  Is there anything else I can do to decrease the anxiety for me?
supporter: Don't get absorbed in the numbers, it can drive you crazy.  Also if you are using social media like twitter and getting inundated with info, remember a lot of it is fake.  I would suggest limiting exposure for a little while just to get you fixed a little bit, if that makes sense.

seeker: Do you think there are some good social media sites that could help?
supporter: Not particularly social media because it open to everyone, just pick and choose where you choose to get info from.  The CDC is a great resource as well as the John Hopkins site which has been tracking since the beginning.   Everybody has a couple of news outlets they trust, use those.

seeker: How can I cope with limiting my visits with my parents because I am afraid to spread COVID?
supporter: First of all you are not alone.  but don't let them see you anxious for sure.  You can also show them if they can how to do video visits.  You can do that all the time, even phone calls every day.  It means a lot.

seeker: That makes sense.  I appreciate the suggestions.  How can I show them the kids care too?
supporter: Nothing will make grandparents smile more than seeing their grandkids on a video call.  If you don't want to bring them when you physically visit have them record themselves on your phone as an example.

seeker: Maybe I can send them some pictures too.  Nothing like a great big hug, but for now some video chats and pictures or recordings may help.  I'm starting to feel a little more relief.
supporter: Of course.  I don't know if they dressed up for Halloween, but see if they want to dress up and take some pictures for grandma.  Pictures and voice and video are wonderful in these times.

seeker: Thank you so much for helping.  I think I can use your advice.  Take care and have a great day!
supporter: You too, I hope I helped.  Take care!

supporter: That is very kind of you to say.

seeker: I have a licensure exam coming up that I must pass at a 90% score. I have dealt with test anxiety all my life (mind goes blank, difficulty concentrating with noise) and I have to take my exam in a testing center around other people next week. I am extra worried due to COVID. This is a 6 hour exam - what are ways I can calm myself at the exam and succeed?
supporter: First of all, you can bring some snacks and water. having an empty stomach will distract you from the exam

seeker: If you were about to take the most important test of your life (ha!) what would you suggest I do to organize my review the days before the exam? Do you have any study suggestions that have worked for you?
supporter: I have been in that situation many times. From my own experience, yes you should review as much as you can. However, relax the last 2-3 days to not overwhelm yourself. You should also do image training, imagine yourself in the test room, plan ahead what you will do like write your name, open the exam booklet...

seeker: You give good advice, how have you grown into a calm, cool person? :) What obstacles did you have to overcome to get to this level of chill?
supporter: It takes alot to grow into that kind of person, I'm not there yet. I find it vital to understand this, you cannot control everything. As long as you try your best, whatever the outcomes are, they all serve a purpose. When one door closes, the others will open

seeker: That is really helpful advice. I think part of my problem is that I still think I can control every detail and need to learn to let things happen once the ball is in motion. For an exam, I want to do so well because so much is riding on it and that freezes me into trying to control for all outcomes... when really, I can only control myself.
supporter: You are right, I also want to be in control of my life. However, as I grow older, I realize that is impossible. Whenever you feel stressed over life issues, I would recommend taking a walk in the park or anywhere with a lot of trees to clear you mind

seeker: I will definitely arrive early to the test center and walk the campus before going in. Get enough to eat beforehand and bring my snacks so I can focus just on the exam. I'm writing all of this down so I don't forget. It is a shame we can't save the chat.
supporter: sounds like a great plan, i believe you will do well

seeker: Do you have any ideas on what I should about sanitizing my workstation at the exam center? I will be around other people and someone will have used my computer before me. I don't think they are cleaning the stations before the next user.
supporter: Buy some alcohol wipe, you can find it at the grocery store, make sure to come in early enough to do that

seeker: Alright. I think the proctors will allow it as long as I don't have a bulky bag with me. Maybe some I can just slip into my pocket. Anything too fussy might be cause for them thinking I am bringing answers in with me. I don't have much else to ask about, these were my main concerns.
supporter: I believe they sell individual packs of 10 wipes too.Good lick with your exam!~

supporter: It might be time to get some more help? Do you think it is bad enough that you might need inpatient treatment?

supporter: It sounds like you have had a really hard time the last eighteen months. As the lockdown is easing, are there any new pastimes you could get involved in that might distract you?

supporter: Poker night does sound like something that might involve a lot of alcohol though :(

supporter: LOL well I am glad to hear that at least. Splitting a twelve pack between six does not seem like a problem to me

seeker: Yeah, I figure 2 beers over 4 hours is not a big deal every once in a while. I just really hope we start opening back up and people get vaccinated. Although, maybe that is just masking some underlying problem, huh?
supporter: That is possible as well and it is definitely worth talking to someone, I think, just in case

seeker: Yeah, that's a good idea. What do you turn to when you are struggling in life?
supporter: Well beer, to be perfectly honest :D

supporter: It really is! I am just taking in the fresh air in the backyard.

supporter: The same happened to me, and then my father passed away. If there is anything I can say, is to swallow pride and cherish the moments you have on earth together. What was the fight over?

seeker: Yeah I am afraid that these things can happen. It was only over material things.
supporter: That was my next question, what the fight was over. Do you think he would be open to mending things?

seeker: It is weird because I called him out for being manipulative so this is his defense.
supporter: Usually when people feel singled out, they only have a few mechanisms. Unfortunately, most people tend to run away instead of fixing things. It tends to be the easier option.

seeker: I would likely take advantage of an opportunity to be the bigger person.
supporter: When you try to fix things, just remember that this is his method. I wouldn't hold back on what you have to say, but just word it so that he doesn't feel the need to flee.

seeker: That is probably decent advice.
supporter: It is HIS responsibility as a parent to want to fix things, but you are also being the bigger person here. I applaud you and hope that he is receptive.

seeker: I hope so too, but the opportunity seems tenuous
supporter: How did you guys leave it?

seeker: Threatening and disparagement haha
supporter: Ha, well after two years, feelings had to have changed. Even a little. Does he live nearby?

supporter: I'm sorry to hear that, what's happening?

seeker: She got pretty upset when I took off my shower head without telling her. Somehow, we ended up arguing about how I don't respect her.
supporter: Do you think there is any truth to what she is saying?

seeker: Maybe. I don't particularly like her and that she maybe picks up on that. But I feel like that's the underlying issue and the shower head argument is just a coverup for her real feelings.
supporter: I see.   Do you live together?

seeker: Yes
supporter: That does sound upsetting.   So how do you two make peace generally, or do you have silences between you?

seeker: I guess it's less peace and more like silence
supporter: So what helps you deal with it?  I have found journaling so helpful when I have personal conflicts.  It helps to get things in perspective, and to vent to a peice of paper

seeker: I've written some of our arguments down before, but it's too painful to look at now.
supporter: Thath's why I don't save my journal entries, too painful

seeker: I used to talk to friends about it, but idk, it all feels empty now.
supporter: Do you have a counselor you can speak with about how to deal with the conflicts?   Maybe he/she could arrange a family meeting

seeker: I get that. It's hard to look at them. I'm not sure what to do to cope. Lately, my coping skills haven't been all to healthy
supporter: I did that with my husband when we were fighting, having a counselor in the room helped us gain insight.

seeker: I have a psychiatrist and I'm trying to figure out how to pay for a therapy currently. I know some offer sliding scale options
supporter: Exercise is helpful for burning off anger, a good long walk... Oh you must be in US?

seeker: Yeah, I'm in the U.S. I used to go on walks and exercise at night. It really helps me sleep.
supporter: I think that would be great!   A good way to burn off frustration and improve physical health at the same time.

supporter: You will get through this....it sounds like you two need to have some good talks to address these conflicts....together the two of you may be able to sort it out.   On a day when things are calm, not during an argument.

supporter: We are accountable to each other.   We both need to walk for our mental health, we have mental health issues

I think that taking care of your basic needs like eating and sleeping
 will help in other aspects of life.

If that's too much, walk to the end f the driveway.  If that's too much, step outside.   If that's too much, put your shoes on.   Baby steps.

seeker: Hi there, I'd love some help
supporter: Great! What’s going on?

seeker: I've been struggling with sleep over the last few months, and it's making me tired during the day.
supporter: Lack of sleep will definitely make you tired during the day!  Is there something bothering you that causes you to stay awake during the night?

seeker: I can't think of anything particular,  but my mood has been low generally for the last wee while which I imagine is probably the cause. I'm so tired during the day but as soon as my head hits the pillow at night I'm wide awake.
supporter: Well it sounds like you’re tired enough for sleep, but you’re still wired and can’t get the sleep you need.

seeker: That's exactly it. Do you have any advice on what I can do?
supporter: Are you getting any physical activity in during the day to make body more willing to cooperate?

seeker: I'm working in a desk job so spend almost all day sitting down. That could be part of the problem.
supporter: I’ve found that physical activity helps me to get to sleep even when I’m troubled mentally.  Another option is to slow your brain down so that your mind is relaxed.  That is much harder for me though!

seeker: That's a good idea. I could try go out for a walk either before or after work as a starting point and see if that makes a difference.
supporter: That sounds like a good plan!  It also helps to make sure that it’s dark and very quiet.  Surprisingly enough, when they did research on sleep disorders they found that a lot of people just needed quiet and darkness.

seeker: Have you tried lavender? I have heard pillow or room sprays can be good for sleep.
supporter: Yep, I’ve tried a LOT of things.  I’m currently struggling with this myself.  I’m even trying out melatonin, tryptophan, and even CBD (not stoney weed oil)!  So far no success, but I’m still trying!

seeker: I've heard people mention melatonin - I might use that later if other methods dont work. It's good to know other people are in the same boat.
supporter: It’s one of the reasons that it’s good to get outside.  Your body makes melatonin from sunshine, so going for a walk outside helps in 2 ways!

seeker: If we had a little more sunshine where I live that would be fantastic!
supporter: Getting good sleep is critical.  Supplementing with melatonin might help compensate for your lack of sunshine!

seeker: I'll look into it for sure. It's something I hadnt considered before this chat.
supporter: Glad I could help.

seeker: Thanks, the help was appreciated.
supporter: Anytime.  Is there anything else you wanted to discuss?

seeker: That was all for today, thank you.
supporter: My pleasure!  Hope your day goes well.  Sweet dreams!

supporter: It is so hard to figure out where to start sometimes. Ok, I'll help with a plan. Maybe you can glance at the dishes and pull out the largest one that is dirty. Let's start there.

supporter: yes, starting with the large pot would be a great place to start! Good thinking!

seeker: Ok, but then what?
supporter: Well, washing the pot will make the overall task look smaller. Then, let's pick a second type of dish to focus on. After you wash the large pot, try to focus on larger bowls, then plates and cups. You could leave the silverware for last.

seeker: Oh, thank you so much! It helps my anxiety to talk through a plan. Sometimes I get so anxious, it is hard to figure out how to break a large task down to something manageable on my own.

supporter: From the short conversation, I can feel how sad you are.

supporter: What kind of arguments did you have with your mom?

supporter: I had similar situation like yours. My mom did not want me to make friends with some people.

supporter: I just had good conversations with my mom to express my thoughts. Did you have a frank chat with your mom to express your concerns?

seeker: I try to but it never ends well if I don't agree with her suggestions.
supporter: Take a deep breath and it can make you feel better.

seeker: OK! I have taken a deep breath.
supporter: ok, that's good. tell me more about your mom's concerns of your friends.

seeker: She feels that they have some bad influence on me because of their family background. I don't do anything bad with them.
supporter: My mom told me similar concerns before. It is understandable.

seeker: All I need is to find a way to show her that I can make some good decisions as well and that she can trust me to make good friends. I have never gotten into trouble before with my friends
supporter: My suggestion is that tell her these facts and she can make a better decision. I think she assumed your friends are bad influencers just based on their family background.

seeker: Do I need to buy her a gift or something to let her know I care so as to start the conversation?
supporter: Yes, a good idea, it pleases her.

seeker: Thank you for your time.
supporter: You are welcome. Hope it will go well.

seeker: The struggle is real my kids act as if they dont hear me which causes me to become overwhelmed and loud then they dont wanna listen anymore. I am well today and you/
supporter: That sounds really hard! Does that mean things tend to escalate quickly in your home?

seeker:
I am loking for ways to communiate better specifically with my 5 year old son. 
well i always get yelling as a response which is what i cant seem to break
as soon as my son gets mad he screams and calls for me no mater where i am or where he is
supporter: That sounds really challenging. I grew up in a home with a lot of yelling, and after a few years it just became our default for communicating with each other. I really regret that we didn't do anything to change the pattern sooner.

seeker:
yes i can not have that become the normal. I want to feel proud of their beviors they need to learn manners which i think is someting they really missed out on in public schools. the need to conform wouldve taught them manners without them even noticing. So far i try to keep myslef calm and communicate simply
i still get screams back and i just try to make him ty again with a nice voice and tell him i am here to help if he can talk to me
supporter: That sounds like you're trying really hard to set a good example.

seeker: i am trying but i was not raised with the best habits so teaching myself and my kids to be good and consotant has been a challenge
supporter: I understand that - I've spent a lot of time trying to teach myself to be better than the home I grew up in

seeker: darn parents, lol
supporter: Ahaha exactly!

seeker: i do hope they learn to be kind and strive to learn and be smart. games and devices have also become somewhat of the enemy, and savior somedays
supporter: One of my friends who has a really peaceful household maintains a high standard of speaking to her kids like adults and only engaging in conversation when they're speaking respectfully

seeker: but ya know they have been the best teachers this far in my life
supporter: I really like how she does that - only engaging in respectful conversation and not letting the yelling escalate

seeker: i try not to engage in harmful destructive communication yes that is important, i am so emotional it is hard to stay calm when i am not liking what's happening
supporter: It's so hard! Who can be a full-time parent and best friend and take care of your own life, too

seeker: well me hopefully lol
supporter: It can be so hard, so frustrating, and so easy to revert to those habits we both grew up with

seeker: thanks i guess i make it sound ok, i am ok they are good kids at the core thewy kjust need to work on not freaking out
supporter: I have a co-worker who has kids with special needs, and she has this great phrase for working with her kids

seeker: what is it
supporter: She says, "is this a small feeling or a big feeling?" and then, "Are you having a big reaction, or a small reaction?", and it really helps her kids self-soothe

seeker: interesting is she implying having a big reaction to a small feeling is unnessacary?
supporter: She's also taught them that if they're being mean to mom (taking something else out on her), they're allowed to say, "I'm sorry, I'm not acting or feeling my best right now, and I'm going to take a minute to myself." Do you think your kids might relate to that?

seeker: thats wise i must sit with that for a bit and at least talk about their feelings more i bet if i help my kids to feel more validated they will feel heard better and maybe not yell
supporter: Yea, exactly! Trying to teach her kids that it makes more sense for their reactions to be more proportionate to their feelings and to the importance of a situation. It's really helped her address tantrums and help her kids be more self-aware

seeker: i would fall over if my kids said that to me, lol, that would be an improvement to say the least
supporter: Ahahahah. I believe in you!

seeker:
thanks a lot random stranger, lol, no offense, it is just so random where we find support righ
t lol
supporter: Happy to be a helpful random stranger to you!

seeker: your two sense has helped thanks alot, i gonna go talk to my son now while this is fresh on my  mind have a good day
supporter: I'll be thinking of you :)

seeker: thanks my name is kaleigh
supporter: I'm Marissa

seeker: Hi Thank you for your time.
supporter: Of course, I would love to hear what is going on.

seeker: Thank you. My name is DJ and I do appreciate your time.
supporter: What would you like to discuss?

seeker: I really have a desire to write a life experience book to help others overcome past failures and struggles.
supporter: That is great!  I am sure so many people would benefit from the advice and outlook.

seeker: I am 66 and believe I can help others. I lack so much motivation.
supporter: It seems like it might be overwhelming for you to begin.  Maybe you can start small, like think of ideas or maybe just start writing 10 minutes a day.

seeker: Yes, I have been given this encouragement from other writers. Yet, still feel like I lack motivation and passion.
supporter: Maybe you can start with a part of your life that you do feel passionate about first.  I know for me, it's easier to start with something I enjoy the most.

seeker: Yeah, thats interesting. I am a Life Coach and that is what I tell others.
supporter: Yes, I understand it is easy to get frustrated with a lack of motivation.

seeker: Thanks. I appreaciate what you are saying.
supporter: I am happy to help. Sometimes what we need is someone who affirms our dreams.

seeker: You said you understand my frustration.....How so?
supporter: Oh, I definitely feel frustrated with myself when I was to start a project and don't have the energy or motivation to go through with it.  This has happened on many home projects or craft project.  Or even with losing weight and make healthy decisions.

seeker: Wow! Thank you for sharing. I appreciate your honesty and you definatly understand about frustration.
supporter: Well, I hope I encouraged you a little to keep going and start you book, at least a part you enjoy.

seeker: Yeah, I've got some ideas. I need to take my own advice.
supporter: Haha, yes, sometimes listening to ourselves can be the hardest!

seeker: I don't know what to do anymore. i feel completely lost.
supporter: Can you talk more about your feelings now?

seeker: Well i just feel ugly all the time. ive changed my eating habits and i just cant seem to lose any weight
supporter: I can completely understand your feelings. I can feel how stressed out you are about your weight.

seeker: ive tried talking to him about it but he doesnt seem to even listen to me at all.
supporter: I have experienced similar situation. I talked to a consultant and he gave me some good advice on diet. Did you talk to a professional?

seeker: mind u i was 125 and fit for the 10 years we were together before we had kids
supporter: I talked to a nutritionist and it really helped. They are professionals who can look into your diet and give suggestions.

seeker: but they dont have kids
supporter: Can you hire a nanny and free your time?

seeker: that did help me in what i should eliminate
supporter: Were you able to eliminate those foods?

seeker: not all completely but i have been taking a little bit out at a time.
supporter: Did you consider moving to cheaper locations?

seeker: not really i have family here which i want my kids to be as close as possible i would have to move to another state. but that would take a lot of consideration on both of our parts
supporter: yes, I can completely understand your situation. Just from chatting with you, I can see how many things are on your plates.

seeker: Hi Sharon. Am good just concerned about my son.
supporter: Oh I see.  What's happening with your son?

seeker: I suspect my son is in bad company. His most recent behaviour is so different from what I am used to
supporter: Oh that's hard to deal with.   My daughter ran with a bad crowd for a while and I remember the deep worry.

seeker: My son is 15. Recently he's keeping to himself and mostly stays locked in his room. He barely allows anyone in.
supporter: And when you try and talk to him about it what does he say?

seeker: He says he's studying online. But I suspect he's doing other stuff online apart from study
supporter: Oh I see.  Apart from isolating how is he doing otherwise, like at school?  Is he still seeing his friends at all?

seeker: Not really. He just has this one particular friend who comes over sometimes and they lock themselves in the room.
supporter: Hmm.  So a lot of mystery.   I can understand you being worried.   Is he your only child?

seeker: I am so scared I don't want to confront him I have always tried to show him how much I trust him as away to make him feel responsible enough
supporter: Thats good parenting!   Perhaps if you frame it as being about you, e.g. "I am getting really worried, can you please explain....it's affecting me (affecting my sleep/work/whatever" .... maybe it will inspire him to be more forthcoming

seeker: Never thought of it that way. That could be a possibility. But he always seems happy and we chat a lot onlythat he his behind closed doors in his room for a long time everyday.
supporter: Hmm.  My other thought is tell him what you just told me, that you have been trying to show him that you trust him....but be honest and tell him you are afraid.   Hopefully, he won't want you feeling that way, and will open up a bit.

seeker: I find reassurance from your words. Its been tough for me this far we have come with my son and I want us to be close even as he growing up to become a young man. I have a good relationship with their teacher and will definitely give her a friendly call to know more from her.
supporter: Oh good.   And it may be just a normal part of his development.   Teens pull away from parents, peer group becomes far more important.  It may be as simple as that.

seeker: Good to know that from an experienced parent. I will try communicate my worries and my intensions to him. I hope he will understand and not pull away.
supporter: And in the meantime remember to take extra good care of yourself :)   Sometimes as moms we forget to do special things for ourselves.   You are doing the hardest and most imporant job in the world so it's important to recognize that and reward yourself for it.   I hope that conversation goes well for you, that you will have with him.

seeker: Thank you for your time and experienced advise.
supporter: Oh you're so welcome, it's been a pleasure speaking with you.

seeker: The pleasure was all mine. Bye.
supporter: bye :)

seeker: Am ok but feeling sad and anxious
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that you are sad and anxious. Do you know what is causing you to feel that way?

seeker: Yes. I recently lost my childhood best friend to covid 19.
supporter: I can only imagine how sad you feel from losing your best friend. Hopefully chatting some will help. I know in the past when I lost someone it was nice to just have a conversation to help put my mind at ease.

seeker: Sure. I feel so lonely sometimes because we were very close.
supporter: I can imagine that you are feeling lonely. Did you have any mutual friends with your best friend that you can reach out to? I am sure they are feeling the same way and it could help both of you to talk to each other and share stories.

seeker: Yes we have mutual friends. I do reach out to them sometimes. But the feeling doesn't go away. It makes me have sleepless nights. I can't sleep. Every time I close my eyes I see him very close to me like we are having conversations.
supporter: It sounds like you were really close to your best friend. It can take time to get through the grief of losing someone. Things will get better I promise.

seeker: I hope so too. And I hope he is a better place. Have you ever lost someone close to you?
supporter: I lost my father when I was 19. That was pretty tough and it took me years to be OK with it. There are still days a decade later where I think about him and miss him.

seeker: Sorry to hear that.
supporter: Time heals all wounds. While that doesn't sound helpful now it is true. I also found focusing on the good experiences I had with my father (or in this case your best friend) helps. Remembering the times where you both were happy.

seeker: I will try to do that. How can I handle this sleepless nights?
supporter: That's a tough one. I personally still struggle with sleep for other reasons. Some things that can help is taking melatonin 30 minutes before bed. I have also had some luck with white noise machines or other soothing sound machines. The biggest thing is to not use your bedroom for anything but sleeping; so don't read a book or play on your phone in bed, you have to train your body that when you go to bed it is time to sleep.

seeker: Sounds like stuff I can try out.
supporter: Having a bedtime routine is also another tip. Try to do the same thing every night before bed. Have a consistent bedtime, wake up around the same time everyday, even on days that you don't have to go to work.

seeker: Good thoughts there. Will definitely try out the tips. I feel better already just talking to you.
supporter: You are welcome. I am sorry for your loss and I hope for the best for you.

seeker: Am feeling down and blue.
supporter: I understand that you are feeling down and blue and that isn't good. What is making you feel down and blue do you think?

seeker:
Recently no one in my family is talking to me. I think they are mad I went back to taking alcohol.
I was depressed because I lost my job.
supporter: I've struggled with alcohol before too and understand how tough it is to not drink especially during a tough time like after losing a job. Don't beat yourself up, it's only natural and you have the power to get through this trying time.

seeker: I feel calm to know someone else knows what am feeling.
supporter: How long ago did you lose your job?

seeker: How can I stop going back to alcohol when am depressed?
supporter: My advice is to try to talk to your family and explain to them that you lost your job and are feeling down. While they may not accept it at first it is a good start to try to give them some context for why you are drinking.

seeker: I am not sure who to talk to first. Mom or Dad? Am worried my mom will make a big issue out of it.
supporter: Talk to who you feel most comfortable with. Start off easy. Hopefully they can help you then talk to the other parent. I am sure your parents have once had a period in life where they were down and blue and can relate to what you are going through.

seeker: I feel reassured now will definitely find time to face dad and let him know what am going through. Thank you was nice talking to someone who can understand me easily.
supporter: You are welcome. Best of luck!

seeker: One more question, did you stop drinking alcohol completely or did you go about your consuption?
supporter: I have done both; I have gone periods of 6-12 months having nothing to drink and then when I could control it I would allow myself to have drinks on special occasions. I tried not to drink during the week and only once on the weekend at most.

seeker: That sounds like a good plan. I hope I will also come up something that can work for me. Also, will try seeking help from my doctor.
supporter: You are welcome. Have a nice day!

seeker: It keeps us up at night because we know she isn't sleeping.  Worse part is there is nothing we can do to help her.
supporter: Hi! It seems someone in the family is having sleeping issues. Correct me if I am wrong

supporter: Sorry to here about it. It must be hard for you to see her in trouble.

seeker: It is.  She's miserable, and it's causing us to not sleep as well.
supporter: I can feel how stressed you are right now but she will recover fast.

seeker: I know she will, I always lack sleep whenever she's not feeling well.  I wish I could be sick for her.
supporter: When my kid have cold, I nebulize her and later it make her sleep well

seeker: We do the same for her, and it helps for a couple hours but then she's up again.
supporter: Some people says giving green tea helps in cold.

seeker: Really, I'll have to try that. Thank you!
supporter: Taking steamed shower helps in cold as well. You can try that too. I will pray for her speedy recovery.

seeker: Thank you so much.  You have been very helpful.
supporter: Mt best wishes are there with you. Be positive she will sleep well and recover soon.

seeker: Hello! I am doing ok today. Just getting through the day I suppose.
supporter: It sounds like you're having a rough day.

seeker: Just an average day if I had to describe it. Nothing particularly unusual or bad. Worked for about 8 hours and now no plans for the night
supporter: I get that. Some days are just meh, but nights can feel especially lonely.

seeker: Exactly. I find that when the night starts seeping in the loneliness comes up especially with no concrete plans or things to keep busy
supporter: I've felt like that too. The business of the day makes you forget, then it's time for bed and you remember.

seeker: And for me it's the build up to bed time. Those hours to fill with either dinner, watching tv, reading or whatever. Plenty of time let me mind wander and think the worst.
supporter: It sounds like your day to day gets very lonely.

seeker: From time to time yes. I have a dog so that's nice company
supporter: Dogs or pets in general really help to alleviate depression.

seeker: Yes! Something to make me feel needed and companionship knowing he's depending on me
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have any friends to talk to or groups about it you can join?

seeker: I do. I've been better about reaching out to people and joining a few online groups. It has helped for sure but I still find myself with the feelings from time to time
supporter: Personally, I have a betta fish, but he seems happy to see me.

seeker: That's cute. Fish are less work than dogs but still a way to feel needed with food and water changes
supporter: I'm glad he doesn't need to walk, but I'm sure the fresh air is nice.

seeker: Thanks. Good to hear that even from a stranger. It feels like a bother to burden others with my "problems" even though they are supportive
supporter: I feel like that too. It's easy to feel "strong" for holding it in, but it's just as strong to let those feelings out.

seeker: Even this was helpful. I was leaning towards pouring that first drink of the night soon, but just a quick chat like this has helped me reframe and stay strong for tonight at least
supporter: I'm glad. Things are tough but you can do it! Moment to moment is easier than a day at a time.

seeker: Well, thank you so much. This was a nice chat that definitely helped me. Hope you have a good rest of your night
supporter: I hope you do too. Keep reaching out when you need it.

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hello my name is Sue, how are you today?

seeker: I am ok. Just very sleepy.
supporter: Why are you sleepy?  Long day?

seeker: I have been having trouble getting to sleep on time.
supporter: Oh I see, so you aren't getting enough sleep am I right?

seeker: Yes. I find it hard to fall asleep. This happens most nights
supporter: What typically happens when you try to go to sleep?   Is it hard to quiet your mind?

seeker: I just feel anxious and sometimes I don't even know why. But yes my mind keeps going.
supporter: Not sleeping well is a problem I have on and off as well, and I have found those next days so tiring and frustrating.   If you like I can share some of the things that have helped me?

seeker: Yes please. Maybe something you did could help me too. Did you also have trouble quieting your mind?
supporter: I use this great free podcast called Tracks to Relax, it has guided meditations that really help me get to sleep.  The seem to shut down my mind when I am thinking too much at bedtime.   Which can happen to me some nights, anxieties can keep me awake.

seeker: That sounds like something I could try. Did you just google Tracks to Relax?
supporter: um I think there may be a website but I found it by opening up the Podcast app on my phone and doing a search..  There are premium options but I just use the free stuff

seeker: I have in the past. Is it on Spotify?
supporter: um i am not sure let me check real quickly, one moment

seeker: That is very nice of you
supporter: yes it is!  you are welcome

seeker: How long does it go for?
supporter: The reason I brought up spotify is that sometimes I listen to a playlist on there called "Gentle Lapping Waves" which is super relaxing...and I set my cellphone to turn it off after half an hour or so.   As for Tracks to Relax I think most are about 40 minutes?   To be honest I am not sure.   I fall asleep midway through hehe

seeker: I do not. But I will try with the podcast. It is easy and free. And if it gets worse I can look into getting professional help.
supporter: OH another trick I use to get the thoughts "out of my head" is journaling.  You are so welcome, it's been a pleasure talking with you.   All the best in your quest for a good night's sleep :)

seeker: That is a good idea too! Thanks again and enjoy the rest of your day.
supporter: you as well :)

seeker: Hi, i'm really anxiety for my next test
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. What about it is making you anxious?

seeker: Perhaps I'm worried if I'll pass the test or not
supporter: That definitely would make someone anxious.

seeker: can you give me an advice?
supporter: Of course. It might help to do something that relaxes you: listening to music, or maybe talking to a friend.

seeker: I like listening to music, it's really goof to relax
supporter: Maybe, you can practice some self affirmation too! If you studied and paid attention, you know you can do your best on the test.

seeker: talking to a friend sometimes it help too
supporter: Sometimes, when you've done all you can do, it helps to rewind.

seeker: well, I tried to do good, but not all the times.
supporter: I know it can be frustrating when we don't do well, but that's ok.

seeker: Yes, but at least I do everything that I can do.
supporter: Okay, whenever you're ready.

seeker: Yes, because sometimes I see people studying before the test and I don't think it's a good idea due to you will be more anxious
supporter: I agree. It can stress you out more when you're already stressed.

seeker: People try studying until late and they don't sleep properly which is bad for them
supporter: Yes, people do better on tests when they are well rested.

seeker: ok, I good now. thank you for talking to me
supporter: Have a nice day/night/evening!

seeker: I could not sleep at night.
supporter: That is unfortunate to hear; is this a usual difficulty at night?

seeker: Yes. At all nights I feel insecured
supporter: It is most uncomfortable when you cannot feel secure in your bed for sleep.

seeker: Yes. I feel like there is no one for me. I think I need some support.
supporter: Some nights I have suffered from feeling as you describe.

seeker: No I feel ashamed to discuss my problem. What did you did in your situation?
supporter: In my situation, I met a small pet dog I became close with; he does not like to sleep alone either, so we are now close and keep each other company at night to sleep.

seeker: That is a good idea but I don't like dogs.
supporter: I understand everyone has their preference about pets or animals.

seeker: Yeah Thank you for understanding me. I thought no one understands me.
supporter: A cat is a sweet companion and also like to sleep comfortable with people at night.

seeker: Yes now I decided to buy a cat. And I think my problems will be sorted after the cat comes.
supporter: I feel alone sometime as well, so do not feel misunderstood. I believe it may be natural for us to feel this way from time to time.

seeker: Yes That may be true. But my problems are disturbing my sleep.
supporter: Hopefully, having a new friend who also enjoys sleeping will assist you with this particular disrbance.

seeker: Yes I think so. I will try out this idea for my next night sleep.
supporter: Have you ever considered an online friend to chat with before going to bed to help to keep you  company?

seeker: No I never considered this before.
supporter: This has helped me to calm my mind in the past, since sometimes they can also relieve their mind with you before they sleep as well. Just as we are talking now.

seeker: Thank you for your concern.
supporter: Do you think this may be a relatable way to help soothe your mind before sleeping?

seeker: Yes I think so
supporter: There are many different people to chat with and know. Many friendly and funny ones too.

seeker: I need assistance in sleeping sound at day time.
supporter: I looks like you have hard time in sleeping. Correct me if I am wrong.

seeker: Yes. I don't want to go by medicine.
supporter: Are you working late at night? is that the reason you want to sleep at day time.

seeker: Not late at night. But thoughout the night, starting in the evening ending in the morning. In between I can sleep enough I want, no throughout the night.
supporter: I can totally understand how you feel without proper sleep. Our body need full rest to function well.

seeker: Do you know any kind of exercise that can bring good sleep, not a medicine.
supporter: As far as I understand that you don't have long sound sleep.

seeker: Yes again. I have to do something to sleep well.
supporter: When I feel restless and want to sleep well, I take warm shower before sleeping and it helps me. At day time try to keep your bedroom dark so you can sleep for longer.

seeker: Warm shower helps you sleep. I learn to do that. I was thinking a bath will keep me fresh and will reduce sleep. Thanks for your advice. Also I am making arrangements to keep my room full dark, no small light at all.
supporter: Some people put soothing soft music to make them sleep too. Have you ever tried that?

seeker: Yes. I like songs. May be that will also help me for good sleeping. I will try that. I think it will help.
supporter: Hope it will help you. Do you any any other help?

seeker: Thanks. I feel satisfied having some ideas. I think these will work. Thanks again. Shall I take a leave ?
supporter: sure! Have a wonderful sleep ahead

seeker: Bye. ! ! !
supporter: Bye! You may submit the test now

seeker: hey
supporter: Hello, my name is Amber, how are you doing?

seeker: I could be better.
supporter: What's been happening?

seeker: I just had a baby 2 months ago and I have been struggling with my physical appearance and dealing with my mental health.
supporter: Is part of that the weight gain from pregnancy?   And what sort of mental health challenges are you having?   Both of these problems are very common for new mothers.

seeker: I didnt keep much weight from the pregnancy but its the loose skin that makes it very challenging to accept and to love my self.
supporter: Oh that is understandable.   I am a mother, and remember worrying about the same thing.

seeker: My depression has gotten worse since having my son. I feel a constant feeling that i'm not a good mother. I feel worthless and having a constant feeling that I don't deserve my son
supporter: I can tell you from personal experience that loose skin, stretch marks, and loosening of "other parts" do all self correct with time.  You will feel better about your body again when they do.

seeker: How did you cope with post partum?
supporter: I was fortunate not to experience depresion.  But I totally went through self doubt, wondering if I was being a good enough mother, and feeling "not up to" the task....it's the hardest job in the world, being a mom, and so exhausting the first while.

seeker: Yes. I mentioned it to them at my 6 week pp check up. I was prescribed to a med to help but I dont think its fully in its works yet.
supporter: Antidepressants can take a couple of weeks to kick in, I am on them too;  I hope you will find them helpful.   It's hard waiting for them to work!

seeker: Thank you, I hope so too. Yes I have my husband helping me. I am a stay at home mom while he goes to work. Im lucky that I am able to stay home with our son but at the same time its hard because because theres a less opportunity to have a break and on top of that he works 12 hour shifts so I rarley get to spend time with my husband.
supporter: Oh that's a long shift...I'm glad you have someone at home to help when he can.   It may seem impossible but you are stronger than you think...you've got this

seeker: Thank you, I really appreciate it. Its nice to be able to talk about it.
supporter: I have one other suggestion before I go, have you any mother and baby groups in your area?   Something you may want to research.   It's been a pleasure speaking with you, you are so welcome.   Know that as hard as it is, these feelings can be a normal experience for a new mother, and you will get through it.

seeker: Ill definitely have to look into it, thank you! I hope you have a great day!
supporter: Thank you you too!

seeker: hello
supporter: Hello

seeker: she has addictions and is living a very dangerous life
supporter: That is nerve wrecking. Did you try to comfort her and tell her that you are there to help her out.

seeker: yes, often
supporter: I love your patience level and would like to keep it going.

seeker: i will but it's such a heavy burden to carry.  i try not to think about it much, but I carry it, you know?   I Hope you are right about her wanting help eventually
supporter: I understand your heavy burden however some kids face these problems and we as parents guide them so that they come out with flying colors.

supporter: I used to be a night owl, going to bed early in the morning.  I reset my schedule very gradually.  I went to bed 15 minutes earlier, and set an alarm for 8 hours later.  I did that for 3 days, then I would ratchet it back another 15 minutes.   It was a gradual process and the only way I could fix it.

supporter: Have you ever tried affirmations or heard of this before?

seeker: No. What is that?
supporter: Affirmations are positive statements you think about yourself. What I like to do when I'm feeling really anxious is say three positive things/attributes I feel about myself over and over again until my anxiety dissipates. Do you think that could help you feel more positively about what those closest to you are saying so much with regards to looks?

seeker: I could try. Do I need to say positive things about my looks or can they be about other stuff?
supporter: Since you are stating that you are concerned about how you look, you should just find a few positive statements with regards to your looks you think about yourself and repeat them. So if you don't think you need to lose weight, you can say something like, "I like my weight." or "I don't need to lose weight." If you think you are beautiful or pretty, you can say "I am beautiful." My three affirmations I use for myself are: I am beautiful, smart, and funny. I say this over and over again until my anxiety has left me.

supporter: No, I didn't. I don't think that antidepressants are addictive, but you could ask your doctor if you have any concerns

seeker: Hi!
supporter: Hello. How are you feeling today?

seeker: Well, I'm a little tired and anxious but I got use to it.
supporter: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. Do you know what's might be causing these feelings of anxiety and fatigue?

seeker: Well, its very difficult to sleep because of the nightmares. Every time I sleep I have the same dream. I recall the event in my sleep and its just horrible.
supporter: That must be very distressing to have the same nightmare every night. Do you have a nighttime routine to help you get to rest in a more relaxed state?

seeker: Yes, I read some magazines and some blogs on internet about some routines but they just don't help.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that you haven't had success with routines. I have suffered with sleeplessness due to bad dreams as well. I find doing yoga with meditative breathing allows me to clear my mind, and sleep better. Do you practice any meditation?

seeker: I have never tried because I'm too anxious to stay still for longer periods of time.
supporter: Having high anxiety makes it very hard to concentrate on meditation. I take a medication for anxiety that has helped me a lot. Have you talked to your doctor about your anxiety?

seeker: Yeah, they gave me pills for that but it didn't help me.
supporter: I'm really sorry you weren't able to get relief with medication. I understand that having someone to talk to can be a relief when you feel so anxious.

seeker: Yeah I actually have my best friends and every time i feel horrible I talked to them.
supporter: I'm sure your friend is glad to be able to lend a listening ear. Sometimes we need to hash out our problems more than once to resolve them.

seeker: Actually, yes. I do a lot of exercise and that actually helps me sleep a little.
supporter: I'm so glad to hear you have some outlet for your anxiety that helps with your sleep. Keeping your body healthy can be a great start to getting your mind in a more calm space.

seeker: No, I'm a student and with the pandemic and all that it's virtual but that keeps me busy.
supporter: I see. Being at home alone most of the time, even when you have virtual meetings, may be contributing to your anxiety. Maybe you could meet up with friends in person at a park or other outdoor location. Is that possible?

seeker: Yeah, don't worry. I go out with my friends regularly.
supporter: That's great! I'm glad you are getting plenty of socialization during this difficult time.

seeker: Thanks :D
supporter: Do you like music? It can be a great way to wind down instead of looking at screens before bedtime.

seeker: I love music, it helps me disconnect from the world.
supporter: Wonderful! I'm so glad our conversation has helped you feel better. It's always nice to be able to get out what's on your mind in a trusting environment.

seeker: I will, thank you so much.
supporter: You are very welcome! I hope you have a wonderful day!

seeker: Same for you!!! and thanks again.
supporter: No problem. I believe you can manage your anxiety, and if you have trouble there is always help available.

seeker: Hi..how are you doing today..
supporter: Hi..Iam doing good..How are you today

seeker: Iam facing post partum depression as I recently had a baby..
supporter: Oh I can relate to that because I also had a baby a year ago and I can understand what you are going through..

seeker: How did you manage to deal with that..
supporter: Do you have anyone to help you with the baby so that you can have some time to relax for yourselves.

seeker: No my husband works in different city and my parents live in a different country..I dont have anyone with me to take care of the baby..
supporter: Oh that will be difficult for you..Can you afford a nanny..

seeker: Yeah I can afford but iam skeptical because of the pandemic..
supporter: Dont worry,just love your baby,when the baby sleeps,try to have some rest and practice yoga and meditation when you have time ,they helped me a lot whn Iam dealing with the depression..

seeker: Oh Thank you for the suggestion..I will follow that..
supporter: Also you can connect on online forums and find help by chatting with other moms who are fcing the same issues..

seeker: Oh that is a great idea..I will certainly look in to it and will consider it..
supporter: Iam glad you like them..I hope you will be better soon and Iam positive about that..love your baby..

seeker: Thank you so much for the help .I really appreciate it .
supporter: No problem..happy to help..Is there any thing else you need help with?

seeker: Nothing..thank you..bye..
supporter: ok bye

seeker: This service is extremely helpful..
supporter: Iam glad to help you provide with emotional support..

seeker: Hello. I am sad because my job is not rewarding. It is a dead-end job and I feel shameful anymore. I don't like talking about my job with anyone since it is so pointless.
supporter: Hi Larry.  What sort of job do you do?

seeker: I am a maintenance supervisor in a manufacturing facility.
supporter: I have had jobs that seemed pointless as well.   I was a sales assistant in a store constantly waiting for customers, it was boring!  Just a paycheque with no fulfillment.  I found it depressing as well.

seeker: Yes that is a very good summary of what is going on. And I am glad to see you can relate. While I am lucky to not work in sales since I know those jobs are extremely tough but the lack of reward is all the same.
supporter: Are there other jobs available in your area that you could apply for that are more up your alley?

seeker: I have not seen anything worth jumping ship for. I am afraid of the old adage of the grass always looks greener from the other side of the fence. Meaning I leave this job and only find a worse job.
supporter: I see., yes that could be a risk for sure.have you spoken to your manager to see if there may be other opportunities in the manufacturing facility for you?   I bet they would rather retrain you for a different position than lose you.

seeker: Unfortunately there are no other positions at the place I work. Yes my boss is very well aware of how unhappy I am. He is also unhappy and has been looking for jobs too. It isn't that great of a place to work at. I have had 3 different friends leave my place of employment, I've just been to lazy to leave too. It's a catch 22, too lazy to leave but due to feeling sad from being here I don't have the energy to try to leave.
supporter: Yes I can understand that.  Sadness and depresion can lead one to feel depleted and lacking motivation to make change.

seeker: Yes, I see a psychologist and she does her best to help me but ultimately it is up to me to make the changes I need to in life.
supporter: Is there anything about your position that you could suggest improving to your boss, to make your job more interesting?   Maybe some ideas you may have for streamlining the work or somethings?

seeker: I've spoke things over with my boss, he has tried a few things. Currently we are in a holding pattern due to some upper management changes and we are awaiting to see how the new manager would like to run things.
supporter: oh I see.  Do you have hobbies outside of work that you find fulfilling?

seeker: I have been slacking on that too. Just don't find pleasure in anything anymore. Now that it is spring time though hopefully that changes.
supporter: Lets hope the new manager improves things for you, it sounds like there is a ray of hope there!

seeker: I should start writing lists. I know that is a great tool for helping.
supporter: Lets hope the new manager can improve things.   And your work with the psychologist is very positive, it's great you reached out for help, that is a strength.   You've spoken with your boss.   You are doing all the right things.

seeker: Thank you for the encouragement .
supporter: you're very welcome, it's been a pleasure talking with you Larry.

seeker: Thank you for your help Sharon. Have a good day.
supporter: you too!  take good care of yourself, bye

seeker: Hi, I'm struggling today.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Anything in particular that is bothering you?

seeker: I just feel worn out with everything I have to do.
supporter: I understand that you are feeling worn out and don't know what else you can do to help your child. Is there something specific going on or is it just life in general?

seeker: My daughter struggles with school work and memory. She learns differently and needs lots of support. I have contacted the school a number of times over the years but never really had any support or acknowledgement from them. I guess it's just an accumulation of things.
supporter: You have tried hard to help her and that is admirable. Don't beat yourself up and be proud of the things you have done for her.

seeker: But what do I now. She's 17 and it's so difficult to give her the time and then  encourage her to tell me when she needs help and for her to be willing to accept it.
supporter: While I do not have kids, from what I have seen my friends and family do in this situation is try to find something that your daughter is interested in and attempt to build off of that. So instead of her learning to just learn, she is learning something that is relevant to her. Maybe that might spark something in her to come up with her way of learning since traditional methods aren't working.

seeker: That is great advice. She does climb and hasn't been able to climb or see her friends with everything closed. I think as she will be able to again soon may be that will help her to relax and get back into it. She does learn through repetition but has lacked enthusiasm especially in the last few months.
supporter: Having her go climbing more sounds like a good plan. Hopefully things are opening up around you now that the vaccine is becoming more common.

seeker: She had heart  surgery as a baby so has actually had the vaccine herself as she's in the vulnerable category.  I think she ends up spending so long making aide memoires that she then leaves herself so little time to actually study.
supporter: I can imagine after having heart surgery as a baby she wants to live life to it's fullest extent and prioritizes making memories over school. Does she ever talk about what her plans are for after high-school? At some point she will have to connect the dots of having to get a job to be able to go out and have fun, and unfortunately doing OK in school comes with that. That or a vocational school to learn a trade (what I personally did).

seeker: What did you do? Her interests are music and photography. Recently she has started a gardening club with the horticulture department at school. She does enjoy her social life well when she has been able to have it. She has had social ups and downs but apart from the epidemic she has been happier than in her earlier years at school. You are right she is becoming an adult and will find her place. At 17 I guess she doesn't have to decide just yet.
supporter: Sorry for the delay. I am glad you are feeling more positive. I was into cars so I went to vocational school to become an auto mechanic. After a couple years of that I realized I wasn't cut out for physical labor and went to college. But the knowledge from working on cars helped me understand things better at college since I had real world applications I could use it on.

seeker: Thank you so much for your time and kindness today. You helped me refocus and some of the things you said were just what I needed to hear.
supporter: Glad I was able to help. Sometimes just having someone to bounce things off of makes a big difference. You have a good heart and good intentions. I wish you and your daughter the best.

seeker: Thank you.  Take care :-)
supporter: You're welcome. It was my pleasure.

seeker: I used to love my boyfriend, but now I can't stand him. Why has this happened and how to break up with him without hurting his feelings much?
supporter: What changed to bring you to the point you can't stand him?

seeker: I just find him extremely annoying. How he walks, talks, breathes even... I should have walked away from him earlier.
supporter: That sounds like a really difficult and uncomfortable situation to be in.

seeker: Yes, it is.
supporter: It's good you know where you're at and what you do, and do not, want.

seeker: How do I tell my boyfriend that I don't want to be him anymore???? How do I break up???
supporter: When ending a relationship, we're not responsible for the other person's emotions. Whatever they feel, they feel, and we can't control that.

seeker: How about me? Will I regret breaking up with him? I've became a better person since we've met.
supporter: You might try talking to him and seeing if he has any awareness of your unhappiness, of you discomfort with his pushing for marriage and children when you're not ready.

seeker: I feel guilty to hurt his feelings and at the same time it pisses me off even more!
supporter: A good friend once told me that all normal, sane people feel guilt when ending a relationship when they're not happy. There is no pleasure in breaking someone's heart, especially when they haven't done anything really wrong.

seeker: You're right. I should talk about it with him openly and tell him how I really feel.
supporter: It sounds like you're maybe not 100% certain you want to end things. That's where talking to him becomes important.

seeker: Maybe I'm afraid of being alone. Maybe things could have been different if it weren't for COVID. Maybe we spend TOO much time together.
supporter: And, if you do have a talk with him and later it becomes clear the relationship still can't work, it won't hit him as such a surprise when you choose to end things.

seeker: Thank you so much for listening me out and for wise advice. I will talk to him, tonight.
supporter: I think that's a good decision. I hope the two of you are able to come to a better understanding of where things are with your relationship.

supporter: Don't over extend yourself though. Make sure to give yourself plenty of you time.

supporter: Maybe set aside a few hours each week where you do something just for you, even if someone else claims that they need you.

ost "online" jobs are probably scams.

supporter: If you are good with numbers and software, you are probably a good fit for other jobs.

supporter: So you're interested in going into the startup world?

supporter: Ok. So you want stability and a higher-level position.

seeker: Stability is much more important, I don't need a higher-level position at this point of time. I am already looking for junior profiles to enter faster in the job market
supporter: Is it possible that you are overqualified for those positions?

supporter: That might work, but I wonder whether HR will want your credentials once you get a job.

seeker: I doubt HR will have any concerns about my credentials about being over-qualified after getting hired. The reporting manager may be anxious rather happy to know about my skillset
supporter: Ok. It's hard to know how companies play those things now. Sometimes they check your social media accounts for any inconsistency.

seeker: Yes, they do check the social media accounts but I tried to keep generic profile over there to avoid concerns.
supporter: That's good thinking. Play it safe.

seeker: Yes, thanks. I will keep trying I guess. Hopefully I get a job soon.
supporter: Is there anything else you would like chat about?

seeker: No, that will be all. Thanks
supporter: Ok. Have a good day.

seeker: Thanks, you too.
supporter: Ok.

supporter: Has the sadness eased over time in the past year? Were you consciously taking some measures to get over the stage?

seeker: Yeah iam implementing of taking a new hobby which is distracting me a little
supporter: On average it takes me about a year to get over this. I feel like there is no better person for me, I don't know what the future brings, and I am imaging all the scenarios where past relationships could have been successful for me. I took a lot of walks and spent a lot of time with friends.

seeker: yeah those are two good strategies to follow..I will be considering them
supporter: I didn't. I wasn't able to afford them. I actually felt bad about venting the situation to my friends. They offered a lot of emotional support and I am sure they didn't want to seeing me like this.

seeker: Even I cannot affod a counsellor..But Iam too embarraseed to talk to my friends..
supporter: I am glad that you are preemptive about it. I think one year in, if you still constantly think about it, a counseling session would help you get closure. Even if it is a one session, you can always assess after trying this out. My current company actually offers free counseling session if I want to, I understand it is called "One Medical"?

seeker: yeah thank you for the help..is there any other strategies i can follow
supporter: I also took up a lot of volunteering. It gives me a purpose and a group to belong to, where I can start fresh, have no baggages and meet new people.

supporter: I am not familiar with the dating situation in pandemic time. I would say take it slow. If it is a right partner for you, it will make you a better person.

supporter: I am glad that we are able to chat. I hope things can start working out for you and you are able to move on to a new chapter of life.

seeker: hey!

supporter: Well darlin that depends. Do you enjoy those things? Why not pamper yourself? Mothers work nonstop, they deserve a break. All in all he is their father and will not risk neglecting them. Because if he does he loses them

supporter: Well there you go. Go run you a hot bath. Toss in a bath bomb, and grab your favorite novel or new novel and soak your troubles away!

supporter: Of course sweetie, just remember to take care of you. There is still a woman under the mother. A lot of moms forget that and neglect themselves.

seeker: That's easy! Someone intelligent, good looking, kind, dominate, hardworking. Someone who loves to get out, but is just as happy to sit down and binge watch netflix.
supporter: Ohh i want one! If you find one, see if he has a brother!

supporter: Great. Well it was great talking to you!

seeker: Hi there, I'm struggling to be honest.
supporter: What are you struggling with?

seeker: I've been finding it really hard to motivate myself to do anything for the last year or so, but it's been getting worse recently. Everything feels like hard work.
supporter: To be honest, I feel the same way sometimes, too.  It is nice to have someone to talk to about this.  Have you talked to anyone else about this yet?

seeker: I haven't really, I feel like other people have their own issues and I don't want to burden them. It's good that others feel the same. Do you have any advice on what makes you feel better?
supporter: Yes.  I agree.  For me personally, I noticed if I think back of a time before I lost my motivation, sometimes it helps me to reenergize a bit.

seeker: Hmm, I'm finding it hard to remember a time I didn't feel like this! I feel like this has been going on forever! I used to enjoy walking, and generally getting things done around the house. I am also self employed and loved putting time into my business but I've been finding that hard recently.
supporter: I have been spending a lot of time home by myself as well.

seeker: How do you cope with it? How do you not get bored and restless?
supporter: I noticed if I try to adhere to a schedule, even a very simple one, such as getting up at a certain time, making breakfast, and showering.  My days tend to go better.

seeker: I've been finding I have a lot of time alone with my thoughts recently.
supporter: Have you tried reading?  I find reading motivates me sometimes, too.  Sometimes too much thinking alone leaves me digging a hole for myself.

seeker: I used to get a lot of pleasure from reading and would always have a book on the go. Now reading feels like a chore, as if I am making myself do it.
supporter: I sometimes force myself to exercise when I get sleepy when I shouldn't be tired during the day.

seeker: That's a good idea I could definitely try that.
supporter: Maybe try YouTubing?  There are a lot of interesting channels that talks about science, technology, personal health, ... etc.  That can be beneficial to you and worthwhile.

seeker: I do watch a lot of youtube, but it's mainly true crime I am into. I always forget there is other content on there other than what is in my subscription box.
supporter: Certainly.  I have a pullup bar and some weights at home.  Even without those, sometimes I just do some bodyweight exercises, such as pushups, squats, ... etc.

seeker: Home workouts would be good. Do you use an app, or just make up the moves yourself?
supporter: Yes, the YouTube algorithm is not always the most helpful sometimes.  You can try logging out to see if you see some other recommendations.

seeker: I will do that after this chat, and see if I can find any home workout videos on there.
supporter: I used to be in the military, so I have a rough idea of what exercises I can perform and how much of it I can do each time.  Looking up more information on it is a great idea.

seeker: I'll do that then, and see if there are any useful apps I can use on my phone so I can do workouts on the go. I know it will be hard to get myself into the habit of doing it but maybe if I stick at it I'll see rewards.
supporter: I recommend finding a friend or partner to keep you accountable.

seeker: I'd love to find a partner! At the moment I can't really go out and dating and I'm finding online dating tedious. That's a good idea, I use excel for work so could set up a spreadsheet for exercise.
supporter: Yes, have some fun with the spreadsheet, too!  Conditional formatting, plotting graphs, generating statistics.

seeker: I'll certainly look into it. Thanks for your help, I'm feeling a little more focused.
supporter: My pleasure!

supporter: do you have any evidence they are laughing at you or not liking you?  or is it a feeling you have?

supporter: i can relate to this.   I went through a breakup a couple of years ago, and left town.   Part of me is relieved I don't have to see those friends we had in common any more.  I didn't want to be jiudged for leaving him.   So I have experienced some similar feelings.

supporter: Ah yes, the public and private can be quite different sometimes for sure

supporter: the other thing is these common friends might feel a bit awkard too about the situation.   They have to figure out how to relate to you both on your own, it's a change of dynamics, so might take a bit of time to settle out.   Can you tell your friend that you'd like to go out for a drink but that you don't feel comfortable talking about your ex at all?  Would your friend respect your request if you made one do you think?

seeker: Yes that's true. I believe he might understand me and accept my request. Would be quite challenging if we will meet my ex wth other friends in same pub. I live in a small town.
supporter: oh I see, yes that could be awkward for sure.

supporter: i hope if you go that you have an enjoyable time, and that your friend respects your boundaries.  And worse case scenario, if your ex is there, you could leave early...if it were me I'd warn my friend that I might have to

supporter: you're very welcome.  and you as well!  Bye.

supporter: Hello, how are you doing today?

supporter: Losing your job is one of the biggest stressors in life, how have you been handling it?

seeker: Well first few month was kind off alright, Was looking for a job in different places without success. And now I am really depressed and I feel so useless.
supporter: I know what it's like to lose a job, and when it's hard to find a new one it can really make you feel low. What activities have you been doing in addition to seeking new employment?

seeker: Nice that you understand me, I was trying job websites alongside with jobcenter in town centre. I have jobseeker allowance but it will not cover the rent
supporter: I am living in a high-rent city and the only way I was able to keep my apartment was to find a roommate. Are there ways you can get help from friends or family until a new job opens up?

seeker: I am renting just a room at the moment, Before I had a girlfriend so we had to split the bill. After she left I had to take all responsibility just on myself to pay bills. I have few friends but don't think they could lend me a lot of money anyway
supporter: One possible solution, if it's possible for you, could be to sub-lease your room to someone else and stay with friends or family. Even if they can't loan you money, they may be able to let you stay with them for a week while you make money renting your room as an airbnb.

seeker: Oh AirBnB might be a solution actually. I will speak to my cousin if I could stay couple of nights at his place.
supporter: What sort of employment are you looking for? Perhaps we can brainstorm some places you can go to make connections for potential work.

seeker: I was working in IKEA warehouse before I got redundant
supporter: Working in a warehouse shows you have great skills for several other types of jobs. Have you checked small independent-contractor sites like TaskRabbit or Lyft to make extra funds while you search for a new permanent job?

seeker: I even haven't heard about those. I am really useless sometimes... What kind of jobs I can find there do you know?
supporter: Well, if you didn't know about them, that's not your fault. It's possible that you could find a new job opportunity while working on smaller tasks or by volunteering for a local organization. You could meet new folks who could provide you with new connections for employment!

seeker: I Will definitely try that. You are really helpful. Have you been doing any jobs through those websites?
supporter: Yes I am able to make a little spending money by doing small tasks like delivering real estate papers, or delivery take-out food. You can google a list of sites like RentSons.com where you can sign up to do an assortment of tasks, and your warehouse skills will come in handy!

seeker: That's cool, I feel now a lot better. Maybe I will be able to find even a girlfriend somewhere on those jobs. I feel lonely after my girlfriend left me
supporter: We all feel lonely when life gets hard, but getting yourself out there to do tasks will help you feel useful AND you could meet your future wife, you never know! I wish you the absolute best!

seeker: Thank you very much for you help. I learned something new today and feel much better
supporter: You're welcome. I think you'll do great.

seeker:
Have a lovely
 afternoon!
supporter: You too!

seeker: Hi..Iam in severe kind of depression and stress.
supporter: Hello, I just connected. What do you want to talk about most?

seeker: I am seeking some emotional help with my depression
supporter: We can start over... It seems like you have having issues with managing depression. Is that so?

seeker: Iam a victim of domestic and sexual abuse by my partner.yes,I need some help
supporter: It is OK to ask for help. Many people do it every day. You deserve to be heard.

seeker: Yeah I have two beautiful kids,I just want to be there for them in their life.
supporter: You have a wonderful dedication to your children, I can tell.

seeker: Yeah also I am looking for some financial security for my kids future which is possible only with a job..
supporter: You mentioned this before, but have you tried therapy sessions?

seeker: Yeah Iam looking to go for therapy ,but not able to find a therapist according to my budget.
supporter: There are many ways to find a mental health professional at little to no cost. Look in your network and see if you can find someone without a co-pay, or if you don't have insurance, you will be able to find people who provide services who use sliding pay scales.

seeker: Those are very helpful ideas..Thank you very much.I will try for sure.
supporter: You are welcome. Sometimes you will pay as little as 0-$20 a session. I've found this to be helpful in my life on multiple occasions.

seeker: Oh I didnt know that the therapy sessions are that inexpensive.I was in a opinion like they cost me 200 $for each session.
supporter: You have to find what is available. Avoid big buildings full of psychologists, usually the more independent practices are reasonable and provide better service IMO.

seeker: What kind of therapies are useful and beneficial to me in my situation.
supporter: Probably someone to talk to, so just a counselor or therapist fits the bill. I am not a doctor so don't take anything I say as medical advice btw.

seeker: Sure..That is very helpful..Can you suggest where to find some online forums to find survivors with my same condition.
supporter: I found a lot of chat boards and information from a google search. You are not alone and it is OK to feel and to be going through this.

seeker: I think you are provided me with valuable help and advice..I appreciate it..Thank you..I think I can exit the chat?what do you say?
supporter: Your are welcome and I wish you the best in life. You can exit if you wish.

seeker: sure.bye.
supporter: bye

seeker: Hello my name is Marie
supporter: Hi, Marie. You are dealing with depression. I'm sorry to hear that.

seeker: I have low energy most of the time except for when I'm working
supporter: What is it about work that gets you going?

seeker: My job is fast paced I work for a call center working from home
supporter: You spend a lot of your day talking and interacting with people. Do you enjoy the work?

seeker: I'm always taking one call after the other and barely got time to think about my problems I'm dealing with
supporter: The work distracts you from your problems but it does not give you time to address them.

supporter: I'm sure you do! Phone support requires a lot of patient explanation. That is challenging for many people.

supporter: I'm glad you have found success and fulfillment at your work.

seeker: Thank you
supporter: If your job is good for you, what do you think makes you feel depressed then?

supporter: Exercise? Reading? School? Friends?
