seeker: I am having too much anxiety and don't know how to deal with it.
supporter: I suggest that you talk to a counsellor.  There should be free services available at your university.

seeker: What kind of advise should I be seeking from the counsellor?
supporter: Well, perhaps they can at least alleviate your anxiety somewhat. Or maybe even get you a sick note to give you a little extra  time to complete your assignment.s

seeker:
Do you think that could hurt my grade if I turn them in
 late?
supporter: No, as long as you have a doctor's letter explaining why.

seeker: But I am not sick, would the counsellor write note for me under this situation?
supporter: There is more than one way to be sick. You sound as though you are suffering from depression and stress.

seeker: I guess you are right... I will try to make an appointment with the counselor next week.
supporter: Do you have any friends or family that you can discuss this with?

seeker: I have an elder sister I can talk to.
supporter: Is she sympathetic to what you are feelign?

seeker: I think so..
supporter: Well that is a good start. Maybe you could make a list of things you want to discuss with your counsellor too.

seeker: I like the idea .. thanks..
supporter: Try not to worry - I hope that things go well with you.

seeker: I hope so.. thank you for you suggestion.
supporter: All the best to you in your future and thank you for talking!

seeker: You have a good day...
supporter: and you :)

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi, how are you doing?

seeker: I am doing fine. How are you?
supporter: I'm doing alright. Is there anything bothering you?

seeker: Yes..  I recently broke up with my partner
supporter: Oh no, that must be hard.

seeker: I am extremely depressed after that..
supporter: That makes sense. How long were you guys together?

seeker: We have been together for last 2 years.
supporter: Oh wow, two years is a long time

seeker: Yes.. we had out ups and downs during the time..
supporter: It sounds like it might not have been the most healthy relationship while it was going on, but it can still really hurt when something like that ends.

seeker: I did not see this was coming.. happened all on a sudden..
supporter: Oh no, being taken by surprise like that can't be pleasant at all.

seeker: No it was not.. now I am in depression and don't know how to get out of it.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have friends you can talk to? Spending time with friends can be a good distraction, and give you people to rant to who know you best.

seeker: I cannot think of anyone I can share my feeling with...
supporter: It sounds like you're feeling pretty alone right now

seeker: Yes, I am..
supporter: You could take the opportunity to try and take up a new hobby. I know it sounds dumb, but finding something to put your energy into could really help

seeker: I am into playing musical instruments.. you think I should pick that up again?
supporter: That sounds like a great idea! That's an awesome skill and sounds like it would be fun to get back into.

seeker: I play flute.. I guess I will start it again.. thanks for the suggestion.
supporter: Yeah no problem!

seeker: I hope so.. I feel better talking to you.. thanks again..
supporter: It was great talking to you too :)

seeker: Have a good day..
supporter: You too!

seeker: Hi, how are you?
supporter: Hello there, how are you doing today?

seeker:
I'm ok. To be honest, 
I'm a therapist and I'm getting burned out on the job.
supporter: I hear you .. it can be very difficult dealing with other peoples' problems all day. Would you consider retraining for something else?

seeker: Maybe. I'm not really young anymore. The thought of going through more school...well, I dunno about that.
supporter: True. So you feel you're stuck in a rut - you're not happy but you don't feel unhappy enough to move on?

seeker: I just feel like I'm in limbo. Just there. People complain all day about their problem. I have a therapist, but I think my therapist is burnt out too.
supporter: It's a vicious cycle isn't it!? What about looking for another profession that does not involve much retraining?

seeker: I'm too young to retire but I don't know how many more years I can slog on with this career. It used to be pretty good. Now, it just seems the same gray job every day.
supporter: Are you in a financial position where you could take some time off, go travelling perhaps, and renew yourself?

seeker: I've thought about that. I'd love to travel. I feel an obligation to my patients. I don't want to abandon them. I could pass them to other therapists, maybe temporarily. I don't know how they would feel about that.
supporter: Well, I would hope that they would understand that even therapists have to have a private life. And I am sure they'd prefer you at the peak of your game and not burned out.

seeker: True. They might wonder how committed I am to them and to the profession if I go away for a while. I've thought about lightening my work load too.
supporter: Yes perhaps you could switch to part time? If you could afford it?

seeker: Money not really the issue. I just worry that I'll keep burning out, just more slowly. Other therapists go through this as well.
supporter: Somewhere at the top of the chain there must a very weary therapist with no-one to talk to. Though I suppose that is where these bots come in :D

seeker: Yeah. One day I'll be replaced by a computer. Then the computers will provide therapy to other computers, who'll need a vacation when they burn out.
supporter: lol. It's an interesting mental picture. I am glad you still have a sense of humour though

seeker: Try to. Humor is a defense mechanism and coping mechanism. I have hobbies. They seem less fun because my job is less fun.
supporter: I am sorry to hear that. On another note, have you considered speakign to your GP? Perhaps medication might help.

seeker: My therapist recommended medication too, but I worry that it might impair my ability to do my job.
supporter: I have tried medication and I found it surprisingly helpful but everyone is different of course. There was no impairment though.

seeker: Ok. That's good to know. I want to be responsible to my patients, but I also have a responsibility to myself.
supporter: Yes  you do! Thank you for talking and you take care of yourself!

seeker: Thanks for your advice and honesty. I feel better now.
supporter: I am glad to hear it :) Goodbye!

seeker: Hi, I feel really sad.
supporter: I am sorry.  What is going on?

seeker: My friends won't hang out with me. I am alone all the time.
supporter: So you feel like they don't want to be around you and have nobody to talk to?

seeker: Yes, but also just no one to hang out with. I am a loner.
supporter: You prefer it that way?

seeker: No. I want to hang out with people.
supporter: I follow you.  It is hard to see people outside of usual social circles right now with the pandemic going on.  Out of curiosity tell me what you like doing with others?

seeker: I like to talk with them, listen to their stories, just hang out have a good time.
supporter: I can understand that. I have not seem my own friends for almost a year because of COVID-19.  It felt isolated and lonely.

seeker: What do you do to feel better?
supporter: It has not been easy but I focused on myself.  I started doing more exercise and weight lifting.  I took up learning how to invest money, and I also got into the habit of reading. Basically I build myself up in body, wallet, and mind so I feel better about myself progressively.   It worked well for me at least.  What do you think might help you?

seeker: That all sounds great. I think I'll need to do more exercising. I do like reading so I'll do that too.
supporter: What would you say might be good exercise or reading goals for you?

seeker: I think just start doing them and continue doing them are good goals for me for now.
supporter: Whatever works for you. All the best and stay safe.

seeker: All the best to you too!
supporter: Bye

seeker: not so well
supporter: I'm fine.  I'm so sorry that you're not feeling well, but I'm here to help.  Could you tell me what's going on?

seeker: my love is broken up
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that.  Everyone goes through break ups like that at some point in their life.  I would suggest moving on and focusing on yourself for a bit.

seeker: but how could I, we are in a relationship for 4 years
supporter: I understand it's difficult when you were in a relationship for so long.  But it's not going to do you any good to cling on to the past.  What was her reason for leaving you?

seeker: she is engaged to a richman
supporter: That's even a better reason for you to just forget about her, with her cheating on you like that, you know she's not the type for you.  You're so much better than her.  So just focus on yourself.  If you need some help emotionally, find yourself a counselor to talk to.

seeker: I tried to forget her, but whenever i tried the memories are repeating again and again
supporter: Just try to focus on your hobbies, and hang out with your close friends.  Keep yourself occupied on other things so you wouldn't have to think about her.  Just think that you're lucky that it ended now, and it would've been worse if you found out about the cheating even later.

seeker: whenever i try to share my feelings with my friends, they are making fun on me
supporter: Awww maybe try to share you feelings with your family then

seeker: but its not easy to me tell it to my family members
supporter: I see.  Over time you'll definitely be able to get over it.  There are so many other women out there that are better than her.  She may have been the perfect woman for you at one point but you really should come to terms that she isn't the one for you anymore.

seeker: I will try to think like that
supporter: Yes just focus on positivity, doing fun things.

seeker: I will try my level best
supporter: Okay that's good.  I can tell that you're making too big of a deal of the situation.  You can think about the good times you've had with her, but that's in the past now so you should be focused on the future instead.

seeker: thankyou
supporter: I'm happy to provide you advice.  If you need advice in the future, you could always find a counselor for you.  I hope you are feeling a bit better.

seeker: Hi, I'm sad
supporter: I am ok.  Been a busy day.  More importantly your upset; what is going on?

seeker: Good for you. My friend died few years ago. And it's so difficult for me
supporter: You mentioned that she died a while back.  Has something stirred up the sadness recently?

seeker: because it's close to her death
supporter: Oh.  The anniversary.   You made it clear you were close to her. Tell me about her.  What was she like? What did she mean to you?

seeker: She was my good friend. Always take caring of me and I the same way. We lived close to each other so we always hang out
supporter: She gave you a lot of meaning and filled your time fondly.  I am taking it that after she passed you probably felt empty and lately it has been getting worse?

seeker: Yes, it's true. It had happened with me
supporter: I can understand that.  My best friend died a few years ago and he was like my brother.  Still does feel empty not having him around.

seeker: Yes, one day she was there with me and the next day she wasn't. It's so hard for anyone
supporter: I take it that the loss was sudden and it was a shock to your system.    So how have you been managing the sadness and grief since it happened?

seeker: I try going out with my family and friend. Avoiding things that we used to do together
supporter: It sounds like your family is being supportive of you and you have a network.  It seems to me that you really put a great deal of mental energy and fortitude into taking care of yourself. Is there anything else that could help you get thru this rough patch you can think of?

seeker:
I don't know. Do you hav
e any ideas?
supporter: I can think of a few.  Physical activity even walking really helps people who are feeling down.  But it does not work for everyone.  I also know there are grief support groups but I do not know if they are open with the pandemic and everything.  I also know that there are a lot of mental health services available for professional counselling if things are too much.  I also heard that having things to do to fill your schedule helps like work or small projects to fill the day up.  What do you think would work best for you?

seeker: Probably will be difficult to find one now. I'll try fill my schedule so I always have something to do.
supporter: What things to you like to do that would benefit you to fill your schedule?

seeker: Exercise, watching, a movie, play games,
supporter: So you have a toolbox of things you can do to stay busy to get you through this.  You seem to have solved this problem for yourself. That is a strength right there.

seeker: Yes, I think so
supporter: Anytime.  Stay safe and live well.  -KJ the nurse

seeker: not really well
supporter: What's wrong? How can I help you?

seeker: i lost my job last week
supporter: That’s a tough situation. I feel for you. Losing a job is hard, but now, with the pandemic, it's especially hard.

seeker: yes the worst situation i met in this year.
supporter: I hear you. This is tough! It is important to be around other people. Don't isolate yourself.

seeker: yes i have someone but they are not ready to talk with me
supporter: That's too bad. Is there another person, a family member? By the way, how long had you worked at the job?

seeker: I know it, but people aroud me are angry because i lost my job
supporter:
That's unfair of them. 
You don't need to discuss the problem. Just chatting with someone can change your mood.

seeker: i worked for six years and 4 monts
supporter: Six years...That's a long time. I bet you were good at your job.

seeker: yes i am, but the compay lay off me to reduce their expences
supporter: The economy really has gotten bad. Many people are in a similar situation. I worry too that I might lose my job.

seeker: dont think like that, it is very hard in that situation
supporter: Many people are angry with you. Have they tried to help you with the job search? Do you want to reach out to them for that?

seeker: try to stay in your job whatever may happen
supporter: I try to stay positive. I talk to people. I think about after the pandemic and how things will be.

seeker: I ask them to do so, but they don't give any informaton back
supporter: Hmm. That's not supportive. Is there an agency in your city that can help you get that kind of info?

seeker: yes, there is one i know
supporter: That's too bad. Normally I would send them an email, see if you can schedule an online chat.

seeker: yeah i would like to get any othe job
supporter: That might not be possible at the moment. Work is scarce. I've looked for extra online work, but so many people are trying to get the same work!

seeker: no i did not apllied it
supporter: That's the next thing for you to do. You might get cash coming in. It will help you stay optimistic.

seeker: i see, i will try to apply for it
supporter: Great! I hope that this chat has been helpful.

seeker: yes i think so
supporter: You're quite welcome! Best of luck with the job search!

seeker: thank you
supporter: I hope so too.

seeker: thank you
supporter: By the way, you need to press the submit button on your end.

seeker: oh sorry i forgot
supporter: No. The supporter cannot submit. The two buttons to the right of the text box should have an option for you.

seeker: hey too. Have got a mental problem need your support if you don`t mind
supporter: Of course, would be glad to support

seeker: Well, i was laid off from work during the Covid-19 period mid-last year (June) at a time when i was financially down. this was the start of my woes. Really need support since i have had rough time recollecting myself
supporter: I see, so sorry to hear that... How are you feeling due to that?

seeker: I feel so anxious since i am not able to  meet most of my family needs as i used to before covid
supporter: Ah I understand, is there any temporary financial support available for you and your family?

seeker: Currently i have no support apart from the meagre earnings of my wife
supporter: I completely understand, I would also feel anxious if I were in this situation. It's an honorable thing that you've taken the initiative and are working hard to support your family.

seeker: Sure. I really need your support on how to manage the anxiety because despite constant reassurance from my wife, i still feel i am letting down my family as a man
supporter: If it makes you feel any better, there are a bunch of workshops that offer support, what little it may be. I'm not sure what country you are in, but I've seen some small organizations that give away grocery vouchers for those in need. Perhaps you could narrow your search to find those as well, if you haven't already

seeker: Wow, that is awesome. You mean deep breaths do help?
supporter: Of course, breathing is the body's most calming function, you dont need a set amount of breaths, but take the time to be aware of the action and the stillness around you

seeker: I actually feel the support from my wife for which i am grateful but then my children are young to understand it all. I used to do a lot for them and constantly tell me to do the same but am unable cause it needs money
supporter: Spending time actively playing with your kids would help, along with morning exercise (but nothing too strenuous) if you choose to do so

seeker: Wow, am amazed! You mean anxiety can be managed so simply?
supporter: I hope you do, positive attitude is the start to a healthy mind. This may not work for everything and the anxiety won't just disappear on day one or maybe ever, but these are steps you would want to start with :)

seeker: sure. Let me adjust my attitude first and accept the situation. Hoping t cope with the situation in due course
supporter: exactly: "maintain a hopeful outlook and visualize what you want rather than what you fear" I really hope I was able to help even if it was a little bit

seeker: That wasn`t little. It was much and am gonna try it out.
supporter: I'm really glad :) and I hope it works out!

seeker: Sure. My hope too.
supporter: Bye, have a great day

seeker: Hi, how are you today?
supporter: hello

seeker: I'm not sure. I can't find a reason. My health is fine. I have friends. I have a place to live.
supporter: your health is fine and you have place to live but you are still sad

seeker: Yes, that's right. I feel like my life is not going in the right direction. In fact, I'm not going anywhere.
supporter: have you talked to anyone about it

seeker: No, not really. I don't know what to talk about. I just feel flat. Something's wrong. I don't know what.
supporter: i have felt that way before but i came over it

seeker: How did you do that? I really need some guidance here. What do I do?
supporter: it came to me like a mood swing for so many days but i started going to meet friends and get closer to my friends for positive vibes

seeker: You met with your friends? I've tried meeting with my friends. I feel ok when I'm with them, but then later, I feel sad again.
supporter: yes, you have to be positive at all time and always do something that makes you happy

seeker: I'm trying to be positive. It doesn't seem to work. I don't know how to change my mood without chemicals.
supporter: have you try yoga or meditating as a therapy

seeker: No, I haven't tried yoga. I thought it was for women. Therapy? You mean like a shrink?
supporter: yoga is not only for women, and yes therapy like a shrink but you don't have to talk to anybody if you do yoga or meditating

seeker: Oh, meditating by myself? I would need someone to help me learn. Is yoga expensive? I don't have much money.
supporter: yoga is not expensive and meditation doesn't have to be with anyone, you can use YouTube video as your tutor. It has work for soo many people including my self

seeker: Ok. I'll check out YouTube. Do I need special clothes or equipment? Or incense or candles or lotoins or something? I'm just a regular guy.
supporter: yes, you have to be in a bright environment. just on the light

seeker: Ok. I can do that. I bet there is something on YouTube about meditation. I'll give it a try. Thanks for your help!
supporter: i hope it work for you

seeker: Hello,  thank you for signing up to listen to me
supporter: What's on your mind?

seeker: I am upset about the loss of my best friend's son dying in a car accident
supporter: I'm really sorry to hear that. When did this happen?

seeker: The accident was Thursday February 25th but he held on until Sunday the 28th
supporter: There's nothing that can prepare you for unexpected tragedies like this. We just have to deal with them as they come.

seeker: I understand what you are saying but that's the problem.  How to deal with such a terrible unexpected loss
supporter: It sounds like you're sticking close to your friend, although it doesn't feel like its helping.

seeker: She is inconsolable..... and me also being upset is not helping matters either.  You are exactly right...it's impossible to help.
supporter: Of course. These things are tough to face on your own, so you did the right thing by reaching out.

seeker: I actually feel a little better.  I will just sit with her and keep her company and be there to listen.  I'm glad I accepted this survey today
supporter: You too, and best wishes.

seeker: Hi, how are you today?
supporter: I am okay. What is going on with you?

seeker: School's going badly. I really wish I had chosen a different major.
supporter: It sounds like it must be overwhelming to keep up with all of your school work.

seeker: I’m majoring in computer engineering. It’s really #%$& hard! Everyone else is way smarter than I am.
supporter: That does sound very difficult, but I think you can do it! Just getting into a program like that shows how smart you are!

seeker: It's kinda late to switch. I'm at the end of my third year. My parents keep bugging me about getting a job.
supporter: To be honest with you, I switched majors a lot in college. I eventually let go of what my family thought and pursued a career I would truly enjoy for myself.

seeker: I wish I were in your shoes! If I change majors now, I have to redo at least a year of school, maybe more. I don't think my parents want to pay for that.
supporter: Personally I took three years longer than it should to get my degree and accrued some debt because of it. Although I feel it is worth it now.

seeker: That's good to know. Maybe I can convince my parents to let me borrow some money. I don't want to be a computer engineer.
supporter: I'm hearing its difficult for you knowing that you are on a path that you don't really want to be on.

seeker: That's a good way to put it.
supporter: A lot of people I know benefited from talking to an advisor or counselor for some direction. Have you done that recently?

seeker: I talked to the school counselor. They laid out some options. It's really about money and time. If those weren't concerns, I would switch in a heartbeat.
supporter: What about meeting with the counselor with your parents, since it seems they would need to support you financially over any extra time it might take?

seeker: That's a good point. Maybe we could have a Zoom meeting, even for just 15 minutes. I need to get my parents to understand my feelings.
supporter: It's been shown that healthy communication can help people listen and respond more considerately when things seem difficult at first.

seeker: I hadn't thought of it that way. I'm so worried about schoolwork that I hadn't stepped back from the whole situation of school itself.
supporter: I definitely can understand that, but it is important to think about your future happiness and security too!

seeker: not bad and you
supporter: It has been a most interesting week across the board.   Been some challenges and hurdles but that makes life the better.  Tell me any challenges you are facing right now?

seeker: the loss of the of my job has been really difficult, possibilities of losing my home and family is really dire
supporter: So it sounds like you lost your livelihood and your concerned of losing everything you have built.   It seems like you are lost on what to do now.

seeker: exactly, my confidence is gone so is my self worth and self esteem.
supporter: Wow.  So this was a real punch to the gut for you.  Out of curiosity; what work were you doing and how long were you doing it?

seeker: I used to work in IT and did it for 14 years
supporter: 14 years?  Wow.  That is really impressive.  It is a very difficult field and it take serious talent to work in IT.  Takes real talent and brainpower to work in IT.

seeker: been doing it long enough for it to be 2nd nature
supporter: So I also take it that not doing it now must feel like you lost part of yourself as well besides the financial risk.  Double whammy.

seeker: yes it does
supporter: This is a large cross to bear. So what do you think your next steps are going to be?

seeker: I have no idea
supporter: May I throw some ideas out at you?

seeker: please
supporter: It sounds like your really down right now about your job, family, and your home.  It sounds like from what you have mentioned finding work would likely be the best goal to work on right now.  What are your thoughts?

seeker: seems a fair suggestion so getting straight back in the game.
supporter: IT right now is highly marketable line of work.  Given the need for networking and teleconferencing right now you are in demand.  And 14 years experience you probably have a competitive advantage in the job market. What do you think your odds of finding a new job are from 0% to 100% right now?  I'd bet pretty high.  What do you think?

seeker: Hi can you help me with my problem?
supporter: Hello. What's on your mind?

seeker: I'm disgusted with my friend for cheating on her boyfriend. Am I right to feel this way?
supporter: Your feelings are valid, no matter what they are.

seeker: Because she's not acting the way she should be acting.
supporter: It sounds like she did something you find really immoral.

seeker: Yeah, but I'm also thinking it's not my business. I should just stay out of it.
supporter: Have you talked to your friend about what she did?

seeker: Yeah, she doesn't really care because she's not going to tell him. I'm questioning whether I should still be friends with her.
supporter: You're definite right to be questioning if this is the sort of person you want to be friends with.

seeker: It's hard to stop thought because we work at the same place.
supporter: If her behavior is getting to you like this, I definitely suggest you try to keep some distance from her as much as you can.

seeker: Yeah, I've been trying to, but she's always talking to me
supporter: It might be a good idea to explain why you're upset with her, even though that's likely to upset her.

seeker: I guess, but I'd rather just avoid her.
supporter: I can definitely understand wanting to avoid a confrontation.

seeker: Yeah, I realize she's quite selfish so confronting her wouldn't help.
supporter: What do you think you can do to minimize your contact with her?

seeker: Just not respond to her messages and avoid the areas she's in
supporter: That sounds like a good plan.

seeker: Is that ghosting?
supporter: What one person calls ghosting, someone else can call looking out for yourself.

seeker: Not doing so well today, I'm having a really hard time at work. I'm feeling super stressed about the workload I have, I just can't keep up with it all!
supporter: I’m sorry to hear that. Work can be a bad source of stress. Do you have anyone that can help with the workload?

seeker: Not really, there's only me in my role so don't really have anyone to help. I have tried talking to my line manager but she doesn't seem to understand just how busy I am.
supporter: Can the company hire any more people? Maybe they can work from home, and take some work off your plate. The line manager might also need some help with her workload.

seeker: From what I hear they aren't willing to hire anyone else, but I don't know the reasons why. I can only speak to my line manager and then she speaks to higher management.
supporter: Your manager sounds unsympathetic. That's very frustrating. A lot of people are in your situation in this pandemic: too much work, not enough help.

seeker: I have been keeping an eye out for other jobs, but like you say things are difficult just now with the pandemic, there isn't a lot out there!
supporter: Very true. Have you talked to your co-workers about this issue? What do they think?

seeker: They are all feeling stretched as well so they understand. I am trying to not talk about it too much with them, I don't want to be seen as the person who's always complaining!
supporter: Yeah, that's a good point. A little complaining is ok, but a lot can get on people's nerves.

seeker: Yeah, I don't want them all to stop talking to me cause they find me annoying! I'm trying to stay positive, but it's hard some days! As much as I try to start the day in a positive frame of mind it quickly gets sucked out of me!
supporter: What do you do outside of work? Hobbies and such.

seeker: At the moment I'm not getting outside as much as I should, I do enjoy gaming but it's hard to find time. I've been working 14 hour days all week! My boyfriend tries to tell me to switch off but it's hard when I know there's all this work waiting to be done.
supporter: You could try setting aside an evening or two a week for time with your BF. Just walk out of the office. Try to set some boundaries.

seeker: Yeah, he says the same kind of thing, that I need to be firmer and just leave when I'm due to. I guess the only way for them to truely see is for the work to just not get done as there's no time!
supporter: From what you're saying, it sounds like you think you have no power. Is that true? Are you really powerless in this situation? Do not underestimate your power over your life.

seeker: I guess I do feel powerless, I feel like they never really listen to what I'm saying, they just act as if they are but then ignore me.
supporter: It sounds like the managers are training you to be resigned to your fate. If they listen to you, it encourages you to complain. If they ignore you, you go away and leave them alone. However, if you leave work early (after 9 hours, say), then they might notice you. Are you willing to take a risk?

seeker: Maybe if I start acting more confidently they will start to listen.
supporter: That's the spirit! Taking control of your own schedule is one display of confidence.

seeker: Hello, I am feeling very sad because I tested positive for Covid this week. I am in quarantine away from my family.
supporter: sorry to hear about that. So your test results were positive. Did I get it right?

seeker:
Yes, I tested positive for the Covid
 virus on Wednesday.
supporter: It must be hard to stay alone. Are you having fever or any other sever symptoms. Hope there is someone to take care of you for a while at least.

seeker: I'm by myself in my house. My wife took the kids to stay with her father until my quarantine period is over. I have mainly cold symptoms - body aches, stuffy head, sore throat.  Nothing too serious so far.
supporter: I had COVID last month with mild symptoms. Good to know that you don't have any sever symptoms. You will recover fast.

seeker: I hope so. I'm on the older side (not senior citizen yet) with high blood pressure, so I'm a little nervous about how it will affect me.
supporter: I can understand staying alone will be devastating.  Keep monitoring your oxygen level. If  that is normal, you don't have to worry. You can read watch tv or can do video calling to your family.

seeker: Thanks for the advice.  We're doing a lot of video calls so I can see everyone.  That helps.
supporter: I wish for your fast recovery. Hope this COVID situation end soon somehow.

seeker: That's what is so frustrating - I feel like a couple more months or so and I'd have the vaccine.  Made it a year, then get infected during the stretch run of this pandemic.
supporter: Very true! It is kind of never ending. There should be some permanent solution for it.

seeker: I don't know if that will ever happen, but if it becomes rare and much less deadly like colds and flu, we should be able to return to a pre-covid life or close to it.
supporter: We can still hope for the best right now. Let's stay positive and fight it.

seeker: I was fighting it, but Covid won this week!
supporter: Think other way. You defeat it and you won.

seeker: I hope so.  I'm only in like the third inning or so right now though.
supporter: You are a strong person. You are almost there to win. Your family is always there with you.

seeker: Thanks for the encouragement.  10 days cannot come fast enough.
supporter: I know but i week has gone so rest will go too. Wishing you fast recovery and take care of yourself.

seeker: Thanks, good luck to you. Nice chatting with you.
supporter: Thank you! It was nice talking to you too.

seeker:
I'm doing fine. 	My proble
m is that my boss keeps hitting on a co-worker, who really doesn't like the guy. What can I do to make it stop?
supporter: Boy, that's a tough one. You've got to handle a problem like that pretty diplomatically. Have you talked to your co-worker, the one the boss hits on?

seeker: I've tried to bring it up with her indirectly, but it's an uncomfortable issue, you know? She is really upset, and I don't know whether it's my place to handle this kind of thing. It's more of an HR issue, but should I go to HR? Will that help, or just get me in trouble? I don't know.
supporter: That's a good question, and I don't know the answer. It depends on your HR department. Have you suggested that the co-worker talk to HR? Is there an anonymous system for filing complaints?

seeker: No, the company hasn't set up a system for passing along info that way. I don't know if she has talked to HR. She might not have because she's worried that it'll get back to her boss, and she'll get punished. I'd like to be supportive, even if I can't help solve the problem.
supporter: That's a good attitude. You want to be supportive and helpful. You sound like a good co-worker. Remember that the problem did not start with you, so you do not need to feel responsible for it.

seeker: Thanks for your words of encouragement? Maybe there is little I can do, but I don't want to let the problem fester. She's a great co-worker and a great worker. We need her on the team. What do you think a good first step would be?
supporter: That's a good question. I would show support for her and empathize with her and her situation. Do you have lunch with her? Can you send her a text letting her know she's valued? She might appreciate that.

seeker: Sometimes we have lunch, but usually she just eats at her desk. I could easily send her texts of encouragement.
supporter: Ok. That's a good first step. I think you have a way forward with this. Maybe after a few texts, you can sit down and talk about solutions in detail, like going to HR.

seeker: Ok. I'll try sending a couple of texts every day. Then I'll see if she wants to have lunch outside with me when the weather gets better.
supporter: That's a good positive step. I think that you've got a pretty handle on the situation. Good for you!

seeker: Thanks. The boss is pretty good at his job. He know how to manage projects and he's good with clients. There is just this one thing that he gets wrong and somebody needs to get him to stop.
supporter: I understand that you're frustrated and sad. I would feel the same way too. I think that anyone else in your situation would feel the same way.

seeker: Thanks. I guess I just have to accept things as they are. I can't afford to leave this job, and it's impossible to find another job at this time. Plus I don't want to abandon my co-worker in her time of need.
supporter: Well, you have to do what is right for yourself. If you find a better job, think seriously about taking it. Your co-worker will not be there forever. You have a responsibility to yourself.

seeker: True. I hadn't thought of it that way. I should consider my needs. Thanks!
supporter: You're welcome! I'm glad that I was able to help you!

seeker: I feel a lot better now. I start sending text messages to my co-worker on Monday. Thanks! Have a good day!
supporter: You too! Have a great day, and good luck with work!

seeker: I am having a really hard time with something that I did to my boyfriend.
supporter: Do you want to talk about it?

seeker: Yes, thank you! I was with him since childhood and we are actually still together. I slipped up one night and hate to admit what I did.
supporter: It sounds like you're holding onto a lot of guilt about this incident.

seeker: Yes, it is intense guilt. I can't think of anything else. I hate to tell you but I cheated on him. I am so sorry and can't look at myself in the mirror.
supporter: That can really weigh you down, beating yourself up with guilt.

seeker: I feel like I am worthless and I don't deserve to ever be happy or laugh again. I really do love him and I don't ever want him to find out what I did. Yes, I cant stop beating myself up. He doesn't know what I did but he is little suspicious.
supporter: You definitely deserve to laugh and be happy. One mistake doesn't define you!

seeker: Thank you! A long time ago his sister told me that he cheated on me and I believed her and so I wanted to get him back.
supporter: It says a lot about your character that you feel badly about this, that you can see and recognize you acted in a way you don't agree with. That's something to build on.

seeker: I appreciate that and have been thinking about character a lot lately. I do believe he cheated on me first, if that even matters now.
supporter: Do you feel like you got what you needed from the experience, as in, that you've "gotten even"?

seeker: Yes, I feel very even! I won't do it again. Can I ever give up the guilt that I feel and move on in our relationship or do I have to tell him what I did? I have known couples who don't tell each other and they are happy now.
supporter: While it may be true in general that honesty is the best policy, in this case I wouldn't suggest telling him. It is just going to cause angry feelings.

seeker: Thank you for making me feel heard. I have been alone in my thoughts and needed to be understood. Yes, I agree with you and I feel like I kind of let it go now that I told you about it.
supporter: I'm glad you're feeling better now that you've gotten it out in the open. Of course, you are welcome anytime.

seeker: That sounds great because I want to keep this private and I know you won't tell anyone so I feel really safe here.
supporter: Absolutely. This is all in complete confidence.

seeker: my recent ex gf gave her daughters drugs while on a video chat with me. While being very dishonest in our relationship, i am devestated about the truth of all of it now that its over. I really loved her. and her kids. we had some great times. I turned her in for giving her kids drugs as thats not okay.
supporter: You are girlfriend is giving drugs to hew own kids. Did I get it right?

seeker: That is what she did. Among many other things.
supporter: That is really intense, unacceptable. I am feeling sorry for the poor little girl and you.  It looks like there is something wrong with her. I can understand what you are going through.

seeker: Its a difficult time. I want to do nothing. It feels very bleek right now worrying about finances and getting set up in a new state.
supporter: It must be hard time for you. You should not worry about her. You should think about your job and the poor girl who is trapped with her.

seeker: her daughters now both live with their dads. so thats taken care of, he kids are safer and better off. I however am devastated that the whole relationship wound up a lie and the whole thing has me really in a bad place mentally.
supporter: I felt the same way when I broke up with my friend for some pathetic things which she did. The good part is girls are safe now. Give some time to yourself. Time will heal everything.

seeker: Thats a hard light to see at the end of the tunnel when things are bleek.
supporter: So sorry to hear about that. You should indulge yourself in some activities like yoga or meditation.

seeker: Finding a better job.
supporter: You will get one soon. Keep working on. My best wishes are there with you. Time never stay the same.

seeker: you dont want to continue to talk
supporter: No, that is not the case. You can talk as much as you want.

seeker: I see. i thought you had left.
supporter: No I am hear and thinking of you and trying to figure out how can you come out of it.

seeker: Hi, how are you?
supporter: Hi there! I'm great, what about you? How can I help today?

seeker: My girlfriend dumped me for someone else! I've been really shook up.
supporter: I'm so sorry to hear that :( Do you have any idea why?

seeker:
I think she just lost interest in me? 
It happened a couple of months ago. I wish I could get over it. I can't get her off my mind. She's dating this total loser.
supporter: That's tough... so you're saying that you grew apart a little? Or do you think it was more one-sided?

seeker:
It probably was more me than her. 
Maybe I should have done more to show her that I cared for her. Am I not romantic enough? Some guys just aren't that way.
supporter: I completely understand, and I don't think you should beat yourself up over it!

seeker: That's a fair point. I shouldn't be too hard on myself.  I didn't really grow up in a romantic family. I don't know how to do that stuff, but maybe I could learn.
supporter: Exactly, and remember everyone is different, perhaps you just weren't her right one, and that can go both ways.

seeker: That's true. I really got hung up on her. I thought she was perfect and that we were perfect together. She didn't see it that way. I can't really change who I am, and she couldn't change who she is.
supporter: That's a great line of thought, its good that you're able to identify that yourself

seeker: What do you think I could do to improve myself?
supporter: I suggest that you stay exactly the way that you are. I feel like you'd be happier that way and also more likely to find someone who shares the same values as you

seeker: Will the same problems show up in the next relationship though? It could be a long search before I find someone that matches with me?
supporter: I guess that depends on you, would you rather compromise for a relationship or find one who'll really last and not have to change?

seeker: I think all relationships require compromise and change. No two people are perfectly compatible.
supporter: That's true, building on that, you could also say that what your ex found to be the problem is not the be-all end-all. What your ex disliked could be what 10000 other girls love in a guy

seeker: That's true. I might end up trying to solve a problem that really isn't there. It's not a bug, it's a feature! :-)
supporter: Wow, you put that really nicely!

seeker: Thanks! You’ve been really helpful today. I can’t thank you enough for your encouragement and insight.
supporter: It was no problem! Thank you for sharing and talking it out!

seeker: I feel a lot better now. Have a great day! Bye!
supporter: Have a great day :) bye!

seeker: I am very sad and depressed because of a recent breakup. How can I ever forget it and move on.
supporter: Oh no. I'm sorry to hear that. What happened?

seeker: I thought everything was great and I already had my wedding dress and we planned a wedding and out of nowhere he dumped me. Now his family won't talk to me either.
supporter: that must be horrible. You were already engaged?

seeker: Yes, we were only engaged for about a month but we have been friends since childhood.
supporter: that sounds really hard. that's a long time to know someone.

seeker: Yeah, it was basically my whole life. We broke up two nights ago and he already changed his number and blocked my on social media.
supporter: that's going to be tough for the next little bit, those sound like some pretty fresh wounds. Have you been able to talk to friends?

seeker: I would like to talk to talk to friends but they happen to be his sisters. So, I am cut off from all of my support. Thank You for talking to me.
supporter: I had a break up last year and while it was painful for a bit, i used it as an opportunity to focus on myself and the things I needed. It ended up being a really good self reflective opportunity. Maybe join a gym or a group of some kind to change your network a bit?

seeker: I have been wanting to join the gym. Is it hard going alone or do you go with friends? I hate doing things all alone.
supporter: I like going to the gym alone but that's just my personal preference. There are fitness groups like bootcamps that you could join and meet new people. Who knows, you may meet a new friend.

seeker: That is a good idea. I need to be around other people who have goals like weight loss. My boyfriend never wanted me to join groups and only wanted me to be friends with his family. That is why I am so alone right now. I made bad choices.
supporter: That sounds hard. You deserve to have friends of your own.

seeker: I agree with you. Do you think that I should try calling his friends and asking for his new number?
supporter: there are lots of different kinds of groups you can join, not just fitness. and you can choose how much you want to actively engage with them. I would suggest taking time for yourself. Maybe give yourself some distance from him. If you both decide to reach out again in the future that may be an opportunity, but definitely take care of you.

seeker: Yeah, I can see your point of view. I have been obsessed with our relationship. We had a fight and it was a verbal war between us and he wouldn't forgive me afterwards.
supporter: sometimes you just need some distance. I hate that old saying but as it goes "there are plenty of fish in the sea".

seeker: It is true and I am a really nice person and have turned down other guys for him. I am going to stop thinking about him and just join the gym today. You have opened my eyes!
supporter: Good luck! you got this. Have fun with it, it sounds like you have other guys who are after you ;)

seeker: It's a pretty day, but I'm sad.  How are you?
supporter: I'm doing well, thank you for asking! Do you mind me asking what's going on that's making you feel sad?

seeker: I don't like being blamed for something when I don't feel I did anything wrong.  A neighbor's dog attacked my dog and another dog within a week and I reported it to our apartment manager and animal control.  She was given the choice to get rid of her dog or move and she decided to move.  But my neighbors are mad at me, because they think I overreacted.  I guess they liked her more.
supporter: It sounds like you feel as though you are being personally attacked/mistreated for something that you feel you handled correctly. Does that summarize what you're feeling?

seeker: Absolutely!  You nailed it!
supporter: I feel as though you absolutely did the right thing! If I were in your shoes, I would have done the exact same thing.

seeker: Thank you!  That makes me feel better!  But, I don't know how to make my neighbors feel that way and I hate being the outcast.
supporter: I have neighbors who act in similar ways. They act as though they run the entire street, but they rent just like everyone else does here. Dealing with them can be very difficult at times.

seeker: Sounds like we live in the same neighborhood!  Ha!
supporter: Just based on what you're saying, I can completely understand why you feel the way that you do. In my opinion, you have every right to feel that way.

seeker: Yep!  That's how I feel.  What should I do to get back in good graces with them?
supporter: I do know people who have gone through the exact same thing in the past. When another animal attacks one of your fur-babies, it's absolutely terrible. However, the fact that this woman was given the option to either get rid of her dog or move tells me that you are 100% correct in the way that you handled this situation. It's unfortunate for the woman, yes, but she should have had more control over her dog. It's bad enough when one animal is attacked, but when it's more than one, that's when you really know that it's a problem. Again, legally, she had to make a choice, and that's because she failed to properly secure her dog. I really don't feel as though you did anything wrong.

seeker: I totally agree with you!  The woman is disabled and I think most of the neighbors feel sorry for her.  I've seen her loose control of the dog before, but she never attacked another dog(s).  I've even seem the dog pull her scooter over and the woman needed lots of help to get back into it.  I think everyone feels sorry for her.
supporter: That probably has a lot to do with it. I would feel sorry for her too, as it is very sad in general. However, it doesn't excuse the fact that her animal attacked two other dogs.

seeker: I've talked to the neighbors face-to-face and they just think that I overreacted.  The woman started getting her dog and private training and so they feel that she was trying.  My point was that my dog weighs 15 pounds and her dog weighs 45 pounds and, if it happens again, I may not have a dog anymore.  I don't want to wait until a dog is killed or badly injured.  I told them exactly what you just said, but they are being mean!
supporter: That is absolutely terrible. In that case, I would just tell them that you refuse to allow another dog to possible injure or kill your own dog, so you did what was necessary to protect your fur-baby. Had you not done anything, this could have happened again, and the outcome may have been much worse. At that point, if they still don't respond kindly, I'd tell them that you still feel as though you did what needed to be done, that you understand why they are upset, but that you will always do whatever it takes to protect your dog. Hopefully, they will stop being mean. Even if they just stop talking to you completely, it's better than them harassing you or something along those lines. If they do start escalating their nasty behavior, I'd let the manager of your complex know that you're being mistreated. I always try to keep things calm and quiet, but I refuse to be taken advantage of or treated poorly.

seeker: Thank you so much!  Those are really good suggestions.  I'll do that and, hopefully, they will calm down.  If not, I have other friends that live outside my neighborhood.  And I can talk to the manager like you said.
supporter: I'm so glad that I was able to offer helpful suggestions! Hang in there. You sound like a strong person! I would definitely spend some time with your true friends who live outside of your neighborhood. I can assure you that if someone else's animal attacked one of mine, I would have done the exact same thing that you did.

seeker: THANK YOU!  Take care!
supporter: You're very welcome! You do the same. Have a wonderful day. Try to do things that make you smile! :)

seeker: Hello
supporter: Hi, how are you doing?

seeker: I am not doing well. I am feeling very depressed due to work load and current household situation
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Would you like to talk about it?

seeker: Yes, due to COVID life is messed up. Work load has increase and more responsibility of household.
supporter: COVID has really changed a lot of stuff. I understand your frustration. Has your work increased because of COVID conditions. Meaning you have to take extra work, or doing tasks that you dislike to do?

seeker: Due to the furlough Company has increased my my work load three times. I am not able to take rest. Getting depressed everday.
supporter: That sounds really bad. I once worked in a company that placed unnecessary pressure on me, with a low pay. I can relate to how you feel. Do you have to depend on this company for work?

seeker: They are paying me well but It is hard to take the load beside I have family and kids responsibility. I don't have time for them.
supporter: I understand. But I want you to think about this. Your mental health is more important right now because it is affecting you. And how you feel really affects those around you, especially the ones who love you. If you take some time to think about what is more important to you in life right now can help you make a decision.

seeker: I can understand that. But my job is really important right now as my partner lost his in COVID. and he is not doing anything right now not even helping at home. It makes me more low and it is hard to take care of 3  younger kids who are staying at home full time.
supporter: Ok, I understand better now. Thank you for explaining. What you are telling should to be something you need to discuss with your partner. Do both of you communicate well with each other? Maybe he is not aware of your situation or how you feel.

seeker: Nowadays he is so frustrated doesn't like to talk even. Whenever I bring household responsibilities or kids topic, he gets frustrated.
supporter: Oh no. I can see from his part he feels upset and frustrated because he may feel useless at the moment. But that's not an excuse to neglect responsibilities. You can maybe make him feel more useful around the house by starting to assign him small tasks. Encouraging him to do stuff and rewarding him with words of encouragement. I know it sounds kind of frustrating to do that, but maybe this small step on your half could also help him.

seeker: Nobody lives near by. Kids are to young to understand. I felt bit good after talking to you. Thanks
supporter: I'm sorry if this did not help the situation. But I'm always glad to listen if you want to talk more.

seeker: Talking to you made me feel good. Thanks for listening to me. I am feeling light now. You are agreat help. Thank you so much
supporter: No problem. I really wish you the best and I hope everything works out!

seeker: Hi !
supporter:
Hi can I help you today?  I 
am here to listen.

seeker: I am laid off.
supporter: Oh I am really sorry to hear that, DId you have the same job for a long time? That sounds very difficult to deal with.

seeker: I was attending a customer . He was having a grievance  which I sorted out. But the management did not like that.
supporter: Thank you for sharing and reaching out for support today. It takes a lot of courage and I commend you for taking the steps to reach out.

seeker:
I was okay with the previous manager. But recently a new young chap joined the duty. He was not experienced 
.He only is the reason for so.
supporter: That is really unfair and hard to deal with are you close to any famliy?

seeker: I am not in any close to any family related to job.
supporter: Do you have any close friends to talk to about any new job prospects?

seeker: I have few friends, I have been talking to them. They also tell I was not any wrong . For the experience and qualification, I will be getting a better job.
supporter: That is a positive outlook and is good to hear that you know you have skills to offer. Would you consider joining a new group at a church or something like that?

seeker: I am so worried of the management taken action on me relying a new unexperienced manager.
supporter: I am sorry that you're feeling stress. Have you ever used writing as a tool to relax?

seeker: My colleagues are also in contact with me. They are also having similar inconvenience as to how to perform?
supporter: Oh, wow then you do have a lot of contacts and some support or at least understanding. Music is a great way to relax and that id very positive in your life and current situation.

seeker: I am so confident I will be having a better job within the next few months.
supporter: That is a great outlook. Thank you for sharing today.

seeker: Meantime I try to learn new things to improve myself personally and professionally.
supporter: Thank you for reaching out today amd letting me listen.

seeker: Do you have any suggestion for me? I always believe the third angle.
supporter: I would suggest getting a pet if you are up for it. They can be support animals.

seeker: That is a good idea. But I dont like being close to any animal and letting them inside the house.
supporter: I can understand that feeling. I think maybe fish would be a distraction you may like to.

seeker: I think motivation, self-development, getting more qualified is of my attention nowadays.
supporter: I understand and believe you have a great focus on a career. I am proud of you and your focus ability.

seeker: Fish tank is a better option. I forgot that. That is why I am more believing in the third angle. Thank you.
supporter: You're welcome I can be available to listen or bounce ideas of off as much as you need.

seeker: Talking to you I feel more relaxed and confident of me.
supporter: That is the goal and what we strive for. You are welcome.

seeker: Okay. Thank you. Can I take a leave. Thank you for your valuable suggestions. BYE ! !
supporter: Bye, have a wonderful day.

seeker: I am feeling very sad lately. I can't seem to shake it.
supporter: I'm sorry to hear that. Would you like to talk about what is making you sad?

seeker: I was in a long term relationship and he broke up with me. I should have broken up with him for cheating my me but I was in love and think that I still am.
supporter: That sounds terrible. But I understand the feeling. I was in the same situation once. It is hard to move passed that. So your pain is very understandable.

seeker: You then you know it feels like the world is collapsing around me.
supporter: I agree. It's like there is no more hope. But do you know something?

seeker: Thank you, I know that sounds right. I had my whole life planned out and it was going to end in a long term marriage and now its all gone.
supporter: This way sound weird, but I tell myself if something is not meant to happen, it would not. If you want to look at a more positive side of this, you can say this was a good thing that happened.

seeker: I have always wanted a cat or a dog but my boyfriend said I wouldn't be good at raising anything. I can try to change my thinking but its really difficult.
supporter: I know you don't want to hear all these positive words right now. But It will get better. Trust me.

seeker: I appreciate the support and need to hear positive words. Do you think I need to take a vacation or something?
supporter: It is hard to get passed someone's words, especially after spending so much time with them. How about start with a fish. I have a betta and he is really easy to take care of. But I have the responsibility of attending to his needs. If you can take care of a fish, you surely can take care of a cat or dog!

seeker: I really love that idea and I love fish! I have always wanted an aquarium. I am thankful for your thoughtfulness and not just telling me what I want to hear.
supporter: I agree. Are you a social person by any chance? By saying that I mean you can still go do those activities, but you can maybe meet people there and ask if you can join their group. That's great in a way because you meet new people and there are no attachments after you leave. It's like a fun, crazy experience :)

seeker: Thank you for the support that is a good idea because I do like going bowling and I heard about a open social bowling night.
supporter: Oh that's awesome! But just remember don't try to distract yourself from the problem. Try to make peace with it. Because if you don't, you cannot move forward.

seeker: I am doing alright.
supporter: I am good, thanks. Is there an issue I can provide you some support with?

seeker: Yeah I am pretty anxious all the time. I feel that I made a mistake coming back to school to get a PhD.
supporter: So, to reiterate, you are suffering from anxiety due to school? Or is your anxiousness also caused by other life factors as well?

seeker: School is the start of the problem. I know that if I quit I can still be successful elsewhere but I also feel if I quit I will let my wife and kids down who were willing to leave family and friends to follow me to the school I wanted to go to.
supporter: I understand what you are going through. It is as if you are being pulled in two directions, but are not sure which is the best option at the given moment. I think it is great that you wanted to go back to school, but if your heart is not in it, then it may not be what you should continue pursuing.

seeker: I know I want this though. I enjoy what I do and what I would do for my career if I graduate. I mainly feel inadequate. I feel that I am not good enough. I am willing to do whatever it takes but fear that whatever my "best" is may not be good enough.
supporter: I can feel your worries when you speak about your anxiety, and I am hoping we can find a way to approach your feelings. Do you think there was a specific instance that is causing doubts within yourself or is it in your nature to self-doubt?

seeker: It is in my nature to self doubt. Additionally, I have had a few bumps in the road during my program and struggle to pick myself up after those bumps. For example, I am on academic probation and have a certain expectation over the next few months that I have to hit to stay in the program due to struggles in previous classes. I am reaching the bar just fine, according to those that I work with, and often feel I am doing quite well but occasionally I start to panic and think that I am not doing as well as I think that I am and start to spiral
supporter: This has also been a past struggle of mine, and I think it partially stems from the bar we set so high for ourselves. We obviously cannot reach the top right away, but have to work our way up. Often times, when facing an obstacle, such as a bad grade, we might retreat further down the path due to fear that it will keep happening. I know that I personally had a tendency to think of my family and friends who I feel are dependent on me or comparing myself with others when the only person we should think of in these instances is ourself. When making progress, tiny steps upward matter more than you think. But when we take a step backward, we cannot fall back down to the starting point by letting our doubts pile upon one another.

seeker: That is a really good point and helpful. Thank you!
supporter: Of course, I am happy to help! I have noticed that letting yourself celebrate a good grade can be really helpful to feel that you are enough and making good progress. But when things do go south, because life certainly happens, we must stay in the present and live life like we usually would, with a drive that we are going to push harder against whatever we have to face next.

seeker: That is exactly right. I need to focus more on what progress has been made and not on what progress hasn't been made yet because there is still time to make that progress.
supporter: Exactly! I also suggest if you are having doubts, talk it out with someone like your partner or a close friend. They can often provide a pick me up you didn't even know you needed. More than anything, give yourself credit and relax. Take some time to just breathe and release the tension. I guarantee it will leave you feeling refreshed and fulfilled for the next tasks you have to face. I believe you can do this and I feel that you believe it too, which is amazing. As often as it is said, believing in yourself is truly the best foundation to achieve your goals.

seeker:
Thanks for the advice and believing in me. This has been challenging and your words of encouragement give me hope for the future
.
supporter: You're welcome. It was great talking to you. Your future is bright, and I wish you all of the luck for the endeavors to get you there.

seeker: Thanks! Same to you!
supporter: Enjoy the rest of your day!

supporter: Hello!

supporter: I can relate because I also have a close friend that seeks constant reaffirmations.

supporter: Sometimes it is very difficult to see yourself through someone elses eyes when you undervalue yourself.

supporter: Possibly explaining it in a way she can relate to would be helpful.

supporter: I can feel your frustration just by our conversation, and I too wish that she could see that you value both her and your friendship enough to reach out to someone that can just listen. Don't forget that your feelings are valid as well.

seeker: I know they are. And yes, she's dealing with a lot, but we all are, and it would be so much better for her if she could trust the people who love her to actually love her.
supporter: Sometimes you have to take a step back and fill your own cup.

supporter: Family is a great support, then you will definitely grow and you don't have to take any stress because you have everything there with you.

supporter: Yes, I have kids. To look them up I need to stay motivated and positive because I am the reflection to them.

supporter: always make sure you get enough rest and when ever you are getting the feeling next time, distract your self with something you love and then continue after a while

good 
is there any other thing i can help you with?

supporter: Hello how are you?  I am here to support you.

supporter: How can I help support you today?

seeker: I've heard the pandemic has affected a lot of people. I'm always alone anyway...or with my roommate,so I haven't noticed much of a difference.
supporter: Have you tried different games that help you get to know each other?  Maybe try a movie or series.  I loved Sweet Magnolia's on Netflix.

supporter: Oh my goodness.  The good thing is there is a moratorium on evictions so she would not be able to do that legally.  CNN can be overwhelming.  Try giving her some type of distraction.  Suggest yoga or some type of bonding.

seeker: I actually do yoga every evening. She hates it. I'm living in her home without a lease, so I wonder if she can just tell me to leave.
supporter: As long as you have property there she would have to formally evict you.  That is the good news.

seeker: That is good news. Thanks for letting me know that.
supporter: I think it is best to stick with a short local news report.

supporter: Check Youtube videos on using Panda's.  It will help you make more money.  I have done over 750,000 hits.

seeker: Oh wow, that's amazing! I've done this particular hit 3 times...I've only found a person once though. I will definitely check out the videos. thank you!
supporter: You are welcome.  Panda's help you keep grabbing hits.  You can store 25 at a time.

seeker: Oh, I see. Great! Thanks so much for chatting with me and for the advice.
supporter: Have a great night and take care of yourself.  It has been a pleasure.

seeker: Hi
supporter: Hello! How are you doing today?

seeker: I'm doing better now that I have someone to chat with!
supporter: I understand, you feel like your losing everyone close to you and wondering about your own mortality now as well?

seeker: Exactly, I worry about losing my aunts because they are in their 70s and 80s. I worry about my own mortality as well.
supporter: Have you told your aunts how much you love them? It may comfort you to know that you've shared exactly how you feel with them while they are here.

seeker: I tell them every time I talk to them and try to spend as much time with them as I can.
supporter: I try to let everyone know I love them too just because we never know when we aren't going to be here anymore. I definitely understand where you are coming from.

seeker: I agree! We never know
supporter: I personally have found some comfort in hearing other people struggle with their own mortality or their beliefs in an after life or different things. Maybe that could be something you could try looking into.

seeker: I will definitely try that. It makes me feel better to know that you have found some comfort in hearing other people's struggles with their mortality or beliefs.
supporter: It sounds to me like you've felt alone in your struggles and you are not alone! Yes I have and I've heard from many others who have as well.

seeker: I have felt alone in my struggles. It's good to know that I'm not alone!
supporter: I'm so happy I could be here for you! It's not fun to feel alone, if we can all lean on each other in times of need the world will be a better place.

seeker: do you have a favorite video or book, or one that you found most helpful?
supporter: I've personally enjoyed looking into all the different types of religions and spiritual beliefs from around the world. It's nice hearing about different beliefs on life and death.

seeker: I agree, the world would be a much better place if we could all lean on each other in times of need!
supporter: You are very welcome! Again I am happy to help and would love to chat any time you are feeling anxious about anything at all!

seeker: Thank you so much! You have helped me more than you know!
supporter: You are very welcome! I hope you have a great rest of your day and please don't hesitate to message if you want to chat again!

seeker: I hope you have a great rest of your day as well! If you ever need someone to talk to feel free to message me!
supporter: Thank you I will! Take care!

supporter: okay. at lease seeing them in the video should have brought you some relief. Are you planning to get vaccinated when you are able to? And what about your friends? once you are vaccinated, it will help you meet your friends in person.

supporter: oh okay. Have you tried checking with your friends to see if you could meet in person but still maintain social distance and wear masks, etc.

supporter: oh okay, have you discussed anything with your friends to see if you find any alternative way of meeting?

supporter: okay. May i ask what do you do for a living? are there ways you can spend time on activities that you like so that it could reduce your sadness?

supporter: I hear you need someone to talk to. What is your situation at your work?

supporter: Being stressed and anxious is something I've experienced as well. I use breathing to help keep me centered, calm.

seeker: Breathing calmly will not help pay the bills if I am made redundant. It's not fair, I cannot be made redundant if they keep giving me more work.
supporter: That sounds tough. Just from chatting with you, I can feel how anxious you are.

supporter: I have also felt unfairly treated at a workplace. Have you tried to talk to a human resources director or a company hotline?

seeker: No, only my direct manager. Do you think that will help?
supporter: I believe you deserve to be treated fairly. I hear that you also believe that you deserve to be treated fairly. Calling a hotline or talking to a human resource profession is a suggestion.

supporter: Expressing your feelings about the companies redundancies. Also, your feelings about the company having no communication or empathy for their employees.

seeker: Ok thanks, i will do that.
supporter: You're welcome. I hope this message finds you well.

seeker: Yes thank you.
supporter: In combination with breathing, I suggest using a thought map to clear your mind. Also going for a walk can help you with your mental or emotional health.

seeker: Hi. How are you?
supporter: Can I help you

supporter: It is actually good. Why you are feeling

supporter: So it should not impact you. Don't worry at all.

supporter: You should not listen your co-worker. Just listen your heart. Do your best.

supporter: Start searching job meanwhile. Don't get panic. You have still lot of time. Be very patience.

supporter: I can assure you don't worry at all. Keep yourself busy  with friends. Go out with them and keep yourself busy. You will be fine soon

supporter: Do meditation or yoga will help you.

supporter: I had a similar situation myself a few years ago and I moved on. I've never regretted it.

supporter: A lunch date or coffee sounds perfect.

supporter: You're welcome. I'm glad to hear that.

Familiarization would not be too bad,

supporter: What is making you struggle?

supporter: Yes, of course it is :). So we are talking about your daughter and her husband and their child together, right?

seeker: Yes, He is a nice guy to others. At home he is so different.
supporter: I understand, people can often show different sides depending on who is around. Do you have any reason to think your daughter or granddaughter are in physical danger?

supporter: That's great news! It sounds as though you are just concerned about how she is sometimes being treat. Have you had any conversation with your daughter about their relationship?

seeker: Yes, numerous. Like I said we are close to our daughter. She wants to stay together and talks with him.
supporter: And that is so important and good to know there is trust from his side, to me it sounds as though that could be an olive branch for you to try and establish a conversation with both of them. An open and positive communication is always the first step in resolving anything.

supporter: I recently went though a similar exercise with a friend and her boyfriend. We sat down in a room and spoke about our feelings. We had ground rules first and everyone knew they could talk without being judged or escalating.

seeker: Thats sounds like a good idea. We have talked with them individually. Now the next step. We shall see.
supporter: I believe you have both their interests in mind. You sound like a positive person and you are just concerned for all 3 people involved.

seeker: For sure, she is our daughter and our granddaughter needs her daddy.
supporter: I hope they will be well receptive of your suggestion for a follow up.

seeker: Thank you. I have some good ideas after chatting with you.
supporter: No worries, I'm grateful for your time as well. If there is nothing else, I hope it all goes well and you have a wonderful weekend :)
